\chapter{Introduction to the Physics 325 Laboratory}
\begin{adjustwidth}{}{-158pt}
\nointerlineskip\leavevmode

The operational details of the laboratory component of Physics 325 are outlined here. We hope you find these experiments an interesting and helpful part of your physics education. Many of the experiments in this course are chosen to be unlike any you have performed before. None of these modern experiments were imagined or even technically feasible until the early portion of the twentieth century.
 
\section{Why are there labs in Physics 325?}

\begin{itemize}
\item To experience nuclear physics, particle interactions, and quantum phenomena first-hand.
\item To gain experience with new measurement instruments and laboratory techniques that are essential to many other areas of experimental physics.
\item To understand the statistical nature of nuclear physics.
\item To experience the extraordinary sensitivity of instruments that are capable of detecting individual particles produced by nuclear decays and very small currents.
\end{itemize}

\section{Laboratory Schedule}

For the first half of the course, all groups do the same lab at the same time. For the second half of the course each group does a different project lab each week. At the end
of the course a poster session is held. Each laboratory group is required to present a poster about an experiment of their choice. The laboratory schedule is presented here.
The schedule for all laboratories is also posted in the display case across from 
room ST039.

\begin{table}[h!]
  \begin{tabular}{ l l }
    Week of & Experiment \\ \hline
    Jan 16 - Jan 20 & Planck's constant with LEDs \\
    Jan 23 - Jan 27 & Electron Gas in Metals \\
    Jan 30 - Feb 3 & Evidence for Quantized Atomic Energy Levels \\
    Feb 6 - Feb 10 & Electron Diffraction \\
    Feb 13 - Feb 17 & Radioactive Decay \\
	Feb 20 - Feb 24 & Reading Week - no labs \\     
    Feb 27 - Apr 7 & Project Labs \\
    Apr 10 - Apr 12 & Poster Session \\
    \\
    & Project Labs\\ \hline
    & Black Body Radiation \\
    & Colour Temperature \\ 
    & Compton Scattering\\
    & Faraday Effect \\
    & Nuclear Decay \\
    & Photoelectric Effect \\
    & Rutherford Scattering \\
  \end{tabular}
\end{table}

There are 7 project experiments available and you must choose five.  You will work with your TA to schedule when you perform these experiments.  This should be done before 
the Reading Break.

The Laboratory Manual for Physics 325 is available online at \\ www.pjl.ucalgary.ca

\section{General laboratory procedures}

The laboratory portion of this course is structured such that you are assigned to a lab section and expected to attend the lab every week on a particular day and time. You 
must be familiar with the lab write-up before you arrive for the lab. You must complete the pre-lab exercises before you arrive at the lab in order to get credit for them. 
The regular labs take roughly 3 hours to complete, while the project labs take from 3 hours to a week depending upon the experiment. Except for the project experiments, the 
experiment, including data analysis and report writing, should be completed during the three-hour lab period. 

Each lab in the lab manual has the same general format. There is an introductory section that provides background information and a theoretical basis for the experiment that
you will be carrying out. After the introduction is a detailed, step-by-step procedure to lead you through the laboratory exercise. When doing these steps try to understand
why the write-up asks you to do each step, rather than just following it blindly. After the procedure is a section on uncertainty analysis. Some hints for assigning errors to
instruments and propagation of errors are provided. Finally, there is the lab worksheet, which explains what is expected from you for pre-lab work and the experiment write-up. 
Your laboratory grade assignment is based on the evaluation of the pre-lab and write-up. 

Before coming to the lab, read all parts of the write-up and complete the pre-lab requirements. You will find it difficult to complete the lab in the time provided if you 
have not first read over the lab and thought about what you are going to do.

Your laboratory station is a shared workplace. For this reason, after you complete your experiment, you should clean up your laboratory station. This includes brushing 
eraser shavings and other litter into the garbage and storing laboratory stools underneath the worktables. All equipment must be turned off but remain plugged in. If some 
instruments or samples were obtained from elsewhere in the laboratory, they must be returned there.

\section{What should you record when conducting an experiment?}

You will want to make sure that there is sufficient detail to complete the report and you might include the following:

\begin{itemize}
\item Date when the record is entered
\item Names and contact information of your laboratory partners
\item Details of the apparatus, including model numbers, serial numbers, etc.
\item Sketch of the experiment (circuit diagram, sketch of layout of components on the bench...)
\item Measured data and uncertainties in tables
\item Example calculations
\item Graphs to explore the behaviour of the data
\item Observations of events that might impact the experiment
\end{itemize}

It is highly recommended that you use a bound laboratory notebook to record the details and results of your experiment. Laboratory notebooks are available from the 
University book store or any office supply store.  Using a bound notebook will ensure that you have a complete record of your experiment and you will not lose or misplace 
individual sheets of paper.  A laboratory notebook is essential in any professional environment and maintaining a careful record of your work is an important habit to 
develop.

Any loose sheets should be stapled or blued in the laboratory notebook.  For example, you may wish to include photographs, excerpts from other documents, graphs, tables, 
spreadsheets, etc. in the notebook.  The origin of these appended pages should be recorded.  For example, provide the reference of the cited work, file name of the 
spreadsheet, or the name and version of the software package used to generate a graph.

\section{What should comprise the laboratory report?}

Communication is an important part of Science and the laboratory report is the key way you share your results and conclusions with your instructor, colleagues, and the 
scientific community.  It is essential to create a document for a specific target audience. You will want to demonstrate that you understand the concepts developed in the 
laboratory.  Therefore, you should make sure that you provide sufficient detail in the presentation of the data, calculations, and subsequent analysis so your TA will know 
that you understand the work you did in the laboratory.  In future courses you will perform experiments that will require you to present your results in the form of a 
scientific paper or technical report.

\vspace{12pt}

Unless otherwise directed, your laboratory report should include the following items:

\begin{itemize}
\item Name of the experiment and date it was performed
\item Names of your laboratory partners
\item Your responses to the Calculations, Analysis, and Discussion in the laboratory manual.  This will probably include tables with measured and calculated data, including
units and uncertainties and graphs of measured or calculated data.
\end{itemize}

\section{Tips about Lab Evaluation}

Each lab may have several different types of questions, listed numerically following the progression of the lab write-up. Different questions ask different things about the
experiment. Some will require answers written in complete sentences. Other questions ask you to provide derivations, fill in data tables, plot graphs, carry out 
calculations, do error analysis, or analyse your results. Your TA will have some basic expectations. These are outlined briefly below. However, please remember that neatness
is essential! If your reports are messy, disorganized, or difficult to follow the TAs are instructed to deduct significant marks.

Several parts of each lab will ask you questions about the lab and/or your results. These are the main portions of the lab that give you the opportunity to demonstrate to 
your TA that you understand the lab. 

You will often be asked to provide derivations or proofs of relevant equations. These are often listed as pre-lab work and can be done in advance.  When doing a derivation,
make sure that each step is clear.  Include explanations of steps where necessary, and make sure that the logical sequence is complete. When you are provided with the 
starting equation and the final equation you are only being evaluated on the intermediate process, so make sure it makes sense. Once again, neatness counts because if it is 
difficult to follow with equations spread all over the page, then it is not a derivation.

There are very significant sections of the labs that ask you to record data in tabular form. These sections will be marked for the quality and quantity. Make sure that:

\begin{itemize}
\item You have as much data as requested.
\item Your data is legible. 
\item Your data is well organized and clear. You should be look at the page and very quickly be able to understand what was recorded.
\item All your data has units, reasonable significant figures, and uncertainties. There are a very few exceptions where uncertainties are not required for some of the data.
These exceptions are clearly noted in the lab write-ups.
\item All data in a table has units clearly associated with it. It is acceptable to include the units in the header for a row or column when it is clear that all entries in
that row or column have the same units.
\item All tables that have calculations associated with them should have sample calculations near the table. Remember to include units, proper significant figures, and 
uncertainties when ever applicable.
\end{itemize}

Once you have the data recorded, you are often required to plot the data or some quantity calculated from the data.  Once again, the plots need to be clear and 
understandable, and they must accurately reflect the collected data.  Marks will be deducted for messiness or for inaccurate plotting.  Every plot or graph needs an 
informative  title, and clear, identifying labels on each axis.  The units of the data plotted along each axis must be clearly identified, and the absolute, quantitative 
scale must be clearly labelled with evenly spaced numerical values.  The data points should be accurately plotted and easily identified.  All data should have error bars 
associated with each point.  If for some reason it is not possible to give error bars, there should be a note on the plot giving a reasonable explanation for the lack of 
error bars.  Reasonable explanations may include that the uncertainties are too small to be seen on the scale of the graph, or that the write-up specifically said not to 
calculate uncertainties on a quantity.

Once the data is plotted, you will often be asked to determine a linear fit to the data.  In this course, the laboratory graphing program should be used to get 
coefficients of lines of best fit. This program works best because it properly handles errors in x and y simultaneously. The best fit line should be drawn on the plot, and 
the slope and y-intercept shown.  Remember that slopes and intercepts do usually have units and errors from the fit and these need to be recorded correctly as well. The 
process of carrying out all requested data calculations should be demonstrated either on the plot or nearby. Use of spreadsheets for data analysis tasks is encouraged except 
for finding lines of best fit. Analytical questions related to the results are often asked near the end of the lab. Answer these thoughtfully, and ensure that your answer 
agrees with your data.

\section{Lab grading standards}

Just showing up for a lab will not equate to a 100\% lab mark. The work will be marked in accordance with generally accepted university-level grading standards, as listed 
below.


\vspace{12pt}
\noindent \textbf{80-100} Excellent: superior performance showing comprehensive understanding of the subject matter. \\

\noindent \textbf{70-79}  Good: clearly above average performance with knowledge of subject matter generally complete. \\

\noindent \textbf{60-69} Satisfactory: basic understanding of the subject material.\\

\noindent \textbf{50-59} Minimal Pass: marginal performance; generally insufficient performance for subsequent courses in the same subject.\\

\noindent \textbf{<49} Fail: unsatisfactory Performance or Failure to meet course requirements.\\

The TAs have been instructed to try to set an evaluation standard that they will maintain throughout the course.  This means that a lab performance of a quality that 
receives a 75\% in January, would also be awarded a 75\% if the lab was done in November. In other words, the expectations for lab performance will not increase over the 
course of the term.  In practice, what this generally means is that lab marks tend to be lower in the early part of a course.  However, as you learn and improve the 
standards of your work over the course of the term, the marks begin to rise, often ending up relatively high by the last lab of the course.


\section{Concluding Comments}

This laboratory has been developed in the hope of providing you, the student, with an interesting and exciting hands-on introduction to the world of experimental Physics. 
We would like to encourage you to take an interest in the material of this course and to ask questions whenever they arise. Start with your TA, and if he or she cannot deal
with the question, take it up with you course instructor, but please, do not just sit around wondering. The best way to learn is to ask.

\chapter{Laboratory Rules}
\begin{adjustwidth}{}{-158pt}
\nointerlineskip\leavevmode

\begin{enumerate}
\item Absolutely no food or drink is permitted in the laboratory at any time. Any food or drink found in the laboratory will be permanently confiscated
\item All broken equipment is to be reported to the laboratory instructor.
\item Laboratory workstations are shared, and should be treated as such. At the end each experiment the equipment is to be neatly organized on the bench, stools are to be pushed under the bench, and eraser bit are to be swept into the garbage.
\item Recycling is located right outside the laboratory. Please respect the environment and place all recycling in the appropriate receptacles.
\item The only acceptable reasons for being excused from a laboratory session are objectively verifiable reasons such as:
	%\begin{enumerate}
	%\item Illness - verifiable with a doctor's slip.
	%\item Funerals - verifiable by giving person, time, and place.
	%\item Auto-mobile accidents - verifiable by accident report.
	%\item University sporting events - verifiable by note from the coach.
	%\end{enumerate}
Students are to contact their TA with in 24 hours of the start of their missed laboratory section in order to make alternate arrangements.
\item Students are encouraged to ensure that all laboratory marks are properly recorded.
\item Offenses such as cheating, plagiarism, or non-academic misbehaviour will be dealt with as outlined in the Student Misconduct section of the university calendar, which 
can be found at, \\
http://www.ucalgary.ca/pubs/calendar/current/k-2.html. \\ Offenses include, but are not limited to:
	\begin{enumerate}
	\item Copying any portion of another student's, past or present, laboratory report. 
	\item Fabrication of data. 
	\item Physical or verbal abuse of laboratory instructor.
	\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\chapter{Laboratory Safety}

\section{Introduction}
People who survive to reach adulthood generally acquire a mental list of safety rules that are followed to prevent injury to themselves and others. These rules are learned 
from sources such as parents, teachers, and experience. However, the practice of experimental physics can involve the handling of materials, instruments, and processes that
lie outside the realm of common experience. The rules described here must be added to your mental list to handle these new situations. This is part of your education in 
physics. For the safety of yourself and others you are required to read, understand, and follow these guidelines.

All of the physics experiments you will perform have been designed with the safety of the student in mind. This necessarily assumes that all the apparatus is used in a 
reasonable manner. Do not mishandle or abuse the equipment. Use your common sense. Always maintain an awareness of the consequences of your actions for yourself and others.
No food, drink, or smoking is permitted in the laboratory, to reduce the chance that it will be contaminated before being consumed. Also, spilled drinks can be dangerous 
near electrical equipment. Some physics experiments use ice or ice water for cooling. Do not eat or drink the ice or ice water, since it may be contaminated. Never work in a
laboratory alone, there should always be someone else present to get help if necessary. In the event of any accident in the lab, you must notify your instructor immediately.
The following comments describe the hazards you may encounter while in a physics laboratory and the relevant safety procedures to follow.

\section{Heavy Metals}
Lead is used for shielding in radiation experiments. Heavy metals such as lead can be absorbed into your body through the skin and mouth. They accumulate in the brain and 
eventually cause brain damage when a large enough amount is present. The total dosage of lead in the brain builds up over your lifetime as a function of total  accumulated 
exposure. Minimize your exposure to lead in the laboratory by handling it as little as possible. Do not touch any food or your face while working with lead. Wash your hands
after handling lead objects. Lead is also very dense. Be aware of this when moving blocks of lead and do not drop them.

Observe the same precautions when doing an experiment that uses mercury. As with lead, mercury can also be absorbed into the body to accumulate over your lifetime. Mercury 
has the added properties that it is a liquid which can be spilled and any open container of liquid mercury produces mercury vapour which can be inhaled. Avoid spilling 
mercury and try to keep it in a sealed container if possible. Make sure there is a spill tray underneath any experiment that involves the use of mercury. If mercury does get
spilled, notify your instructor so that it can be cleaned up. 

\section{Radiation}
The total dose of radiation you receive depends on the source intensity, the time you are exposed, and your distance from the source. For x-rays and gamma-rays the source 
intensity drops as the inverse square of the distance. For alpha and beta particles the drop is even faster. Minimize the time that a radioactive source is near you. Keep 
radioactive sources  as far away from you as you reasonably can, consistent with doing the experiment. There are strict regulations about the storage and handling of 
radioactive sources. Do not open, drop or lose them.

\section{Lasers}
Lasers are sources of concentrated parallel beams of monochromatic light, which can quite easily be focussed to tiny spots where the power density is high enough to cause 
damage. Never look into a laser beam, or let it shine into your eye, since you may suffer retinal damage if the laser power is high enough. Reflections from polished 
surfaces are almost as dangerous as the direct beam. Never shine a laser into someone elseâs eyes. Resist the temptation to shine the laser around the room or into the 
hallway. If this is done a person could accidentally gaze into the beam.

\section{Rotating Machinery}
Some experiments use pumps, motors, or other moving mechanisms. Keep fingers and other appendages away from such devices. Be especially careful about long hair and 
loose clothing.

\section{Electricity}
Always wire together your circuits with the power off. Make sure the circuit power is off when changing or moving components around. If you must work on live 
circuits only touch the insulated portions and make sure one hand is in your pocket or behind your back. This eliminates the possibility of current flow through the heart 
and lungs, which can be fatal. Do not touch live exposed connections under any circumstances. Beware of loose wires which can fall off or make unintentional connections, 
usually with undesirable results. Be especially vigilant around high voltage circuits. If the voltage is high enough, it is not necessary to touch the circuit to get a 
shock, since sparks can jump across a gap of air. Capacitors require particular care since they can store charge internally for hours after being disconnected from a 
circuit. Make sure capacitors are discharged before touching the terminals. When using spark timers on the air tracks make sure the hands of all your lab partners are clear
before starting the spark source.

\section{Cryogenic Materials}
Some physics experiments involve the use of liquid nitrogen, liquid helium, dry ice, or an organic solvent cooled with dry ice. These materials are cold. Do not touch them 
with your hands. Wear protective gloves when handling a container containing a cryogenic material. Do not splash or spill these cold liquids. Be careful not to touch parts 
that have been in contact with a cryogenic material, they will be cold as well. If a spill does happen, notify your instructor but do not touch the spill, it will evaporate
naturally. There must always be a way for evaporated cryogenic liquid to escape from a vessel, otherwise a dangerous build-up of pressure will occur.

\section{Pressure and vacuum vessels}
Gas bottles are under high pressure. If they are breached they will explode with the force of a bomb. Never jar or mishandle a pressure vessel when it is pressurized. 
Vacuum systems will implode when breached. Do not jar or abuse them either. Always bring the vacuum (or pressure) back to normal slowly. Before adjusting any valves make 
sure you understand the purpose of each valve and the consequences of operating it. Turn it slowly at first so you can change your mind if something seems to be wrong.

\section{Microwaves}
People wearing heart pacemakers or other life supporting electro-metallic implants should refrain from doing physics experiments that involve microwaves.

\section{Strong Magnetic Fields}
Strong magnetic fields will erase your credit cards, computer disks, and audio tapes. They will also damage watches, tape players, and other electronic devices. Do not leave
any such objects near a strong magnet or electromagnet. Check the area around an electromagnet before turning it on. People wearing heart pacemakers or other life supporting
electro-metallic implants should also refrain from doing physics experiments that involve powerful magnetic fields. Anything containing a magnet, or magnetic material like 
iron, steel, nickel, or cobalt, should also be kept away from strong magnetic fields. They may be damaged or pulled into the region of the field with enough force to break 
something.

\section{Stroboscopes}
Some people are susceptible to epileptic seizures or severe migraine headaches if they view strobe lights flashing at a frequency of 5 to 25 Hz. Refrain from doing an 
experiment involving strobe lights if you know you are susceptible. Notify the instructor immediately if you see someone adversely affected by an operating stroboscope.

\chapter{Radiation Safety in the Undergraduate Physics Labs}
\begin{adjustwidth}{}{-153pt}
\begin{center}
{\LARGE {\bf In case of emergency contact campus security at \\ \vspace{0.5cm} 403.220.5333 or \#3 on lab phone}}
\end{center}

\vspace{1cm}

This document provides information on radiation safety for course instructors, teaching assistants, and students working in the undergraduate laboratory in the Department of Physics and Astronomy at the University of Calgary.  The first section provides a general overview of radiation safety with specific details on handling accidents, in accordance with UofC policies.  The second section includes safety precautions for specific experiments in the laboratory where individuals may be exposed to radioactive substances.  The third section includes a description for the safe use of the neutron source in the laboratory.
\\
\\
M. Wieser.\\
February 11 2013

\subsection{{\bf Revision History}}

February 13 2013 -- Added Radiation Safety document from November 26 2012, correction to telephone numbers; added section on experiment-specific safety information; added document on safe use of neutron source. (M. Wieser)\\

\newpage



\section{\Huge \bf I. Radiation Safety }

The following document on radiation safety was assembled from documentation prepared by the University of Calgary Environment, Health, and Safety Office. 

\subsection{\LARGE{\bf Terminology}}

{\bf Activity} -- Is the measure of the number of radioactive nuclei that change or disintegrate per unit time (for example per second).  The unit of activity used is the Becquerel.  One Becquerel represents 1 nuclear disintegration per second.\\ 

{\bf Exposure} -- The Roentgen (R) is the old unit of exposure and is defined or measured as the ability of photons to produce ionization in air. The roentgen is no longer used in radiation protection, as it applies only to photons (gamma and x-rays) and is related only to their effect in air. The S.I. unit has no name; the units are Coulomb per kilogram.\\

{\bf Absorbed Dose} -- The Gray (Gy) is defined as the amount of energy deposited per unit mass of tissue. The absorbed dose can result from all types of radiation in any material. One gray (Gy) = 1 joule per kg of mass and it is necessary to define the absorbing material when using grays as a unit for absorbed dose. One Gray will produce various levels of tissue damage depending on the type of radiation.\\

{\bf Equivalent Dose} -- The dose equivalent or Sievert (Sv) is the amount of energy absorbed in a given mass multiplied by a quality factor (Q), which is specific for each type of radiation.\\
\begin{equation}
1\ Sv = 1\ Gy \times Q
\label{equ:rsUnits}
\end{equation}

Quality factors for various type of ionizing radiation are listed below. The higher the quality factor, the higher the absorbed energy damage in tissues.


\begin{table}
\begin{center}
%\scalebox{0.9}{
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
Type of Radiation & Energy Range & Quality Factor \\
\hline
Photons & all & 1 \\
\hline
Electrons & all & 1 \\
\hline
Neutrons & < 10 keV & 5 \\
\hline
& 10 keV to 100 keV & 10 \\
\hline
& >100 keV to 2 MeV & 20 \\
\hline
& >2 MeV to 20 MeV & 10 \\
\hline

\newpage
\subsection{\LARGE{\bf Types of Radiation}}

{\bf Alpha particles} are doubly charged helium nuclei (He$^{2+}$). Sources of alpha radiation are common in nature and include thorium, uranium, and radium. Alpha emitting radioisotopes with one exception (Sm-147) have atomic numbers greater than eighty-two. Alpha particles are highly energetic. Alpha particles have energies of 4 MeV or greater. A thin absorber such as a sheet of paper or the dead layer of the skin easily stops alpha particles. Alpha sources do not present a great hazard external to the body. Inside the body, however, alpha emitters are highly significant, because the alpha particle is doubly charged and relatively massive. The alpha particle undergoes many interactions with surrounding atoms, depositing all its energy in a very small volume.\\

{\bf Beta decay} involves the emission of a negative beta (negatron) which is an electron, which originates from the nucleus or the emission of a positron, the "anti-matter" of the negatron. The mass is identical to the beta but unlike the negative beta it has a positive charge. Therefore, a beta particle is an unpaired singly charged electron possessing kinetic energy. The higher the energy of the particle, the greater the ability of the particle to penetrate a material. Low-energy beta particles (less than 0.2 MeV) are easily absorbed in the outer layer of skin; beta-emitting sources external to the body present a somewhat greater threat of penetration when compared to alpha emitters. Sources inside the body within cells or incorporated into biologically active molecules may give significant radiation doses that disable and kill cells. \\

{\bf Photons} (Gamma and x-ray radiations) have no mass, and are uncharged electromagnetic radiation that can pass through matter. Gamma and x-rays ionize materials, through which they pass, causing excited electrons to be ejected from the atomic structure. Gamma and x-rays have identical physical characteristics, and differ only in how they are produced. The penetrating ability of gamma and x-rays makes them biological hazards whether they are external or internal. Gamma rays result from the emission of energy as an excited nucleus drops from one energy level to a lower energy state. X-rays result from transitions within the electron cloud of an atom or are emitted when a charged particle is quickly decelerated by running into dense material. \\

{\bf Neutron} radiation is the least common in the research laboratory. The absorption properties of neutrons are very complex as compared to charged particles and electromagnetic radiation. Neutron absorption is a function of the absorber's atomic weight, neutron to proton ratio, and interaction probabilities with various nuclei. Exposure to neutron radiation is a concern as the biological damage from sources external and internal to the body is greater than equivalent amounts of beta and gamma radiation.\\

\subsection{\LARGE{\bf Natural Background Radiation}}

Naturally occurring background levels of radiation can typically range from 1.0 to 3.5 mSv per year and in some places can be much higher. Background in Calgary is between 1.2 and 1.8 mSv per year. The highest known widespread level of background radiation is in Kerala and Madras States in India where a population of over 100,000 people receive an annual dose rate, which averages 13 mSv, due to the higher levels of terrestrial radiation. In Ramsar Iran, inhabitants who live in some houses in this area receive annual doses as high as 132 mSv from the local terrestrial sources. \\

The average person in Calgary receives approximately between 2 -- 3 mSv every year from naturally occurring background radiation as well as man-made sources.  Approximately 80 \% of the dose is from natural sources of radiation.  Radon is a major component of that exposure. \\

\begin{table}
%\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Source & Canadian Population Average \\
\hline Cosmic Radiation & 0.30 mSv/yr \\
\hline Terrestrial Radiation & 0.35 mSv/yr \\
\hline Internal Radionuclides & 0.35 mSv/yr \\
\hline Inhaled (Radon) & 1.00 mSv/yr \\
\hline Subtotal & 2.00 mSv/yr \\
\hline & \\
\hline Medical/Dental & 0.92 mSv/yr \\
\hline All other Consumer Products & 0.12 mSv/yr \\
\hline Nuclear Power & 0.01 mSv/yr \\
\hline Total & 3.05 mSv per year \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\label{tbl:rsExposure}
\caption{Common sources of radiation exposure, and their average doses per year}
%\end{center}
\end{table}

Cosmic radiation consists of high-energy particulate radiation produced in the stars and our own sun that bombard the earth and makes the atoms in the upper atmosphere radioactive. Sunshine Village, at an altitude of one mile, has a cosmic radiation intensity of about 0.5 mSv/yr compared to an intensity of about 0.25 mSv/yr observed at sea level. Calgary's cosmic radiation level is approximately 0.40 mSv/yr. \\

Terrestrial (Natural radioactivity) radiation consists of penetrating gamma and x-rays that result from the radioactive decay of naturally occurring, radioactive materials (for example, potassium, uranium, thorium, etc.) found in the earth's crust.  Most building materials contain some small amounts of radioactivity. The average Canadian population dose equivalent is 0.35 mSv per year. \\

Radon is an inert gaseous element resulting from the decay of uranium. Since radon is a gas, it readily escapes from soil, especially if the soil has been disturbed in any way. Radon-222 has a half-life of 38 days which produces several radioactive elements collectively referred to as "radon daughters" which are not gases and, therefore, precipitate out of the atmosphere by attaching themselves to dust particles in the air. Estimates of the average dose equivalent to the lungs vary, but the average effective dose equivalent for Canada is around 1 mSv per year. \\

Internal radiation exposure results from the presence of naturally occurring radionuclides (K-40, C14, H-3, etc.) ingested into the body like non-radioactive elements. Potassium is an important part of our body and the food system. Potassium is incorporated into many tissues and contributes more than 95\% of the internal dose experienced by the population. Potassium-40 makes up 0.0117\% of all potassium.  The average dose equivalent due to internal radionuclides is approximately 0.35 mSv per year. \\

\newpage
\subsection{\LARGE{\bf Effects of Radiation}}

Radiation causes ionizations in the molecules of living cells. These ionizations result in the removal of electrons from the atoms and form ions. The ions formed go on to react with other atoms and cause damage in the cell. An example of damage would be a gamma ray, which passes through the cell. The water molecules near the DNA might be ionized and the ions might react with the DNA and cause the bonds to break. \\

The doses that we receive every day from background radiation are low and the cells can repair radiation-induced damage rapidly.  Cells might not be able to repair the damage at higher doses (up to 1000 mSv) and these cells may either be changed permanently or die.  The body can replace most cells that die. However, cells changed permanently may go on to produce abnormal cells. These abnormal cells may become cancerous under the right circumstances.  This is the origin of our increased risk to cancer as a result of radiation exposure. \\

Radiation biology is the study of interactions between any type of radiation and living organisms or organic materials.  The energy absorption initiates the effects that are observed in living irradiated systems. No effects are produced, if the radiation is transmitted, scattered or reflected, or if the energy is otherwise not absorbed. Biological effects are roughly proportional to the amount of energy absorbed. \\

When any agent (chemicals, radiation, excessive heat, etc.) damages a cellular component, a multitude of measurable effects can result. The type of cell damage will depend upon what the specific agent is that the cell is exposed to.  Also, the amount of damage will be related to how much of the agent reaches that particular kind of cell. The changes maybe initially restricted to either a single cell or a few types of cells. Whole organs or organ systems may be affected in time due to the absence of a required function that upsets the equilibrium or control of the whole-interrelated system.  Any alteration of the genetic information carried by the genes, or of the processes associated with mitosis can result in either a permanent change in the nature of the cell (mutation), or in the cell's death. \\

Radiation passing through living cells causes ionization or excitation of atoms and molecules contained in the cell. The human body is comprised of large amounts of water.  Water molecules are the most likely targets for being hit by photons or charged particles. The reaction is the formation of an ion pair: H$_{2}O^{+}$ and an electron e$^{-}$.  The H2O$^{+}$ is rapidly hydrated $H_{2}O^{+} + H_{2}O \to H_{3}O^{+} + OH^{*}$. Here the OH$^{*}$ is a "free radical"; a species that contains an unpaired orbital electron and is highly chemically reactive. The electron will also react with a water molecule $e^{-} + H_{2}O \to H_{3}O^{-} + OH^{*}$. After the electron slows down from bumping into other water molecules, it will yield another free radical, this time hydrogen. The products are separated by a considerable distances so that immediate back reactions to form water are not favoured. \\

The radicals can combine with each other and with any number of other molecules with a cell (dissolved oxygen to give a variety of potent oxidizing agents such as hydrogen peroxide, superoxide, molecular oxygen, and the perhydroxy radical).  \\

Both the initial radicals and by-products can migrate to biologically important molecules (like DNA) and cause bond breakage and/or oxidation of attached functional groups. The energy of the radiation is transferred to biologically significant molecules, by changing their structure (bond breakage) or chemical reactivity (oxidation of functional group).  This form of energy-transfer is known as the INDIRECT EFFECT and accounts for a significant fraction of the damage in cells. \\

The actual radiation (x-ray, gamma ray, beta particle, neutron) may cause ionization in DNA or other biological significant molecule. The energy of ionizing radiation (x-ray, gamma ray, beta particle, neutron) is far greater than the energy required to break bonds in organic molecules. The extent of this interaction (DIRECT EFFECT) occurring depends on the number of particular molecules in the cell, and the size of the molecule.\\

Depending how a molecule is damaged, different results may occur (death of the cell, change in the production of an essential enzyme or protein, cause uncontrolled reproduction of the cell into many cells, damage is repaired by the cell, etc.). Both direct and indirect effects contribute to the overall number of such damaging events to the DNA and will vary for individual cell types.\\

The basic assumption in radiation protection is that the harmful effects of ionizing radiation are related to the absorbed dose.  One of the questions that is often asked is whether the effect of low-level ionizing radiation is cumulative or whether it is harmful only if it exceeds some threshold value.  Most of the evidence indicates that there are effects of both kinds.  Some effects, such as cataracts, do not occur below a certain threshold level of radiation. Other effects, such as the onset of cancer, do not appear to have any threshold and the risk of inducing such an effect increases with increasing dose.\\
\vspace{-0.5cm}
\begin{table}
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|l|}

\caption{Radiosensitivity of a variety of cells, tissues, organs, organisms, and other substances}

Radiosensitivity is the relative susceptibility of cells, tissues, organs, organisms, or other substances to the injurious action of radiation. In general, it has been found that cell radiosensitivity is directly proportional to the rate of cell division and inversely proportional to the degree of cell differentiation. In short, this means that actively dividing cells or those not fully mature are most at risk from radiation. The most radio-sensitive cells are those which (1) have a high rate of division, (2) have a high metabolic rate, (3) are of a non-specialized type, and (4) are well nourished.  Table \ref{tbl:rsRadiosensitivity} gives examples of cells with low and high susceptibilities to radiation. \\

\subsection{\LARGE{\bf Working Safely with Radioactive Substances}}

{\bf Time, Distance, and Shielding} are the three basic radiation protection principles that MUST be used to minimize external radiation exposures, however prior to using these three principles you need to know the specifics of the radioactive source you are using, including activity, type of emissions, and the energies involved.\\

{\bf Identification} -- Knowing the type and energy of the emitter will determine the appropriate type of shielding, the assay method, and technological methods required to safely handle the material. \\

{\bf Time} -- Radiation doses are directly proportional to the time spent in the radiation field. The workers dose is halved, when the time spent in a given radiation field is halved.  Therefore, preplan the procedures to reduce the time in an exposure field. Develop a detailed plan for carrying out the steps before beginning any new procedures. Complete as much preparation work as possible before incorporating any radioactive materials are into the experimental procedures. Practice the techniques required for the procedure to reduce the time of exposure. Prior to beginning the procedure organize and have readily available all the necessary materials, tools, and equipment. \\

{\bf Distance} -- Radiation doses are inversely proportional to the distance squared (inverse square law). Increasing the distance from a radiation source will reduce the amount of exposure received. Remote handling devices (forceps, tongs, or tweezers) can greatly reduce the exposure to hands or extremities. Do not work directly over open containers of radioactive materials. \\

{\bf Shielding} -- Radiation doses can be greatly reduced by the use of the appropriate type of shields. Store and work with high-energy beta emitters behind Lucite shielding. Keep gamma emitters behind lead shielding. Ensure that all surfaces of the shielding containers (top, bottom, front, back, \& sides) are appropriate. Do not assume that the floor or a wall is adequate shielding. Personnel working in adjacent spaces may receive unnecessary and/or unmonitored exposures due to inadequate or lack of shielding. Radioactive material and samples when not in use shall be returned to appropriate shielded storage areas. Wear plastic safety eye wear to protect the cornea of your eye from beta radiation. \\

Radioactive material located inside the body may result in an internal radiation dose. Internal doses are hazardous and more difficult to detect and quantify than external doses. Therefore, significant emphasis is placed upon preventing the internalization of contamination. \\

{\bf Radioactive contamination} refers to the presence of radioactive material in areas or on surfaces where it is not desired. Radioactive contamination is actual physical material that typically cannot be seen, but can be transferred from one surface to another through contact. Radioactive contamination can be airborne, or deposited directly on surfaces.  It is essential to remove gloves and laboratory coats when leaving the laboratory. {\bf Do not use the computer keyboard, alpha spectrometer, or other devices while wearing gloves that were used for the preparation of the radioactive sources}.  \\

Four potential routes of intake include absorption, ingestion, inhalation, and wounds. Absorption takes place when direct skin contact is made with a contaminated surface or when skin is exposed to airborne contamination. The primary means of inhalation is through the use of volatile substances outside of the fumehood. Ingestion is the accidental consumption of contaminated food or liquids.  The accidental injection of radioactive materials with needles or sharps is remotely possible.  Absorption is the most common route of intake in a research or University setting.\\

\noindent
{\bf When working with radioactive materials, always:}
%\vspace{-2cm}
\begin{enumerate}[noitemsep]
\item Define and label the work area. 
\item Label equipment. 
\item Use personal protective equipment. 
\item Perform a dry run. 
\item Perform procedure using good work practices. 
\item Use appropriate housekeeping practices.
\end{enumerate}
\newpage

\subsection{\LARGE{\bf Reportable Incidents}}

\noindent
{\bf The following require IMMEDIATE reporting to Campus Security and Radiation Safety at anytime.}

\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item A spill of radioactive material (outside of the radioactive work area)
\item Personal contamination (including clothing)
\item Known or suspected internal contamination
\item Known or suspected external exposure where person(s) may have received a dose in excess of 3 mSv (300 mRem) 
\item Widespread contamination
\item Loss or theft of any quantity of nuclear substance (radioactive material)
\item A release of a quantity of radioactive nuclear substance into the environment not authorized by Licensed activity
\item An attempted or actual breach of security or sabotage at the site of the licensed activity
\item A serious illness or injury incurred or possibly incurred as a result of the licensed activity
\item The death of any person at a nuclear facility as a result of licensed activity
\end{itemize}

\subsection{\LARGE{\bf Emergency Response to a Radioactive Spill}}
\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item Notify all occupants in the area about the spill, if contaminate is volatile evacuate the area immediately.
\item Secure the area, keep all individuals from entering.
\item Ensure prompt first aid treatment is administered for injured personnel.
\item Remove all contaminated clothing and place in a plastic bag. Attempts must be made to remove all external contamination as soon as possible. Flush the area for a minimum of 15 minutes, if contamination is splashed in the eyes, mouth, or on skin.
\item Report the spill to Campus Security (403 220-5333) or Environmental Health \& Safety (403-220-6345) immediately.
\item Contain large volumes of non-volatile liquid spills to prevent further spreading. Ensure proper personal protective equipment is being worn.
\item Remain in the area to provide information and assistance in the clean up.
\item Ensure that all spilled and contaminated materials are properly packaged for disposal and are treated as hazardous wastes. Ensure that all other items in the clean up are decontaminated.
\end{itemize}

\newpage
\subsection{\LARGE{\bf Specific Procedures for Managing Personal Contamination}}
Immediate corrective actions should be taken if you know or suspect that you may have radioactive contamination on your clothing or skin. Prompt actions will minimize your exposure and will prevent a further spread of contamination. The primary concern regarding contamination on the clothing or skin is the increased probability of intake and resultant internal radiation exposure. Remember, radioactivity can enter the body by way of inhalation, ingestion, absorption, or through breaks in the skin.

\subsection{\bf Guidelines for contaminated wounds}

Minor wounds (puncture, scrape, and cut) while working with radioactivity require IMMEDIATE actions to limit any possible internal radiation exposure. Since minor wounds typically involve the hands, the following guideline is written for this situation.

\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item Remove your gloves; turn them inside out, and DO NOT dispose.
\item Save the gloves and the object that caused the wound for monitoring and isotope identification. Information obtained from these items may help determine whether an internal exposure is likely.
\item Allow the wound to bleed and flush it gently with clean water. This will remove any radioactivity present in the wound and may prevent its absorption into the body.
\item Bandage or cover the wound, and seek medical attention if required.
\item Contact Campus Security (403-220-5333) or Environmental Health \& Safety (403-220-6345) immediately.
\end{itemize}

{\bf NOTE:} For serious injuries or illnesses, always seek prompt medical attention first. Treatment and safety of the seriously injured person(s) ALWAYS takes precedence over radioactive contamination control. Emergency Services will only treat decontaminated individuals.

\subsection{\bf Guidelines for Contaminated Clothing}
\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item Put on and wear a clean pair of gloves to carefully remove all contaminated clothing in such a way as to prevent a further spread of contamination, especially to the skin. Remove clothing inside out to contain the contamination.
\item Seal the contaminated clothing in a plastic bag. Write the following information on the bag: Name, telephone number of the owner of the clothing, and the radioisotopes involved.
\item After removal of contaminated clothing, carefully monitor all exposed skin areas. Monitor your hands. Follow the guidelines below if skin contamination is detected.
\item Contact Environmental Health \& Safety (403-220-6345) for cleaning of contaminated clothing. The clothing will most likely be stored until the radioactivity has decayed, if the clothing cannot be cleaned and the isotopes involved are short-lived.
\end{itemize}

\subsection{\bf Guidelines for Personal Contaminations}
Contamination deposited directly on the skin can cause intense irradiation of the skin as well as substantially increasing the risk for intake into the body.
\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item Use mild hand soap or other appropriate solution for use on the skin. Some decontamination solutions and cleansers contain harsh chemicals and are not intended for use on the skin.
\item Water used for skin decontamination should be lukewarm in temperature. Water that is too hot or too cold will increase the blood flow to the area and increase the absorption of the contamination.
\item Gently wash or scrub the affected skin areas for about 2 to 3 minutes. Pay special attention to the fingernails if the hands are contaminated
\item Rinse with clean water and gently pat dry. Re-monitor the area with a contamination monitor.
Repeat this procedure as necessary, RUB DO NOT SCRUB.
\item NOTE: Gloves should be worn to prevent the spread of radioactive contamination to the hands during decontamination operations.
\item Work from the center of your body out (if your forearm is contaminated wash from the elbow towards the hand, hold your arm such that the water runs off your arm into the sink, not onto the floor or your body).
\item Monitor affected skin areas after every decontamination; attempt to determine effectiveness.
\item Stop cleaning immediately if contamination cannot be removed, or if the skin becomes irritated.
\item Rinse your eyes in an eyewash station for at least 15 minutes to flush foreign material out.
\item Rinse your mouth with water, but DO NOT swallow.
\item Blow your nose and keep the tissue, it will be analyzed for radioactive contamination. The nose filters approximately 50\% of particulate matter.
\item Have someone absorb surface liquids, and liquids in the outer ear, lean to the side which has the liquid in it. Do not stick anything in your ear.
\end{itemize}

\subsection{\bf Procedures for Decontamination of Equipment and Areas}

Tools, equipment, and work areas must be free of radioactive contamination whenever possible. All users are responsible for conducting surveys and promptly decontaminating all items and surfaces, if required.

\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item Always wear protective clothing during decontamination operations. Minimum requirements include wearing a labcoat and two pairs of gloves (triple gloving is highly recommended).
\item There are several products commercially available for decontamination. Alternatively, two tablespoons of Alconox or Sparkleen can be dissolved in water to make a paste.
\item Methods used in decontamination include washing, scrubbing, abrasion, and corrosive methods. Always start with washing before progressing to more difficult decontamination methods.
\item DO NOT use methods such as grinding, sanding, scraping or chipping contaminated surfaces without the specific direction of Environmental Health \& Safety.
\item Complex items should be disassembled as much as possible to allow sufficient cleaning of inner surfaces which may be contaminated. Do not disassemble if such action will jeopardize the operational integrity of the item or equipment.
\item Use disposable materials, such as paper towels.
\item Minimize the spread of contamination during decontamination operations. Avoid wiping a highly contaminated cleaning towel over a less contaminated surface. Generally, the best technique is to start at the edge of a contaminated area and work toward the area of highest contamination. The exception to this, however, would be to clean highly contaminated areas first if those areas were creating unacceptably high radiation exposure levels.
\item Frequently monitor surfaces during decontamination with either portable survey instruments or swipe tests to determine the effectiveness of the procedures being used. Continue decontamination as necessary.
\item Conduct SWIPE TESTS to confirm that there is no removable contamination.
\item Items and surfaces which cannot be successfully decontaminated must be identified and controlled as radioactive material. Such areas may also require shielding.
\item Ensure that all radioactive waste generated during decontamination is properly collected and disposed into the solid and liquid waste containers.
\end{itemize}

\newpage
\section{\LARGE{\bf II. Safety information for Specific Experiments in Physics 325}}

{\bf When working in any laboratory, no food or drink should be stored or consumed.  Wash your hands after handling any radioactive material before leaving the laboratory.}

\subsection{\bf Rutherford Scattering}

The Rutherford scattering experiment uses sealed sources to calibrate the alpha spectrometer. Sealed sources contain radioactive isotopes that are sealed in metal or plastic and these sources may be handled without specific safety equipment.  Nevertheless, exposure to any radioactive substance should be minimized.  In this experiment, the sealed sources are contained within the bell jar and you will not handle the sources at all.  Alpha particles from the decay of $^{241}$Am are incident on a gold target.  The americium source is enclosed in the bell jar and you will not have to handle this source at all.  

\subsection{\bf Compton Scattering}

The 35 milliCurie $^{137}$Cesium source used in the Compton scattering apparatus is dangerous.  The basic rule to follow is avoid the gamma ray beam. Do NOT put any part of the body (notably hands and heads) in the path of the gamma ray beam. Stay completely out of the white painted area at all times when the gamma ray beam aperture is open. Handle the gamma ray stopper plug only by the extremities (the rings). Move the gamma ray detector assembly only by the magnets or the black knobs that are out of the white painted area. When changing the target rod, always close the gamma ray beam aperture first. Do NOT leave the apparatus unattended if the stopper is removed. Caution anyone entering the Compton scattering experiment area when the gamma ray beam aperture is open. Always plug the gamma ray beam aperture with the stopper when the experiment is completed.
Sealed sources are used to calibrate the gamma spectrometer. Sealed sources contain radioactive isotopes that are sealed in metal or plastic and  these sources may be handled without specific safety equipment.  Nevertheless, exposure to any radioactive substance should be minimized.  Once the calibration of the detector is complete, return the source to the storage container immediately.  

\subsection{\bf Radioactive Decay}

The radioactive decay experiment uses indium metal that is activated by a flux of neutrons.  The indium metal becomes radioactive and decays by beta-minus decay to an isotope of tin.  This isotope has been chosen because it is a weak, short half-life beta emitter with low chemical activity so it is not dangerous. Your TA will expose the indium metal to the neutron flux and you will not have to work with the neutron source in this experiment.  However, there are some precautions when handling the indium metal.  Do not touch the indium with your fingers or drop it on the floor. Handle the indium only with tweezers.

\newpage
\subsection{\bf Nuclear Decay}

This experiment requires special precautions because the radioactive sample is not sealed:
\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item Wear latex gloves, a laboratory coat, and goggles at all times.
\item Do not operate the equipment (computer, alpha spectrometer, etc.) while wearing gloves.  Only touch the instruments with clean hands to avoid spreading radioactive contamination. 
\item Perform all operations inside the plastic trays.
\item Do not let the stirring rod touch anything except the inside of the beaker.
\item Do not let the eye droppers touch anything except their own sample bottle.
\item Mouth pipetting is forbidden.
\item Rinse the beaker, graduated cylinder, and stirring rod with distilled water after use.
\item Put all disposable solids into the solid radioactive waste beaker.
\item Put all left over liquid from rinsing and filtering in the liquid radioactive waste bottle. 
\item Do not touch the surface of the sample with anything.
\end{itemize}
You will have to filter your sample prior to analysis with the alpha spectrometer.  At this point, it is important to do a "test run" to make sure that the filter apparatus is not leaking before you pass the radioactive solution through the filter paper.  To test the operation of the filter, set up the filter funnel and check that nothing leaks around the sides by pouring in some distilled water. Usually, if there is a leak, it is because the filter paper is not properly centered over the screen. Once it is ready, then pour the contents of the beaker into the funnel. \\

Once prepared, the sample disc should only be touched with tweezers.  Do not touch the radioactive source with hands (whether wearing gloves or not). Rinse the beaker, graduated cylinder, and stirring rod with some distilled water after the sample preparation is completed. The rinse water and the filtered liquid must both be poured into the liquid radioactive waste bottle. \\

Sealed sources are used to calibrate the alpha spectrometer. These sources contain radioactive isotopes that are sealed in metal or plastic and these sources may be handled without specific safety equipment.  Nevertheless, exposure to any radioactive substance should be minimized.  Once the calibration of the detector is complete, return the source to the 
storage container immediately.\\

\multirow{2}{*}{Demonstrate} &  \multirow{2}{*}{10)} & \multirow{2}{*}{Quickly replace the central plug back into the chamber.}\\
& & \\
\hline
\multirow{2}{*}{Demonstrate} &  \multirow{2}{*}{11)} & \multirow{2}{*}{Lock the brass rod into place.}\\

\end{tabular}}

\end{table}

\newpage
\subsection{{\bf Activation of Material (Indium) by Slow Neutrons (n,$\gamma$)}}

Slow and thermal neutrons interact with indium to produce excited states. Natural-abundance indium has two stable isotopes, $^{113}$In (4.2\%) and $^{115}$In (95.8\%). The neutron-capture reactions are:

\begin{equation}
^{113}In \to \begin{cases} ^{114}In*\ \ \ \ \ ;\ \ \ \ \ \sigma = 8\ barns \ \ \ T^{1/2} = 50\ days \\ 
^{114}In\ \ \ \ \ \ \ ;\ \ \ \ \ \sigma = 4\ barns \ \ \ T^{1/2} = 72\ sec \\ 
\end{cases}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}
\ \ \ \ ^{115}In \to \begin{cases} ^{116}In**\ ;\ \ \ \ \ \sigma = 81\ barns\ \ T^{1/2} = 2.18\ sec \\ 
^{116}In*\ \ \ \ ;\ \ \ \ \ \sigma = 81\ barns \ \ \ T^{1/2} = 81\ min \\ 
^{116}In\ \ \ \ \ \ ;\ \ \ \ \ \sigma = 40\ barns \ \ \ T^{1/2} = 14.1\ sec \\ 
\end{cases}
\end{equation}

Data on capture cross sections are available online.  Because of the higher isotopic abundance of $^{115}$In, and its larger cross section, the predominant radioactive isotope formed is $^{116}$In and isomeric states. $^{116}$In and $^{116}$In* decay via $\beta$ decay into stable $^{116}$Sn according to:

\begin{equation}
^{116}In \to ^{116}Sn + e^{-} + \overset{-}{\nu}_{e}.
\end{equation}

While the decay from the $^{116}$In ground state (1+) proceeds directly into the $^{116}$Sn ground state (0+), the isomeric states decay into excited states of $^{116}$Sn. Several $\gamma$ rays are emitted in their de-excitation.

%\newpage
\begin{figure}
\includegraphics{/usr/local/master/labs/physics325-WI2017/Radiation-Safety-in-the-Undergraduate-Physics-Labs/indium-isotopes.png}
\caption{Simplified decay schemes for indium isotopes}
\end{figure}

Simplified decay schemes for indium isotopes.

When a very thin sample is irradiated, the rate of activation is directly proportional to the neutron flux. Thick samples perturb the neutron flux and depress the rate of activation. While any sample is being activated, it is also decaying. Thus we have two competing processes that determine the absolute value of the radioactivity of the sample at any point in time. The rate of activation is given by:

\begin{equation}
R=\sigma \phi\ N_{t}\ (for\ thin\ samples),
\end{equation}

Where $\Phi$ = average neutron flux, $\sigma$ = activation cross section, and Nt = number of target nuclei. The rate of decay is given by $\lambda$N, where $\lambda$ = $\frac{1}{\tau}$ = the decay constant, and N = the total number of radioactive nuclei present. The rate of change in N is the difference between the rate of activation and the rate of decay:

\begin{equation}
\frac{dN}{dt} = R -\lambda N
\end{equation}

A detailed discussion of the rates of activation and decay will be found in Reference (1), p. 765 - 771, and Reference (2) Chapter 19. \\
\\
\noindent
(1) G. F. Knoll, {\it Radiation Detection and Measurement}, (John Wiley \& Sons, 1979), pp. 71-73, Chap. 14, pp. 765- 773, and 2nd edition (1989).\\
(2) N. Tsoulfanidis, {\it Measurement and Detection of Radiation}, (Hemisphere Publishing Corp., 1983), pp. 155-162, Chap. 14, Chap. 15, pp. 433-439.
\end{adjustwidth}

\chapter{Planck's Constant from LEDs}

\section{Equipment}

\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item LED apparatus 
\item Fluke multimeter (2) 
\item Anatek power supply
\item Set of connecting leads (2)
\end{itemize}

\section{Preparation}
Carefully read the theory section of this lab write-up to ensure that you understand how light emitting diodes (LEDs) are being used to determine Planck's constant as well as the difficulties that arise in doing so.  You may find it useful to read about photon energy quantization in your textbook as well as review the function of semi-conductor doping.

\section{Goals of the Experiment}
Many undergraduate labs make use of LEDs to estimate, through non-spectroscopic means, a value for Planck's constant. The method usually employed makes assumptions about the relationship between an LED's built-in voltage and its band gap voltage. This lab will explore these assumptions and illustrate the inherent problems that arise if they are not valid. Additionally, this lab will develop an understanding of LEDs under both forward and reverse bias conditions.


\section{Theory}

In the nuclear theory of single atoms, the electrons surrounding the nucleus are organized into 
different energy levels (shells). Quantum mechanics predicts that the energy levels of these 
electrons can only have certain discrete values. However, a solid piece of material contains a 
large number of atoms bound together. As atoms are squeezed together, the energy levels from 
electrons in adjacent atoms overlap with each other. The inner low energy electrons close to the 
nucleus have energy levels that are almost unaffected. However, the energy levels of the outermost
or \textbf{valence electrons} spread out into continuous bands. Depending on how close the atoms are 
squeezed, these bands may even start to overlap. The \textbf{valence band} is the band of energies 
that the valence electrons occupy. The next empty band outward is called the \textbf{conduction band}
. The difference in energy between the valence and conduction bands is called the \textbf{band gap}. 
If an electron gains enough energy to move to the conduction band it becomes free to move around. 

If the material is an \textbf{insulator} the valence band is completely full, the conduction band is empty
and the band gap between these two energy bands is large. The electrons require a large amount of energy
before they can be promoted to the conduction band. For this reason insulators are poor conductors.
On the other hand, if the valence band is only partly filled (the valence band and the conduction 
band are equivalent), or if a full valence band overlaps the empty conduction band because of tight
atomic packing the material is a \textbf{conductor}. Electrons easily become mobile in conductors. When
the valence bands and conduction bands do not overlap but are quite close together the material is a 
\textbf{semiconductor}. Here even a small amount of extra energy is enough to promote some electrons to
the conduction band. Such energy can be provided by the temperature of the material alone. At very low
temperatures semiconductors are insulators. As the temperature increases the number of conduction
electrons increases rapidly. At high temperatures semiconductors behave like conductors.

The above description holds true for pure materials where all the atoms are of the same 
element. The picture changes when impurities are added. This is especially true for semiconductors.
Remember that a semiconductor has a partially filled valence band. If impurities are added that 
have enough electrons to fill the valence band \textbf{plus} one more electron, then the remaining free
electron is basically in the conduction band.  An \textbf{electron} free in this way is called a 
\textbf{donor}. Such a material is called an \textbf{n-type semiconductor}. Similarly, if an impurity 
is added that will fill the valence band to capacity \textbf{minus} one electron then the remaining 
absence of an electron is very likely to attract electrons to it. A missing electron, or \textbf{hole},
made in this way is called an \textbf{acceptor} and such a material is called a 
\textbf{p-type semiconductor}. In n-type semiconductors the charge carriers are the electrons. In 
p-type semiconductors the charge carriers are the holes. The holes move through the material in the 
same way as a bubble flows through a fluid. Tuning the properties of a semiconductor by adding donor or
acceptor materials is called \textbf{doping}.

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}

\node[font=\scriptsize]at(2.5,1.8){e$^-$  e$^-$ };
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Equilibrium situation for a diode}
\label{fig:PC1}
\end{marginfigure}

The basic building block of all modern electronics is constructed by joining together an 
n-type semiconductor and a p-type semiconductor to form a \textbf{pn junction}. The device made from 
such a single pn junction is called a \textbf{diode}. In a pn junction at equilibrium, holes from the 
p side tend to drift towards the n side while free electrons from the n side drift in the other 
direction. At the junction these drifting electrons and holes recombine. This drift current causes the
n side of the junction to acquire a net positive charge because some of the excess electrons have 
drifted away. Similarly, the p side will get a net negative charge because some of the excess holes 
have drifted away. The difference in charges shifts the energies of the valence and conduction bands on
both sides of the junction. This equilibrium situation for a diode is shown in Figure 
\ref{fig:PC1}. Notice that electrons in the conduction band on the n side of the junction 
cannot easily move to the p side because the conduction band there now has higher energy.

When a voltage is applied to the diode so that the p side is made more positive and the n side more 
negative, the diode is said to be \textbf{forward biased}. When a diode is forward biased, the 
difference between energy levels on the p and n sides of the junction is decreased. It is now easier 
for free electrons to cross from the n side to the p side. The energy level diagram for a forward 
biased diode is shown in Figure \ref{fig:PC2}. When a diode is \textbf{reverse biased} the p 
side is made more negative. Now the difference in energy levels is increased which makes it even harder
for electrons to cross the junction. What this means is that the conduction of a diode changes with the
voltage across it. At large forward voltages the diode is a very good conductor while at large reverse
voltages the diode is a very poor conductor. Contrast this behaviour with that of a simple conductor. A
piece of metal is a very good conductor no matter what voltage is applied to it and an insulator is a 
very poor conductor no matter what voltage is applied to it. 

The equation for the current, I, flowing in a diode is given by

\begin{equation}
I=I_0(e^{\frac{ev}{kT}}-1),
\label{equ:PC1}
\end{equation}
where I$_{0}$ is a constant characteristic of the diode, e is the electron charge, k is Boltzmann's 
constant, T is the absolute temperature, and V is the voltage applied to the diode. At room 
temperature this becomes

\begin{equation}
I=I_0e^{38.6V},
\label{equ:PC2}
\end{equation}
Since usually I$_0$ is very small.

\begin{marginfigure}

\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Forward bias diode}
\label{fig:PC2}
\end{marginfigure}

The movement of holes in the diode is also affected by the voltage applied to the diode with the 
difference that the holes move in the other direction. An electron that gains enough energy from the
applied voltage to cross the junction is called an \textbf{excited electron}. Occasionally an excited 
electron will jump into a hole instead of flowing to the voltage source. This process is called 
\textbf{recombination}.  When an excited electron recombines with a hole the excess energy of the 
electron is carried away by a photon. In normal diodes the probability of recombination is very small.
This happens because the mobility of the holes is very different from that of the electrons. Special 
materials can be used to tune the mobility of the electrons and holes so that the probability of 
recombination is very high. A diode designed to emit photons in this way is called a \textbf{light 
emitting diode} or \textbf{LED}. The energy of the emitted photon is directly dependent on the size of
the band gap. Furthermore, Planck's constant determines the wavelength of photons with given energy. 
Hence the wave length of light emitted by the LED is determined by the band gap and Planck's constant. 
These quantities are related by the equation

\begin{equation}
\lambda={\frac{hc}{E_{BG}}},
\label{equ:PC3}
\end{equation}
where $\lambda$ is the wavelength of the photon, h is Planck's constant, c (c = 299792458 m/s) is the speed of
light and E$_{BG}$ is the energy in joules that separates the valence and conduction bands in the p-type (the band
gap). Knowing the relation for the wavelength of light with respect to its frequency and rewriting  
energy as charge multiplied by potential one arrives at the formula

\begin{equation}
h={\frac{eV_{BG}}{f}},
\label{equ:PC4}
\end{equation}

%***********REVISED BY WESLEY KYLE MAY 12, 2015**********************************************
%REASON: CORRECTING INACCURATE INFORMATION AND PROVIDING BETTER EXPLANATION OF ASSUMPTIONS

where f is the frequency of the photon and eV$_{BG}$ is the potential difference across the band gap, from the p-side conduction band to the p-side valence band. The voltage measured across the LED when it just begins to shine is often called the \textit{turn-on voltage}. This voltage approximates the \textit{built-in voltage}, V$_0$, of an LED. The built-in voltage is the energy that is required to move an electron across the pn junction to the p side (see Figure \ref{fig:PC3}). Once it is there, the electron is free to undergo recombination with a hole and produce a photon with an energy equal to that of the band gap. To be clear, there is no direct, intrinsic connection between these two energies. Their relationship depends on the material used as a semi-conductor, the doping material and extent of doping, as well as the design of the LED (e.g., direct or indirect band gap). The amount they differ by, $\Delta E$, will vary across different LEDs. 

%This experiment nevertheless treats $\Delta E$ to be constant. When using Equation \ref{equ:PC3} to determine Planck's constant this assumption is equivalent to treating 

So it is not reasonable to assume that measurements of the built-in voltage are the same as the band gap voltage. It may still be possible, however, to measure Planck's constant using Equation \ref{equ:PC3}. The only assumption required is that $\Delta E$ be constant across each LED. This might be achieved by selecting LEDs with the same design and construction materials.

To illustrate this, one can look at what happens to the equivalence relation between V$_{BG}$ and V$_0$ if one says that the energy of the band gap is equal to the built-in voltage plus some difference, $\Delta E$,

\begin{equation}
eV_{BG}=h\nu=\dfrac{hc}{\lambda}=eV_{0}+\Delta E
\label{equ:PC5}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}
eV_{0}=hc\dfrac{1}{\lambda}-\Delta E
\label{equ:PC6}
\end{equation}

What is seen here is the equation of a straight line where, if the built-in voltage can be determined and the frequency of each LED is known, Planck's constant can be determined from the slope of a fitted linear curve. It is known from Equation \ref{equ:PC6} that a consistent difference between the built-in voltage and the band gap voltage does not affect our ability to determine Planck's constant. Instead, the difference manifests itself as a non-zero y-intercept. Thus, the only necessary assumption to equate V$_{BG}$ and V$_0$ (that is, set $\Delta E=0$) is that the energy difference be the same for each LED.



\begin{figure}[h!]
\centering
\usetikzlibrary{decorations.pathmorphing}

\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[](1,3)--(3,3)--(5,2)--(7,2);
\draw[](1,1)--(3,1)--(5,0)--(7,0);

\draw[fill=lightgray](3,3)--(5,2)--(5,0)--(3,1)--cycle;

\node[]at(6.9,2.25){$e^-$};
\node[]at(4.3,2.8){$e^-$};

\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{A band gap diagram illustrating the inequality of the band gap voltage and the built-in voltage.}
\label{fig:PC3}
\end{figure}

By measuring the built-in voltage of a set of LEDs and comparing them to the spectroscopically determined band gap voltages by finding $\Delta E$ the validity of this assumption may be put to the test.

\section{Apparatus}

A display board is provided for you that holds an assortment of 8 LEDs ranging in wavelength from the infra-red at 859 nm to the blue at 475 nm.  The Anatek power supply is connected to the \textbf{bias voltage} connection that powers each LED. An ammeter is connected in series with the rest of the circuit to measure the current through the LED and a voltmeter is connected in parallel with the power supply to measure the bias voltage.

\section{Experimental Procedure}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Apply a forward bias of 10 V to each LED and check the ammeter to ensure a current is passing through the LEDs (see Figure \ref{fig:PC4} for a circuit diagram and wiring instructions). If any are found to be not functioning, inform your TA.
\item To explore the current-voltage behaviour of an LED through an I-V plot select an LED and apply a forward bias of 0 to 7 V in increments of 0.2 V and record at least 30 measurements of the current through the LED at each bias voltage.
\item With each of the remaining 7 LEDs, collect at least 10 measurements of current for bias voltages between 3 and 7 volts. These measurements are started above 3 V to ensure that the bias voltage is greater than the built-in voltage of each LED and will be used to estimate the built-in voltage of each LED.
\item To explore the reverse biased behaviour of an LED select an LED and apply a reverse bias of 0 to 5 V in increments of 0.5 V and record at least 10 measurements of the current through the LED at each bias voltage.
\end{enumerate}




\section{Error Analysis}

Take the wavelength of each LED to be exact as given. These values have been determined spectroscopically and will be used to find the true band-gap voltage of each LED. The uncertainty in readings of voltage and current with the Fluke multimeter is the instrument error as shown on the bottom of the instrument. Its format is given as a percentage of the readout value plus the last digit of the readout. For example, a reading of $3.45$ VDC might have an uncertainty of $\pm (0.3\%+1$ digit$)$. This yields an uncertainty of $\pm (3.45\times.003+0.01)$. We then record our observation as $3.45$ V $\pm\ 0.02$.

\vspace{12pt}

\textbf{To be handed in to the laboratory instructor}

\label{fig:PC5}
\end{marginfigure}
