\chapter{Electron Gas in Metals}

\section{Equipment}

\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item Neva thermionic emission tube 
\item Korad DC power supply
\item Neva mains rectifier 
\item Fluke multimeters (2)
\item Set of connecting leads (3)
\end{itemize}
\section{Preparation}

The student should review the theory of Fermi-Dirac and Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics.

\section{Goals of the Experiment}

The purpose of this experiment is to examine the current-voltage characteristics of an electron tube, to determine the barrier energy and the work function of tungsten using Maxwell-Boltzmann and Fermi-Dirac statistics, respectively, to examine the space charge region using the Child-Langmuir three halves power law, and to make a Richardson plot of thermionic emission.  

\section{Theory}

In the late nineteenth century it was discovered that hot metals emitted charged particles. This process is now known as \textbf{thermionic emission}. Thomas Edison discovered thermionic emission as he looked for ways to keep soot from clouding his incandescent light bulbs. To collect some of the material responsible for the soot, Edison placed a metal plate a small distance from the filament. When this metal plate was connected to the positive terminal of the battery, he was able to measure a small 
electrical current across the gap. He could not observe any current when the plate was connected to the negative terminal of the battery.  Edison concluded that the plate 
was collecting negative charge, but could not explain exactly why. Because it did not eliminate the soot problem, he did little with this discovery.  

The physicist J.J. Thomson followed up on Edison's work. He performed measurements on the electric and magnetic deflections of the particles given off by the filament. 
Thomson found the same value for the charge to mass ratio of the particles originating from the filament as he had with previous experiments with \textbf{cathode rays}. 
Later researchers were able to devise methods to control this emission, which started the science of electronics. It would not be wrong to assert that the birth of 
electronics started with the discovery that the filament in Edison's light bulb emitted electrons.  

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[very thick,rounded corners=10pt] (0.4,0) rectangle (4.6,2); % main body of electron tube
\draw[very thick] (1,0.5) -- (1,1.5) (4,0.5) -- (4,1.5); % electrodes
\draw (1,1) -- (0,1) -- (0,2.5) -- (2.35,2.5) (2.65,2.5) -- (5,2.5) -- (5,1) -- (4,1); % wires
\draw (2.35,2.35) -- (2.35,2.65) (2.45,2.43) -- (2.45,2.57) (2.55,2.35) -- (2.55,2.65) (2.65,2.43) -- (2.65,2.57); % voltage supply
\draw[thin,dashed] (1.2,0.75) -- (1.2,1.25)(1.4,0.75) -- (1.4,1.25) (1.6,0.75) -- (1.6,1.25) (1.8,0.75) -- (1.8,1.25); % flowing electrons
\draw[thin,dashed] (2.2,0.75) -- (2.2,1.25)(2.4,0.75) -- (2.4,1.25) (2.6,0.75) -- (2.6,1.25); % flowing electrons
\draw[thin,dashed] (3,0.75) -- (3,1.25)(3.2,0.75) -- (3.2,1.25); % flowing electrons
\draw[thin,dashed] (3.7,0.75) -- (3.7,1.25); % flowing electrons
\draw[thin,->] (1.5,1.6) -- (3.5,1.6); % electron flow arrow
\node[text centered] at (2.5,0.3) {Electrons}; % electron label
\node[right] at (0,-0.4) {Cathode}; % cathode label
\node[left] at (5,-0.4) {Anode}; % anode label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (0.5,-0.25) -- (1,0.5); % cathode arrow
\draw[ultra thin,->] (4.5,-0.25) -- (4,0.5); % anode arrow


\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Electric current flow through an electron tube}
\label{fig:egElectronTube}
\end{marginfigure}


In this experiment the thermionic emission of electrons from the hot tungsten filament of an \textbf{electron tube} is investigated. The emitter of the electrons is known as
the \textbf{filament} or \textbf{cathode}. The collector receiving the electrons is the \textbf{plate} or \textbf{anode}. Figure \ref{fig:egElectronTube} illustrates a typical electron tube. 
Thermionic emission is observed by examining the electric current between the cathode and anode. Any gases in the tube will interfere with the electrons, so an evacuated 
tube is used. Therefore, it is necessary to study the separate but related phenomenon of \textbf{electric current flow} in a vacuum. It turns out that the atomic properties
of the cathode material determines the behaviour of the electrons in the gap. 

From experimental results, physicists have established that the  \textbf{valence electrons}, usually one per atom in a metal, are essentially free to move throughout the 
metal. For this reason a metal can be considered a "gas" of free electrons surrounding a regular arrangement of positive ions which form a crystal lattice. This  
\textbf{electron gas} is the source of thermionic emission in a metal. The inter-atomic forces between the crystal lattice of ions and the electron gas constitute the so 
called metallic bonds.  

At the metal boundary there exists a potential barrier which keeps most of the electrons confined inside the metal. As an approximation for electrons inside a metal, one can
consider the electrons to be confined in a box where they collide elastically with the walls of the box bouncing back and forth between them. Electrons do not interact with
each other except through elastic collisions like in an ideal gas. The electron gas model holds when the metal is pure, free of imperfections, and when lattice vibrations 
can be ignored. 

The energy distribution of the electrons in the metal determines their emission from the surface of the metal when it is hot. In order to compute the electron energy 
distribution, the number of electrons, N(E), having some energy, E, needs to be calculated. At any constant temperature, T, this is given by the expression

\begin{equation}
N(E)=g(E)f(E),
\label{equ:egNumberOfElectrons}
\end{equation}
where \textbf{g(E)} is the \textbf{density of states function} and \textbf{f(E)} is the \textbf{statistical distribution function}. The density of states function is the 
number of energy states available to electrons with energy between E and E + $\Delta$E. The statistical distribution function is the probability that a particle will occupy a state
of energy E.


\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}

\draw[very thick] (0,5) -- (0,0) -- (4,0) -- (4,5); % infinite potential well
\draw[ultra thin,<->] (0,-0.5) -- node[below] {L} (4,-0.5); % length arrow

\node[right] at (4,0) {s=0}; % s=0 label

\draw (0,1) sin (2,1.25) cos (4,1); % s=1 upper
\draw (0,1) sin (2,0.75) cos (4,1); % s=1 lower
\node[right] at (4,1) {s=1}; % s=1 label

\draw (0,2) sin (1,2.25) cos (2,2) sin (3,1.75) cos (4,2); % s=2 upper
\draw (0,2) sin (1,1.75) cos (2,2) sin (3,2.25) cos (4,2); % s=2 lower
\node[right] at (4,2) {s=2}; % s=2 label

\draw (0,3) sin (0.67,3.25) cos (1.33,3) sin (2,2.75) cos (2.67,3) sin (3.33,3.25) cos (4,3); % s=3 upper
\draw (0,3) sin (0.67,2.75) cos (1.33,3) sin (2,3.25) cos (2.67,3) sin (3.33,2.75) cos (4,3); % s=3 upper
\node[right] at (4,3) {s=3}; % s=3 label

\draw (0,4) sin (0.5,4.25) cos (1,4) sin (1.5,3.75) cos (2,4) sin (2.5,4.25) cos (3,4) sin (3.5,3.75) cos (4,4); % s=4 upper
\draw (0,4) sin (0.5,3.75) cos (1,4) sin (1.5,4.25) cos (2,4) sin (2.5,3.75) cos (3,4) sin (3.5,4.25) cos (4,4); % s=4 lower
\node[right] at (4,4) {s=4}; s=4 label



\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Standing waves in an infinite potential well}
\label{fig:egStandingWaves}
\end{marginfigure}

It seems easiest to begin by examining a \textbf{one dimensional metal}.  The density of states function can be found in a one dimensional metal in the following way. 
Suppose the electrons are confined in a one dimensional box of length L. The box can be viewed as a one dimensional potential well with an infinite potential barrier, as 
shown in Figure \ref{fig:egStandingWaves}.  In a quantum mechanical description the electrons have wave properties associated with them. Because the electrons collide with the walls of the box, the
quantum states of the electrons must consist of standing waves for which a node occurs at each wall. The path length from wall to wall must be an integral number, s, of half
wavelengths so that    

\begin{equation}
L=\frac{s\lambda}{2},
\label{equ:egPathLength}\ \ \ \text{s = 0,1,2,...}
\end{equation}
 As the wavelength, {$\lambda$}, of the standing wave decreases, the energy of the electron increases.


According to de Broglie, an electron with a wavelength, {$\lambda$}, has momentum, p, given by 

\begin{equation}
p=\frac{h}{\lambda},
\label{equ:egMomentumAndWaveLength}
\end{equation}
where h is Planck's constant (h=4.136x10$^{-15}$eV$\cdot{s}$ or 6.626x10$^{-34}$J$\cdot{s}$). Since the electrons in the metal have non relativistic velocities their 
momentum is then

\begin{equation}
p=\sqrt{2mE}.
\label{equ:egMomentumAndEnergy}
\end{equation}

Substituting Equations \ref{equ:egMomentumAndWaveLength} and \ref{equ:egMomentumAndEnergy} into Equation \ref{equ:egPathLength} gives

\begin{equation}
s=\frac{2L}{\lambda}=\frac{2Lp}{h}=\frac{2L\sqrt{2mE}}{h}.
\label{equ:egEnergyOfState}
\end{equation}
Taking the derivative of Equation \ref{equ:egEnergyOfState} with respect to energy gives a relationship between {$\Delta$}s and {$\Delta$}E which is

\begin{equation}
{\Delta}s=\frac{L}{h}\sqrt{\frac{2m}{E}}{\Delta}E.
\label{equ:egdStateAnddEnegrgy}
\end{equation}

Each standing wave can represent two states of an electron, one with spin up and one with spin down. So Equation \ref{equ:egdStateAnddEnegrgy} is doubled to get the density of
states which is

\begin{equation}
g(E){\Delta}E=2{\Delta}s=\frac{2L}{h}\sqrt{\frac{2m}{E}}{\Delta}E.
\label{equ:egDensityOfState1}
\end{equation}

Consider an example of N electrons in the box at temperature T = $0$ K. According to the \textbf{Pauli exclusion principle}, which states that no more than two fermions can 
occupy one and the same energy state, the electrons will fill the lowest possible energy states, one electron per state, starting with E = $0$ to the state with the highest energy E = {$\varepsilon$}$_{F}$ called the \textbf{Fermi level}. The difference in energy between the ground state and the Fermi level is called the {\bf Fermi energy}. The number of electrons in this situation will be equal to the number of states with energies between zero 
and {$\varepsilon$}$_{F}$ so that

\begin{equation}
N=\int_0^{\varepsilon_F}g(E)\,dE = \int_0^{\varepsilon_F}\frac{2L}{h}\sqrt{\frac{2m}{E}}\,dE = \frac{4L}{h}\sqrt{2m\varepsilon_F}.
\label{equ:egNumberAtFermi}
\end{equation}
The Fermi energy to be calculated in terms of the number of electrons in the potential well is

\begin{equation}
\varepsilon_F = \frac{N^2 h^2}{32 m L^2}.
\label{equ:egFermiEnergy}
\end{equation}
The density of state for this example can be found by isolating L/h from Equation \ref{equ:egFermiEnergy} and then substituting the result into Equation \ref{equ:egDensityOfState1}.

\begin{equation}
g(E){\Delta}E=\frac{1}{2}\frac{N}{\sqrt{\varepsilon_F E}}\Delta E.
\label{equ:egDensityOfState2}
\end{equation}

Analogous calculations for a three dimensional potential well of side L are found in a similar manner as for the one dimensional case except that spherical shells are used 
instead of strips. The density of states for the three dimensional case turns out to be


\begin{equation}
g(E){\Delta}E=\frac{8\sqrt{2} \pi L^3 m^{3/2}}{h^3}\sqrt{E} \Delta E.
\label{equ:egDensityOfState3D}
\end{equation}

Up to this point, the density of states of the electrons in a metal in which the electrons have energies between E and E + {$\Delta$}E has been examined. The number of 
electrons in a metal having these energies has only been calculated for the special one dimensional case at T = $0$ K. To find this number for a real three dimensional metal 
at any temperature the statistical distribution function f(E) relevant to the electrons is required.

If electrons in the three dimensional box were treated as distinguishable, non-interacting classical particles without spin, colliding elastically with the walls of the box, then the 
\textbf{Maxwell-Boltzman}n distribution function would determine the electron energies. This classical distribution function has the form

\begin{equation}
f_{MB} (E)=\frac{N}{V}\left(\frac{h^2}{2 \pi mkT}\right)^{3/2}e^{\frac{-E}{kT}}
\label{equ:egMBDistribution}
\end{equation}
where N is the total number of particles, V has replaced L$^{3}$ as the volume of the three dimensional box, and k is the Boltzmann constant (k=1.38$\times10^{-23}$ J/K). When this 
distribution function was applied to the electrons in metals it was found to yield inconsistent results. 

The aforementioned inconsistencies were removed by A. Sommerfeld in 1928. He assumed the electrons were \textbf{not} classical particles and instead obeyed quantum 
mechanical \textbf{Fermi-Dirac} statistics. The Fermi-Dirac distribution function is given by

\begin{equation}
f_{FD} (E)=\frac{1}{e^{\frac{E-\varepsilon_{F}}{kT}} + 1}
\label{equ:egFDDistribution}
\end{equation}
In this approach, the electrons in a metal are treated as indistinguishable particles having spin 1/2. The functional behavior of Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics and that of 
Fermi-Dirac at different temperatures are illustrated in Figures \ref{fig:egMBStatistics} through \ref{fig:egHighTemp} below. 		

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[->] (0,0) -- (0,3); % vertical axis
\node[left] at (0,3) {f(E)}; % vertical axis label
\draw[->](0,0) -- (3,0); % horizontal axis
\node[below] at (3,0) {E}; % horizontal axis label
\draw (0.1,2.8) .. controls(0.2,2) and (0.25,0.25) .. (1,0); % T~0 line
\draw[dashed] (0,1.5) .. controls(0.6,0.4) and (2,0.3) .. (2.8,0.2); % T >> 0 line
\node[right] at (1,2) {T\ {$\sim$}\ 0\ K}; % T~0 label
\node[right] at (1.5,1.65) {T\ {$\gg$}\ 0\ K}; % T>>0 label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (1.1,2) -- (0.25,1.5); % T~0 arrow
\draw[ultra thin,->] (1.6,1.65) -- (0.95,0.63); % T>>0 arrow
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution function at two temperatures}
\label{fig:egMBStatistics}
\end{marginfigure}

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[->] (0,0) -- (0,3); % vertical axis
\node[left] at (0,3) {f(E)}; % vertical axis label
\draw[->](0,0) -- (3,0); % horizontal axis
\node[below] at (3,0) {E}; % horizontal axis label
\draw[rounded corners=5pt] (0,2) -- (2,2) -- (2,0) -- (2.5,0); % T~0 line
\draw[dashed] (0,1.8) -- (2.8,0.4); % T >> 0 line
\node[right] at (2.5,2) {T\ {$\sim$}\ 0\ K}; % T~0 label
\node[right] at (2.5,1.65) {T\ {$\gg$}\ 0\ K}; % T>>0 label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (2.6,2) -- (2,1.75); % T~0 arrow
\draw[ultra thin,->] (2.6,1.65) -- (1.54,1.04); % T>>0 arrow
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Fermi-Dirac distribution function at two temperatures}
\label{fig:egFDStatistics}
\end{marginfigure}

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[->] (0,0) -- (0,3); % vertical axis
\node[left] at (0,3) {f(E)}; % vertical axis label
\draw[->](0,0) -- (3,0); % horizontal axis
\node[below] at (3,0) {E}; % horizontal axis label
\draw [dashed] (0.1,2.8) .. controls(0.2,2) and (0.25,0.25) .. (1,0); % MB T~0 line
\draw[rounded corners=5pt] (0,2) -- (2,2) -- (2,0) -- (2.5,0); % FD T~0 line
\node[right] at (0.5,2.5) {Maxwell-Boltzmann}; % MB T~0 label
\node[right] at (2.5,2) {Fermi-Dirac}; % FD T~0 label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (0.6,2.5) -- (0.15,2.3); % T~0 arrow
\draw[ultra thin,->] (2.6,2) -- (2,1.75); % T~0 arrow
\node[text centered] at (1,1.2) {T\ {$\sim$}\ 0\ K}; % temperature label
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Fermi-Dirac and Maxwell-Boltzmann distributions at T {$\sim$} 0 K}
\label{fig:egLowTemp}
\end{marginfigure}

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[->] (0,0) -- (0,3); % vertical axis
\node[left] at (0,3) {f(E)}; % vertical axis label
\draw[->](0,0) -- (3,0); % horizontal axis
\node[below] at (3,0) {E}; % horizontal axis label
\draw[dashed] (0,1.8) -- (2.8,0.4); % FD T >> 0 line
%\draw (0,1.5) .. controls(0.6,0.4) and (2,0.3).. (2.8,0.2); % MB T >> 0 line
\draw (0.11,1.9) .. controls(0.6,0.6) and (2,0.5).. (2.8,0.4); % MB T >> 0 line
\node[right] at (1,2.5) {Fermi-Dirac}; % FD T>>0 label
\node[right] at (2,2) {Maxwell-Boltzmann}; % MB T>>0 label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (1.05,2.5) -- (0.33,1.65); % FD T>>0 arrow
\draw[ultra thin,->] (2.05,2) -- (0.77,0.72); % MB T>>0 arrow
\node[right] at (0.05,0.2) {T\ {$\gg$}\ 0\ K}; %temperature label
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Fermi-Dirac and Maxwell-Boltzmann distributions at T {$\gg$} 0 K}
\label{fig:egHighTemp}
\end{marginfigure}

The spin of fermions is the main cause for the differences between the two distribution functions. Figure \ref{fig:egMBStatistics} illustrates the Maxwell-Boltzmann 
distribution function for two temperatures, one near absolute zero and one at tens of thousands of degrees. When the temperature is low this distribution is very steep as 
the majority of particles are in their lowest energy state. As the temperature increases the Maxwell-Boltzmann curve flattens out because more particles have enough energy 
to exist at higher energy levels. Figure \ref{fig:egFDStatistics} shows the functional behaviour of Fermi-Dirac statistics. When temperatures are near zero, the majority of 
fermions occupy energy levels starting from zero to to E ={$\varepsilon$}$_{F}$. At high temperatures even particles in the ground state may move to higher energy levels, 
which causes the Fermi-Dirac "square" to become linear. Figure \ref{fig:egLowTemp} illustrates that the two distribution curves are very different at low temperatures. At low 
temperatures the Pauli exclusion principle causes the extreme differences between the curves.  At very high temperatures, quantum effects become small. In such a case the 
probability of finding two particles in one energy level is also small, therefore it does not matter if the particles undergo the exclusion principle. For low density and 
high temperatures the Fermi-Dirac statistics approaches that of Maxwell-Boltzmann, as seen in Figure \ref{fig:egHighTemp}.

Equation \ref{equ:egNumberOfElectrons} can now be used to calculate the number of electrons {$\Delta$}N with energies between E and E + {$\Delta$}E at some temperature T. 
According to Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics this number, {$\Delta$}N$_{MB}$, would be

\begin{equation}
\Delta N_{MB}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{8\sqrt{2} \pi Vm^{\frac{3}{2}}}{h^3}\sqrt{E}\frac{N}{V}\left(\frac{h^2}{2\pi mkT}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}e^{\frac{-E}{kT}}\Delta E.
\label{equ:egNumberMB}
\end{equation}
where the factor 1/2 "removes" the spin from the electrons. While Fermi-Dirac statistics determines this number, {$\Delta$}N$_{FD}$, to be

\begin{equation}
\Delta N_{FD}=\frac{8\sqrt{2} \pi Vm^{\frac{3}{2}}}{h^3} \frac{\sqrt{E}}{e^{\frac{E-\varepsilon_F}{kT}}+1}\Delta E.
\label{equ:egNumberFD}
\end{equation}

Thermionic emission only involves the component of velocity, v$_{x}$, of electrons perpendicular to the tungsten surface of the emitting filament. Only a certain portion of
the electrons having non-zero x-component of velocity will contribute to the current out of the emitting surface.  These electrons must have sufficient velocity such that 

\begin{equation}
\frac{1}{2}mv_{x}^2 \geq E_{B} ,
\label{equ:egMinimumEnergy}
\end{equation}
where E$_B$ is the \textbf{tungsten potential barrier}

The relationship between the energy E and the speed v of the electrons is

\begin{equation}
E=\frac{mv^2}{2}=\frac{m(v_{x}^2+v_{y}^2+v_{z}^2)}{2}.
\label{equ:egEnergyAndVelocity}
\end{equation}
and its derivative is 

\begin{equation}
{\Delta}E=mv{\Delta}v=m\sqrt{(v_{x}^2+v_{y}^2+v_{z}^2)}{\Delta}v,
\label{equ:egChangeEnergyAndVelocity}
\end{equation}

Equations \ref{equ:egNumberMB} and \ref{equ:egNumberFD} can be rewritten with the velocity and this gives the number of electrons {$\Delta$}N whose speeds are between v and v +
{$\Delta$}v.  Making the required substitutions gives

\begin{equation}
{\Delta}N_{MB}=4{\pi}N\left(\frac{m}{2{\pi}kT}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}e^{\frac{-mv^2}{2kT}}v^{2}{\Delta}v,
\label{equ:egNumberMB2}
\end{equation}
and

\begin{equation}
{\Delta}N_{FD}=\frac{8{\pi}Vm^{3}}{h^3} \frac{v^2{\Delta}v}{e^{\frac{mv^2-2\varepsilon_F}{2kT}}+1}
\label{equ:egNumberFD2}
\end{equation}

To obtain the number, {$\Delta$}N$_{MB,x}$, of electrons between v$_{x}$ and v$_{x}$ + {$\Delta$}v$_{x}$ for the Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics, first Equation 
\ref{equ:egNumberMB2} must be changed from spherical to Cartesian coordinates.  This is done by replacing 4{$\pi$}v$^{2}$ {$\Delta$}v by 
{$\Delta$}v$_{x}${$\Delta$}v$_{y}${$\Delta$}v$_{z}$. The y and z velocity components are removed by integrating over v$_{y}$ and v$_{z}$ from +{$\infty$} to -{$\infty$}. 
The number of electrons is then

\begin{equation}
{\Delta}N_{MB,x}=nV\left(\frac{m}{2{\pi}kT}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}{\Delta}v_{x}\int\limits_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\int\limits_{-\infty}^{+\infty}e^{\frac{-m(v_{x}^2+v_{y}^+v_{z}^2)}{2kT}}dv_{y}dv_{z}
\label{equ:egNMBx}
\end{equation}
which becomes,

\begin{equation}
{\Delta}N_{MB,x}=nV\sqrt{\frac{m}{2{\pi}kT}}e^{\frac{-mv_{x}^2}{2kT}}{\Delta}v_{x},
\label{equ:egNMBx2}
\end{equation}
where n = N/V is the concentration of electrons in tungsten. To find the emission current the number of electrons falling on the boundary per second must be calculated. To 
achieve this, first multiply Equation \ref{equ:egNMBx2} by the charge of the electron and the surface area of the metal. Then divide Equation \ref{equ:egNMBx2} by the volume V 
of the tungsten filament. Lastly, multiply by v$_{x}$ because, in some small interval of time, $\Delta t$, all the electrons with the velocity component v$_{x}$ which are contained in a layer of depth v$_{x}\Delta t$ in front of the boundary will arrive at the boundary and escape the metal. The emission current, I$_{S,MB}$, predicted assuming Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics is


\begin{equation}
I_{S,MB}=aen\sqrt{\frac{m}{2{\pi}kT}}\int\limits_{\sqrt{{2E_B}/{m}}}^{+\infty}v_{x}e^{\frac{-mv_{x}^{2}}{2kT}}dv_{x}=aen\sqrt{\frac{kT}{2{\pi}m}}e^{\frac{-E_B}{kT}}
\label{equ:egEmissionCurrentMB}
\end{equation}
where a = 3.2$\times10^{-5}$m$^{2}$ is the surface area of the tungsten filament and e = 1.602$\times10^{-19}$ C is the electron charge.

The same procedure can be followed using Fermi-Dirac statistics. Starting with Equation \ref{equ:egNumberMB2} and proceeding as earlier, the emission current, I$_{S,FD}$,  
predicted by Fermi-Dirac statistics is

\begin{equation}
I_{s,FD}=2a\left(\frac{2{\pi}mek^2}{h^3}\right)T^2e^{\frac{-\phi}{kT}},
\label{equ:egEmissionCurrentFD}
\end{equation}
where {$\phi$}= E$_{B}$-{$\varepsilon$}$_{F}$ is the work function of the metal. 

Equations \ref{equ:egEmissionCurrentMB} and \ref{equ:egEmissionCurrentFD} can be rewritten in the simplified forms

\begin{equation}
I_{S,MB}=aA_{MB}T^{\frac{1}{2}}e^{\frac{-E_B}{kT}}
\label{equ:egSimpleEmissionCurrentMB}
\end{equation}
and
\begin{equation}
I_{S,FD}=2aA_{FD}T^2e^{\frac{-\phi}{kT}},
\label{equ:egRDEquation}
\end{equation}
where
\begin{equation}
A_{MB}=en\left(\frac{k}{2{\pi}m}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}
\label{equ:egAMB}
\end{equation}
and
\begin{equation}
A_{FD}=\frac{2{\pi}mek^2}{h^3}.
\label{equ:egAFD}
\end{equation}
Equations \ref{equ:egSimpleEmissionCurrentMB} and \ref{equ:egRDEquation} predict the maximum current, called the \textbf{saturation current}, that a metal will 
emit at a temperature T given there is no externally applied electric field on the metal. Equation \ref{equ:egRDEquation} is called the \textbf{Richardson 
Dushman equation}. It has been found that this equation predicts correctly the saturation current as a function of temperature and work function. This seems reasonable 
because electrons are fermions and hence obey Fermi-Dirac statistics. The constant A$_{FD}$, is essentially the same for all metals at room temperature.

\caption{Characteristic Curve of tungsten}
\label{fig:egCharacteristicCurve}
\end{figure}

Basically, the experiment consists of heating a tungsten filament to a known temperature, applying a known voltage between the cathode and anode, and then measuring the 
emissive current. The three variables that can be manipulated in this experiment are the temperature, voltage, and emission current. Any two of these variables can be 
plotted as a function of the other, while the third variable is held constant. The resulting curve is called a \textbf{characteristic}. Figure \ref{fig:egCharacteristicCurve}
shows three 
\textbf{current-voltage} characteristic curves.

Using the curve depicted by temperature T$_{3}$ in Figure \ref{fig:egCharacteristicCurve} as a representative, it is observed that the curve consists of three sections, the
\textbf{exponential range (ab)}, the \textbf{space charge range (bc)}, and the \textbf{temperature limited range (cd)}. It can be seen that the emission current increases at
any constant potential as the temperature increases from T$_{3}$ to T$_{1}$, The figure also illustrates that the three ranges themselves increase in size as the temperature
increases.

The application of an electric potential difference between the cathode and anode manipulates the emission current by either accelerating or retarding the motion of the 
electrons. This potential difference need not necessarily be positive in order to obtain an emission current. The exponential range is found exclusively in the region of 
negative collector potentials. Not all the electrons have enough energy to reach the collector. Many of them instead return to the filament. In this range the measured 
current consists only of the electrons that have enough energy to first overcome the potential barrier of the metal and then surmount the energy barrier produced by the 
negative applied electric potential. The Richardson Dushman equation needs to be modified in the exponential range. If the retarding voltage and the cylindrical symmetry of
the anode are taken into consideration the equation becomes

\begin{equation}
I_{E}=I_{S,FD}\frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}}\sqrt{\frac{eV}{kT}}e^{\frac{-eV}{kT}},
\label{equ:egRDExponential}
\end{equation}
where V is the negative collector potential.

%%\draw (2,1) -- (2,0) -- (3,0);

%\node[right] at (2,2) {Fermi-Dirac}; % FD T>>0 label
%\draw[ultra thin,->] (1.05,2.5) -- (0.33,1.65); % MB T>>0 arrow
%\draw[ultra thin,->] (2.05,2) -- (0.77,0.72); % FD T>>0 arrow
%%\node[right] at (0.05,0.2) {T\ {$\gg$}\ 0\ K}; %temperature label
%\end{tikzpicture}
%\caption{Fermi-Dirac and Maxwell-Boltzmann distributions at T {$\gg$} 0 K}
%\label{fig:egFDDistribution}
%\end{marginfigure}
%It was thought for a time that this relation supported a classical velocity distribution within the metal, because Equation 28 can be deduced from classical statistics. It 
%is known now, however, that the Fermi-Dirac distribution inside the metal degenerates to the classical form for electrons in this region as illustrated in Figure 8. 
As the potential is increased the number of electrons reaching the anode is increased. This increasing charge produced by the electrons significantly affects the emission 
current and the current-voltage characteristic is described by a power law. This marks the end of the exponential region and the beginning of the space charge region.  

In order to examine this range, the electric charge produced by the electrons themselves must be taken into account. This charge is called \textbf{space charge} and it 
occurs anytime there is a current. Not all of the electrons that are emitted have enough energy to reach the collector. For relatively small negative and positive potential
differences, many electrons leaving the filament return to it. The electrons that return to the filament form a negatively charged cloud near the filament. The cloud of
negative charge causes the electrons to initially climb a potential hill, produced by the electrons, before their journey to the collector. A precise mathematical 
description of this range is difficult. However, the empirical \textbf{Child-Langmuir 3/2 power law} agrees with experimental results well at high temperatures. In this 
law, the current is proportional to the gap voltage to the 3/2 power such that

\begin{equation}
I_{E}{\propto}V^{\frac{3}{2}}.
\label{equ:egCL3/2}
\end{equation}
As the potential between the emitter and collector increases further, more electrons reach the collector. When the potential becomes large, all the emitted electrons are 
collected by the anode and this marks the beginning of the temperature limited region. 

Temperature is the primary factor in determining the emission current in the temperature-limited range.  All the emitted electrons are forced to move to the collector by the
large applied potential. At this point further increases in gap potential should not increase the emissive current because the number of electrons are limited only by the 
work function of the metal. However, Figure \ref{fig:egCharacteristicCurve} illustrates that the temperature-limited range is not perfectly flat. The slightly positive linear
slope in this region is attributed to the lowering of the metal's potential barrier by the electric field produced by the applied emitter-collector potential. This is known
as the \textbf{Schottky effect}.
 
In the temperature limited range the current is linear with the gap voltage. The saturation currents predicted by Equations \ref{equ:egSimpleEmissionCurrentMB} and 
\ref{equ:egRDEquation} were derived assuming no gap potential. The measured saturation current is found by extrapolating the linear current-voltage line back to zero potential
voltage. This point is represented by b' in Figure \ref{fig:egCharacteristicCurve}. When the potential is zero the Richardson equation is used to find the work function of the
tungsten. Dividing Equation
\ref{equ:egRDEquation} by T$^{2}$ and then taking the log of both sides gives

\begin{equation}
ln\left(\frac{I_{S,FD}}{T^2}\right)=ln(2aA_{FD})-\frac{\phi}{kT}
\label{equ:egRichardsonPlotFD}
\end{equation}
The graph of  ln(I$_{S,FD}$/T$^2$) vs 1/T is called a \textbf{Richardson plot}. If Equation \ref{equ:egRichardsonPlotFD} holds, then the data would be expected to be a straight 
line with slope -{$\phi$}/k and intercept ln(2aA$_{FD}$).
 
The corresponding plot for classical statistics is found using Equation \ref{equ:egEmissionCurrentMB} and is 

\begin{equation}
ln\left(\frac{I_{S,MB}}{T^{\frac{1}{2}}}\right)=ln(aA_{MB})-\frac{E_B}{kT}.
\label{equ:egRichardsonPlotMB}
\end{equation}

From the resulting slope in Equation \ref{equ:egRichardsonPlotFD} the work function of the tungsten can determined and compared with the accepted value {$\phi$}= 4.55eV. The 
barrier energy deduced from Equation \ref{equ:egRichardsonPlotMB} can be compared with the known value  E$_{B}$ = 13.5eV. If the experimentally determined value of the barrier
energy differs greatly from the accepted value it is possible to conclude that Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics do not apply to the electron gas in tungsten metal.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Connect circuit as illustrated in Figure \ref{fig:egExpSetup}.
\item The temperature of the tungsten cathode is the primary factor in thermionic emission. Select a constant heating current I$_{H}$ around 2.5 A. The heating current is 
related to the temperature of the filament by the interpolation equation 

\begin{equation}
T=-6.673I_{H}^4+102I_{H}^3-574.92I_{H}^2+1764.1I_{H}-326.59.
\label{equ:egFilamentTemp}
\end{equation}
Measure the emission current I$_{E}$, when the temperature is held constant and the applied voltage V$_{m}$ is varied from 0 V to 300 V in 20 V increments. For best results
wait about half a minute to let the diode tube come to equilibrium after a change in either the temperature or the potential.
\item Repeat Step 2 with five different cathode temperatures ranging from 1800 K to 2300 K. 
\item Select a temperature between 2300 K - 2600 K.  Measure the emission current I$_{E}$, when the temperature is held constant and the applied voltage V$_{m}$ is varied 
from 0 V to 200 V in 10 V increments.  At high temperatures the emission current may be high enough that the anode power supply can not reach the full value of 200 V.
\item Repeat Step 4  with two different cathode temperatures ranging from  2300 K to 2600 K. 
\item Perform any measurements required for optional parts of the experiment.

\end{enumerate}
\section{Error Analysis}
The uncertainty in the multimeter measurements are determined as suggested on the multimeter. All the other parameters examined in this experiment are derived from
 multimeter measurements. The errors in these parameters are found using the standard techniques of error propagation.  

There are a number of systematic errors present in this experiment. The slight temperature dependence of the work function has not been included in the derivation of 
Equation \ref{equ:egRDEquation}. This can alter the constant A$_{FD}$ by factors of 2 or larger. The quantum mechanical reflections of the electrons at the surface of the 
metal are not taken into account. The reflections can modify the barrier potential. The metal surface is non uniform rather than the idealized crystal that was used. This 
changes the expected emission current. The interpolation equation for the temperature only gives the temperature at the mid-point of the filament. The leads to the filament
will cool the ends of the filament resulting in the temperature not being constant throughout the filament. Finally, because the cathode and the anode have different fermi 
energies, there exists a potential, called the \textbf{contact potential}, in the gap even when there is no applied voltage. The actual potential between the cathode and 
anode would be a sum of the applied voltage and the contact potential.  In more sophisticated models these effects can be taken into account, but they have been neglected 
in this treatment.  

\vspace{12pt}

\section{Preparation}

You should understand the postulates that go into the derivation of the Bohr model of the atom and the outcomes of the model with regards to the quantization of energy levels. You should understand the design and outcomes of the Franck-Hertz experiment. You should be able to use a digital volt meter and digital current meter to make measurements of DC voltages and DC currents.

\section{Goals of the Experiment}

At the end of this experiment, you should be able to use data including the number of scattered electrons as a function of electron energy to provide evidence of quantized atomic energy levels in helium atoms.

\section{Theory}
In this exercise, you will conduct an experiment to explore the quantization of atomic energy levels. You will collect evidence to support the results of the Bohr model, a model that suggests that an electron can only accept or emit energy in discrete amounts. To do this, you will use a tube filled with low-pressure helium gas and fitted with an electron gun and collector circuit. The electrons will serve as projectiles which collide with the helium atoms, which act as the targets.

To begin with, lets consider how energy can be transferred when two particles interact with each other. An elastic collision occurs when the total kinetic energy of both the electron and helium atom does not change. Because the helium atom is much more massive than the electron (~10$^{-26}$ kg vs. ~10$^{-30}$ kg), to a reasonable approximation, the scattered electron suffers no appreciable loss of kinetic energy. An inelastic collision occurs when the kinetic energy of both the electron and helium atom changes as a result of the interaction. Here, we might expect that a portion of the initial kinetic energy of the electron is transferred as internal energy of the helium atom. According to the Bohr model, energy is only transferred as internal energy of the helium atom in fixed amounts. It is not possible to transfer energy smoothly or continuously.


How can we observe this transfer of energy using the helium-filled tube in this experiment? If no kinetic energy is transferred from the electron to the internal energy of the atom, the collisions are elastic. Therefore, we don't expect to see a change in the kinetic energy of the scattered electrons.  However, if the kinetic energy of an electron corresponds to a quantized change in internal energy of a helium atom, then an inelastic collision could occur resulting in the electron losing all of its kinetic energy. We will look for electrons that have lost most of their kinetic energy.

\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{An illustration depicting the journey of an electron within the Franck-Hertz tube. The energy of colliding electrons is charted along the bottom of the diagram.}
\label{fig:cpTheory}
\end{figure}


In the helium tube (refer to Figure \ref{fig:cpTheory}), electrons are produced by heating a metal filament called the cathode (A). This cathode produces electrons with a relatively small variability in kinetic energy (on the order of 1 eV). The electrons are then accelerated by a potential difference between the cathode (A) and anode (B). Having gained kinetic energy, E$_{max}=eV_{max}$, the electrons then enter an essentially field-free region in the bulb where they collide with helium atoms (C). Electrons that possess a kinetic energy equivalent to the energy of an electronic transition of helium will undergo inelastic collisions with the helium atoms and lose all of their kinetic energy. The energy lost by a colliding electron goes into exciting an electron within the atom. The colliding electron is swept into the collector ring (D). This process, repeated for the many electrons emitted by the cathode, results in a current in the collector circuit. An increase in collector current is observed when increasing numbers of electrons lose kinetic energy due to inelastic collisions with the helium atom. Electrons that are not swept out of the tube by the collector ring strike the inner surface of the bulb (E), which is coated with a transparent conductive film that enables electrons to flow back to the anode.

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[<->](1,3)--(1,1)--(5,1);
\draw[](1,1.3)--(1.5,1.3)--(2.5,2.5)--(2.5,1.3)--(3,1.3)--(4,2.5)--(4,1.3)--(4.5,1.3);
\draw[](.95,2.5)--(1.05,2.5);

\node[font=\tiny,rotate=90]at(.5,2){energy of};

\node[font=\tiny]at(3,.8){time};
\node[font=\tiny]at(1.38,1.15){$V_{min}$};
\node[font=\tiny]at(1.38,2.5){$V_{max}$};
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{The apparatus sweeps the selected range of electron energies by changing the accelerating voltage (from $V_{min}$ to $V_{max}$) many times per second allowing rapid data collection.}
\label{fig:energyVsTime}
\end{marginfigure}

By increasing the accelerating voltage from $V_{min}$ to $V_{max}$ and recording the resulting collector current we can identify those electron energies that produce spikes in collector current and thus infer the energies of electronic transitions of helium. The apparatus ramps the accelerating voltage and measures the collector current (see Figure \ref{fig:energyVsTime}) many times per second, and records the results on a computer.

\section{Experimental Procedure}

\begin{figure}
\centering
\begin{tikzpicture}

\subsection{Setting up the equipment}
\item Connect the circuit shown in Figure \ref{fig:cpSetup}. This circuit will power the cathode and control the accelerating voltage. Be sure to connect the Vernier voltage sensors to the LabPro in the specified channels.

\item Download the file "Evidence-for-Quantized-Atomic-Energy-Levels.cmbl" from the pjl website (www.pjl.ucalgary.ca/courses/physics325.html", and open it with the logger pro software.

\item Temporarily connect both leads from both of the voltage sensors to the ground terminal on the controller, and zero them in the software by clicking on the zeroing icon in the top toolbar. Once zeroed, reconnect the voltage sensors to the controller.

%\item Connect the negative leads of both Vernier voltage sensors to a ground terminal on the controller. Be sure to open LoggerPro \textcolor{red}{\large{{\bf (Once the cmbl file is finalized we'll have to put a reference to it in here)}}} and zero the sensors in the software before continuing.

\item Connect the positive lead of the Vernier voltage sensor connected to channel 1 to the controller terminal marked {\bf Slow 1} and the positive lead of the Vernier voltage sensor connected to channel 2 to the controller terminal marked {\bf Slow 2}.

\item Set the cathode power supply, $P1$, to $3$ V, and the anode bias power supply, $P2$, to $1.5$ V. The Fluke multimeter can be used to verify this value by connecting its leads across the terminals of the power supply.

\item Adjust the minimum and maximum voltage for each sweep by adjusting knobs 4 and 5 on the controller. Their values can be monitored via a multimeter with its negative lead connected to a ground terminal on the controller and its positive lead connected to terminals 3 or 4 (max and min, respectively) on the controller (see Figures \ref{fig:cpSetMinVoltage} and \ref{fig:cpSetMaxVoltage}). The minimum voltage, $V_{min}$, should be $~17$ V and the maximum, $V_{max}$, should be $~25$ V. Record these values, and update the corresponding in LoggerPro.

\subsection{Collecting the data}
\item In LoggerPro, click on {\bf Experiment -> Data Collection} and ensure that the {\bf length} is set to at least 26 seconds, and that the {\bf Sampling Rate} is set to 100 samples/second.
\end{enumerate}

Click the {\bf Collect} button to begin collecting data and immediately after the sensors begin to collect measurements, press the {\bf Slow Run} button on the controller.

\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Translating the data}
We want to know the energy of incident electrons have been accelerated (accelerating voltage), and how many electrons are collected by the ring (collector current). What the Vernier voltage sensors are actually give us is a representation of those values that must be then mapped into that data we want.

\begin{enumerate}[resume]
\item To convert back to current we just need to multiply the voltage by $-667\ \frac{A}{V}$ to obtain the proper collector current in picoAmperes. This conversion factor is determined by the electronic components used to build the current to voltage converter. This conversion has been preloaded into the column "I-collector" in the .cmbl file

\item Obtaining the accelerating voltage is more complicated. What is actually being measured is a signal that increase linearly from some initial voltage, to a final voltage over the period of 25 seconds. The good news is that we have all the information we need. We set the values of $V_{min}$ and $V_{max}$ so we know what the actual initial and final voltages are, we know that it increase linearly, and we know it takes takes 25 seconds to complete. From this we can derive the mapping function

\begin{equation}
V_{acc}(t)=\frac{V_{max}-V{min}}{25}t+V_{min}.
\label{equ:cp1}
\end{equation}

This calculation has been preloaded into the column "V-acc"



%~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Linear Mapping~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~





%To do this we define a function, $E=E(t)$, which maps all of our time values to energy values. Here we assume a linear relationship between time and energy as we should expect from the linearly ramping accelerating voltage.


%The circuitry in the apparatus is designed such that the accelerating voltage ramps linearly with time from the minimum voltage to the maximum voltage which means the energy of accelerated electrons does so as well. If we define two points on this line, two times and their corresponding energies, we can define the function that maps all points in time to an energy. The two best points to use are the first peak (at $E(t_1)=19.8$ eV) and the onset of ionization (at $E(t_2)=24.6$ eV).

%The equation for the line is then,

%\begin{equation}
%E(t) = 19.8+4.8\dfrac{(t-t_1)}{(t_2-t_1)}
%\label{equ:cp2}
%\end{equation}



%~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~End Linear Mapping~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~






%\item In LoggerPro, click on {\it Data -> New Calculated Column...} and define a new column according to the function we determined in the previous step where the variable $t$ is replaced by the data from channel 1. Call this column $V$ for potential and give it units of $eV$. Click {\it Okay} to return to the plot.

%\item Change the x-axis of the LoggerPro plot to the previously created calculated column by clicking on the x-axis label and selecting $V$ from the list.


%\item Use the provided simulation to help answer the relevant discussion questions. \textcolor{red}{\large{{\bf (Insert name of simulation and location here, if we end up using it.)}}}

\end{enumerate}

\textbf{To be handed in to the laboratory instructor}

\section{Pre-lab}
\begin{enumerate}

\item In this lab the helium spectrum is explored by increasing the energy of electrons that collide with helium atoms and measuring the resulting collector current. Sketch a prediction of what a plot of collector current versus electron energy would look like. (Hint: see Table \ref{tab:cp1} for quantum electron excitation energies)

\item Does this apparatus explore the absorption or emission spectrum of helium? Why?

\item Describe two significant differences between the apparatus that you will use in this experiment and that used by James Franck and Gustav Hertz in 1914 in the so-called "Franck-Hertz Experiment" (excluding the obviously modern automated and digital components).

\item Calculate the kinetic energy of an electron accelerated through a 10.0 V potential difference, both in joules and in eV.

\item What is the order of magnitude for energy level transitions in He atoms that you expect? Discuss how you arrived at your answer.



\end{enumerate}

\section{Data Requirements}

\begin{enumerate}[resume]
%\item A table of values for anode voltage and collector current. Include the tube operating parameters such as the cathode current and the voltage applied to the collector ring.

\item A graph of collector current versus electron energy.

%\item On the graph of collector current versus electron energy, draw the theoretical spectral lines listed in Table \ref{tab:cp1}.


\end{enumerate}

\section{Discussion}
\begin{enumerate}[resume]
\item Discuss the shape of the peaks in your graph. Why do you not observe shape changes in collector current?
%It could be argued that if the peaks are not sharp that there must not be quanized energy levels. Is this a valid conclusion, and if not suggest some alternative reasoning to explain the shape of the peaks?

%\item The current model for the helium atom suggest that the energy of the left most peak is due to  an energy level that is 19.819 eV above the ground state, and that the bottom of the linear portion of the graph that appears at higher energies corresponds to the ionization energy of 24.586 eV. Does your data refute this claim?

\item The energy of the left most peak is theoretically the result of exciting an atom from it's ground state to an excited state that is 19.819 eV above the ground state. Similarly the base of the linear portion, that appears on the right side of the graph, theoretically is the result of the incident electrons having enough energy to ionize a helium atom, where the ionization energy of 24.586 eV. What energies do you measure for these two points? If there is is a discrepancy between the theoretical and experimental results discuss potential causes for the discrepancy.

\item The visible range of wavelengths of light is between $400$ and $800$ nm. The relationship between wavelength and energy (in electronvolts) is expressed as

\begin{equation}
E(eV) = e\dfrac{hc}{\lambda}
\label{equ:cp3}
\end{equation}


\noindent where $h=6.626\times10^{-34}\ Js$ and $e=1.602\times10^{-19}\ C$. Calculate what this range is in electronvolts and discuss why one cannot observe the spectral lines of Table \ref{tab:cp1} by using a spectroscope.

\item Could one use this apparatus to observe spectral lines of helium in the visible range? Explain your answer.

%\item Using the simulation, estimate the variance (or the FWHM) of the electron energy distribution, i.e., the variance that produces a spectrum that most closely resembles the one seen in the experiment.

%\item What would the spectrum look like if we could generate electrons of a single distinct energy? Produce a sketch.

%\item What would the spectrum look like if the electrons had an equal probability of undergoing a completely inelastic collision at every energy? Produce a sketch.

%\item Describe the significant features in your graph of collector current versus anode voltage.

\item What systematic errors are present which contribute to the overall uncertainties in the experiment?

\section{Appendix: Electronic Quantum Numbers and Atomic States}

Quantum mechanical ideas are used to describe atomic states of helium. The state of a single electron bound in an atom can be described by {\bf quantum numbers}. Note that these numbers do not apply to free electrons in the electron beam. The {\bf principal quantum number}, $n$, describes the average distance of the electron from the nucleus. Possible values for $n$ are $1,2,...$, where larger values of $n$ imply a larger average distance. The {\bf azimuthal quantum number}, $\ell$, is the orbital angular momentum of the electron. For a given $n$, the possible values of $\ell$ are integers from $0$ to $n-1$. The values of $\ell$ are often denoted by the letters; s (sharp) for $\ell=0$, p (principal) for $\ell=1$, d (diffuse) for $\ell=2$, f (fundamental) for $\ell=3$, g for $\ell=4$, h for $\ell=5$, i for $\ell=6$, k for $\ell=7$, and so forth. These names and their corresponding letters originate in early spectroscopic nomenclature. The {\bf spin}, $s$, of an electron is always $1/2$. The spin and azimuthal quantum numbers combine in two ways to give the {\bf total angular momentum quantum number}, $j$, which has values $\ell+s$ and $\ell - s$. When $\ell=0$, $j$ is $1/2$, otherwise $j$ has values $\ell+1/2$ and $\ell-1/2$.

Electrons with identical $n$, $\ell$, $j$, and $s$ still behave differently in the presence of a magnetic field. This leads to magnetic quantum numbers to further differentiate these states. The projection of l on the magnetic field direction is called, $m_{\ell}$, the {\bf magnetic orbital quantum number}. The possible values for $m_{\ell}$ are $\ell$, $\ell-1$, ...,$1$, $0$, $-1$, ..., $-\ell$. The spin can be parallel or antiparallel to the applied magnetic field. This gives the {\bf magnetic spin quantum} number $m_s$, which has the two values $1/2$ or $-1/2$. There are similar quantum restrictions for $j$ in a magnetic field. This leads to the {\bf magnetic quantum number} $m_j$ with allowable values from $-j$ to $+j$ in integer steps. The state of a bound electron is uniquely determined by a group of four quantum numbers $(n, \ell, j, m_j)$ or $(n, \ell, m_l, m_s)$. Both systems are in common use.

Notice that both sets of four quantum numbers use $n$ and $l$. This leads to the idea of electron {\bf shells} and electron {\bf subshells}. All electrons with the same principal quantum number are said to be in the same shell. All electrons in a shell with the same azimuthal quantum number are said to be in the same subshell. For example, a $4d$ electron subshell has electrons with quantum numbers $n=4$ and $\ell=2$. So $j=3/2$ or $5/2$. For $j=3/2$, $m_j$ has possible values $-3/2$, $-1/2$, $1/2$, and $3/2$. For $j=5/2$, $m_j$ has possible values $-5/2$, $-3/2$, $-1/2$, $1/2$, $3/2$, and $5/2$. Alternatively, using the other set of four quantum numbers, $n=4$ and $\ell=2$ so $m_\ell$ has values $-2$, $-1$, $0$, $1$, and $2$ and $m_s$ has the values $1/2$ or $-1/2$. These both lead to the result that a $4d$ subshell can hold 10 electrons.

In theory, the states of the entire atom, called {\bf atomic states}, depend on the states of all the electrons in the atom, their interactions with each other, and with the nucleus. However, in practice it turns out that only electrons in {\bf unfilled subshells} affect the atomic state and the other interactions can be neglected. These outer electrons are called {\bf valence electrons}. For more than one valence electron, the atomic state of the configuration is {\bf not} simply described by the individual quantum numbers of each electron, because the electrons interact with each other as well with the nucleus. Understanding the atomic states of atoms with many electrons is still an area of research. However, for atoms with two valence electrons, it is possible to roughly describe the atomic states by a scheme called {\bf LS coupling}. In this scheme, magnetic quantum numbers are ignored. This makes it possible to determine quantum numbers for the atom as a whole from simple combinations of the individual electron quantum numbers.

The total spin, $S$, of the atomic state is determined from the sums of the individual spins of the electrons. However, $S$ is always zero or more. For an even number of electrons, $S$ is an integer. For odd numbers of electrons, $S$ is a half-integer. For a single electron $S=s=1/2$. For two electrons, $S$ can be $0$ or $1$ from the calculations $1/2-1/2$ and $1/2+1/2$. Successive values of $S$ for more electrons can be found by adding and subtracting $1/2$ to each possible value of $S$ for one less number of electrons, remembering that $S$ cannot be negative. So for three electrons, $S$ is $3/2$ or $1/2$ by the calculation $0+1/2$ and $1+1/2$. For four electrons $S$ is found by $1/2\pm1/2$ and $3/2\pm1/2$ to get $0$, $1$, and $2$. For five electrons $S$ is $1/2$, $3/2$, or $5/2$.

The total orbital angular momentum, $L$, is found from the $\ell$ of each electron. For a single valence electron $L=\ell$. Otherwise, the upper value of $L$ is the sum of all the $\ell$ values of the valence electrons. The lowest value of $L$ is the absolute value of the largest possible difference between $\ell$ values that is greater than or equal to zero. If $\ell_1=1$ and $\ell_2=2$, the possible values for $L$ are $1$, $2$, and $3$. $L$ is symbolized by the upper case letters $S$ for $L=0$, $P$ for $L=1$, and so on for $D$, $F$, $G$, $H$, $I$, $K$, $L$ in the same pattern as the lower case letters for the azimuthal quantum number $\ell$.

Once $L$ and $S$ are determined, the total atomic angular momentum, $J$, has possible values from $|L-S|$ to $L+S$ in integer steps. So for $L=3$ and $S=2$, $J$ has values $1$, $2$, $3$, $4$, and $5$. For $L=3$ and $S=3/2$, $J$ has values $3/2$, $5/3$, $7/2$, and $9/2$. For $L \ge S$ there are $2S+1$ different values of $J$. For $L < S$ there are $2L+1$ different values for $J$. The value $2S+1$ ($2L+1$) is called the multiplicity of the levels. For the case of helium, $S$ is $0$ or $1$ so the multiplicity is $1$ or $3$. Levels with $2S+1=1$ are called singlet states. Similarly, $2S+1=2$ are doublets, $2S+1=3$ are triplets and so on.

In the $LS$ system, the atomic state is described by the $n$ and $\ell$ values of the valence electrons, the total orbital angular momentum $L$, the multiplicity $2S+1$, and the total angular momentum $J$. Notationally, the multiplicity is written as an anterior superscript, $L$ is designated by the appropriate letter and $J$ is a posterior subscript. For example $^2P_{3/2}$ is an atomic state with $L=1$, $S=1/2$, and $J=3/2$. This state is read as doublet $P$ three halves. Sodium has a single valence electron. In the ground state this valence electron has quantum numbers $n=3$, $\ell=0$. This implies that $L=0$, $S=1/2$, $2S+1 = 2$, and $J=1/2$. The ground state of Sodium is written as $3s^1\ ^2S_{1/2}$. Similarly, Potassium also has a single valence electron, but in a higher subshell. The ground state of Potassium is $4s^1\ ^2S_{1/2}$. The $\ell$ quantum number is frequently omitted when it is redundant, such as for a single valence electron. For example, the first excited state of Potassium would place the valence electron in the $4p$ subshell. This excited atomic level is designated as $4^2P_{1/2}$.

Helium levels can only be singlets or triplets because the possible values for $S$ are $0$ or $1$. Singlet helium has two electrons with opposite spin and is called Parahelium. Triplet helium has two electrons with equal spin and is called Orthohelium. In the ground state both electrons are in the $1s$ subshell. Their quantum numbers are $n=1$, $\ell=0$, $j=1/2$, and $m_j=\pm 1/2$. So the atomic state is $1^1S_0$.

Table \ref{tab:cp1} and Figure \ref{fig:cpGrotrian} show some of the excited states of helium. One electron moves to successively higher energies while the other one remains at the lowest possible energy. Note that singlet states really are single and that triplet states really do appear with three distinct energies, except for $L<S$. States where both electrons are above the ground state are possible but quite uncommon.

\section{Preparation}

Review the de Broglie hypothesis.

\section{Goals of the Experiment}

To show that electrons interact with a crystal in a manner consistent with waves rather than classical particles. To show that the pattern produced
by the outgoing electrons is the diffraction pattern expected from waves whose wavelength is related to the electron energy by the de Broglie 
relation and Planck's law.

\section{Theory}



Light is known to behave in dualistic ways; it behaves like a stream of particles in some experiments and like a wave in others. In 1924, Louis de 
Broglie (1892-1987) suggested that the same might be true of electrons. His electron wave hypothesis was, at the time, a radical departure from established 
concepts, but received, almost immediately, experimental verification. It was observed that a beam of electrons, striking a foil target, produced a
pattern that was just like an interference pattern for light. Hence, electrons did exhibit wave characteristics similar to those of photons. The 
relationship between electron wavelength ${\lambda}$, electron momentum p and Planck's constant h (h=4.136x10$^{-15}$eV$\cdot{s}$ or 6.626x10$^{-34}$J$\cdot{s}$) is 

\begin{equation}
\lambda=\frac{h}{p}=\frac{h}{mv}.
\label{equ:WavelengthAndMomentum}
\end{equation}
Similarly, for electron energy E and electron frequency f

\begin{equation}
E=hf.
\label{equ:EnergyAndFrequency}
\end{equation}

\draw (e1) -- (f1) -- (f2) -- (e2) -- (e3) -- (f3) -- (f4) -- (e4) -- (e5) -- (f5) -- (f6) -- (e6) -- (e7) -- (f7);
\draw (g1) -- (f1) -- (f2) -- (g2) -- (g3) -- (f3) -- (f4) -- (g4) -- (g5) -- (f5) -- (f6) -- (g6) -- (g7) -- (f7);

%draw intersecting lines
\draw (2.2,-0.2) -- (2.2,2.8) (2.8,-0.2) -- (2.8,2.8) (3.4,-0.2) -- (3.4,2.8); % vertical lines
\draw (0.1,-0.2) -- (1.6,2.8) (-0.2,0) -- (1.2,2.8) (-0.2,0.8) -- (0.8,2.8); % diagonal lines
\draw[<->] (2.2,2.7) -- node[above,sloped]{\tiny{$d_{b}$}} (2.8,2.7); % db distance
\draw[<->] (2.8,2.7) -- node[above,sloped]{\tiny{$d_{b}$}} (3.4,2.7); % db distance
\draw[<->] (0.8,2.8) -- node[above,sloped]{\tiny{$d_{a}$}} (1.12,2.64); % da distance
\draw[<->] (1.2,2.8) -- node[above,sloped]{\tiny{$d_{a}$}} (1.52,2.64); % da distance
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Carbon Crystal Structure}
\label{fig:CrystalStructure}
\end{marginfigure}




In this experiment, electrons, emerging from the cathode due to thermionic emission, are subjected to an accelerating potential V$_{a}$ and 
incident on a carbon film target. The carbon film target consists of randomly oriented sheets of carbon atoms. In each sheet, the atoms are in a 
hexagonal arrangement which provides two distinct diffraction planes, as shown in Figure \ref{fig:CrystalStructure}, with spacing d$_{a}$
= 0.123 nm  and d$_{b}$ = 0.213 nm. It is noted that the random orientation of carbon atom sheets will correspond to the rotating optical 
grating in the demonstration, hence, if waves were diffracted by this carbon film target, a circular pattern would be anticipated. As there are 
effectively two gratings involved, two separate series of maxima are anticipated in the resulting diffraction pattern.

\caption{Path Length Difference \\
A: Diffraction path length \\
B: Target screen distance \\
H: Ring radius \\
L: Luminescent screen \\
S: Diffraction plane \\
{$\theta$}: Diffraction angle
}
\label{fig:PathLength}
\end{marginfigure}
For a Fraunhoefer or far field diffraction pattern to be observable on the plane screen S in Figure \ref{fig:PathLength}, it is necessary 
that 
\begin{equation}
\lambda=dsin\theta,\ \ \ \ \ (n=1\ for\ first\ order\ maxima)
\label{equ:DiffractionCondition}
\end{equation}
which, for the triangle in Figure \ref{fig:PathLength}, can be written as
\begin{equation}
\lambda=dsin\theta=\frac{d\cdot{H}}{A}=d\left[\frac{H}{\sqrt{H^{2}+\left(B-X\right)^{2}}}\right]
\label{equ:DiffractionCondition2}
\end{equation}
where  d  is the lattice spacing constant, H  is the diffraction ring radius, A  is the diffraction path length, 
B is the target-screen distance and X is the diffraction plane to screen distance calculated using:

\begin{align}
X&=Radius-|CD|=R-\sqrt{R^2-H^2}
\label{equ:edBulbgeometry}
\end{align}

%\end{comment}

An electron accelerated by a voltage V$_{a}$ has the energy

\begin{equation}
E=eV_{a}=\frac{p^2}{2m}
\label{equ:ElectronEngergy}
\end{equation}
where e is the charge of the electron (e=1.602x10$^{-19}$C), and m is the mass of the electron (m=0.511MeV/c$^{2}$ or 9.109x10$^{-31}$ kg). In this case Equation 
\ref{equ:EnergyAndFrequency} can be written as 

\begin{equation}
\lambda=\frac{h}{p}=\frac{h}{\sqrt{2meV_{a}}}
\label{equ:WavelengthOfElectron}
\end{equation}
where  e  is the electron charge, $V_a$ is the accelerating voltage and  m  is the electron mass. Furthermore, from Equations 
\ref{equ:DiffractionCondition2} and \ref{equ:WavelengthOfElectron}, 	

\begin{equation}
H=\frac{Ah}{d\sqrt{2meV_{a}}},
\label{equ:RingRadius}
\end{equation}
Equation \ref{equ:WavelengthOfElectron} can be used to determine {$\lambda$} for an electron with energy eV$_{a}$. Equation \ref{equ:RingRadius} can be used to calculate the lattice spacing constants d$_{a}$ and d$_{b}$ for a carbon lattice.

\section{Experimental Procedure}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Somewhere in the room there will be set up a two dimensional grating. When illuminated with a He-Ne laser, this grating will produce a 
rectangular array of dots on the screen/wall. As you spin the grating, which is free to rotate, the rectangular array will merge into concentric 
circles.
\item Using the supplied calipers, measure the target-screen distance B and the radius of the bulb R. Connect the circuit shown in \ref{fig:ExperimentalSetup}. Have your
lab instructor inspect it before applying power. Set the variable resistance to 20 ${\Omega}$  and turn on the 6.3 VAC heater power supply. The heater
current should be about 200 mA. At this current, the heater element should glow red hot. If the heater glows too hot (orange-yellow) increase the 
resistance in the circuit to about 25-30 ${\Omega}$.
\item Turn on the high voltage power supply (\ul{be extremely careful with any high voltage power supplies}) and increase the accelerating voltage 
V$_{a}$ to about 5,400 V. At this voltage, the intensity of the screen pattern will be at its maximum. It may be necessary to adjust the heater
current again in order to obtain easy legibility of the scale divisions on the optical scale projector. The heater has a thermal response time of 
about 30 s. The focusing voltage should be kept constant at -25.0 V  throughout the experiment. Use the adjustable magnet to focus the electron beam at the centre of the tube face before taking any measurements.
\item Measure H using the supplied optical projectors. The illuminated scale produces a virtual image extending out into space beyond the plexiglass end of the instrument. The virtual image can be positioned in the plane of the diffraction rings for very accurate readings. Align the scale projector perpendicular to the axis to measure H. 
Determine 
%X and 
H  for 10 different values of  V$_{a}$ ranging from 5,400 to 3,000 V  in 250 V decrements.
\item Due to the small size of the diffraction tube, only two rings will be visible. Both rings have n=1, see Equation \ref{equ:DiffractionCondition}, 
and correspond to the two grating constants resulting from the hexagonal structure of the carbon film. Determine which ring corresponds to which 
grating constant (d$_{a}$ or d$_{b}$). The diffraction rings are observed on the inner spherical surface of the diffraction tube. The carbon target is
not positioned at the centre of tube curvature and, as a consequence, A must be calculated for each H 
%and X data pair 
separately.   
\end{enumerate}

\section{Error Analysis}

Uncertainties in H 
%and X 
originate from simple measurements and can be estimated individually. Uncertainties for voltage measurements, however, result
from instrument errors for both the high voltage probe and the Fluke multimeter, and must be considered jointly. See the back panel on the multimeter.
The accuracy of the high voltage probe is 1\%. Propagate uncertainties using an appropriate method.

\chapter{Radioactive Decay}

\section{Equipment}

\end{itemize}

\section{Goals of the Experiment}

The purpose of the laboratory is to introduce the student to the phenomenon of radioactive decay and introduce the idea of half-life. Students will also
acquire experience in radiation measurement techniques.

\section{Theory}

The decay of radioactive material is a process which follows statistical laws. It is impossible to predict when one particular nucleus in the material 
will suddenly decay. Predictions can only be made when large numbers of nuclei are considered, and here, only the average number of nuclei which will 
decay can be predicted. The larger the number of nuclei the more accurate will be the theoretical predictions.

It is always found that the average rate at which nuclei decay is proportional to the total number still left unchanged. This can be written as

\begin{equation}
\frac{dN}{dt}=-{\lambda}N,
\label{equ:rdAverageDecayRate}
\end{equation}

where N is the number of nondecayed nuclei still present and the proportionality constant {$\lambda$} is called the decay constant. The constant 
{$\lambda$} is a characteristic property of the kind of radioactive nuclei under consideration. The negative sign is used because N decreases with 
increasing time due to disintegration of the nuclei. If N$_{0}$ is the number of atoms at t=$0$, integration of Equation \ref{equ:rdAverageDecayRate} 
gives

\begin{equation}
N(t)=N_{0}e^{-{\lambda}t},
\label{equ:rdExpDecay}
\end{equation}
where N(t) is the number of atoms left at time t which have not undergone nuclear decay. 

At a time t=T$_{half}$, when half of the original atoms have decayed, we have

\begin{equation}
N(T_{half})=\frac{N_{0}}{2},
\label{equ:rdNAtHalfLife}
\end{equation}
and Equation \ref{equ:rdExpDecay} takes the form

\begin{equation}
T_{half}=\frac{ln2}{\lambda}\cong\frac{0.693}{\lambda}.
\label{equ:rdHalfLife}
\end{equation}

Since this is the time for one half of the atoms to undergo decay, the quantity T$_{half}$ is called the \textbf{half-life}.
\\

A Geiger counter pointed at the radioactive source gives a count rate R which is proportional to the rate of decay dN/dt. This means R=kN and 
R$_{0}$=kN$_{0}$ when t=$0$. The proportionality constant k is less than one. When both sides of Equation \ref{equ:rdExpDecay} are multiplied by k the result
becomes

\begin{equation}
R=R_{0}e^{-{\lambda}t}.
\label{equ:rdCountRate}
\end{equation}
Once ${\lambda}$ is known, the half-life can be found from Equation \ref{equ:rdHalfLife}.

\section{Apparatus}

The source of radioactive $^{116}$In used in this experiment is prepared as follows. Before the start of the lab, samples of indium metal ($^{115}$In) 
will have been made artificially radioactive by irradiating them with neutrons for several hours. This process is called "neutron activation". A metal 
foil of pure indium, 96\% of which is the isotope indium-115, is subjected to neutron bombardment from a strong neutron source. The probability of 
neutron capture by the indium is enhanced by several orders of magnitude if the activating neutrons are slowed down. This is accomplished by surrounding
the neutron source with paraffin wax so that the neutrons suffer repeated collisions with hydrogen nuclei losing some kinetic energy each time. The 
nuclear reaction for the neutron activation of indium-115 is

\begin{equation}
_{49}^{115}In+\ _{0}^{1}n\rightarrow\ _{49}^{116}In\ (unstable).
\label{equ:rdIn115ToIn116}
\end{equation}
The unstable $^{116}$In then decays by the nuclear reaction

\begin{equation}
_{49}^{116}In\rightarrow\ _{50}^{116}Sn\ +\ \beta^{-} +\ \bar{\nu}_e.
\label{equ:rdIn116ToSn116}
\end{equation}
Notice that what has happened is that a neutron in the nucleus has decayed into a proton, an electron, and a neutrino by the reaction

\begin{equation}
_{0}^{1}n\rightarrow\ _{1}^{1}p\ +\ e^{-} +\ \bar{\nu}_e.
\label{equ:rdNeutronDecay}
\end{equation}
some of the indium metal has been transmuted into tin metal by this process.
\\

Detection of the indium radiation is accomplished by means of a Geiger-Mueller counter. The Geiger tube registers a count as soon as a charged particle
enters the sensitive volume inside. It misses a count only when two charged particles enter in such close succession that the tube has not yet recovered 
from the first particle when the second one arrives. The tube is thus basically 100\% efficient in registering alpha and beta particles at low count 
rates, provided they can penetrate into the Geiger tube. For this reason the entrance window to the tube is a very thin piece of mica (it has a mass of 
only 2-3 mg/cm$^{2}$). Please do not touch the mica window as it is very easily broken. Once the power is turned on the counter will accumulate events for the
time interval preset on the front dial. A light will flash once for every 10 events detected. Once time is up the display changes to the new reading of
counts detected in that interval. To begin a new detection sequence the reset button is pressed.  Note that after the counter begins accumulating events
pressing the reset button will not start the counter over. The reset button is only active after the preset time interval has passed.

\section{Experimental Procedure}
\begin{enumerate}

\item Even when there is no activated indium present the Geiger counter will still detect events. This happens because of the presence of cosmic rays and
natural radioactivity in the building, the air, and even the Geiger tube walls. This \textbf{background} radiation must be subtracted from readings taken
with the indium present, so that the radiation intensity due solely to the indium is measured.
\item Power up the Geiger counter and let it stabilize for five minutes. Then with the detector placed exactly the same way as when measuring the indium
obtain 5 samples of background radiation. Each sample should be taken with the counter set for a 3 minute acquisition. The average of these 5 readings 
will be the background that you subtract from each indium reading. 
\item When you are ready to measure the radioactive indium take the sample tray from under the Geiger tube and bring it to the laboratory technician who 
will be present at the back of the room. This person will give you a sample of the activated indium to measure. Place the sample tray under the detector
tube in the same place it was for the background measurements.
\item Leave the count time for the Geiger counter set at 3 minutes. Start the stopwatch and reset the Geiger counter at the same time. For the next 80 -
120 minutes at 4 minute intervals  reset the Geiger counter to take a new reading. Make sure to record the counts obtained in each 4 minute interval 
before resetting the Geiger counter. The Geiger counter acquires data for 3 minutes  so there will be a spare minute to take down the reading and get 
ready to start the next cycle.

Note 1) \textbf{Do not} move the indium or the Geiger counter while measuring the decay. If the distance from the Geiger counter to the sample were to 
change the readings will alter. What you have done is change the value of k in the middle of the experiment.

Note 2) \textbf{Do not} touch the indium with your fingers or lose it on the floor. This isotope has been chosen because it is a weak, short half-life 
beta emitter with low chemical activity so it is not dangerous. But it always pays to be careful.

Note 3) If the counting rate with the fresh indium source is less than 5 times the background counting rate, consult your instructor.

\end{enumerate}

\section{Error Analysis}

The total number of detected counts, R$_{T}$, must be converted to counts per minute for analysis. This is done to eliminate differences due to different Geiger counter sampling times. The Geiger counter counts per minute, R$_{g}$, is given by

\begin{equation}
R_{g}=\frac{R_{T}}{count\ time}.
\label{equ:rdMeasuredCountsPerMinute}
\end{equation}

The actual indium counts per minute, R$_{a}$, are then found from the expression

\begin{equation}
R_{a}=R_{g}-R_{b},
\label{equ:rdCorrectedCountsPerMinute}
\end{equation}
where R$_{g}$ is the total counts per minute measured by the Geiger counter (sample plus background) and $R_{b}$ is the number of \textbf{background counts per minute}. Again, the background counts per minute are determined from the total number of background counts, R$_{Tb}$, by use of Equation \ref{equ:rdMeasuredCountsPerMinute}.


It is important to realize that it is in principle impossible to determine $R_{b}$ precisely. It is only possible to determine the average background counts per minute, $\hat{R}_b$  separately from R$_{g}$. This average background count rate approximates the true background that really occurred while the sample was being measured. The best estimate of R$_a$ then must be

\begin{equation}
R_{a}=R_{g}-\hat{R_{b}}.
\label{equ:rdFinalCountsPerMinute}
\end{equation}

We can express this in terms of the raw counts collected from the Geiger counter, $R_T$ and $R_{Tb}$.

\begin{equation}
R_a=\dfrac{R_T}{3}-\dfrac{1}{5}\sum\limits_{i=1}^5R_{b_i}=\dfrac{R_T}{3}-\dfrac{1}{15}\sum\limits_{i=1}^5R_{Tb_i}
\label{equ:rdActualCounts}
\end{equation}

By assuming independent (uncorrelated) variables, we can approximate the uncertainty in the measurement of $R_a$ by the method of partial derivatives, i.e., 

\begin{equation}
u(R_a)\approx \sqrt{\left| \dfrac{\partial R_a}{\partial R_T}\right|^2u(R_T)^2+\sum\limits_{i=1}^{5}\left| \dfrac{\partial R_a}{\partial R_{Tb_i}}\right|^2u(R_{Tb_i})^2}
\label{equ:rdActualCountsError}
\end{equation}

The assumption of non-correlation between $R_T$ and $R_{Tb}$ is a reasonable one since the background counts depend only on constants of the lab environment and not on the measurements of $R_T$. We find the following expression for the uncertainty in $R_a$,

\begin{equation}
u(R_a)=\sqrt{\dfrac{1}{9}R_T+\dfrac{1}{225}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{5}R_{Tb_i}}
\label{equ:rdErrorInRa}
\end{equation}

or in terms of the averaged background counts per minute, $\hat{R}_{Tb}$,

\begin{equation}
u(R_a)=\sqrt{\dfrac{1}{9}R_T+\dfrac{1}{15}\hat{R}_{Tb}}
\label{equ:rdActualCountsError2}
\end{equation}

\vspace{12pt}
