\section{{\bf Preperation}}

The student should review this lab write-up and the chapter in the textbook on the historical development of Quantum Mechanics, specifically those parts relating to 
Blackbody Radiation. In addition, the student should ensure that they understand how a thermocouple and thus a thermopile operates.

\section{{\bf Goals of the Experiment}}
To measure the radiation incident on a detector observing a blackbody source as a function of the distance from the source and the temperature of the source.  To determine 
the total radiant energy from the source and to examine the relationship between the temperature of a black body and the energy of the radiation emitted.

\section{{\bf Theory}}

Frequently, when an object is heated, it changes color and the color of the object is a good indicator of how hot it is. The red hot element on an electric range is
cooler than the white hot element in a light bulb but it is hotter than an automobile radiator that does not appear to be glowing at all. By the 1800's physicists 
were able to measure the radiation given off by a body and they found that it varies in a very predictable manner that depends on the temperature of the body. It was
found that the {\bf intensity}  of radiation emitted from an ideal nonreflecting surface varies as the {\bf fourth power} of its temperature. This relationship is now known as 
the {\bf Stefan-Boltzmann law}. The idealized nonreflecting surface that radiates only according to its temperature is now known as a black body. A {\bf black body} is an object
that emits electromagnetic radiation which depends {\bf only} on the temperature of the body.

The form of the law involving the fourth power greatly interested physicists. Considerable work was done to understand why the Stefan-Boltzmann law had this 
particular form. No one was able to correctly derive the behaviour of a black body until in 1900 Max Planck realized that an extra fundamental assumption was 
required. This was the idea that radiation is {\bf quantized} and can only be emitted in discrete energy packets. This insight was the beginning of quantum theory. So in a
sense, this experiment, which examines the radiation emitted by a black body, is the originator of quantum theory.

It turns out that a hot furnace with a {\bf hole} in it is a fairly good approximation of a black body. The hole in the furnace acts like a {\bf radiator} of electromagnetic 
energy. The {\bf size} of the furnace determines the amount of power coming out of the hole. The {\bf area} of hole determines the size of the black body. The {\bf temperature} of 
the furnace determines the spectrum of the emitted radiation. Note that all three of these properties of the furnace can be varied independently. A blast furnace at
a steel mill emits considerably more power than a pottery kiln even though they both could be operating at the same temperature. In either furnace, a hole in the 
side could have different sizes no matter what the temperature is.

Suppose the black body has area A and emits a total power P$_{t}$. Then the {\bf radiance} of the black body, R, is defined as the total power radiated per unit area, so that

\begin{marginfigure}%fig1
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[](0,3.5)--(5,3.5);
\draw[fill](0,3.5)ellipse(.1 and .35); %source
\draw[fill=gray](5,3.5)ellipse(.06 and .17); %detector
\draw[thick](5,3.5)arc(0:44:5); %hemisphere
\draw[thick](5,3.5)arc(0:-44:5); %hemisphere
%rays
\foreach \r in {25,50,-25,-50}{
\begin{scope}[shift={(0,3.5)},rotate=\r]
\draw[ultra thin,->](0,0)--(4.5,0);
\end{scope}
}
%labels
\node[rotate=-90]at(5.2,6){Forward Hemisphere};
\node[]at(2.8,3.8){Detector (Area a)};
\node[]at(1,0.9){Source (Area A)};
%\draw[open triangle 60-open triangle 60](0.1,3.2)--(4.9,3.2);
\draw[fill=white, triangle 60-open triangle 60](0.1,3.2)--(4.9,3.2);
\node[fill=white]at(2.5,3.2){r};
\draw[->](0.8,1.1)--(.1,3.1);
\draw[->](4.2,3.8)--(4.9,3.6);
\draw[->](5,6)--(4.7,5.5);
\end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Detector Area}
  \label{fig:bbDetector}
\end{marginfigure}


\begin{equation}
R=\frac{P_t}{A}.
\label{equ:bbRadianceFromPower}
\end{equation}

The radiance of a black body follows the Stefan-Boltzmann law. Therefore,

\begin{equation}
R=\sigma T^4,
\label{equ:bbRadianceFromTemp}
\end{equation}
where T is the temperature of the body in Kelvins and $\sigma$ is the {\bf Stefan-Boltzmann constant}.

Suppose that the radiant energy from the hole in the furnace is uniformly distributed over the entire forward hemisphere. Also, assume that the source area is small
enough that the radiant energy being emitted from it can be approximated as a point source. Then to measure the black body radiation, a {\bf detector} has to be placed 
somewhere inside this forward hemisphere. As seen in Figure \ref{fig:bbDetector}, clearly, a detector of area, a, at some distance, r, from the oven will intercept only a small 
fraction of the emitted power. The amount depends on the size of the detector aperture as well as its distance from the oven. Let the amount of power incident on 
the detector be P$_{i}$. Then if the fact that the detector is flat instead of hemispherical is also ignored, the amount of incident power is

\begin{equation}
P_i = \frac{a}{2 \pi r^2}P_t.
\label{equ:bbCorrectedIncidentPower}
\end{equation}
Taking Equations \ref{equ:bbRadianceFromPower} through \ref{equ:bbCorrectedIncidentPower} together yields the formula

\begin{equation}
R=\frac{2 \pi r^2}{aA}P_i.
\label{equ:bbRadius}
\end{equation}
%added Nov 24, 2016 to provide a complete model for testing.
Finally by equating Equations \ref{equ:bbRadianceFromTemp} and \ref{equ:bbRadius} a model

\begin{equation}
P_{i}=\frac{a A \sigma}{2 \pi r^{2}}T^{4}
\label{equ:bbModel}
\end{equation}
is obtained that, if valid, predicts the relationship between the Power output by a black body, and it's temperature.

\section{{\bf Experimental Setup}}

The apparatus is set up as shown in Figure \ref{fig:bbSetup}. A furnace is arranged at one end of an optical bench and a detector is arranged at the other end.

  \caption{Experimental Setup}
  \label{fig:bbSetup}
\end{figure}


The detector outputs a voltage that is proportional to the incident detected power. A multimeter is used to measure this voltage. The digital multimeter is a 
sensitive instrument, and susceptible to thermal voltages in its circuitry. Therefore, it is best to leave it on for about half an hour before making observations. 
This allows the instrument to reach a uniform operating temperature throughout.

The detector is called a {\bf Moll's thermopile}. It is a collection of constantan-manganin thermocouples. Each thermocouple is a metal junction in which a heat gradient 
induces a potential difference. The conversion factor that relates detector voltage to incident power is given on the apparatus. This factor takes the form of a 
number like 22 $\frac{mV}{mW}$. The entrance to the detector is shown in Figure \ref{fig:bbThermopile}. It is a polished metal funnel which has a 22{$^\circ$} angle of aperture. A hole at the pointed end 
is the actual entrance to the detector and it has a diameter of 0.01 m.

\begin{figure}%fig3
\begin{tikzpicture}
%funnel
\draw[](2,0)--(9.5,0)--(9.5,1)--(8,1)--(8,2)--(2,.3)--cycle;
\draw[shift={(0,5)}](2,0)--(9.5,0)--(9.5,-1)--(8,-1)--(8,-2)--(2,-.3)--cycle;
%detector
\draw[fill=lightgray](9.5,2.5)ellipse(.1 and 1.45);
%ray
\draw[very thick](1.3,5)--(8.5,1.8);
%demarcation lines
\draw[very thin, draw=lightgray](4.1,4.1)arc(-20:-33:1.5);
\draw[very thin, draw=lightgray](5.5,2)arc(180:200:2);
\draw[very thin, draw=lightgray](1.5,2)--(7.5,2);
\draw[very thin, draw=gray](8.5,2)--(10.5,2);
\draw[very thin, draw=lightgray](1,3)--(7.5,3);
\draw[very thin, draw=gray](8.5,3)--(10.5,3);

\draw[very thin, draw=lightgray,<->](1.2,.3)--(1.2,3);

%labels

\node[font=\small]at(5.85,1.7){$11^{\circ}$};

\node[font=\small,fill=white]at(1.9,1.1){x};

\end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Dimensions of the Moll's Thermopile}
  \label{fig:bbThermopile}
\end{figure}

The thermopile is very sensitive to infrared radiation. Unfortunately, every physical body radiates thermal energy that can be detected by the thermopile, which 
affects the results of the experiment. Once data taking commences, experimenters should avoid being anywhere where radiation from a body or clothing may be detected
by the thermopile. The apparatus should be located as far as possible from any reflecting surfaces, both in front and to the side. For protection, there is a glass 
cover on the detector. This must be removed before taking measurements.

The radiation to be examined is that which emanates from the cylindrical cavity of the oven insert, which is assumed to emit like a black body. However, surfaces of
the oven also radiate energy as the oven heats up, which would contaminate the black body results. To avoid this contamination, a cooling jacket is placed in front 
of the oven, with its aperture centered on the oven opening. Cold tap water circulating through the cold jacket keeps its' temperature at about 10 $^{\circ}$C, which should 
reduce surface radiation to insignificant levels.

The iris between the oven and the detector serves to limit the field of view of the detector, ideally just to the aperture inside the cold jacket. In reality this is
difficult to achieve, but a good approximation would be to set the iris opening to be slightly smaller than that of the detector funnel. To minimize losses in the 
detector cone due to multiple reflections (each reflection causes a slight reduction in intensity), the detector should be far enough from the source that each ray 
is reflected at most once. There is a minimum distance beyond which the detector should be placed so that multiple reflections cannot occur. This minimum distance 
can be determined from the geometry of the funnel seen in Figure \ref{fig:bbThermopile} and the diameters of the source and detector apertures.

\section{{\bf Experimental Procedure}}

\begin{enumerate}
\item Check to see if the multimeter and the oven have been warmed up prior to the lab period.  The oven should be warmed up to at least 600 {$^\circ$}C. If this has not been
done, turn on the multimeter and the Variac, increase the Variac power to 85\%, and go have a coffee! Also, make sure that cold water is circulating through the cold
jacket. It will take about 50-60 minutes for the equipment to be ready, if it is starting cold.
\item Find the calibration label on the thermopile that you will be using during this experiment and record the calibration factor in your lab notebook.
\item Using the vernier calipers, measure the openings in the cold jacket and the funnel entrance.  Set the detector at 40 cm from the source, with the iris midway 
between them, and adjust the iris opening to an appropriate size. Make sure all components are properly aligned. {\bf Do NOT} poke anything into the inner aperture of the
funnel. The thermopile detector is fragile and expensive and cannot be disturbed.
\item To test the dependence of radiative intensity on distance from the source, keep the oven temperature constant and take readings of power (voltage) for varying
detector positions, from 40 cm to 150 cm.  Keep the iris at a constant distance from the detector, about 20 cm away.  At least ten different distances should be 
measured.
\item Determine a suitable separation between the source and the detector to keep reflections in the funnel at one or less. To test the relationship of radiance and
temperature, turn the oven off and take measurements every 30 {$^\circ$}C from 600 {$^\circ$}C down to 300 {$^\circ$}C. Again, keep the iris about 20 cm from the 
detector.
\end{enumerate}

\section{{\bf Error Analysis}}

Most of the measurement errors will be standard reading errors, tempered with the judgment of the experimenter. The thermopile - voltmeter combination introduces some
significant uncertainties into the calculations. Due to fluctuations in voltmeter readings, an error of 0.01 mV is suggested for the voltmeter. The student is free to
investigate this and come up with alternatives, within reason. If the PASCO thermopile is used, the absorbing surface occupies only 1/6 of the area at the back of 
the funnel.  This suggests that about 1/6 of the radiation incident on the funnel opening will be recorded by the voltmeter, but warming of adjacent surfaces may 
increase this amount. Relative to these uncertainties, measurement errors in aperture sizes and oven temperatures should be insignificant.

\vspace{12pt}

\section{Discussion}

\begin{enumerate}[resume]
\item Discuss the plot made for Data Requirement \ref{req:bbPower-vs-Distance}. What does this graph show about the validity of the model?
\item Discuss the plot made in Data Requirement \ref{req:bbLnPower-vsLnTemp}. What is the significance of $P_{0}$? What does in represent, and why does it need to be included in the plot in Data Requirement \ref{req:bbLnPower-vsLnTemp}? What can be determined from the slope of the plot? What can be determined from the intercept of the plot?
\item Explain how your source separation graph reflects on the assumption that the black body is acting like a point source radiator. Explain whether your results 
support or refute the assumption that the black body acts like a point source.
\item How does your value for the Stefan-Boltzmann constant compare with the accepted value that you found in Prelab exercise \ref{prl:bbSBConstant}?
\item Discuss the accuracy and significance of your results, making ample reference to sources of error in the lab.
\item Discuss any {\bf one} of the following items.

\item The black body temperature of the cloudless night sky background is about 250 K. Explain what this statement means.
\item The black body temperature of the background radiation of space is about 3 K. Explain what is meant by this statement.
\item An {\bf angle} is some portion of an arc of a circle of radius 1, so that a full circle has an angle of 2$\pi$ {\bf radians}. Similarly, a {\bf solid angle} is some portion of the 
surface of a sphere of radius 1, so that a full sphere has a solid angle of 4$\pi$ {\bf steradians}. Compute the solid angle subtended by the detector in this experiment.
\end{enumerate}

\section{{\bf Preparation}}

Review the principles of the blackbody spectrum.

\section{{\bf Goals of the Experiment}}

To understand the idea of colour temperature, and how to measure it with an optical pyrometer. To get more experience with the black body spectrum. To learn the basic ideas of quantitative colour theory.

\section{{\bf Theory}}


It is known from experience that glowing coals are warmer than wood and that a rock is not as hot as molten lava. When a cold stove element is turned on to high it becomes warmer, soon begins to glow a deep red and glows a brighter and a lighter red as it continues to heat up. It turns out that there is a direct relation between the colour that an object glows and how hot it is. Blacksmiths have often applied this concept in their metal work. The metal would be left in the forge until it glowed the proper colour and then shaped. It is possible to tell that the metal just pulled from the forge is hot without even touching it. The heat {\bf radiating} from it can be felt without direct contact.
   
Every body warmer than its surroundings radiates heat in the form of {\bf electromagnetic radiation}. The total intensity of the radiation increases with the temperature of the body. The emission is spread over the entire electromagnetic spectrum. Each wavelength is emitted with a different intensity. A plot of the intensity radiated at each wavelength for the entire electromagnetic spectrum is known as an intensity spectrum. It turns out that the {\bf intensity spectrum} of a body changes with the temperature of the body. 

\begin{marginfigure}%fig1
\begin{tikzpicture}

%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(5,6);
\draw[pattern=crosshatch](0,0)--(5,0)--(5,2.3)--(4.1,2.4)--(4.1,.9)--(.9,.9)--
(.9,4.1)--(4.1,4.1)--(4.1,2.6)--(5,2.7)--(5,5)--(0,5)--cycle;
\node[font=\small]at(2.5,2.5){Blackbody cavity};
\node[font=\small]at(2.5,2.2){cross-sectional view};

\end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Blackbody Cavity}
  \label{fig:ctBlackbodyCavity}
\end{marginfigure}


An intensity spectrum of interest in the latter half of the 19th century was that of the {\bf black body}. A black body is any object that absorbs all electromagnetic radiation. Black bodies must also be in thermodynamic equilibrium with their surroundings. To accommodate this condition, black bodies are typically made in the form of a cavity which would ideally have no openings. Such a design would ensure that no radiation from the body could escape thus ensuring the condition of thermodynamic equilibrium. In practice however an enclosed cavity does not provide any way to examine the radiation inside the body. For experimental purposes a small hole is made in the cavity. Such a cavity is shown in Figure \ref{fig:ctBlackbodyCavity}. As long as this hole is small compared to the dimensions of the cavity the amount of radiation being lost will also be quite small compared to the radiation being emitted and absorbed by the cavity walls.

Physicists working with black bodies were trying to obtain a mathematical expression that described its intensity spectrum at all temperatures. In 1900 Lord Rayleigh (1842-1919) proposed a formula that worked well at long wavelengths, but broke down at shorter ones. This formula is now known as the Rayleigh-Jeans formula in honour of James Jeans (1877-1946) who discovered a correction to the formula. Shortly afterwards Max Planck (1858-1947) announced that he had derived an expression that agreed across the entire spectrum with experimental data taken at a wide range of temperatures. His expression was based on the assumption that the radiation was quantized. Planck's assumption was an early supporter  of quantum theory. A black body intensity spectrum at a given temperature is given by {\bf Planck's distribution equation} which states that


\begin{equation}
I_{B}(\lambda,T_{B}) = \frac{2\pi hc^{2} \lambda^{-5} }{e^{\frac{hc}{\lambda kT_{B}}}-1},
\label{equ:ctPlanckDistributionEquation}
\end{equation}
where  h is Planck's constant (h=6.6261x10$^{-34}$ Js), c is the speed of light (c=2.9979x10$^{8}$ $\frac{m}{s}$), k is Boltzmann's constant (k=1.3807x10$^{-23}$ $\frac{J}{K}$), $\lambda$ is the wavelength of the light, and T$_{B}$ is the temperature of the blackbody. I$_{B}$ is the intensity of radiation for a given wavelength and temperature of a blackbody. 
	
\begin{figure}%fig2
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(11,6);
\node[above right]at(.5,.5){\includegraphics[scale=.8]{/usr/local/master/labs/physics325-WI2017/Colour-Temperature/colortemp1.png}};

\node[font=\scriptsize]at(2.6,.6){$200$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(3.73,.6){$400$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(4.85,.6){$600$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(5.95,.6){$800$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(7.1,.6){$1000$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(8.2,.6){$1200$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(9.3,.6){$1400$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(5.5,0.2){Wavelength (nm)};
\node[font=\scriptsize,rotate=90]at(.5,3){Intensity (Js/m$^{3}$)};

\draw[dashed](3.3,5.5)--(3.3,.7);
\draw[dashed](5.8,5.5)--(5.8,.7);

\draw[<->](3.35,5.4)--(5.75,5.4);
\node[fill=white,font=\scriptsize]at(4.5,5.55){Visible};
\node[fill=white,font=\scriptsize]at(4.5,5.2){Spectrum};

\end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Planck's distribution equation at different temperatures}
  \label{fig:ctPlancksDistribution}
\end{figure}



Figure \ref{fig:ctPlancksDistribution} shows a plot of Equation \ref{equ:ctPlanckDistributionEquation} for three different temperatures. There are two important characteristics to note from this plot. First, the peaks of the plots shift towards shorter wavelengths with an increase in temperature, and second, the area under the curve also increases with temperature indicating that total intensity of the radiation increases with temperature. The two vertical lines in Figure \ref{fig:ctBlackbodyCavity} indicate the upper and lower limits of the {\bf visible spectrum}. It can be seen that part of the radiation of a hot black body lies in the visible range. This explains why some hot bodies glow.

The intensity spectrum which is emitted by a given body is dependent on the temperature of that body. Cooler bodies (below $\sim$700 K) radiate mostly in the infrared range of the spectrum and therefore are not visible to the human eye. However, when bodies are heated above this, the intensity radiated at wavelengths in the visible region is large enough that the body begins to glow a deep red. As the body is heated further it becomes brighter, and the colour changes to yellow, to white, and eventually to blue (at $\sim$20000 K). The radiated spectrum and the visible colour are both fingerprints of the temperature.

{\bf Colour temperature} is the colour that a body glows at a given temperature. The {\bf colour temperature method} determines the unknown temperature of a glowing body by matching its intensity spectrum, or rather its colour, with the spectrum of a glowing black body of known temperature. The temperature obtained is known as its {\bf black body temperature}. Figure \ref{fig:ctPlancksDistribution} implies that when the temperature of a body increases the intensity radiated at each wavelength also increases. What this indicates is that the intensity radiated at any given wavelength is also a fingerprint of the temperature of the body. So, if the intensity at one wavelength of a blackbody's intensity spectrum is the same as the intensity of the same wavelength of a second blackbody's intensity spectrum then it can be assumed that both intensity spectra are also the same. If the intensity spectra of both bodies are the same then they are also at the same temperature.

  \caption{An Optical Pyrometer}
  \label{fig:ctPyrometer}
\end{figure}


The instrument used to compare the intensities at a given wavelength of two glowing bodies is known as a {\bf pyrometer} and is shown in Figure \ref{fig:ctPyrometer}. Inside the pyrometer is a {\bf reference wire} with an adjustable current. By adjusting the current through the wire, the temperature can be altered. The pyrometer is calibrated so that the black body temperature of the reference wire is known. A microscope located at one end of the pyrometer is used to focus the pyrometer on a sample body of unknown temperature and the light from the glowing sample is superimposed  over the reference wire. The light from the superimposed bodies is then sent through a filter which allows only a small bandwidth of light, centred around a wavelength of 653 nm, to pass thorough. The current through the reference wire, and therefore its temperature, is adjusted until the intensities radiated at this wavelength by both bodies are the same. When this state is reached, the reference wire "disappears" into the sample body. They now appear to be the same colour and it can be assumed that the two bodies have the same intensity spectrum, and therefore the same temperature.

A common example of a glowing body is the light bulb. In this experiment the colour temperature of a tungsten filament from a quartz halogen lamp will be examined. Light bulb filaments are made of tungsten because of its extremely high melting point. The problem with tungsten is that at high temperatures it will oxidize in the presence of air forming toxic tungsten oxide. To avoid this problem the tungsten is encased in quartz envelope which has had the air replaced with a small amount of a halogen, usually iodine or bromine. Tungsten evaporates at high temperatures, which causes the filament to weaken and eventually break. Vapour from the tungsten also eventually comes into contact with the cooler quartz and condenses, forming a coating which obstructs the light from the filament. To solve these problems the quartz envelope is filled with a halogen gas. The vapour reacts with the gas at a much lower temperature than the melting point of tungsten. Tungsten vapour would much rather form with the gas than condense on the quartz, therefore reducing the tungsten coating on the quartz. When the gas which has formed with tungsten approaches the filament it becomes hotter, and the tungsten returns to the filament. This reaction is most likely to occur at the hotter parts of the filament which are also the thinnest. The filament is therefore self-repairing which increases the life of the bulb. 

The quartz however causes a small percentage of the electromagnetic radiation to be reflected back. A small correction must be made to account for this loss in intensity. This correction is obtained using Fresnel's equation for incident light that is perpendicular to the normal of the surface. Fresnel's equations for the first interface states that 

\begin{equation}
\frac{I_{r}}{I_{i}} = \left(\frac{n-n^{\prime}}{n+n^{\prime}}\right)^{2},
\label{equ:ctIntensityRatio}
\end{equation}
where I$_{r}$ is the intensity of the light that is reflected at the first interface, I$_{i}$ is the intensity of the incident light on this interface, n is the index of reflection for quartz (n=1.54), and n$^{\prime}$ is the index of refraction for a vacuum (n$^{\prime}$=1). Note that the index of refraction of a gas is often approximated as the index of refraction of a vacuum. From the conservation of energy, the total intensity of light into the first interface must equal the total intensity out. As a result

\begin{marginfigure}%fig4
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(5,6);

\draw[](0,1.5)rectangle(5,2.5);
\draw[rounded corners=3](0,4.5)rectangle(5,4.7);
\draw[decorate,decoration={coil,segment length=3.3pt,amplitude=2.3}](0,4.6)--(5,4.6);
\draw[->,line width=2](1.5,4.5)--(1.5,2.5);
\draw[->,line width=1.3](2,2.5)--(2,3.8);
\draw[->,line width=1.3](1.5,2.5)--(1.5,1.5);
\draw[->,line width=.6](2,1.5)--(2,2.5);
\draw[->,line width=.6](1.5,1.5)--(1.5,.5);
\node[font=\small]at(2.5,5){Tungsten filament};
\node[font=\small]at(3.8,2.7){First interface};
\node[font=\small]at(3.8,1.7){Second interface};
\node[font=\small]at(3.5,.5){Quartz envelope};
\draw[very thin,->](2.4,.8)--(2.3,1.7);
\node[font=\small]at(1.3,3.5){I$_i$};
\node[font=\small]at(2.2,3.1){I$_r$};
\node[font=\small]at(2.2,2){I$_{r}{'}$};
\node[font=\small]at(1.3,1){I$_t{'}$};
\node[font=\small]at(.9,2){I$_t=$I$_i{'}$};

\end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Determining the fraction of light intensity that is passed through a quarts bulb}
  \label{fig:ctQuartzBulb}
\end{marginfigure}

\begin{equation}
I_{i} = I_{r} + I_{t}
\label{equ:ctIncidentIntensity}
\end{equation}
where I$_{t}$ is the intensity of light transmitted through the interface. 

The intensity of the light transmitted through the first interface is therefore

\begin{equation}
I_{t} = I_{i}\left[1-\left(\frac{n-n^{\prime}}{n+n^{\prime}}\right)^{2}\right]=I_{i}^{\prime}.
\label{equ:ctTransmittedIntensity}
\end{equation}
The intensity of light transmitted through the first interface is the intensity of light that is incident on the second interface. Using the same reasoning as above, the intensity transmitted through the second surface I$_{t}^{\prime}$, is   

\begin{equation}
I_{t}^{\prime} = I_{i}^{\prime}\left[1-\left(\frac{n-n^{\prime}}{n+n^{\prime}}\right)^{2}\right]=I_{i}\left[1-\left(\frac{n-n^{\prime}}{n+n^{\prime}}\right)^{2}\right]^{2}.
\label{equ:ctTransmittedIntensity2}
\end{equation}
For simplicity let 

\begin{equation}
\delta = \left[1-\left(\frac{n-n^{\prime}}{n+n^{\prime}}\right)^{2}\right]^{2},
\label{equ:ctFresnelCorrection}
\end{equation}
be the {\bf Fresnel correction}. Then the actual initial intensity of the light radiated by the wire, I$_{i}$, is,

\begin{equation}
I_{i}=\frac{I_{t}^{\prime}}{\delta}.
\label{equ:ctFresnelCorrection2}
\end{equation}							
With the Fresnel correction included, Equation \ref{equ:ctPlanckDistributionEquation} is written as 

\begin{equation}
I_{B}(\lambda,T_{B}) = \frac{2\pi hc^{2} \lambda^{-5}\delta^{-1}}{e^{\frac{hc}{\lambda kT_{B}}}-1}.
\label{equ:ctPlanckDistributionEquation2}
\end{equation}

	Equation \ref{equ:ctPlanckDistributionEquation2} applies to black bodies. However many glowing objects, including tungsten filaments, are not black bodies but are rather {\bf gray bodies}. A gray body is any body that reflects some electromagnetic radiation. Gray bodies have a emission spectrum that is dependent not only on temperature, but also on how close the body is to being a black body. It turns out that each body has an intrinsic temperature dependent proportionality function, known as its {\bf emissivity}. Emissivity is unitless and has values that lie between 0 and 1. A perfect black body has an emissivity of 1. There are two different types of emissivity that are used in this experiment. There is one that is used when dealing with the entire intensity spectrum of a body, known as the {\bf total emissivity}, $\varepsilon_{T}$, and a second that is used when dealing with only one wavelength, known as the {\bf spectral emissivity}, $\varepsilon_{S}$. It is important to note that spectral emissivity is valid only for a specified wavelength and that each wavelength has a different spectral emissivity. In this experiment the spectral emissivity at 650 nm is used because this is the wavelength of light for which the pyrometer is sensitized. In the case of tungsten the spectral emissivity is given by

\begin{equation}
\resizebox{.9\hsize}{!}{$\varepsilon_{S} (T_{B} , \lambda = 650 nm) = -3.8798x10^{-10}T_{B}^{2} - 2.3877x10^{-5}T_{B}+4.8189x10^{-1}$},
\label{equ:ctSpectralEmissivity}
\end{equation}
where $\varepsilon_{S}$ is the spectral emissivity as a function of the black body temperature and wavelength.

	The black body intensity spectrum of a gray body is obtained by multiplying the intensity spectrum of a gray body by the emissivity. The intensity spectrum of a gray body is described by the equation

\begin{equation}
I_{G}(\lambda,T_{G}) = \frac{2\pi hc^{2} \lambda^{-5} \varepsilon_{S}}{e^{\frac{hc}{\lambda kT_{G}}}-1},
\label{equ:ctGreyBody}
\end{equation}
where I$_{G}$ is the intensity spectrum of a gray body with a temperature T$_{G}$.

Since the pyrometer measures intensities, the gray body's temperature can be obtained by equating Equations \ref{equ:ctPlanckDistributionEquation2} and \ref{equ:ctGreyBody} to get
				
\begin{equation}
\frac{2\pi hc^{2} \lambda^{-5} \varepsilon_{S}}{e^{\frac{hc}{\lambda kT_{G}}}-1} = \frac{2\pi hc^{2} \lambda^{-5}\delta^{-1}}{e^{\frac{hc}{\lambda kT_{B}}}-1}.
\label{equ:ctGreyBody2}
\end{equation}
Then solving Equation \ref{equ:ctGreyBody2} for T$_{G}$, yields the formula			

\begin{equation}
T_{G}=\frac{hc}{\lambda k \ln{ \left[ \varepsilon_{S} \delta \left( e^{\frac{hc}{\lambda k T_{B}}} - 1\right) +1 \right]}}
\label{equ:ctGreyBody3}
\end{equation}
So by knowing the spectral emissivity for the wavelength which is passed by the pyrometer, the Fresnel correction, and the black body temperature, the gray body temperature can be found.

	A second way of determining the gray body temperature of a wire is by applying the law of conservation of energy. The wire is in a vacuum and energy put into the wire can only dissipate through electromagnetic radiation. As a result power in, P$_{in}$, equals power out, P$_{out}$.

	The power radiated by the wire is proportional to the radiance of the wire and the surface area of a wire. By assuming that the wire is cylindrical the output power should be

\begin{equation}
P_{out} = I_{Total} \pi d L,
\label{equ:ctPowerOut}
\end{equation}
where  I$_{Total}$ is the total radiated intensity, L is the length of the wire, and d is the diameter of the wire. The tungsten filament in the quartz halogen lamp used in this experiment has a diameter of 7x10$^{-5}$ m $\pm$ 5x10$^{-6}$ m and a length of 0.63 m $\pm$ 0.01 m. The total intensity can be determined by adding up the intensity radiated at each wavelength. This is the same as integrating Equation \ref{equ:ctPlanckDistributionEquation2} over all wavelengths. By doing this it can be shown that 

\begin{equation}
I_{Total} = \sigma T_{B}^{4},
\label{equ:ctIntensityTotal}
\end{equation}
which is known as the {\bf Stefan-Boltzmann law}, and $\sigma$ is the {\bf Stefan-Boltzmann constant}. By applying Equation \ref{equ:ctGreyBody} to Equation \ref{equ:ctIntensityTotal} the Stefan-Boltzmann law can be written as

\begin{equation}
I_{Total} = \varepsilon_{{\scriptscriptstyle T}} \sigma T_{G}^{4},
\label{equ:ctIntensityTotal2}
\end{equation}
where the total emissivity is used because the expression is dealing with the total intensity radiated. The total emissivity for tungsten is given by

\begin{equation}
\varepsilon_{T}(T_{G}) = -3.4481x10^{-8}T_{{\scriptscriptstyle G}}^{2} + 2.5000x10^{-4}T_{G}-1.0484x10^{-1},
\label{equ:ctTotalEmissivity}
\end{equation}
where $\varepsilon_{T}$ is the total emissivity as a function of the gray body temperature. By substituting Equation \ref{equ:ctIntensityTotal2} into Equation \ref{equ:ctPowerOut} the power out becomes

\begin{equation}
P_{out} = \varepsilon_{{\scriptscriptstyle T}} \sigma T_{G}^{4} \pi d L.
\label{equ:ctPowerOut2}
\end{equation}
	
	The power input into the wire is

\begin{equation}
P_{in} = i^{2}R,
\label{equ:ctPowerOut3}
\end{equation}
where i is the current flowing through the wire, and R is the resistance of the wire. It is known that the resistance of a wire is proportional to its length, and inversely proportional to its cross-sectional area. The resistance of a wire also increases with an increase in temperature. The wire resistance can be written as

\begin{equation}
R = \frac{\rho L}{A},
\label{equ:ctResistance}
\end{equation}
where A is the cross-sectional area of the filament and $\rho$ = $\rho$(T$_{G}$) is the {\bf resistivity} of the wire. Resistivity is a function of the gray body temperature and is given by
 
\begin{equation}
\rho(T_{G}) = 1.7993x10^{-14}T_{G}^{2} + 2.6359x10^{-10}T_{G}-3.2316x10^{-8},
\label{equ:ctResistivity}
\end{equation}
where $\rho$ has units of $\Omega$m. By substituting Equation \ref{equ:ctResistance} into Equation \ref{equ:ctPowerOut3} and assuming that the cross-section of the wire is a circle, of diameter d, P$_{in}$ becomes 

\begin{equation}
P_{in} = \frac{4i^{2} \rho L}{\pi d^{2}}.
\label{equ:ctPowerIn}
\end{equation}
Equating the power into the wire with power out of the wire yields

\begin{equation}
\frac{4i^{2} L}{\pi d^{2}} = \varepsilon_{{\scriptscriptstyle T}} \sigma T_{G}^{4} \pi d L.
\label{equ:ctPowerIn2}
\end{equation}
Finally by rearranging Equation \ref{equ:ctPowerIn2}, the expression

\begin{equation}
\frac{i^{2}}{d^{3}} = \frac{\varepsilon_{{\scriptscriptstyle T}} \sigma \pi^{2} T_{G}^{4}}{4 \rho},
\label{equ:ctPowerIn3}
\end{equation}
is obtained. Equation \ref{equ:ctPowerIn3} suggests that the wire temperature can be deduced from the wire diameter and the current flowing through it. If a plot of $\frac{i^{2}}{d^{3}}$ versus $\frac{\varepsilon_{T} \pi^{2} T_{G}^{4}}{4 \rho}$ produces a graph with a slope that is within error of the Stefan-Boltzmann constant then it can be concluded that both methods of measuring the temperature of the wire are valid. 

	Colour temperature relates the colour of an object to its temperature. It seems reasonable to expect that it is possible to reverse the procedure and calculate the colour of an object given its temperature. In order to calculate the colour of an object, colours must be represented numerically. The study of colour and the eye has revealed how colours, or rather colours as the eye perceives them, can be reproduced. The human eye uses what is known as {\bf cones} to see colours. There are three types of cones in the eye. One that is sensitive to spectral light of short wavelengths, one that is sensitive to medium wavelengths, and one that is sensitive to longer wavelengths. When light reaches a cone each wave will stimulate the cones according to its wavelength. The closer the wavelength is to a cone's maximum sensitivity, the greater stimulation it will cause. A signal is then sent to the brain, where the brain compares the intensities of the signals from the three different types of cones to determine what colour is being seen. Two colours are perceived to be the same colour if they have the same effect on the eye. This means that the colours do not need to be comprised of the exact same wavelengths with the exact same intensity, but rather the amount that each type of cone is stimulated by the two sources must be the same. 

	David Wright (1906-1997) and John Guild tested a large number of subjects to examine how humans perceive colours in terms of three primary colour functions. The results were used to create three plots known as {\bf color matching functions}. The CIE (Commission Internationale de L'Eclariage) {\bf standard observer} colour matching functions are denoted by x$_{CIE}(\lambda)$, y$_{CIE}(\lambda)$, and z$_{CIE}(\lambda)$, and are shown in Figure \ref{fig:ctColorMatchingFunctions}. These functions describe how much effect each wavelength has on the perception of colour by humans.

\begin{figure}%fig5
\includegraphics{/usr/local/master/labs/physics325-WI2017/Colour-Temperature/colortempcie.png}
  \caption{Color matching functions}
  \label{fig:ctColorMatchingFunctions}
\end{figure}



	The primary colour intensities needed to reproduce a colour requires the knowledge of the colour's actual intensity spectrum, which can be determined experimentally. One example of a such a function is Planck's distribution  equation for a black body at a given temperature. Let I($\lambda$) be the spectrum of a colourful object. Using the colour matching functions, the human perceived colour of the spectrum I($\lambda$) is given by three {\bf tristimulus} values X, Y, and Z given by the expressions		

\begin{equation}
X=\int\limits_{\lambda = 0}^{\lambda = \infty}I(\lambda)x_{CIE}(\lambda) d \lambda,
\label{equ:ctCIE}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}
Y=\int\limits_{\lambda = 0}^{\lambda = \infty}I(\lambda)y_{CIE}(\lambda) d \lambda,
\label{equ:ctCIE2}
\end{equation}
and

\begin{equation}
Z=\int\limits_{\lambda = 0}^{\lambda = \infty}I(\lambda)z_{CIE}(\lambda) d \lambda,
\label{equ:ctCIE3}
\end{equation}
In practice these integrals are often approximated as summations of the form
				
\begin{equation}
X \approx \sum\limits_{\lambda = 380\ nm}^{\lambda = 780\ nm}I(\lambda)x_{CIE}(\lambda) \Delta \lambda,
\label{equ:ctCIE4}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}
Y \approx \sum\limits_{\lambda = 380\ nm}^{\lambda = 780\ nm}I(\lambda)y_{CIE}(\lambda) \Delta \lambda,
\label{equ:ctCIE5}
\end{equation}
and

\begin{equation}
Z \approx \sum\limits_{\lambda = 380\ nm}^{\lambda = 780\ nm}I(\lambda)z_{CIE}(\lambda) \Delta \lambda,
\label{equ:ctCIE6}
\end{equation}
where $\Delta \lambda$ is the interval at which the colour matching functions were determined, usually 1 nm or 5 nm. Using this method, the colour of any perceived spectrum can be calculated as the triplet XYZ. The full range of colours visible to the average human eye lies inside the three dimensional XYZ {\bf color space}.

	To make the XYZ colour space easier to visualize, the colour information is separated from the brightness information. This is done by normalizing XYZ using the expressions

\begin{equation}
x = \frac{X}{X+Y+Z}\ ,
\label{equ:ctCIE7}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}
y = \frac{Y}{X+Y+Z}\ ,
\label{equ:ctCIE8}
\end{equation}
and

\begin{equation}
z = \frac{Z}{X+Y+Z}\ .
\label{equ:ctCIE9}
\end{equation}
Note that the by adding Equations \ref{equ:ctCIE7}, \ref{equ:ctCIE8}, and \ref{equ:ctCIE9} together that it can be shown that 

\begin{equation}
z = 1-x-y,
\label{equ:ctZ}
\end{equation}
Equation \ref{equ:ctCIE9} and z can therefore be discarded. This leaves behind the xy colour space which is a representation of all perceived colours independent of their brightness. Figure \ref{fig:ctChromaticityDiagram} is a picture of all the colours in the xy plane, and is known as a {\bf chromaticity diagram}. Colours corresponding to the visually perceived colour of a black body must also appear on the chromaticity diagram. Each different temperature corresponds to a different colour. A plot of blackbody colour versus blackbody temperature appears on the chromaticity diagram as a curve called the {\bf Planckian locus}. 

\begin{figure}%fig6
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(11,12);

\node[above right]at(0,0){\includegraphics[scale=.24]{/usr/local/master/labs/physics325-WI2017/Colour-Temperature/chromaticityDiagram.png}};
\node[]at(4.6,8.2){Green/yellow};
\node[]at(2.3,6.9){Green/blue};
\node[]at(3.1,4.8){White};
\draw[-open triangle 45](3.7,4.8)--(4.3,4.7);
\node[]at(5.5,7.4){Planckian locus};
\draw[-open triangle 45](5.4,7.2)--(5.4,5.7);
\node[]at(9,7.9){Visible spectrum};
\node[]at(9,7.5){(nm)};
\node[]at(6.7,4.6){Purple/red};
\node[rotate=25]at(6.3,2.9){Line of purple};
\node[]at(3.5,2.7){Blue/purple};

\end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Chromaticity diagram}
  \label{fig:ctChromaticityDiagram}
\end{figure}

	If an expression for the Planckian locus were known, then it would be possible to calculate the perceived colour of a blackbody with a given temperature. Although analytical, formulae for the Planckian locus are not possible, empirical formulae are commonly used instead. The empirical formulae are obtained by fitting functions to the Planckian locus in the xy chromaticity space. The x chromaticity can be expressed as

\begin{equation}
\resizebox{.9\hsize}{!}{$\frac{1}{x} = -0.053895 \ln({T_{B})}^{4} + 1.5488 \ln({T_{B}})^{3} - 16.225 \ln({T_{B}})^{2} + 73.697 \ln({T_{B}}) - 121.12$},
\label{equ:ctInverseX}
\end{equation}
for 1 000 K $\leq$ T$_{B}$ $\leq$ 10 000 K and

\begin{equation}
\resizebox{.9\hsize}{!}{$\frac{1}{x} = -0.014663 \ln({T_{B})}^{4} + 0.65589 \ln({T_{B}})^{3} - 11.047 \ln({T_{B}})^{2} + 83.107 \ln({T_{B}}) - 231.71$},
\label{equ:ctInverseX2}
\end{equation}
for 10 000 K $\leq$ T$_{B}$ $\leq$ 50 000 K. Similarly, the y chromaticity can be expressed as 

\begin{equation}
\resizebox{.9\hsize}{!}{$\frac{1}{y} = -0.081937 \ln({T_{B})}^{4} + 2.4442 \ln({T_{B}})^{3} - 26.538 \ln({T_{B}})^{2} + 123.55 \ln({T_{B}}) - 203.31$},
\label{equ:ctInverseY}
\end{equation}
for 1 000 K $\leq$ T$_{B}$ $\leq$ 10 000 K and

\begin{equation}
\resizebox{.9\hsize}{!}{$\frac{1}{y} = 0.0031207 \ln({T_{B})}^{4} - 0.072 \ln({T_{B}})^{3} + 0.0867 \ln({T_{B}})^{2} + 7.7666 \ln({T_{B}}) - 41.626$},
\label{equ:ctInverseY2}
\end{equation}
for 10 000 K $\leq$ T$_{B}$ $\leq$ 50 000 K. \\

	Further transformations are required to convert perceived colours in xy space into colours that can be displayed on a video screen or computer monitor. The standard colour space used in computers and video is called {\bf sRGB}, which denotes the standard Red, Green, Blue phosphors used to display colours on a screen. To display the colour of a black body on a screen it is therefore necessary to convert an xy colour on the Planckian locus into the corresponding colour in sRGB space. The procedure for this is as follows.

	Equation \ref{equ:ctZ} is used to recover z from x and y. Then rgb can be found using the linear transformation

\begin{equation}
\begin{bmatrix} r \\ g \\ b \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3.242979 & -1.538336 & -0.498920 \\ -0.968998 & 1.875492 & 0.041545 \\ 0.055668 & -0.204117 & 1.057698 \end{bmatrix}.
\label{equ:ctRGMMatrix}
\end{equation}
If any of the r, g, and b values are less than 0 then that particular colour cannot be displayed on a standard RGB monitor. This is called an {\bf out of gamut} colour. 

On other hand, if the r, g, and b can be displayed, then they are normalized to obtain the sRGB value. Let m be the largest of r, g, and b. Then sRGB is given by

\begin{equation}
R = \frac{r}{m}, \ \ \ \ \ G = \frac{g}{m}, \ \ \ \ \ B = \frac{b}{m}.
\label{equ:ctRGMNormalized}
\end{equation}
Lastly, many computer applications specify sRGB values as integers. Typically, computers can display 256$^{3}$ different colours. This sRGB discrete colour space is given by multiplying R, G, and B by 255 and then taking only the integer parts.

\end{figure}


	Figure \ref{fig:ctExperimentalSetup} shows the experimental set up that will be used to measure the temperature of a quartz halogen lamp filament using the colour temperature method, and eventually determine the sRGB values for some colour temperatures. 

	The {\bf AC current probe} measures the current flowing through a wire by taking advantage of the fact that a current creates a magnetic field that is proportional to the magnitude of the current. The magnetic field induces a current in the probe which is measured by the ammeter. The cord for the quartz halogen lamp contains two wires. The two wires carry current in opposite directions causing the magnetic fields to cancel out. To avoid this an {\bf AC line separator} is used to separate the two wires so that the probe can be clamped around only one wire.  

\section{{\bf Experimental Procedure}}

\begin{enumerate}
\item Attach the long threaded mounting rod to the bottom of the pyrometer and secure the rod in a bench clamp so that the eyepiece of the pyrometer is close to the end of the table, and can easily be looked into by someone seated at the end of the table. Secure the quartz halogen flood lamp in the second bench clamp. Place the second bench clamp about 35 cm away from the pyrometer bench clamp. 
\item Plug the halogen flood lamp into the wire separator and plug the separator into the variac. Clip the AC transformer into the loop of the separator that reads x1 and plug the current probe connector into the multimeter mA and common plugs. Note that the current probe connector has a small tab with the label GND. This plug should be inserted into the common plug. Also note that the current read off of the multimeter is 10$^{3}$ times smaller than the actual current. For example, when using the AC current probe, a reading of 0.375 mA corresponds to an actual current of 375 mA.   
\item Turn on the quartz halogen lamp, and set the voltage to approximately 25 volts. Ensure that the range selector on the pyrometer is set to 'L'. Look through the pyrometer and adjust its position until a bright light can be seen. Adjust the reference focus until the wire comes into sharp focus, and adjust the source focus until the tungsten filament comes into sharp focus. Press the reference wire switch and adjust the reference wire current until the wire inside the pyrometer can be seen to glow red. Re-adjust the position of the pyrometer until the wire is superimposed on the filament in the lamp. 
\item Adjust the reference wire current until the wire and the filament appear to be the same brightness. When the two bodies are of the same brightness the reference wire should appear to merge into the filament at all points where the two bodies intercept. Practice taking measurements at this voltage until results become consistent. Note that pyrometer readings should be taken from the scale that matches that of the range selector on the end of the pyrometer (L, H, xH) and that the temperature the pyrometer measures temperatures is in $^{\circ}$C and must be converted to K.
\item The relationship between current and graybody temperature of tungsten as predicted by Equation \ref{equ:ctPowerIn3} can be tested. Reduce the voltage to 15 volts and begin to make temperature measurements of the filament at increments of 5-10 volts from 15-140 volts. Record the temperature, current, voltage (as read off of the variac), and range. If when making a measurement the reference wire is past the maximum calibrated temperature simply, switch the range selector to a higher range. Refocus the source focus and continue making measurements. 
\item The connection between colour and temperature would suggest that if a colour, corresponding to a specific temperature, is reproduced and then looked at with the pyrometer, that the temperature measured by the pyrometer should agree with the temperature used to calculate that colour. Enter the R, G, and B values calculated in the pre-lab into a painting program that can create custom colours. Make a large rectangle of this colour on a computer monitor, look at it with the pyrometer and make a colour temperature measurement of this colour. 
\end{enumerate}

\section{{\bf Error Analysis}}

The error in the pyrometer changes depending of the range in which it is operating. When in the 'L' range take the error to be 4$^\circ C$, when in 'H' or in 'xH' take it to be 8$^\circ C$. Take the error in the current as listed on the bottom of the multimeter, and the variac as exact. Assume the equations for emissivity and resistivity given as exact. Use standard error propagation methods to determine the error in the corrected temperature and the Stefan-Boltzmann constant. Sources of error not taken into account include differences in diameter along the wire, the bandwidth of the 653 nm colour filter, and the light reflected by the back of the lamp.

\vspace{12pt}

\begin{equation}
\int\limits_{0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{3}}{e^{x}-1}dx=\frac{\pi^{4}}{15}.
\label{equ:ctHint}

\section{{\bf Data Requirements}}
\begin{enumerate}[resume]
\item A table of data containing filament voltage, current, and black body temperature together with appropriate errors.
\item Calculate the $\varepsilon_{S}$, T$_{G}$, $\varepsilon_{T}$, and $\rho$ (using Equation \ref{equ:ctResistivity}) of the filament together with appropriate errors, at each voltage.
\item Make a plot of $\frac{i^{2}}{d^{3}}$ versus $\frac{\varepsilon_{T} \pi^{2} T_{G}^{4}}{4 \rho}$ to obtain a value with error for the Stefan-Boltzmann constant. 
\item Calculate the resistance, with error, of the wire at each voltage by two different methods. One method is to use Equation \ref{equ:ctResistance}. The other method is to use Ohm's law, V=iR. 
\item Plot the two resistances against each other. If they are the same then it would be expected that a line of best fit would have a slope of one and an intercept of zero.
\item Results from the colour temperature measurement of the computer monitor.
\item Calculate the CIE x,y colour space coordinates for each temperature using Equations \ref{equ:ctInverseX} and \ref{equ:ctInverseY}. Note that Equations \ref{equ:ctInverseX} and \ref{equ:ctInverseY} are functions of black body temperatures only therefore use the black body temperatures as measured. The effect of the quartz envelope is negligible for this calculation.
\end{enumerate}

\section{Discussion}
\begin{enumerate}[resume]
\item Discuss the plot of $\frac{i^{2}}{d^{3}}$ versus $\frac{\varepsilon_{T} \pi^{2} T_{G}^{4}}{4 \rho}$ and explain its significance. 
\item Compare the measured values of the Stefan-Boltzmann constant with the accepted value.
\item Discuss the results of the resistance plot and explain its significance.
\item When looking at the coloured rectangle on the computer screen did the pyrometer measure the colour as the temperature used to calculate the coordinate. Discuss whether or not these results are reasonable.
\item Discuss which of the colour temperatures, measured for the lamp, are out of gamut and cannot be duplicated on a computer monitor
\item Considering the melting point of tungsten are the measured temperatures of the filament reasonable.
\item Standard daylight has a colour temperature of about 6500 K. Compare this with the surface temperature of the sun, and explain the discrepancy if there is one.
\item According to the CIE chromaticity diagram is it possible for a blackbody to appear to be green or purple?  Why or why not.
\end{enumerate}

\chapter{Compton Scattering}

\section{Equipment}

\begin{marginfigure}[+1.5in]
\includegraphics{/usr/local/master/labs/physics325-WI2017/Compton-Scattering/cs-setup.jpg}
\caption{Equipment setup}
\label{CSsetup}
\end{marginfigure}

\begin{minipage}{0.5\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item Compton scattering apparatus with 35 mCi caesium-137 source and removable detector
\item Pulse Height Analyzer (PHA) with printer
\item 1.0 mCi cobalt-57 gamma source
\item 1.0 mCi barium-133 gamma source
\end{itemize}
\end{minipage}
\begin{minipage}{0.5\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item 1.0 mCi caesium-137 gamma source
\item assortment of scattering rods
\item detector stand with source shelves and lead and aluminum shields
\item oscilloscope
\end{itemize}

\section{Preparation}
\begin{itemize}
\item Review the ideas of classical and relativistic momentum and energy. Study the theory of Compton scattering.
\item ``Radiation Safety Training'' required before conducting this experiment. 
\end{itemize}
\section{Goals of the Experiment}

	To investigate the interaction between gamma ray photons and electrons in matter. To get experience with nuclear particle detectors. To observe and explore gamma ray spectroscopy.

\section{Theory}

	The fundamental ability to see things is based on the interaction of light with matter. One of the common ways that light interacts with matter is called \textbf{scattering}. Scattering is the name given to processes that alter the direction in which light is travelling. Depending upon the type of scattering, other properties of the light such as the frequency can also be changed. It is common knowledge that visibility is much poorer in the fog than when it is clear. One reason this happens is because the water droplets making up the fog scatter the light so that the direction is randomized. The original scene is first hazy and then obscured completely as the fog becomes denser. Rainbows, the blue sky, and the red sky at sunset all arise because of light scattering. Dozens of different kinds of light scattering modes are now known.
 
	Gamma radiation is a high energy form of light, so it follows that it too can be scattered. In fact, at high energies new types of scattering appear that are not observable at lower energies. One such new type of scattering is known as \textbf{Compton scattering}. Here, instead of scattering off of water droplets, the gamma rays scatter from the outer valence electrons in the atoms themselves. The phenomenon of Compton scattering helped solidify the theory that light is quantized and emitted as small massless packets called \textbf{photons}.

	In the early part of the twentieth century, it was well established that light is an electromagnetic wave. However, evidence was beginning to mount that suggested that light also consisted of photons. The prevailing electromagnetic theory predicted that light scattering from electrons should only change frequency depending on the time the electron was exposed to light  and on the light intensity. The American physicist Arthur Compton (1892-1962) gathered evidence that showed this did not happen. Instead, the scattered light changed frequency only with the scattering angle. Compton then proceeded to explain his results theoretically using special relativity and the quantum theory of light.

	For this experimental and theoretical work, Compton was awarded the 1927 Nobel prize in physics. Additionally, it was Compton who originally coined the term \textit{photon}, for a quantum of light. With the discovery and explanation of Compton scattering, many lingering doubts that physicists had about quantum theory and special relativity were dispelled. It is now accepted that special relativity holds true and that light has both wave and particle properties. Special relativity and light wave particle duality are topics that are still under active investigation today.

	Suppose that a beam of gamma rays falls on some target. Following Compton, assume the gamma rays consist of photons, each with initial momentum $p_i$ and initial energy $E_i$, where 

\begin{equation}
E_i = hf_i = p_ic
\label{equ:csEnergy}
\end{equation}

with $h = 6.62606876\times10^{-34}\ J\cdot s$ being Planck's constant, and $c = 299792458\ m/s$ is the speed of light in a vacuum. So each photon has energy and momentum in proportion to its frequency. Further assume that Compton scattering is due to an elastic collision between a gamma ray photon and a stationary free electron.

\begin{figure}
  \usetikzlibrary{arrows,snakes,backgrounds,shapes,calc,patterns}
  \usetikzlibrary{circuits.ee.IEC}
  \begin{tikzpicture}[circuit ee IEC]
    %particles
    \draw [fill=lightgray] (0,0) node (v1) {$\gamma$} ellipse (0.5 and 0.5);%photon initial
    \draw [fill=gray] (5,0) node (v2) {e} ellipse (0.5 and 0.5);%electron initial
    \draw [fill=lightgray] (10,2.5) node (v3) {$\gamma$} ellipse (0.5 and 0.5);%photon final
    \draw [fill=gray] (10,-2.5) node (v4) {e} ellipse (0.5 and 0.5);%electron final
    %labels
    \node[right] at (-0.5,-1) {$p_i, E_i$};
    \node[right] at (9.5,1.5) {$p_s, E_s$};
    \node[right] at (9.5,-3.5) {$p_e, K_e$};
    \node[right] at (7.25,0.5) {$\theta$};
    \node[right] at (7.25,-0.5) {$\phi$};
    \begin{pgfonlayer}{background}%lines and arrows in background
      \draw (0,0) -- (10,0);%path
      \draw [-triangle 60] (0,0) -- (2.5,0);%arrow
      \draw (5,0) -- (10,2.5);%path
      \draw [-triangle 60] (5,0) -- (7.5,1.25);%arrow
      \draw (5,0) -- (10,-2.5);%path
      \draw [-triangle 60] (5,0) -- (7.5,-1.25);%arrow
      \draw (6.8794,-0.684) arc (-19.9988:20:2);%angle
    \end{pgfonlayer}
    \end{tikzpicture}
  \label{fig:csCollision}
  \caption{Photon-electron collision}
\end{figure}

	In this case, the electron struck by the photon is initially at rest and both energy and linear momentum are conserved. So this situation can be treated like the billiard ball collision depicted in Figure \ref{fig:csCollision}. After impact the photon has lost some energy and momentum to the electron. The scattered photon leaves the collision at angle $\theta$ with energy $E_s$ and momentum $p_s$. The electron leaves the collision at recoil angle $\phi$ with momentum $p_e$ and kinetic energy $K_e$.

	By conservation of momentum, the electron must have gained the momentum the photon lost so the electron momentum is

\begin{equation}
\vec{p_e} = \vec{p_i} - \vec{p_s}
\label{equ:csMomentum}
\end{equation}

Similarly, the kinetic energy of the electron is

\begin{equation}
K_e = E_i - E_s
\label{equ:csKineticEnergy}
\end{equation}

	It is the scattered gamma rays that are of interest here since they can be detected after leaving the target. This happens because gamma rays are penetrating whereas electrons are not. So eliminating the angle $\phi$ and using conservation of momentum yields the formula

\begin{equation}
p_e^2 = p_i ^2 + p_s^2 - 2p_ip_scos\theta
\label{equ:csConservationMomentum}
\end{equation}

In this experiment the energy of the scattered gamma rays are examined, so the momenta in Equation \ref{equ:csConservationMomentum} need to be converted to energies. Multiplying both sides of Equation \ref{equ:csConservationMomentum} by $c^2$ and substituting Equation \ref{equ:csEnergy} yields

\begin{equation}
p_e^2c^2 = E_i ^2 + E_s^2 - 2E_iE_scos\theta
\label{equ:csConservationEnergy}
\end{equation}

To eliminate $p_e$, Compton used the \textbf{relativistic energy momentum relationship} for the electron which is

\begin{equation}
p_e^2c^2 = K_e^2 + 2m_ec^2K_e
\label{equ:csRelEnergyMomentum}
\end{equation}

where $m_ec^2$ is the \textbf{rest mass energy} of the electron. Substituting Equations \ref{equ:csRelEnergyMomentum} and \ref{equ:csKineticEnergy} into Equation \ref{equ:csConservationEnergy} gives the result

\begin{equation}
\frac{1}{E_S}-\frac{1}{E_i}=\frac{1}{m_ec^2}(1-cos\theta)
\label{equ:csConservationEnergySub}
\end{equation}

Using Equation \ref{equ:csEnergy} to convert the energy of the photons to their wavelength gives

\begin{equation}
\lambda_s - \lambda_i = \Delta \lambda = \frac{h}{m_ec}(1-cos\theta)
\label{equ:csScattering}
\end{equation}

which is \textbf{Compton's scattering formula}. This formula predicts that a scattered photon undergoes a wavelength change dependent only on the scattering angle and that the maximum change happens at an angle of 180$\ \degree$. The wavelength change is independent of the incoming wavelength, which means that the same magnitude of wavelength shift happens for visible light as for x-rays or gamma rays. For example, at a scattering angle of 60$\ \degree$, the Compton scattering formula predicts a change in wavelength of 1.2 pm (picometers). For visible red light with a wavelength of 600 nm (nanometers) this change is nearly invisible. However, gamma radiation with an energy of 600 keV has a wavelength of 2 pm. At this wavelength, a shift of 1.2 pm is a 60$\%$ change which is easily detected. It is for this reason that gamma rays are often used to examine Compton scattering.

\begin{figure}
  \usetikzlibrary{3d}
  \begin{tikzpicture}[y={(-1cm,0.5cm)},x={(1cm,.5cm)}, z={(0cm,1cm)}]%coordinate system
    \coordinate (O) at (0, 0, 0);%define origin
    \draw (0,-4.5,0)--(0,3,0);%xaxis
    \draw (0,0,0)--(2.5,0,0);%yaxis
    \draw (-0.05,0,-2) rectangle (0.05,0,4);%z-axis thick
    \draw [-triangle 90,thick] (0,0,0) -- (2,0,0);%arrow
    \draw [-triangle 90,thick] (0,3.6,0) -- (0,0.5,0);%arrow
    \draw (0,0,0) ellipse (3 and 4);%ellipse
    \node [shape=circle,draw=black,thick,scale=0.6] at (0,0,4.15){};%e
