    \draw (0,5.5,-1)--(0,5.5,0)--(0,4,0);%rectangle
    \draw (0,5.5,0)--(1,5.5,0)--(1,4,0);%rectangle
    \node [shape=circle,draw=black,thick,fill=lightgray,scale=1.2] at (0,3.6,0){};%c
    \node [shape=circle,draw=black,thick,fill=black,scale=0.5] at (0,4.5,0){};%a
    \draw (0,4.5,0)--(0,3.6,0.2);%emitting ray from a to c
    \draw (0,4.5,0)--(0,3.8,-0.2);%emitting ray from a to c
    \node [shape=circle,draw=black,scale=2] at (2.5,0,0){};%cylinder
    \node [shape=circle,draw=black,thick,scale=1] at (2.5,0,0){};%cylinder
    \node [shape=circle,draw=black,scale=2] at (3.5,0,0){};%cylinder
    \node [shape=circle,draw=black,scale=1,very thin] at (3.2,0,0){};%cylinder
    \draw [very thin] (3.2,0,0.17)--(3.9,0,0.18);%cylinder
    \draw [very thin] (3.2,0,-0.17)--(4.1,0,-0.18);%cylinder
    \node [shape=circle,draw=black,scale=1,very thin] at (4,0,0){};%cylinder
    \draw (2.3,0,0.37)--(3.3,0,0.37);%cylinder
    \draw (2.7,0,-0.37)--(3.7,0,-0.37);%cylinder
    \draw (0,-.5,0) arc (-75:0:.5);%theta angle
    %labels
    \node at (0.5,-0.3,0){$\theta$};
    \node at (0,4.9,-0.2){a};
    \node at (2,5.5,-0.7){b};
    \node at (0,3.6,-0.4){c};
    \node at (0,2,-0.4){d};
    \node at (0,0,4.4){e};
    \node at (1.3,0.3,0){f};
    \node at (1.9,-0.5,0){g};
    \node at (2.7,-0.5,1.2){i};
    \node at (3,-0.5,0.5){h};
  \end{tikzpicture}
  \label{fig:csApparatus}
  \caption{Experimental Apparatus}
\end{figure}

	In this experiment, the source used is caesium-137 which emits gamma rays with an energy of 661.66 keV. The experimental apparatus is shown in Figure \ref{fig:csApparatus}. The caesium pellet at (a) is enclosed in a shielded box (b) except for a conical aperture at (c). A gamma ray beam (d) is emitted from the box through the aperture and strikes the rod (e). The gamma rays undergo Compton scattering from electrons in the rod. The Compton formula predicts that scattered gamma rays (f) will be emitted from the rod at a wide range of angles up to and including 180$\ \degree$. A movable assembly (i) observes the scattered gamma rays at some particular angle  though the entrance aperture (g) with the gamma ray detector (h).

	The Compton scattering formula predicts the energy of the gamma rays emitted from the rod at a particular angle. However, it does not predict the \textbf{number} of gamma rays that are emitted at each angle. If the number turns out to be small then Compton scattering would not be readily observable even if the effect was real. Fortunately, it turns out that the number of gamma rays at each angle is indeed significant, so the Compton scattering effect is predicted to be readily observable with gamma rays. The actual population of scattered gamma rays at various angles is determined by a quantity called the \textbf{nuclear cross-section}.

	The nuclear cross-section, $\sigma$, is the \textbf{effective area presented by the target} of an interaction. In the macroscopic world a target has one particular area. However, in nuclear cross-sections the area of an object is not well defined, and the probability of an interaction extends over a diffuse region centered on a neighbourhood of the object but usually larger. Nevertheless, in nuclear cross-sections, as with macroscopic targets, the larger the cross section, the easier it is to hit the target. For this reason, the unit of nuclear cross-section is named a \textbf{barn} (from the expression to hit the broadside of a barn). One barn (b) has an area of $10^{-28}\ m^2$. The nuclear cross-section for Compton scattering is denoted by $\sigma_c$.

	For Compton scattering the target is an electron and the interaction is the scattering of a gamma ray at one particular scattering angle. Classically, the nuclear cross-section of an electron would be the cross-sectional area of the electron. This value is taken to be the square of the \textbf{classical electron radius}, $r_e = 2.81794\times10^{-15}\ m$. Since the electron is not really a discrete fixed target and the gamma ray photon interacts with it in a probabilistic manner, the Compton scattering cross-section has to take quantum mechanics into account. So the nuclear cross-section is expected to be $r_e^2$ multiplied by a quantum correction factor that depends on the scattering angle. The cross-section for Compton scattering derived from quantum theory is

\begin{equation}
\sigma_c = \frac{r_e^2}{2} \left(\frac{E_s}{E_i}\right)^2 \left[\frac{E_i}{E_s} + \frac{E_s}{E_i} - sin^2\theta \right]
\label{equ:csCrossSection}
\end{equation}

The Compton scattering formula can be used to eliminate $E_i$ and $E_s$ from Equation \ref{equ:csCrossSection}. Rewriting Equation \ref{equ:csConservationEnergySub} in ratio form gives

\begin{equation}
\frac{E_i}{E_s}=1+\alpha(1-cos\theta)
\label{equ:csConservationRatio}
\end{equation}

where $\alpha$ is the ratio of the incoming gamma ray energy ($E_i$) to the electron rest mass energy ($m_ec^2$). In this experiment $\alpha$ has the value 1.295. Substituting this into Equation \ref{equ:csCrossSection} yields the expression

\begin{equation}
\sigma_c = \frac{r_e^2}{2} \left[ \frac{1+cos^2\theta}{[1+\alpha(1-cos\theta)]^2}\right]\left[1 + \frac{\alpha^2(1-cos\theta)^2}{(1+cos^2\theta) [1+\alpha(1-cos\theta)]}\right]
\label{equ:csKleinNishina}
\end{equation}

This is called the \textbf{Klein-Nishina formula} for the nuclear cross-section of Compton scattering in honour of the two physicists who first derived this expression in 1929. Although it appears complicated, it really only is the classical cross section of the electron multiplied by a single constant that happens to depend on the scattering angle and on the initial gamma ray energy.

	Once found, the Compton scattering cross-section can be used to predict the number of gamma rays that are scattered into each scattering angle. Alternatively, the count rate at a particular scattering angle versus the incoming gamma ray count rate can be used to determine the measured Compton scattering cross-section. Either way, the cross section relates the outgoing scattered gamma rays to the incoming gamma rays.

	However, usually the target is a piece of material containing a large number of electrons rather than one electron. Furthermore, the incoming gamma rays bombard an area of the target, not just a single point. Lastly, gamma ray detectors only observe gamma rays in a particular solid angle and with a given efficiency. Many scattered gamma rays escape uncounted. These extra parameters must be corrected for when measuring the scattering cross-section.

	Suppose that $F_b$ is the \textbf{flux} of bombarding gamma rays striking the target (flux is the count rate per unit area), $C_d$ is the count rate of scattered gamma rays observed by the detector at angle $\theta$, $N_e$ is the number of electrons irradiated in the target, $\Omega$ is the solid angle intercepted by the detector, and E is the \textbf{efficiency} with which the detector observes the gamma rays. Then the Compton scattering cross-section is the ratio of scattered gamma rays to incoming gamma ray flux multiplied by a correction for the number of electrons, detector solid angle, and efficiency. This yields the formula

\begin{equation}
\sigma_c = \frac{C_d}{F_b}\cdot\frac{1}{N_eE\Omega}
\label{equ:csCrossSectionCorrection}
\end{equation}

	Equation \ref{equ:csCrossSectionCorrection} can be used to measure the scattering cross-section, which can then be compared with the theoretical value predicted by the Klein-Nishina formula. An inspection of Equation \ref{equ:csCrossSectionCorrection} and Figure \ref{fig:csApparatus} suggests that nearly all of the quantities are fixed values determined by the geometry and materials of the apparatus. The flux of gamma rays striking the target is determined by the count rate of the gamma source pellet, $C_{\gamma}$, and the distance from the source to the target ($r_s$ = 0.343 m). The flux striking the target is the source count rate divided by the surface area of the entire sphere at the radius of the target. So

\begin{equation}
F_b = \frac{C_{\gamma}}{4\pi r_s^2} = \frac{C_{\gamma}}{4\pi\cdot(0.343\ m)^2} = C_{\gamma}\times(6.7640\times10^{-1})\ m^{-2}
\label{equ:csFlux}
\end{equation}

The target is a cylindrical rod with a diameter of 0.0127 m. It has been established that the bombarding gamma ray beam intercepts the target over a height of 0.074 m. The number of electrons in a cylindrical target of volume V made of a pure element with atomic number Z, atomic mass A, and density $\rho$ is

\begin{align}
N_e &= \frac{N_A\rho VZ}{A} \\
&= \frac{\rho Z}{A}(6.022\times10^{23}\ atom/mol)\left(\frac{0.0127\ m}{2}\right)^2(0.074\ m\pi) \\
&= \frac{\rho Z}{A}(5.6452\times10^{18})\ m^3/mol
\label{equ:csNumElectrons}
\end{align}

where $N_A=6.022142\times10^{23}$ atoms per mole is \textbf{Avogadro's constant}. The solid angle over which the detector observes gamma rays is determined by the area of the detector, $A_d$ and the distance from the target to the detector, $r_d$. The detector crystal is a disk 0.0254 m in diameter at a distance of $r_d = 0.343$ $m$ from the target rod. The solid angle is the detector area divided by the square of the distance so

\begin{equation}
\Omega = \pi\left(\frac{0.0254\ m}{2}\right)^2\cdot\frac{1}{(0.343\ m)^2}=4.3069\times10^{-3}
\label{equ:csSolidAngle}
\end{equation}

	Lastly, the detector crystal used to observe the scattered gamma rays is not 100$\%$ efficient at detecting them. As the gamma energy increases, the photons become more penetrating and the probability that the photon passes completely through the detector increases. The efficiency of the detector is given by the empirically derived power law

\begin{equation}
E = 16.0E_s^{-0.55}
\label{equ:csDetectorEfficiency}
\end{equation}

where $E_s$ is the scattered gamma ray energy in keV. This formula is valid for gamma ray energies between 180 keV and 680 keV and detector crystals 0.0254 m in diameter. For example, at 600 keV the detector has an efficiency of 0.49. At this energy, less than half the gamma rays are picked up by the detector.

	Collecting the constants together gives the final result that

\begin{equation}
\sigma_c = (6.0806\times10^{-17})\ \frac{mol}{m}\left(\frac{1}{C_{\gamma}}\right)\left(\frac{A}{\rho Z}\right)\left(\frac{C_d}{E}\right)
\label{equ:csCrossSectionFinal}
\end{equation}

Equation \ref{equ:csCrossSectionFinal} shows that the Compton scattering cross-section depends on the source count rate, the target material, and the efficiency corrected scattered count rate. This formula can be used to experimentally measure the cross-section or predict the count rate at different angles.

	The detector records the arrival and energy of the scattered gamma ray photons. To be recorded, the gamma ray must interact with the detector material. The full energy of the gamma ray is only recorded when the gamma ray is entirely absorbed inside the detector. In an ideal detector, this absorption happens for each and every gamma ray that intercepts the detector. In this case a plot of the detector output, called the \textbf{energy spectrum}, would look like Figure \ref{fig:csIdealSpectrum}. The only energy at which counts are recorded is at the scattering energy $E_s$. The only feature visible in the energy spectrum is the \textbf{full energy peak} or \textbf{photopeak} corresponding to the energy of the scattered gamma rays emitted from the target.
\begin{marginfigure}
 \begin{tikzpicture}
    \draw[->,ultra thin] (0,0) -- (4.2,0);%axis 
    \draw[->,ultra thin] (0,0) -- (0,4.2);%axis
    \draw[-,thick] (3.3,0) -- (3.5,3.9) -- (3.7,0);%plot
 	\draw[-,ultra thin] (3.4968187,-0.2) -- (3.4968187,4.5);%energy line
  	\node at (1.5,-0.5) {\small{Energy}};%label
  	\node at (3.5,-0.5) {\small{$E_s$}};%label
  	\node at (-1,2.5) {\small{Counts}};%label
  	\node at (1.75,4.75) {\small{Photopeak}};%label
  	\draw (2.6,4.6)--(3.25,3.5);%photopeak pointer
  \end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Ideal Energy Spectrum}
\label{fig:csIdealSpectrum}
\end{marginfigure}
	The ideal energy spectrum displayed in Figure \ref{fig:csIdealSpectrum} only appears when the detector is large enough to absorb all the gamma rays that enter. In practice, such detectors are seldom used because of their expense and fragility. For smaller detectors, such as the one used in this experiment, much of the energy appears elsewhere in the energy spectrum because the incoming gamma ray is partly absorbed and the remaining fraction escapes the detector.

	The primary interaction by which the detector material absorbs incoming gamma rays is also Compton scattering. Inside the detector, the gamma ray strikes an electron and the recoil electron is quickly absorbed, taking away some of the energy. The remaining energy is carried away by the scattered gamma ray which can undergo further Compton scattering or escape from the detector completely. If the scattered gamma ray escapes from the detector the full energy $E_s$ will not be recorded and only some fraction appears on the energy spectrum instead.

	In the lower limit of $0\ \degree$ scattering, the gamma ray carrying all the energy escapes and the recoil electron has no energy at all. At the upper limit, the most energy a gamma ray can lose at one time from Compton scattering is at an angle of $180\ \degree$, where the incoming gamma ray strikes the electron head-on and the scattered gamma ray is bounced completely backwards. In this case the recoil electron gets the maximum energy which is subsequently deposited into the detector. This process of scattered gamma rays escaping from the detector gives rise to a band of energies ranging from zero to some maximum value in the energy spectrum. This band is called the \textbf{Compton continuum}. The maximum value of this continuum, corresponding to the escape of a $180\ \degree$ scattered gamma ray, is called the \textbf{Compton edge}. Some of the scattered gamma rays undergo \textbf{multiple Compton interactions}. This tends to fill in the region between the photopeak and the Compton edge. Figure \ref{fig:csRealSpectrum} shows a more realistic gamma ray energy spectrum with a photopeak, Compton continuum, Compton edge, and multiple Compton interactions.

\begin{figure}
  \begin{tikzpicture}
    %coordinate system
    \draw[->,very thin] (0,0) -- (10.2,0); 
    \draw[->,very thin] (0,0) -- (0,4.2);
    %plot
    \draw[-,thick] (7,1.5) node (v1) {} -- (7,0.75) -- (9.3,0.5) -- (9.5,3.4) -- (9.7,0);
    \draw[thick]  plot[smooth, tension=.7] coordinates {(v1) (3.5,1) (0.5,1.5)};
    \draw [-,thick] (0.5,1.5) -- (0.5,0);
    %labels
    \node[right] at (0.3,3) {Compton continuum};
    \node[right] at (1.75,3.5) {Compton edge};
    \node[right] at (2,4) {Multiple Compton events};
    \node[right] at (6.5,4) {Photopeak};
    \node[right] at (-0.2,-0.25) {0};
    \node[right] at (6.75,-0.25) {$E_c$};
    \node[right] at (9.25,-0.25) {$E_s$};
    %arrows
    \draw [ultra thin] (3.65,3) -- (4.75,1.1);%compton continuum
    \draw [ultra thin] (8.5,4) -- (9.5,3);%photopeak
    \draw [ultra thin] (4.2,3.5) -- (7,1);%compton edge
    \draw [ultra thin] (6.1,4) -- (8,0.65);%events
    \draw[-,ultra thin] (9.5,0) -- (9.5,4.5);%E_s
    \draw[-,ultra thin] (7,0) -- (7,2);%E_c
  \end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Energy Spectrum with photopeak, Compton continuum, Compton edge, and multiple Compton interactions}
  \label{fig:csRealSpectrum}
\end{figure}

	The energy of the Compton edge, $E_c$, is the incoming energy $E_s$ less the energy, $E_{180\ \degree}$, of a $180\ \degree$ scattered gamma ray that has escaped. Using Equation \ref{equ:csConservationEnergySub} to find $E_{180\ \degree}$ gives the result

\begin{equation}
E_c = E_s - E_{180\ \degree} = E_s - \frac{E_s}{1+\frac{2E_s}{m_ec^2}} = \frac{2E_s^2}{m_ec^2+2E_s}
\label{equ:csEdgeEnergy}
\end{equation}

	The energy spectrum displays several other notable features. caesium-137 actually decays by beta decay, thereby emitting an electron. The beta particles are absorbed by the intervening air and the target and so do not affect the experiment. However, after emitting an electron, often (92$\%$ of the time), the resulting isotope, barium-137, remains in an excited state denoted as Ba$^{137}$. This excited state quickly decays (the half-life is 2.3 minutes) and emits the 661.66 keV gamma ray used in this experiment. Instead of emitting a gamma ray, a barium  electron near the nucleus can be given this energy instead, which changes its orbit. Then the remaining electrons reshuffle, and a K-shell x-ray is emitted. For Ba$^{137}$ this K-shell x-ray has an energy of 31.45 keV. This x-ray can appear as a photopeak at the low end of the energy spectrum.

	The shielding surrounding the detector also contributes features to the energy spectrum. Any materials with high atomic number will generate K-shell x-rays that can be seen by the detector if they are struck with gamma radiation. Since the detector is surrounded by lead, a lead K-shell xray of 72.14 keV frequently appears. In addition, besides happening inside the target and inside the detector material, Compton scattering also occurs inside the shielding. The Compton scattered gamma rays emitted from the shielding are mostly at high angles between 135$\ \degree$ and 180$\ \degree$, which implies gamma rays of energy around 200 keV. The feature that appears in the spectrum due to Compton scattering in the shielding is called the \textbf{backscatter peak}. These features are shown in Figure \ref{fig:csRealSpectrumMore}. The science of studying and interpreting spectra such as the one seen in Figure \ref{fig:csRealSpectrumMore} is known as \textbf{gamma ray spectroscopy}. This experiment presents several gamma ray spectra that can be checked for the presence of the features outlined in Figures \ref{fig:csIdealSpectrum}-\ref{fig:csRealSpectrumMore}.

\begin{figure}
  \begin{tikzpicture}
  %coordinate system
  \draw[->,very thin] (0,0) -- (10.2,0); 
  \draw[->,very thin] (0,0) -- (0,4.2);
  %plot
  \draw[-,thick] (7,1.5) node (v1) {} -- (7,0.75) -- (9.3,0.5) -- (9.5,3.4) -- (9.7,0);%lines
  \draw[thick]  plot[smooth, tension=.7] coordinates {(v1) (3.5,1) (0.5,1.5)};%arc
  \draw[-,thick] (0.5,1.5) -- (0.5,0);
  \draw[-,thick] (0.7,1.45) -- (0.8,4) -- (0.9,1.4);%peak1
  \draw[-,thick] (1,1.36) -- (1.1,2) -- (1.2,1.31);%peak2
  \draw[-,thick] (2.3,1.1) -- (2.5,1.4) -- (3.2,1.01);%peak3
  \draw[-,ultra thick,draw=white,white] plot[smooth,tension=0.7] coordinates {(0.715,1.45) (0.8,1.425) (0.878,1.4)};%peak1
  \draw[-,ultra thick,draw=white,white] plot[smooth,tension=0.7] coordinates {(1.01,1.36) (1.1,1.35) (1.175,1.33)};%peak2
  \draw[-,ultra thick,draw=white,white] plot[smooth,tension=0.7] coordinates { (2.329,1.1) (2.8,1.04)  (3.155,0.998) };%peak3
  %labels
  \node[right] at (8,5) {Compton edge};
  \node[right] at (10,4) {661.66 keV Photopeak};
  \node[right] at (1,6) {Barium K-shell X-ray};
  \node[right] at (2,5.5) {Lead K-shell X-ray};
  \node[right] at (3,5) {Backscatter peak};
  \node[right] at (-0.2,-0.25) {0};
  \node[right] at (6.75,-0.25) {$E_c$};
  \node[right] at (9.25,-0.25) {$E_i$};
  %arrows
  \draw [ultra thin] (10,4) -- (9.5,3);%photopeak
  \draw [ultra thin] (8,5) -- (7,1);%compton edge
  \draw [ultra thin] (1,6) -- (0.8,4);%barium k-shell x-ray
  \draw [ultra thin] (2,5.5) -- (1.1,2);%lead k-shell x-ray
  \draw [ultra thin] (3,5) -- (2.5,1.4);%backscatter peak
  \draw[-,ultra thin] (9.5,0) -- (9.5,4.5);%E_s
  \draw[-,ultra thin] (7,0) -- (7,2);%E_c
  \end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Energy Spectrum with other notable features}
  \label{fig:csRealSpectrumMore}
\end{figure}

\section{Experimental Procedure}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Do a warm up and performance check of the gamma detector system. The gamma detector has two housings. The small upright assembly is for calibration and testing. The larger horizontal movable assembly is used for the Compton scattering experiment itself. To begin, make sure the gamma detector is in the upright assembly. If the detector has to be moved, do it carefully because the gamma detector is fragile and expensive. First set the high voltage to 650 V and then turn on the high voltage power supply. After this, turn on the low voltage power supply (12, 24V). Once the power supplies are on, leave the detector to warm up and stabilize for about 15 minutes. While the detector is warming up turn on the computer and laser printer. The gamma ray acquisition program should appear once the computer has finished booting. Place the Cs$^{137}$ calibration disk under the detector and practice acquiring an energy spectrum. Set the horizontal scale to 1024 and the vertical scale to AUTO. Examine the energy spectrum and compare it with the examples seen in Figures \ref{fig:csIdealSpectrum}-\ref{fig:csRealSpectrumMore}. Observe the output signal from the detector on the oscilloscope. Each detected gamma ray is displayed as a negative pulse on the oscilloscope. The amplitude of the pulse represents the energy of the gamma ray photon. With no source under the detector, the pulses should be relatively rare. With the Cs$^{137}$ calibration disk under the detector, there should be large numbers of pulses.

\item Once the detector has warmed up, Perform an energy calibration of the gamma ray detector system. Begin by erasing the existing energy calibration. If this is not done, the new calibration values will not overwrite the current calibration, they will only distort the existing one. Three points are needed to establish a proper energy calibration and three small calibration sources are provided for this purpose. Use the caesium-137 photopeak at 661.66 keV for the first point. Use the highest energy barium-133 photopeak at 356.02 keV for the second point. Lastly, use the cobalt-57 photopeak at 122.06 keV for the third point.

\item \textbf{Safety precautions}: The 35 milliCurie caesium-137 source used in the Compton scattering apparatus is \textbf{dangerous}. Review the \textit{"Radiation Safety Information"} article at the beginning of the laboratory manual or obtain a copy from the lab instructor. The basic rule to follow is "\textbf{avoid the gamma ray beam}". Do NOT put any part of the body (notably hands and heads) in the path of the gamma ray beam. Stay \textbf{completely} out of the white painted area at all times when the gamma ray beam aperture is open. Handle the gamma ray stopper plug \textbf{only} by the extremities (the rings). Move the gamma ray detector assembly \textbf{only} by the magnets or the black knobs that are out of the white painted area. When changing the target rod, \textbf{always} close the gamma ray beam aperture first. Do \textbf{NOT} leave the apparatus unattended if the stopper is removed. Caution \textbf{anyone} entering the Compton scattering experiment area when the gamma ray beam is operational. \textbf{Always} plug the gamma ray beam with the stopper when the experiment is completed.

\item Following the precautions explained above, examine the main gamma ray source and make sure the gamma ray beam aperture is closed with the stopper plug. Place the detector into the horizontal shield assembly. Insert the aluminum target rod into the Compton scattering apparatus. Remove the stopper plug to enable the gamma ray beam (again, remember to follow the safety instructions). For at least eight angles ranging from 30$\ \degree$ to 130$\ \degree$ acquire a gamma ray spectrum and determine the energy of the scattered gamma ray photopeak. The scattering count rate decreases as the angle increases, so a longer acquisition time might be required to get a good spectrum. In practice, a live time of 600 seconds suffices for angles above $80\ \degree$.

\item Perform any \textbf{one} of the following investigations.\label{optionalSec}
\begin{enumerate}
  \item For at least five angles, measure the scattering count rate and use it to find the Compton scattering cross-section, $\sigma_c$, using Equation \ref{equ:csCrossSectionFinal}. To get better results, measure the background count rate at each angle (count rate with target rod removed) and subtract it from the scattering count rate. Compare the measured cross-section with the theoretical Klein-Nishina cross-section predicted by Equation \ref{equ:csKleinNishina}.
    \item Equation \ref{equ:csCrossSectionFinal} suggests that the scattered count rate should be linear with the quantity ($\rho Z/A$) at any fixed scattering angle. Using the different target rods provided, design and implement an experiment to test this hypothesis.
    \item Measure the width, profile, and symmetry of the gamma ray beam. Measure $C_\gamma$ and compare it with the theoretically predicted value based on the  calculated count rate at the source and the solid angle of the detector. Determine whether the gamma ray beam is properly aligned with the $0$ axis by acquiring data on both sides of $0$.
    \item Design and implement an experiment to examine the Compton edge in the energy spectrum and compare it with the expected energy of the Compton edge predicted by Equation \ref{equ:csEdgeEnergy}.
    \item Equation \ref{equ:csConservationEnergySub} suggests that the scattered gamma ray energy $E_s$ is independent of the target material (as long as there are electrons in it). This suggests the hypothesis that the scattering energy at a fixed angle is independent of the scattering material. Design and implement an experiment to test this hypothesis using the available target rods.
    \item The upright detector stand has two different shields. One made from lead and one made from aluminum. Acquire a Caesium-137 spectrum with the lead shield and with the aluminum shield for the same amount of live time. Ask your laboratory instructor for hints on how to set up the instrument to acquire for a specific length of live time. Subtract the two spectra and examine the difference for evidence of a backscatter peak and a lead K-shell x-ray photopeak. The aluminum K-shell x-ray is too low in energy to be observed by the detector used in this experiment.
    \item Compton's scattering formula was derived using Equation \ref{equ:csRelEnergyMomentum}, which assumes the recoil electron energy momentum relationship follows special relativity. This feature can be used to test whether the recoil electron obeys classical mechanics or special relativity. Equation \ref{equ:csRelEnergyMomentum} can be rewritten in the form
      \begin{equation}
        \frac{p_e^2c^2}{K_e}=2m_ec^2+K_e
        \label{equ:csScatteringRewritten}
      \end{equation}
If the electron obeys classical mechanics the energy momentum relationship for the electron can be presented in the form
      \begin{equation}
        \frac{p_e^2c^2}{K_e}=2m_ec^2
        \label{equ:csScatteringClassical}
      \end{equation}
Equations \ref{equ:csScatteringRewritten} and \ref{equ:csScatteringClassical} imply that if the quantity $\frac{p_e^2c^2}{K_e}$ is plotted versus $K_e$, then the electron follows special relativity if a straight line of slope one is obtained, whereas if the electron behaves classically a straight line of slope zero is obtained. In both cases an intercept of $2m_ec^2$ is predicted. Compton scattering provides a means to test this assertion since $K_e$ is found from Equation \ref{equ:csKineticEnergy} and it can be shown that
      \begin{equation}
        \frac{p_e^2c^2}{K_e}=\frac{2E_iE_s(1-cos\theta)}{E_i-E_s}+E_i-E_s
        \label{equ:csScatteringRelativistic}
      \end{equation}
Design and implement an experiment to test whether the recoil electron obeys relativity or classical mechanics. Dividing by small numbers greatly magnifies errors. For this reason, use angles above 30$\ \degree$ so that the quantity $E_i-E_s$ is large.
    \item Compton scattering is quite useful for nondestructive testing of materials because the source and detector can both be on the same side of the material. Design and implement an experiment to investigate whether it is feasible to determine the target rod material simply by observing scattered gamma rays at a high angle (say above 120$\ \degree$).
\end{enumerate} 
\end{enumerate}

\section{Error Analysis}
	The largest source of error in energy measurements of gamma rays is the spreading that occurs because of statistical variations inside the detector. This results in a peak appearance that is wide and rounded instead of narrow and sharp. A standard method of assigning error to a peak in a radiation spectrum is to use the \textbf{full width half maximum}, or \textbf{FWHM} as seen in Figure \ref{fig:csGaussian}.

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=0.8]
\pgfplotsset{ticks=none,compat=1.9}
\newcommand\gauss[2]{1/(#2*sqrt(2*pi))*exp(-((x-#1)^2)/(2*#2^2))} % Gauss function, parameters mu and sigma
\begin{axis}[every axis plot post/.append style={
  mark=none,domain=-3:5,samples=50,smooth}, % All plots: from -2:2, 50 samples, smooth, no marks
axis lines=none
]
\addplot[color=black,thick] {\gauss{1}{0.9}};
\end{axis}
    %coordinate system
    \draw[->,very thin] (0.4,0.45) -- (6.75,0.45); 
    \draw[->,very thin] (0.4,0.45) -- (0.4,6);
%labels
\node[right] at (-0.25,5.25) {H};
\draw[-,ultra thin] (0.25,5.25)--(6,5.25);
\node[right] at (-0.6,2.62){H/2};
\draw[-,ultra thin] (0.25,2.62)--(6,2.62);
\node[right] at (3.2,-0.25){E};
\draw[-,ultra thin] (3.42,0)--(3.42,1.8);
\draw[-,ultra thin] (3.42,2.3)--(3.42,5.75);
\node[right] at (2.72,2){FWHM};
\draw[-triangle 60] (3.42,2.62)--(2.6,2.62);
\draw[-triangle 60] (3.42,2.62)--(4.3,2.62);
\node[right] at (3.35,3.4){$\Delta$E};
\draw[<->] (3.43,3.1)--(4.11,3.1);
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Gaussian Distribution}
\label{fig:csGaussian}
\end{marginfigure}

	If an energy peak has height H, then the FWHM of a peak is the width of the peak at half height or H/2. The error in the energy of the peak, u(E), can be taken to be the standard deviation, $\sigma$, of the peak. For a Gaussian distribution this is given by
      \begin{equation}
        u(E) = \sigma = \frac{FWHM}{2.35}
        \label{equ:csGaussDist}
      \end{equation}
	Strictly speaking, most peaks are not Gaussian because peaks often overlap or are superimposed on some other background. Nevertheless, the FWHM technique is still a reasonable approximation for the error in the energy of the peak. The formal procedure is to subtract away the other peaks and the background so that the peak rides on a horizontal line as in Figure \ref{fig:csGaussian}. This procedure is not required for this experiment.

	The error in the count rate is determined from the statistics of counting events in the standard way. If C counts are detected in T seconds, then the count rate, R, is C/T with an error R given by
      \begin{equation}
        u(R) = \frac{\sqrt{C}}{T}
        \label{equ:csCountRateError}
      \end{equation}
	The gamma ray detector has a certain width so it accepts gamma rays from an interval of angles, not just one angle. For this apparatus the angular interval of the detector is about $4\degree$. A reasonable value for the angular error is half of the angular interval. So the error in the scattering angle, $u(\theta)$, is on the order of $2\ \degree$. 

\vspace{12pt}

\textbf{To be handed in to the laboratory instructor}

\section{{\bf Goals of the Experiment}}

To investigate magnetically induced optical activity. To determine the Verdet constant and the dispersion coefficient for a variety of optical media.

\section{{\bf Theory}}

First observed by Michael Faraday (1791-1867) in 1845, plane-polarized light propagating through a transparent material (such as glass, water or gas) along the direction of an applied magnetic field, experiences a rotation of its plane of polarization. Faraday's observation was one of the earliest indications of a relationship between electromagnetism and light. The theoretical treatment of the effect is complex, requiring the use of the quantum mechanical theory of dispersion and the effects of magnetic field on the atomic and molecular energy levels. The discussion of the effect here will be limited to a simplified classical argument (due to H.A.Lorentz, J.J.Larmor and A.E.Becquerel; 1896) in which the structure and spectra of atoms are not described in detail. The basic relationship between the angle of Faraday rotation, $\phi$ , the optical path length through the medium, $D$, and the applied magnetic field $B$ is linear 

\begin{equation}
\phi = V  B,
\label{equ:feFaradayRotation}%1
\end{equation}
where V is a constant of proportionality, called the Verdet constant.

	Consider a hydrogen atom with one electron in a circular orbit around the atomic nucleus. In the absence of a magnetic field, the electron is moving under the influence of a central, attractive, inverse-square force $F$

\begin{equation}
F = \frac{mv^{2}}{r} = 4 \pi^{2} f^{2} m r = m \omega^{2} r,
\label{equ:feForce}%2
\end{equation}
where $e$, $m$, $v$, $r$, $f$ and $\omega$ are the electron charge, mass, velocity, radius of orbit, frequency and angular velocity respectively. For very small changes in $F$, the above expression can be differentiated to obtain $dF$ which is 
				
\begin{equation}
dF = 8 \pi^{2} f m r \cdot df = 2mr \omega \cdot d \omega.
\label{equ:fedForce}%3
\end{equation}
The differential magnetic force acting on the orbital electron due to the application of an external magnetic field is 

\begin{equation}
dF = e v B = 2 \pi e B f r = e B r \omega.
\label{equ:fedForce2}%4
\end{equation}
Equating the above two differentials and solving for $d\omega$ gives				

\begin{equation}
d \omega = 2 \pi \cdot df = \frac{e B}{2 m}.
\label{equ:fedAngularVelocity}%5
\end{equation}

The quantity $d\omega$ is the angular frequency of precession of the electronic orbits, due to the influence of the applied magnetic field, also called the {\bf Larmor frequency}. It can be seen from Equation \ref{equ:fedAngularVelocity} that the Larmor frequency for a given particle is directly proportional to $B$, the intensity of the magnetic field (since the ratio $e/m$ is constant). The precession of electronic orbits is also applicable to atoms having a large number of orbital electrons or for complex molecules (for instance glass or organic compounds). Here, however, the classical model becomes inaccurate because of the electron to electron interactions.

\begin{figure}%fig1
\begin{tikzpicture}[x={(1cm,0cm)}, y={(0cm,1cm)}, z={(.3cm,1cm)}, scale=1.7]
\coordinate (O) at (0, 0, 0);
%linear polarized
\foreach \x in {0,-1.5,1.5}{
\draw[ultra thin,open triangle 45-](0+\x,0,-0.2)--(0+\x,0,5);
}
\foreach \z in {0,.2,...,5}{
\draw[->](0,0,0+\z)--(0,{.7*cos(36*\z)},0+\z);
}
\foreach \z in {0,.2,...,4.8}{

}
%left-circularly polarized
\foreach \z in {0,.714,...,5}{

}

}

}

}

}

\draw[ultra thin,draw=gray](1.5,.4,0+\z)arc(90:450:.4);
}
%labels
\draw[thin,gray,->](2.2,0,1.35)--(2.2,0,2);
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(-2.7,1,4.5){the angular velocity};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(-2.7,.86,4.5){of electric vectors};

\node[font=\scriptsize]at(2.2,0,1.3){time};

\node[font=\scriptsize]at(2.7,.25,0){polarization};

\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Linearly polarized light}
\label{fig:feLinearlyPolarizedLight}
\end{figure}


Linearly polarized light can be thought of as the superposition (vector sum) of two circularly polarized component waves whose electric vectors (phasors) are, in the absence of a magnetic field, rotating at the same angular frequency, $\omega_{0}$, in opposite directions, as shown in Figure \ref{fig:feLinearlyPolarizedLight}. In an optical medium where the Larmor precession has been induced by the application of a magnetic field, the angular frequency of each circular wave will be different. Depending on the orientation of $B$ and the direction of wave propagation relative to it, the angular frequency of each circular wave will be as follows

\begin{equation}
\omega_{r} = \omega_{0} + d \omega
\label{equ:feAngularVelocityRight}%6
\end{equation}
and

\begin{equation}
\omega_{l} = \omega_{0} - d \omega
\label{equ:feAngularVelocityLeft}%7
\end{equation}

Since $\omega_{l}\ < \ \omega_{r}$, the two circular waves emerge from the medium with a phase shift. This phase shift is caused by the velocity difference at which the two circular waves propagate through the medium (a change in $\omega$ translates into changes in velocity $v$ and refractive index $n$). In traversing a medium of length $D$ the electric vector $E$ of any circular wave rotates through an angle 

\begin{equation}
\theta = \frac{2 \pi D}{\lambda}.
\label{equ:feRotationAngle}%8
\end{equation}
Using the relationships

\begin{equation}
n = \frac{c}{v}\ ,
\label{equ:feRelationship1}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}
v = f \lambda,
\label{equ:feRelationship2}
\end{equation}
and

\begin{equation}
c = f \lambda_{0}.
\label{equ:feRelationship3}
\end{equation}
where $c$ and $\lambda_{0}$ are the speed and wavelength of light in vacuum; $v$ and $\lambda$ are the speed and wavelength of light in a medium and $f$ is the frequency of light one obtains

\begin{equation}
\lambda = \frac{\lambda_{0}}{n},
\label{equ:feWavelength}%9
\end{equation}
and

\begin{equation}
\theta = \frac{2 \pi D}{\lambda_{0}}n.
\label{equ:feRotationAngle2}%10
\end{equation}
Consequently, upon emerging from the optical medium, 

\begin{equation}
\theta_{r} = \frac{2 \pi D}{\lambda_{0}}n_{r}.
\label{equ:feRotationAngleRight}%11
\end{equation}
and

\begin{equation}
\theta_{l} = \frac{2 \pi D}{\lambda_{0}}n_{l}.
\label{equ:feRotationAngleLeft}%12
\end{equation}
are the angles of rotation for the two circular vibrations. Here, $n_{r}$ and $n_{l}$ are the refractive indices for the right, and the left-circular vibrations respectively. The angle of Faraday rotation, $\phi$, is the angle through which the plane of polarization appears to have rotatated upon traversing the optically activated medium. It is one half the difference between $\theta_{r}$ and 
$\theta_{l}$. Figure \ref{fig:feCircularComponents} shows the left and right electric field components before and after traversing the optically activated medium. Using Equations \ref{equ:feRotationAngleRight} and \ref{equ:feRotationAngleLeft}, the angle of Faraday rotation is found to be

\begin{figure}%fig2
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(11,6);

\foreach \x in {0,5}{
\draw[very thin](2.5+\x,3)ellipse(1.4 and 1.4);
\draw[](2.5+\x,1)--(2.5+\x,5);
\draw[](.5+\x,3)--(4.5+\x,3);
}
\begin{scope}[shift={(2.5,3)}]

\node[font=\small]at(8.1,3.6){$\theta_r$};
\node[font=\small]at(7.2,2.7){$\phi$};

\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Circular components of linearly polarized light}
\label{fig:feCircularComponents}
\end{figure}


\begin{equation}
\phi=\frac{1}{2} \left( \theta_{r} - \theta_{l} \right) = \frac{\pi D}{\lambda_{0}} \left(n_{r} - n_{l} \right).
\label{equ:feFaradayRotation1}%13{fig:feRefractiveIndex}
\end{equation}

As explained above, refractive indices,$n_{r}$ and $n_{l}$, are different because of the Larmor precession. The slight variability of the refractive index with changing wavelength is referred to as {\bf dispersion}. Figure \ref{fig:feRefractiveIndex} shows a dispersion relationship typical for most types of glass. This relationship will be used to approximate the magnitude of ($n_{r}- n_{l}$) used in Equation \ref{equ:feFaradayRotation1}. Assuming that ($n_{r}- n_{l}$) is small, it can be approximated by the slope of the straight line tangent to the curve at the point ($\lambda_{0}$, $n$) multiplied by the width of the interval ($\lambda_{r} -\lambda_{l}$), as shown in Figure \ref{fig:feRefractiveIndex}. Thus ($n_{r}- n_{l}$) can be replaced by

\begin{figure}%fig3
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(11,8);
%function and tangent
\draw[<->](2,6)--(2,1)--(8,1);
\draw[domain=3:7.8]plot({\x},{(120./(\x^3))+1.4});
\draw[very thin,domain=2.5:5.5]plot({\x},{(-360./256.)*\x+8.88});
%demarcation lines
\draw[](2,3.25)--(4,3.25)--(4,1);
\draw[](2,3.75)--(3.72,3.75)--(3.72,1);
\draw[](2,2.75)--(4.47,2.75)--(4.47,1);
%demarcation arrows
\draw[->](3,1.5)--(3.7,1.5);
\draw[->](5,1.5)--(4.5,1.5);
\draw[->](2.5,4.5)--(2.5,3.77);
\draw[->](2.5,2)--(2.5,2.74);
%labels
\node[]at(5,6.35){Refractive index and different wavelengths};
%\node[]at(5,6.){of optical medium};
\node[]at(1,5.5){refractive};
\node[]at(1,5.2){index, n};
\node[]at(1.5,3.7){n$_r$};
\node[]at(1.5,3.24){n};
\node[]at(1.5,2.7){n$_l$};
\node[]at(5.1,5){slope $\frac{dn}{d\lambda}\Big|_{\lambda=\lambda_0}$};
\node[]at(2.8,4.15){$\Delta$n};
\node[]at(3.3,1.7){$\Delta\lambda$};
\node[]at(3.6,.7){$\lambda_r$};
\node[]at(4,.7){$\lambda_0$};
\node[]at(4.5,.7){$\lambda_l$};
\node[]at(5,.2){wavelength of light, $\lambda$};
\draw[->,very thin](4,5)--(3,4.7);

\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{How the refractive index of an optical medium varies with wavelength}
\label{fig:feRefractiveIndex}
\end{figure}

\begin{equation}
\left( \frac{d n}{d \lambda} \right)_{\lambda = \lambda_{0}} d \lambda.
\label{equ:fedn}%14
\end{equation}
The quantity $d\lambda$ is found to be

\begin{equation}
d \lambda = d \left( \frac{c}{f} \right) = - \frac{c}{f^{2}} d f = - \frac{\lambda^{2}}{c } d f = - \frac{\lambda^{2}}{2 \pi c } d \omega,
\label{equ:fedLambda}
\end{equation}
and $d\omega$ is given by Equation \ref{equ:fedAngularVelocity}. So we can write

\begin{equation}
(n_{r} - n_{l}) = \frac{\lambda_{0}^{2} e B}{2 \pi c m} \left( \frac{d n}{d \lambda} \right)_{\lambda = \lambda_{0}}.
\label{equ:fedn2}%15
\end{equation}
Equation \ref{equ:feFaradayRotation1} is then used to get

\begin{equation}
\phi = - \frac{e \lambda_{0}}{2 m c} \left( \frac{d n}{d \lambda} \right)_{\lambda = \lambda_{0}} D \cdot B,
\label{equ:fedFaradayRotation2}%16
\end{equation}
which is {\bf Becquerel's equation}. This can be written simply as $\phi = V D B$ where

\begin{equation}
V = - \frac{e \lambda_{0}}{2 m c} \left( \frac{d n}{d \lambda} \right)_{\lambda = \lambda_{0}},
\label{equ:fedFaradayRotation3}%17
\end{equation}
is the {\bf Verdet} constant. This yields Equation \ref{equ:feFaradayRotation}.

The experiment will test the validity of Equation \ref{equ:feFaradayRotation} in various optical media. Figure \ref{fig:feExperimentalSetup} shows the experimental apparatus. A laser beam of known frequency is polarized and enters the electromagnet through a hole in the pole pieces. The optical medium is placed in the gap between the pole pieces. The plane of polarization of the laser beam is rotated when the optical medium is subjected to a magnetic field. The angle of Faraday rotation is then measured on the angular scale of the analyzer. 

The procedure for measuring the angles is most easily accomplished by measuring the angle for which the light intensity entering the photometer is at a minimum (angle of extinction) with or without the magnetic field present. The laser beam remains extinct only for a very brief angular interval which allows for taking accurate measurements.

Measurements of the angle of rotation, length of the optical medium and magnetic field intensity, with the help of Equations \ref{equ:feFaradayRotation} and \ref{equ:fedFaradayRotation3}, will in turn facilitate the calculation of the Verdet constant and  the dispersion coefficient for each optical medium.

\section{{\bf Experimental Procedure}}

\begin{enumerate}
\item Turn on the photometer and choose a suitable operating range for working under the given background lighting conditions. The indicator should never go off scale.
\item Before turning on the power supply, make certain that there is water running through the cooling coils of the electromagnet (see Figure \ref{fig:feExperimentalSetup}). The electromagnet will get overheated and damaged otherwise. Also note that because of remanent magnetism in the core of the electromagnet, $B$ is not going to be zero for zero current. The current I can be increased to a maximum of about 3.5 A, at a maximum voltage of about 250 V. 
\item For each optical medium measure, $d$, the net length of the sample. Place the sample in the sample holder inside the electromagnet gap and, for zero current through the coils, find the angle at which the polarizer-analyzer pair extinguishes the laser light falling onto the photocell. This is the angle of extinction. The laser beam is plane polarized upon leaving the laser, but it is too intensive to be aimed directly at the photocell. 
\item Record the angle of extinction, then take measurements of  versus I for a full range of coil currents I. Due to time constraints, $B$ is not measured directly in the experiment. Use the calibration equation to convert from I to $B$, where I is measured in Amperes and $B$ is in Tesla. The calibration equation is

\begin{equation}
B = -0.00092942 + 0.12506632 I - 0.00896964 I^{2}
\label{equ:feBConversion}
\end{equation}

\item For samples containing a liquid, it will be necessary to subtract the effect of the container on the readings obtained in the experiment. This is accomplished by taking a separate set of readings using an empty cell, then correcting the original readings. For each optical medium, tabulate the data, plot $\phi$ versus $d \cdot B$ and calculate the value of the Verdet constant $V$.
\item For each optical medium, calculate the value of the dispersion coefficient $\frac{dn}{d\lambda}$. The wavelength of the laser can be found on the laser. 
\item Perform steps 3 through 6 for the Test Material, SFS09 material, SFS06 material, SF8 material and one other material of your choosing.
\end{enumerate}

\section{{\bf Error Analysis}}

Uncertainties in this experiment arise in the measurements of the magnetic field intensity, the effective length of the optical medium and the angle of Faraday rotation. Propagate the uncertainties using any appropriate method.

\section{Preparation}

	Review the Radiation Safety in the Undergraduate Physics Labs document found on the PHYS 325 web-page on the PJL website. Sign-off with your TA to indicate that you have read and understand how to work with nuclear materials in this lab safely.

\section{Goals of the Experiment}

	To study the radioactive decay of $^{226}$Ra using an alpha spectrometer and gain experience using radiochemistry techniques in order to purify a $^{226}$Ra sample.

\section{Theory}

\subsection{Alpha Particle Detection}
	
	Henry Becquerel (1852-1908) discovered \textbf{radioactivity} in 1896 when he noticed that some uranium compounds caused film to be exposed even in the absence of light. 
	He later determined that the source of the radioactivity was not chemical in nature but in fact the phenomenon originated from the element \textbf{uranium}. 
	In 1902 Marie (1867-1934) and Pierre (1859-1906) Curie found that \textbf{thorium} also exhibited radioactivity. 
	Becquerel and the Curies received the 1903 Nobel prize in physics for these discoveries. 
	The Curies proceeded to carefully study the ores of uranium and thorium to further isolate the actual sources of the radiation. 
	They found two new elements \textbf{polonium}, named after Marie Curie's homeland of Poland, and \textbf{radium}, named after radioactivity itself.
	These new elements turned out to be even more radioactive than thorium and uranium. 
	After four years of effort, a tenth of a gram of radium was isolated from several tons of ore. 
	Unfortunately Pierre Curie died in a traffic accident in 1906. 
	Marie Curie took over Pierre's professorship at the Sorbonne and continued to work on the study of radioactivity. 
	In 1911 Marie Curie received a second Nobel prize in chemistry for her work on the isolation of polonium and radium. 
	The units of radiation activity are now called \textbf{Becquerels} (Bq) and \textbf{Curies} (Ci) in honor of their work.

	It is now known that radioactive elements are unstable and emit radiation in the process of transforming themselves into stable elements lower down in the periodic table. 
	Several different kinds of radioactive decays exist, including  \textbf{gamma decay}, \textbf{beta decay}, and \textbf{alpha decay}. 
	Moreover, the same element can decay in different ways and different isotopes of the same element exist which can also decay in different ways. 
	This experiment examines the radioactive decay of one isotope of radium known as $^{226}_{88}$Ra. Radium 226 is known to decay by the emission of an alpha particle into radon 222. 
	The reaction is

\begin{equation}
^{226}_{88}Ra \rightarrow \  ^{222}_{86}Rn + \alpha
\label{equ:RaDecay}%eq1
\end{equation}

If conservation of mass-energy is applied to this reaction, the equation becomes

\begin{equation}
mass(^{226}_{88}Ra)c^2 = \  mass(^{222}_{86}Rn)c^2 + mass(\alpha)c^2 + Q
\label{equ:RaDecayMassEnergy}%eq2
\end{equation}

where $c = 2.99792\times 10^8\ m/s$ is the speed of light in vacuum and $Q$ is the excess mass energy of the process. Decay is only possible if $Q$ is positive. This excess energy appears mostly as the kinetic energy of the  particle. This kinetic energy can be measured and used as a signature for the observed decay.

\end{figure}
\newpage
Figure \ref{fig:ndApparatus} shows the experimental arrangement. A sample of purified radium 226 is placed underneath a detector. The detector produces a characteristic electrical pulse for each particle emitted from the radioactive sample that interacts with the detector. The size of this pulse is determined by the kinetic energy of the detected particle. The probability of the emitted particle being detected depends upon the degree of interaction of the particle with the detector material. Alpha particles are easily stopped and absorbed so there is a high probability that they will be intercepted by the detector. On the other hand, gamma rays are quite penetrating, so the probability of interaction with the detector is lower, especially if the detector is thin. Beta particles are more penetrating than alpha particles but less penetrating than gamma rays.

	As the sample emits radiation, the \textbf{solid state detector} produces a stream of pulses of varying heights into an instrument called a \textbf{pulse height analyser} or \textbf{PHA}. This instrument tallies all the incoming pulses and sorts them according to their size. The PHA counts the number of pulses that arrive at each energy and graphs the result. The end product on the display is an \textbf{energy spectrum} of the sample. Peaks in the energy spectrum correspond to the characteristic energies at which the sample is emitting alpha particles, beta particles, or gamma rays. Even though particles and rays are emitted from the sample almost mono energetically, the spectrum shows significant spreading around the peaks. %Peaks from decays are inherently wide because of the effect of neutrinos.

%	This spreading of beta and gamma ray peaks happens because the emitted particles are subject to other processes on the way between the emitter and the detector and because the detector electronics and the PHA do not treat each electrical pulse in a perfectly uniform manner. Gamma rays are inherently penetrating, so it is quite likely that a  ray can pass through the detector leaving behind only a fraction of its energy. This fraction varies from event to event, with the end result of a widened peak about some centered value.

%The spreading phenomenon for alpha particles is even more prominent than in beta and gamma particles. 
Alpha particles are easily attenuated such that a sheet of paper is sufficient to completely block them. 
Therefore the thickness of the sample can have a large effect on the energy of the ejected alpha particle. 
Alpha particles emitted from within a sample can lose a portion of their energy before they escape the surface. 
This causes a spreading of the peaks and it is for this reason that only trace amounts of radium are used, minimizing the sample's thickness.
Further peak spreading can also occur from the interaction of the alpha particles with the air between the sample and the detector. 
To minimize this effect the chamber is put under vacuum.

\subsection{Decay Chains}

	Radium decays to another element which is in turn unstable and so decays further. It turns out that this sequence of decays extends through about ten different elements before finally culminating in an element that is stable. The other isotopes in the decay chain of radium are called \textbf{daughter products}. This means that any sample of radium left for any length of time automatically becomes contaminated with several other elements, even if it was pure to begin with. So, in order to study the energy spectrum of radium 226 and nothing else, the sample must be purified. Fortunately, the isolation of radium undertaken in this experiment is considerably easier to perform than the four years of arduous effort the Curies undertook to do it the first time.

	Radioactive decay is a process of \textbf{transmutation}. After a decay, the actual element remaining has changed to a \textbf{different} element. This means that radium can be \textbf{chemically separated} from the element that it decays into and all the other daughter products. Radium is a group 2 metal. So chemically, it acts like barium or calcium. Moreover, all the other natural group 2 metals are stable and no isotope of any other group 2 metal appears in the decay chain of radium. This means that any chemical process that preferentially isolates group 2 metals will succeed in separating radium from all of its daughter isotopes. If such a chemical procedure is performed on a sample that once contained only radium, then the result will be a sample whose only remaining radioactive constituent is pure radium. At least for a short while.

	A spectrum of this sample can be taken to observe the radioactivity of radium 226. The theory of radioactive decay predicts that the radium should decay into another element. If this element in turn is unstable it should also decay. This process continues until an isotope is reached that is stable. Eventually an equilibrium should be reached where the radium 226 decay and all the daughter decays are present.

	In this experiment spectra are first taken with calibrated sources of known energy to establish an accurate energy scale on the display. Next, a pure radium 226 sample is prepared and an initial spectrum is taken immediately after preparation. This should yield the energy or energies for the decay of radium alone. Lastly, the spectrometer is left to continue acquiring the spectrum for at least another 24 hours. This should be sufficient time to record the decays of all the other daughter products of radium. The peaks in these spectra can be compared against tables that contain the currently known and accepted decay modes and energies of each isotope. These tables can also be used to determine the sequence of reactions that radium decay follows all the way down to the final stable daughter isotope.

\vspace{12pt}

\textbf{Preparation of the radium 226 sample}
\\
\\
	From a safety point of view, this experiment requires \textbf{special precautions} because the radioactive sample is \textbf{not sealed}. So there is a danger of contamination unless proper procedures are followed. If unsure about anything refer to the \textbf{Radiation Safety in the Undergraduate Physics Labs} document or seek the help of the TA. \textbf{Please observe the following precautions as you follow the chemical procedure described below:} 
        
        \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*),noitemsep]
        {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item \textit{Wear latex gloves, a laboratory coat, and goggles at all times.}}
        {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item \textit{Do not leave the lab wearing said gloves or laboratory coat.}}
        {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item \textit{Perform all operations inside the plastic trays.}}
        {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item \textit{Do not let the stirring rod touch anything except the inside of the beaker.}}
        {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item \textit{Do not let the eye droppers touch anything except their own sample bottle.}}
        {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item \textit{Mouth pipetting is forbidden.}}
        {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item \textit{Rinse the beaker, graduated cylinder, and stirring rod with distilled water after use.}}
        {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item \textit{Put all disposable solids into the solid radioactive waste beaker.}}
        {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item \textit{Put all left over liquid from rinsing and filtering in the liquid radioactive waste bottle.}}
        {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item \textit{Do not touch the surface of the sample with anything.}}
        {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item \textit{Make sure to thoroughly wash your hands after completing the experiment and before consuming any food.}}
       \end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}
\item Place 5 mL of the radium salt solution into a 25 mL beaker. While stirring with a rod, add 2 drops (no more!) of Ba(NO$_3$)$_2$ solution and 10 drops of K$_2$SO$_4$ solution. Allow the solution to stand for 5 minutes while stirring gently every 10 seconds or so. The BaSO$_4$ will start precipitating out making the solution slightly cloudy. The BaSO$_4$ crystal lattices are slightly impregnated with radium and its decay products.

\item Add 2 mL of disodium-EDTA and NH$_4$OH solution and stir for 1 minute. The cloudiness of the mixture should disappear. If not, keep stirring for 5 more minutes. If the mixture is still cloudy add another mL of disodium-EDTA. This process isolates radium from its decay products. To recover the BaSO$_4$ precipitate, (which will have radium atoms in some of its vacancies and interstitials) add 2 mL of concentrated acetic acid. Using the indicator paper, confirm a pH level of about 4. If the indicator paper does not show adequate acidity, add more acid, carefully, in small quantities.

\item Wait 15 minutes, stirring occasionally. The next step is to pass the solution through a fine filter to keep the solid material while removing the liquids. Note that the filter is \textbf{white} while the non-porous spacer is \textbf{blue}. The filter apparatus is shown in Figure~\ref{fig:ndRadium}. While waiting, set up the filter funnel and check that nothing leaks around the sides by pouring in some distilled water. Usually, if there is a leak, it is because the filter paper is not properly centered over the screen. Once it is ready, pour the contents of the beaker into the funnel. After a few minutes, the solution should be dripping through the filter. If the drip rate is too slow, vacuum may slowly be applied. If the solution does not seem to be dripping double check to make sure a spacer wasn't used in place of a filter. After the solution has run through, rinse the inside of the funnel with distilled water and apply vacuum to remove the last traces of liquid.

\item While the sample is dripping through the filter, spread some white glue onto a plastic sample disk. When the sample is ready, very carefully remove the filter and glue it onto the plastic disk. \ul{Do NOT touch the surface}. Use the supplied tweezers as a spatula to move the filter onto the disk from underneath without touching the top. This is the radium 226 source. Allow the sample to dry. Place a table lamp over it to speed up the drying process. The radium sample is now ready to be placed into the spectrometer and measured. Again, when transferring the disk to the sample chamber, do \textbf{not} touch the filter surface and do \textbf{not} let the filter surface touch anything. Rinse the beaker, graduated cylinder, and stirring rod with some distilled water after the sample preparation is completed. The rinse water and the filtered liquid must both be poured into the liquid radioactive waste bottle. Any solid wastes like the pH paper and the gloves should be left in the solid radioactive waste container.
\end{enumerate}

\section{Experimental Procedure}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Turn on the spectrometer using the power switch at the back of the unit. Notice that there are two detector chambers referred to as inputs 1 and 2 from left to right, respectively. Turn the computer on and start the Maestro PHA software unless it is already running. Make sure the spectrum window corresponds to the chamber that will be used. If not, the appropriate chamber can be selected via the drop-down menu in the top tool-bar. Turn on the vacuum pump connected to the spectrometer.
%The spectrum area can be cleared by choosing the \textit{Clear} item from the \textit{Acquire} menu. Erase any previous energy calibrations by going to \textit{Calibration} under the \textit{Calculate} menu and clicking on the \textit{Destroy Calibration} button in the resulting pop-up window. Next,  

%Before collecting data, the chamber pressure and detector bias settings must be set. To adjust these settings open the \textit{MCB Properties} window under the \textit{Acquire} menu. The chamber pressure settings are under the \textit{Alpha} tab. Use the drop-down menu to select whether to vent, pump down or maintain the pressure of the chamber. When pumping down the chambers make sure the \textit{Vacuum Monitoring} box is checked. Note that both chambers are connected so they will vent and pump down at the same time, therefore make sure that both chamber doors are closed when pumping down the pressure. The detector bias can be turned on and off under the \textit{High Voltage} tab. Before turning the bias on, make sure that the \textit{Target} box reads 60 Volts. The following precautions need to be observed when using this detector:

%        \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*),noitemsep]
%          {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{\ul{Always set the detector bias to zero before pumping down or venting the chamber(s).}}}
%          {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{\ul{Do not expose a biased detector to light as it overflows the detector amplifier.}}}
%          {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{\ul{Never store a source in the sample chamber(s) except when taking a spectrum.}}}
%        \end{enumerate}
        
\item The following procedure should be used whenever inserting or removing a sample into the sample chamber:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*),noitemsep]
    {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{{Put the source into the chamber without touching the detector or the sides and close the chamber door.}}}
    {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{{The chamber pressure settings are adjusted under the \textbf{Alpha} tab in the \textbf{MCB Properties} window. To pump the chamber down, set the target pressure to \textbf{300 mTorr}, set the vent/pump drop-down menu to pump and check the vacuum monitoring box.}}}
    {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{{Wait until the chamber pressure stabilizes around the target pressure.}}}
    {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{{To adjust the detector bias voltage, click the \textbf{Acquire} menu and open the \textbf{MCB Properties} window. Under the \textbf{High Voltage} tab, turn the detector bias on making sure the target box reads {\bf 60V}.}}}
    {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{{To begin collecting data, click the green "Go" button in the top tool-bar on the far left. Similarly, to stop collecting data click the red "Stop" button.}}}
    {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{{After acquiring a spectrum, turn the detector bias off, unclick the vacuum monitoring box and set the vent/pump drop-down menu to vent. }}}
    {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{{Wait until the pressure equalizes before opening the chamber door to retrieve source.}}}
  \end{enumerate}
        
\item Do an energy calibration of the spectrometer with the $^{239}$Pu-$^{241}$Am-$^{244}$Cm triple source and the $^{230}$Th source. Always handle alpha sources by grabbing the edges and make sure to never touch the top or bottom. Place this source disk onto the sample holder and slide it into one of the top spots making sure it does not come into contact with anything. Note that the calibration is specific to one shelf, therefore all future sources must be placed on the same shelf. Acquire a spectrum for the triple source and thorium source for about five minutes. Calibrate the spectrum using the three largest peaks of the triple source and the two largest peaks of the $^{230}$Th  source. The triple source energies are 5156.59 keV ($^{239}$Pu), 5544 keV ($^{241}$Am), and 5804.82 keV ($^{244}$Cm) and the two $^{230}$Th  peaks are 4621.2 keV and 4687.7 keV. The calibration procedure is as follows:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*),noitemsep]
    {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{Erase any previous energy calibrations by going to the \textit{Calculate} menu, selecting \textit{Calibration} and then clicking on the \textit{Destroy Calibration} button in the resulting pop-up window.}}
    {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{Acquire the triple source spectrum. The three largest peaks correspond to the three energies stated in the paragraph above. Select a channel close to the apex of the first peak, go to the ROI menu and click on "Mark Peak". The peak will turn red indicating that it is a Region of Interest (ROI). Select a channel within this ROI, go to the \textit{Calculate} menu select \textit{Calibration} and input the corresponding energy of that peak. The program will automatically select the channel of the apex. Do this for the remaining two peaks of the triple source. Once the triple source peaks are calibrated create a ROI Report under the \textit{File} menu, save the spectrum, clear it, clear the ROI's and acquire the $^{230}$Th  spectrum. }}
    {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{Calibrate the two $^{230}$Th  peaks using the same procedure used for the triple source.}}
    {\setlength\itemindent{25pt}\item\textit{Once the $^{230}$Th  peaks are calibrated, create a ROI Report, save the spectrum, clear the ROI's and clear the spectrum. The detector is now calibrated for the analysis of your $^{226}$Ra sample.}}
  \end{enumerate}

\item For all spectra taken with this experiment, remember to save a copy of the spectrum in a computer file for later analysis. As a consistency check of the energy calibration, measure the spectra of the polonium 210 source which emits $\alpha$ particles at an energy of 5304.38 keV.

\item Prepare the $^{226}$Ra sample and obtain an initial spectrum of about ten minutes duration. 

\item Continue gathering data for at least another 24 hours to yield a final spectrum.

\item When measurements are completed dispose of the radium sample into the solid waste container. Do not leave any sources in the sample chamber.

\item Perform any \ul{one} of the following investigations.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\Alph*.,]
    \item Explain how to use your final radium spectrum to estimate the mass of radium present in the sample. Determine how many picograms of radium are in the sample.
    \item As a rule of thumb, although there are exceptions, the larger the energy of decay the shorter the half-life. For all the alpha sources used in this experiment, plot alpha energy versus half life. Does the graph suggest any correlation between half life and energy? Is the relationship linear (straight line), logarithmic (straight line on a log graph) or does a power law (straight line on a log-log graph) fit the data best?
    \item Explain how to use the final radium spectrum to estimate the activity of the sample. Find the activity of your sample in both Curies and Becquerels.
    \item Treat your peaks as statistical distributions and compute the mean, variance, and skewness of one of them. Compare your directly measured standard deviation to the one inferred from the FWHM. Compare your skewness to the expected skewness of a Gaussian which is zero.
    \item The $^{230}$Th  source has a calibrated activity of 5.89 nCi. Using your $^{230}$Th  spectrum, estimate the actual activity of the source and compare it to the expected value. Discuss possible reasons for any discrepancies.
    \item Some of the isotopes in the decay chain of radium 226 (including radium 226 itself) can decay in more than one way. Using the Firestone isotope tables, trace the decay chain in more detail. Identify some of the rarer decay schemes that have been observed to happen. Some of these decay modes are exotic enough that they are not mentioned in your textbook.
    \item The half life of radium 226 is thousands of years. The half life of all the other daughters is comparatively short, a few days at most. In this situation, the rate of production of the daughters is ultimately limited by the much slower rate of decay of the radium parent. Here, it is expected that the concentration of each daughter should approach a constant value. This phenomenon is called \textbf{secular equilibrium}. The hypothesis of secular equilibrium can be tested by recording the height of a peak versus time to see whether it actually approaches a constant value. For one of the daughter peaks, record at least six peak heights over a period of two or three days. Plot a graph of peak height versus time. Present your conclusions on whether the peak height appears to be approaching a constant value or not.
    \end{enumerate}
  \end{enumerate}


\section{Uncertainty Analysis}
The largest source of uncertainty in energy measurements of $\alpha$ particles is the width of the peaks caused by the attenuation of the $\alpha$ particles before hitting the detector. This results in a peak that is wide and rounded instead of narrow and sharp. A standard method of assigning error to a peak in a radiation spectrum is to use the \textbf{full width half maximum}, or \textbf{FWHM} as seen in Figure \ref{fig:ndGaussian}.

\begin{marginfigure}%fig3
  \begin{tikzpicture}[scale=0.8]
    \pgfplotsset{ticks=none}
    \newcommand\gauss[2]{1/(#2*sqrt(2*pi))*exp(-((x-#1)^2)/(2*#2^2))} % Gauss function, parameters mu and sigma
    \begin{axis}[every axis plot post/.append style={
          mark=none,domain=-3:5,samples=50,smooth}, % All plots: from -3:5, 50 samples, smooth, no marks
        axis lines=none
      ]
      \addplot[color=black,thick] {\gauss{1}{0.9}};
    \end{axis}
    %coordinate system
    \draw[->,very thin] (0.4,0.45) -- (6.75,0.45); 
    \draw[->,very thin] (0.4,0.45) -- (0.4,6);
    %labels
    \node[right] at (-0.25,5.25) {H};
    \draw[-,ultra thin] (0.25,5.25)--(6,5.25);
    \node[right] at (-0.6,2.62){H/2};
    \draw[-,ultra thin] (0.25,2.62)--(6,2.62);
    \node[right] at (3.2,-0.25){E};
    \draw[-,ultra thin] (3.42,0)--(3.42,1.8);
    \draw[-,ultra thin] (3.42,2.3)--(3.42,5.75);
    \node[right] at (2.72,2){FWHM};
    \draw[-triangle 60] (3.42,2.62)--(2.6,2.62);
    \draw[-triangle 60] (3.42,2.62)--(4.3,2.62);
    \node[right] at (3.35,3.4){$\Delta$E};
    \draw[<->] (3.43,3.1)--(4.11,3.1);
  \end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Gaussian Distribution}
  \label{fig:ndGaussian}
\end{marginfigure}

	Suppose an energy peak has height H. Then the FWHM of a peak is the width of the peak at half height or H/2. If the peak is Gaussian, then the error in the energy of that peak, $u(E)$, can be taken to be the standard deviation, $\sigma$, of the peak. For a Gaussian distribution this is given by

\begin{equation}
\Delta E = \sigma = \frac{FWHM}{2.35}
\label{equ:ndGaussian}
\end{equation}

	Strictly speaking, the peaks in this experiment are not Gaussian because alpha particle peaks tend to have tails on the low energy side and peaks can also overlap. Nevertheless, the FWHM technique is still a reasonable approximation for the error in the energy of the peak. Often peaks overlap or are superimposed on some other background. For these situations, the procedure is to subtract away the other peaks and the background so that the peak rides on the zero line as seen in Figure \ref{fig:ndGaussian}. This extra procedure is not needed for this experiment because the extra accuracy gained thereby is unimportant here.

	No further error analysis of the data in this experiment is required except for the error in the energy, which should be determined by the FWHM method described here.

\section{Discussion}
\begin{enumerate}[resume]
  \item Identify and label all of the peaks measured by the alpha spectrometer. Using a Chart of the Nuclides, the CRC handbook, or the Firestone isotope tables, list the possible decays undergone by the prepared $^{226}$Ra source and its daughter nuclides. It is sufficient to restrict your attention to only the decay of highest probability at each step. Calculate theoretical Q values for the alpha decays and compare these with your measured values. Remember that Q values are different from the kinetic energy of the alpha particle because of recoil of the nucleus. Label the final $^{226}$Ra spectrum based on your identification of the isotopes undergoing alpha decay. For each daughter product, determine whether the element is a solid, liquid, or gas at room temperature.
  \item Discuss any \ul{two} of the following items.
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\Alph*.]
      \item Why is it necessary to evacuate the chamber in which the source is positioned for measurement? Why is it more practical to place a radioactive sample underneath a detector facing up, rather than above a detector and facing down?
      \item The PHA records the energy of the alpha particle along the x-axis. What is recorded along the y-axis? What factors affect the height of a peak measured by the spectrometer?
      \item Other decays besides alpha decay are occurring as the $^{226}$Ra and daughter nuclides decay. Explain why the occurrences of these decays are not recorded by the PHA.
      \item Radium has a long half life on the order of thousands of years. All the unstable daughter products of radium have much shorter half lives on the order of days or hours. This implies that the rate of production of each of the daughters is limited to the rate at which radium decays. In practice, after a week or two, the concentration of all the daughters should be the same. However, what happens in this apparatus is that the first peak (the decay of radium into radon) ends up being more than twice as large as all the other peaks and the remaining peaks are the same height. Why does this happen?
      \item Judging from the initial spectrum, discuss how well the chemical separation of the radium from its daughters worked.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Discuss the results of the optional part of the experiment.
\end{enumerate}

\chapter{Photoelectric Effect}%\label{Photo}

\section{Equipment}

\begin{minipage}{0.5\textwidth}
\begin{itemize}[noitemsep]
\item Leybold Photocell
\item Jarrell Ash Monochromator
