\section{Preparation}

	You should review Einstein's explanation of the photoelectric effect. Review the band theory of conduction in metals, and the diffraction of light.

\section{Goals of the Experiment}

	To investigate some properties of the photoelectric effect and photocells. To get some experience with low level current measurements. To better understand optical spectra by using a monochromator and a Tungsten-Halogen lamp as a line source.

\section{Theory}

	The \textbf{photoelectric effect} is one example of an interaction between energy and matter. In the photoelectric effect, a material is illuminated with a beam of light and electrons are ejected from the material. These emitted electrons are called \textbf{photoelectrons}. This effect occurs in any material, whether solid, liquid, or gas. The photoelectric effect was first noticed by Heinrich Hertz (1857-1894) in 1887 when he observed that shining ultraviolet light into the region between a spark gap raised the conductivity of the air in the gap. Later experiments showed that shining ultraviolet light onto a metallic plate gave it a positive charge. In 1898 Philipp Lenard (1862-1947) and J. J. Thompson (1856-1940) showed that the particles being emitted were actually electrons. Lenard later won the 1905 Nobel prize in physics for his work on electrons. Thompson won the 1906 Nobel prize for his related work on the conduction of gases. As described below, the photoelectric effect has many properties that simply cannot be accounted for by a wave theory of light. In 1900, to partly explain the effect, Max Planck (1858-1947) suggested that an atom could only absorb or emit energy in discrete bundles called \textbf{quanta}. He was later honoured with the 1918 Nobel prize for this insight. It was left to Albert Einstein (1879-1955) in 1905 to fully explain the photoelectric effect using Planck's ideas. Einstein's theory of the photoelectric effect explains all the observed properties of the photoelectric effect. He won the 1921 Nobel prize for this work. Einstein's theory of photoelectricity was experimentally verified by Robert Millikan (1868-1953) in 1916 in a series of careful measurements that also accurately determined Planck's constant for the first time. This work earned Millikan a Nobel prize in 1923. The physics experiment to be done here is in fact similar in method and construction to Millikan's prize winning experiment.

	If one assumes that the photoelectric interaction is simply a light wave phenomenon then several conclusions follow immediately. The wave theory predicts that the energy of the emitted electrons is proportional to the square of the light frequency. Also, there should be photoelectrons at any wavelength, if the light is intense enough. Third, the electron energy should be proportional to the light intensity. Fourth, the electrons should be emitted with a large delay that depends on the light intensity and the illumination area. Lastly, the amount of electrons knocked off should be proportional to the size of the atom and hence to the amount of surface exposed to the light.

	Experimental measurements of the photoelectric effect show that \textbf{none} of these properties are true. The energy of the photoelectrons varies \textbf{linearly} with frequency. Below a critical frequency, \textbf{no} photoelectrons are emitted regardless of the light intensity. Furthermore, the photelectron energy is \textbf{independent} of the light intensity and the illumination area. Lastly, there is essentially \textbf{no delay} between the arrival of light and the emission of photoelectrons, regardless of the light intensity and illumination area.

	Einstein explained the photoelectric effect by supposing that the energy of electromagnetic radiation is carried in discrete bundles called \textbf{photons}.  The energy, $E$, of a photon is given by

\begin{equation}
E = hf
\label{equ:pePhotonEnergy}
\end{equation}

where $f$ is the frequency of the light and $h$ is Planck's constant. The currently accepted value for Planck's constant is $6.6261\times10^{-34}$ $J\cdot s$. Equation \ref{equ:pePhotonEnergy} implies that higher frequency light like ultraviolet radiation is more energetic than lower frequency light such as infrared light. Each photon can only give up a discrete amount of energy, $E$, to an electron. Suppose that the electron is bound to the material with energy $W$. This is then the amount of energy needed to liberate an electron from the surface of a material. $W$ is called the \textbf{work function} of the material. Any extra energy is transformed into kinetic energy of the photoelectron.

	The energy balance equation for the incoming photon versus the outgoing photoelectron is

\begin{equation}
hf = W + K
\label{equ:peEnergyBalance}
\end{equation}

where $K$ is the kinetic energy of the photoelectron. Therefore, a photoelectron has kinetic energy given by

\begin{equation}
K = hf - W
\label{equ:pePhotoelectronKineticEnergy}
\end{equation}

	This equation handily explains all the observed features of the photoelectric effect. There is a lower limit below which the light generates no photoelectrons because a photon with energy less than $W$ does not have enough energy to liberate an electron from the surface of the material. If the photon does have sufficient energy (high enough frequency), an electron is knocked loose as soon as a photon interacts with it. This explains why the emission of photoelectrons is nearly simultaneous with the arrival of the illuminating light. Also, Equation \ref{equ:pePhotoelectronKineticEnergy} shows directly why the energy of a photoelectron varies linearly with the illuminating light frequency. Lastly, Equation \ref{equ:pePhotoelectronKineticEnergy} shows that the energy of a photoelectron is independent of light intensity. When a bright light illuminates a surface, many more electrons are knocked out of the surface because there are more photons, but each photoelectron has the kinetic energy specified by Equation \ref{equ:pePhotoelectronKineticEnergy}. Brighter illumination induces a higher \textbf{photocurrent}, simply because more photoelectrons are in motion.

	The arrangement used for examining the photoelectric effect is shown in Figure \ref{fig:pePhotocell}. Light is made to shine on a potassium surface called the \textbf{photocathode}. Photoelectrons are ejected from this surface and collected by the nearby platinum ring called the \textbf{anode}. The work function of potassium is 2.30 eV and the work function of platinum is 5.65 eV. This means light with a wavelength longer than about 540 nm will not eject electrons from either the platinum or the potassium. Light with a wavelength shorter than 220 nm will begin to eject photoelectrons from the anode as well as the photocathode. This gives a window from 540 nm to 220 nm in which photoelectrons are ejected from the photocathode alone. This is the wavelength range for which Equation \ref{equ:pePhotoelectronKineticEnergy} can be examined. The anode and photocathode are in vacuum so the  photoelectrons do not lose energy except at the anode.

          \end{tikzpicture}
          \caption{Photocell}
          \label{fig:pePhotocell}
        \end{figure}
	 The emission of electrons from the photocathode (photocurrent) is detected by the electrometer. An \textbf{electrometer} is basically an extremely sensitive current meter. The anode voltage polarity opposes the arrival of photoelectrons. The energy of the photoelectrons is found by raising the anode voltage to the point where the photocurrent stops. If the illuminating light is monochromatic, this \textbf{stopping potential} , $V_s$, gives a determination for the kinetic energy of the photoelectrons so that

\begin{equation}
V_s = \frac{h}{e}f - \frac{W}{e}
\label{equ:peStoppingPotential}
\end{equation}

	Since $e = 1.6022\times10^{-19}$ C, plotting stopping voltage versus illumination frequency gives a value for Planck's constant from the slope of the line. The arrangement of Figure 1 also permits experimental verification that stopping voltage (kinetic energy) is independent of light intensity but the photocurrent (as measured by the electrometer) is strongly dependent on the light intensity. It is also possible to verify that below a certain critical frequency, no photocurrent is stimulated regardless of light level.

	Equation \ref{equ:pePhotoelectronKineticEnergy} suggests that the intercept of the graph yields the work function of the potassium photocathode, $Wc$. A more careful examination indicates that this is incorrect. Both the cathode and the anode are made from metals. This means the outer shell electrons inside the metal partially fill an energy band called the \textbf{conduction band}. The highest energy level in the conduction band with an electron in it is called the \textbf{Fermi energy}. At absolute zero there are no electrons above the Fermi energy and all energy levels below the Fermi energy are completely filled with electrons. At higher temperatures this boundary is not sharp as many electrons move to higher levels on thermal energy alone. The fact the the Fermi energy lies in the middle of the conduction band explains why the metal is a good conductor. There are many nearby unfilled energy levels available for the electrons to occupy.

	To fully remove an electron, a surface needs more energy than just the Fermi energy. The aggregate attraction of the complete metallic lattice prevents the electron from being free even when removed from the conduction band. The extra required energy to completely free an electron from the surface is called the \textbf{surface barrier energy}. The surface barrier energy depends greatly on the exact nature of the surface. Impurities, trace gases, and crystal structure all affect the surface barrier energy and hence the perceived work function of the material. The work function for a metal is the sum of the Fermi energy and the surface barrier energy. Figure \ref{fig:peEnergyLevels} shows an energy level diagram for the conduction electrons in the metallic cathode and anode. The retarding voltage applied to the anode determines the potential difference between the Fermi levels in the anode and photocathode. As shown in Figure \ref{fig:peEnergyLevels}, this is \textbf{not} the retarding potential seen by a photoelectron travelling between cathode and anode.

  \caption{Energy Levels\\0) Photon Arrives\\1) Photoelectron overcomes cathode Fermi energy\\2) Photoelectron overcomes cathode surface barrier\\3) Photoelectron overcomes stopping potential V'\\4) Photoelectron attracted by surface potential\\5) Electron moves into the conduction band}
  \label{fig:peEnergyLevels}
\end{marginfigure}

	To find the true retarding potential as seen by a photoelectron, let $V_s'$ be the true stopping potential and $V_s$ be the potential as seen by the voltmeter. Then from Figure \ref{fig:peEnergyLevels}

\begin{equation}
V_s ' = V_s + \frac{W_a}{e} - \frac{W_c}{e}
\label{equ:peTrueStoppingPotential}
\end{equation}

and Equation \ref{equ:peStoppingPotential} is really

\begin{equation}
V_s ' = \frac{h}{e}f - \frac{W_c}{e}
\label{equ:peTrueStoppingPotentialCathode}
\end{equation}

As seen by the voltmeter this is

\begin{equation}
V_s  =  \frac{h}{e}f - \frac{W_a}{e}
\label{equ:peStoppingPotentialAnode}
\end{equation}

	The above discussion suggests that the measured intercept should be regarded with some suspicion. However, the slope determination is not affected. It also suggests that the transition of the photocurrent to zero as the stopping potential is increased will be gradual rather than abrupt because the photoelectrons arise from a population of conduction electrons with widely varying energies. Some electrons will manage to cross from cathode to anode on thermal energy alone. This is \textbf{thermionic emission}. Since this current flows even without light, it is also called \textbf{dark current}. At room temperature the dark current is very small. 

	Another obscuring phenomenon is that over time the anode ring becomes contaminated with cathode material. Now the anode will also emit photoelectrons when illuminated. This is rectified by heating the anode until it begins to glow light red. Both ends of the anode are connected to an Anatek power supply capable of delivering 2 Amperes. Note that under normal operation one side of the anode is left unconnected. The procedure should be done in a darkened room while carefully observing the anode. The entire process does not last longer than 15 seconds. This procedure can only be carried out by qualified lab staff.

\end{scope}
\begin{scope}[very thick,decoration={markings,mark=at position 0.25 with {\arrow{>}}}]%arrow position
\draw[ultra thin,postaction={decorate}] (0.4,4.5) -- (4.35,3.5);%path1
\draw[ultra thin,postaction={decorate}] (4.35,3.5) -- (0.3,2);%path1
\draw[ultra thin,postaction={decorate}] (0.3,2) -- (4.2,0.9);%path1
\draw[ultra thin,postaction={decorate}] (4.15,4.025) -- (0.3,3);%path2
\draw[ultra thin,postaction={decorate}] (0.3,3) -- (4,2);%path2
\draw[ultra thin,postaction={decorate}] (4,2) -- (0.4,0.5);%path2
\end{scope}
%labels
\node[right] at (0.75,6.25) {\small{Input White Light}};%label
\node[right] at (0.75,6) {\small{(Hot Tungsten-Halogen)}};%label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (3.2,6) -- (3.55 ,5.8);%pointer
\node[right] at (0.5,5) {\small{50 micron Entrance Slit}};%label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (3,5) -- (3.5,5.2);%pointer
\node[right] at (5,2.5) {\small{Tiltable reflection grating}};%label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (5,2.5) -- (4.5,2.9);%pointer
\node[right] at (5,4) {\small{45 degree mirror}};%label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (5,4) -- (4.5,4);%pointer
\node[right] at (5,0.5) {\small{45 degree mirror}};%label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (5,0.5) -- (4.8,0.5);%pointer
\node[right] at (0,0) {\small{Main parabolic mirror}};%label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (1,0.1) -- (0.2,0.5);%pointer
\node[right] at (1.5,-0.3) {\small{50 micron exit slit}};%label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (3,-0.2) -- (3.5,-0.1);%pointer
\node[right] at (1,-0.6) {\small{Output monochromatic light}};%label
\draw[ultra thin,->] (3.6,-0.5) -- (4.1,-0.4);%pointer
  \end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Light path of the monochromator}
  \label{fig:peLightPath}
\end{figure}


	The photocell must be illuminated with monochromatic light for meaningful results. The method chosen for generating such light in this experiment is called a \textbf{monochromator}. It has the advantage that a large number of frequencies can be easily generated. This permits a careful examination of Equation \ref{equ:peStoppingPotentialAnode}. The light path of the monochromator is shown in Figure \ref{fig:peLightPath}. In effect, it is a reflection grating spectrometer that is connected backwards. It generates monochromatic light from a source instead of analyzing one frequency of light from a source as a spectrometer would. The source used is an ordinary Tungsten-Halogen lamp. This lamp generates light from the far infrared into the ultraviolet. To select a given wavelength, a knob rotates the grating. Special gears couple this rotation to a display that reads out the wavelength chosen in nanometers. The output from the monochromator is not truly monochromatic. The output spectral width is roughly 1 nanometer.

	The photocurrents to be measured in this experiment are on the order of picoamperes ($10^{-12}$ Amperes). At these low current levels, special precautions must be taken to obtain valid measurements. Materials that are normally considered to be insulators become conductors instead. The reason is because a source of picoampere current at one volt potential has an effective resistance of $10^{12}\ \Omega$. This resistance is comparable to the resistance of many common insulators such as paper, rubber, and plastic. Instead of insulating the circuit, these materials act like ordinary resistors and become part of the circuit. 

	To help with low current measurements, the wiring should be as short a possible. This minimizes the amount of insulator present and reduces the area available for noise pickup. The electrometer is designed with this in mind. The sensing preamplifier head is separate from the rest of the instrument. In this way the sensing head can be placed very close to the source to be measured using short cables. The photocell cathode is directly connected to the electrometer sensor head with a short 20 cm cable.

	Materials under mechanical motion or stress exhibit charge imbalances that manifest themselves as currents. These are called \textbf{piezoelectric effects}. Frictional effects such as when two materials rub against each other also produce charge displacements. These are called \textbf{triboelectric effects}. To eliminate these sources of error, motion, vibration, and mechanical stress must be prevented in all components, connections, and wiring. 

	Very high resistance materials like sapphire, quartz, and Teflon should be used where possible. These have volumetric resistances on the order of $10^{17}\ \Omega$. The electrometer head is insulated with sapphire. However, \textbf{cleanliness} is important. Contaminants such as dust, moisture, grease, fingerprints, and salt provide paths for \textbf{surface leakage currents}. Do \textbf{not touch} circuit components or wires by hand. Use a tissue or rubber gloves instead.

	Lastly, reduce stray electrical fields by reducing air currents and the motion of nearby people. Articles that generate strong static electric fields like sweaters, furs, coats, or long hair should be removed from the low current measurement area.


\section{Experimental Procedure}

{\bf Note: The room lights must remain off for the duration of this experiment.}

\begin{enumerate}
\item The first step is to initialize and check the electrometer. No adjustments are needed on the remote preamplifier near the photocell. Short the input by engaging the input shorting switch (this is the up position). This switch is useful for momentarily turning off the meter input when experimental adjustments need to be made. Turn on the unit by setting the function switch to the + current setting. Allow a warm up time of 10 minutes. The electrometer measures currents by reading the voltage across one of three large resistors whose values are specified on the instrument cover. Under normal experimental conditions only R2 is required, except for measuring 10 nA where R1 is needed. Set the input resistor switch to R2. The meter movement and the range switch determine the voltage measured across R2. The current is then found simply from Ohm's law. Turn the range switch to the 1 V range. After the instrument has warmed up, adjust the zero controls until the meter reads zero on the 1 mV range with the input shorted. Put the range switch back to 1 V to reduce the chance of an overflow. Using a tissue (not hands) disconnect the photocell cable from the input and connect the 10 nA current source instead. Measure the current output from each of the three current sources using the electrometer. The current is measured by turning off the shorting switch and reducing the range switch until the meter registers the largest voltage possible without going out of range. If the three current readings are within the correct orders of magnitude as specified on the current source then the electrometer is operating properly. Reconnect the photocell cable (remember, no fingerprints). Always leave the input shorting switch engaged except when taking a measurement.

\item Turn on and check the adjustable stopping potential. Turn on the multimeter and the power supply. Set the power supply to 10.0 V. This voltage remains unchanged for the rest of the experiment. Check that the meter reads the output of the decade divider correctly and that each knob alters the reading by 1 V, 0.1 V, and 0.01 V. Set all knobs on the divider to zero.

\item The monochromator is aligned and adjusted correctly. No adjustments are necessary. Do not bump, jar, or move the monochromator. However a performance test is always appropriate. Power up the laser and shine it into the entrance slit. The laser wavelength is 632.8 nm. Rotate the grating until the laser light is visible at the exit slit. Take note of the monochromator reading of the laser line. This serves as a monochromator offset calibration which should be used for all later measurements. Remove the laser and slide the Tungsten-Halogen lamp forward until it touches the monochromator input slit. Turn on the lamp. The variac voltage for the lamp must be set at 110 V, any higher and the lamp will burn out. With the room lights off, check that the colours visible from the exit slit are consistent with the monochromator wavelength reading. The experiment is now ready for operation.

\item %With the room lights off and the photocell still covered, d
Determine the current being emitted by the photocell. It may be negative, in which case the -current setting is required. This gives a baseline zero reading for the darkened photocell. You may want to think about what this current might be if there is one.

\item These measurements will have to be made in darkness. A small flashlight is used to read and operate the electrometer, divider, multimeter, and monochromator. Keep the flashlight beam away from the photocell. 
%Rotate the photocell cover so that it is open. 
For as many wavelengths as you feel are necessary (at least 12), take measurements of the stopping potential of light with wavelengths ranging from 420 nm to 600 nm. Use a consistent criterion to detect when the photocurrent has stopped. The best method is to simply adjust the divider until the needle reads zero, without changing the range setting of the electrometer. The Fluke multimeter reads out the potential $V_s$. The monochromator dial indicates the wavelength in nm. Notice that the current jumps wildly when people move near the photocell or when the divider is adjusted. The method to use is to make a divider adjustment and then move away and stay still until the electrometer stabilizes. Make further adjustments to the decade divider as required until a zero current reading is obtained. 

\item Perform one of the optional investigations.
\end{enumerate}

\section{Error Analysis}
	As discussed in the theory section, there are many variables that affect the outcome of this experiment which are not under the control of the experimenter. No error analysis for these effects is required. Once the monochromator offset is found using the laser, the maximum wavelength error over the 400 nm to 600 nm range will be $\pm$1.0 nm. Estimate a reasonable error for the stopping potential. This will not be an instrument error. Rather, it will reflect the uncertainty of finding the actual zero current point that represents the stopping potential. For current measurements, the uncertainty is propagated from the voltage uncertainty (half the smallest division on the meter) and the resistor uncertainty. The resistor uncertainty can be estimated from the number of significant figures that specify the resistor values on the cover of the electrometer. For example, two significant figures implies an error on the order of $\pm$5 in the next smaller digit position. The wavelength error and stopping potential error will propagate to an error in the slope from which Planck's constant is found.

\section{Preparation}

	Carefully study the theory section of the experiment and perform the prelab. Review the phenomenon of Rutherford scattering in your textbook.


\section{Goals of the Experiment}

	To investigate Rutherford scattering using both theory and measurement. To gain experience with pulse height analyzers and nuclear pulse counting techniques. To become familiar with a historical experiment that contributed to the development of modern atomic theory.


\section{Theory}
	A beam of alpha particles emitted from some source is directed at a foil target. Measurements have found that a surprisingly large number of the alpha particles experience deflection through large angles. This important discovery led to the adoption of the Rutherford model of the nuclear atom in place of the Thomson model. It is a classic example of progress in physics arising from the interplay between experimental physics and theoretical physics.

	It is possible to develop a mathematical model of \textbf{Rutherford scattering} if a number of assumptions are made. We assume that

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*),noitemsep]
{\setlength\itemindent{14pt}\item The force causing the deflection of the alpha particles is Coulomb repulsion.}
{\setlength\itemindent{14pt}\item The force center and the alpha particle may be treated as points.}
{\setlength\itemindent{14pt}\item Electrons surrounding the nucleus do not affect the alpha particle trajectory.}
{\setlength\itemindent{14pt}\item The force center does not recoil, it is stationary.}
{\setlength\itemindent{14pt}\item Newton's Laws apply, relativity and quantum mechanics can be neglected.}
\end{enumerate}

	In this model, the positively charged alpha particle approaches a positively charged nucleus and changes direction because of electrostatic repulsion. Using the above assumptions it is possible to show that the trajectory of the alpha particle is a hyperbola given by (Fig. \ref{fig:rsTrajectory})

\begin{equation}
\frac{1}{r} = \frac{1}{b} \sin\phi + \frac{(ze)\cdot(Ze)}{8\pi\epsilon_0Kb^2}(\cos\phi - 1)
\label{equ:rsTrajectory}%eq1
\end{equation}

	This hyperbola is expressed in polar coordinates (r,$\phi$). The variable b is called the \textbf{impact parameter} and represents the minimum possible distance of the alpha particle from the nucleus if neither were charged. An impact parameter of zero is a direct collision. The alpha particle has electronic charge ze while the nucleus has charge Ze. Therefore the kinetic energy of the alpha particle, K, must be expressed in electron-volts for the dimensions of Equation \ref{equ:rsTrajectory} to balance.
\begin{marginfigure}
  \centering
  \begin{tikzpicture}
    \draw[very thin] (0,0) -- (6,0);%axis
    \filldraw (4,0) node (v2) {} circle (5pt);%nucleus
    \node[right] at (4,-0.5) {nucleus};%nucleus label
    \draw[ultra thick]  plot[smooth, tension=.7] 
    coordinates {(0,1) (2.5,1) (4.5,2) (6,4)};%trajectory
    \filldraw (1,0.94) node (v1) {} circle (3pt);%alpha particle
    \node[right] at (0,1.5) {$\alpha$ particle};%particle label
    \draw[very thick,-triangle 90] (0.2,1) -- (0.6,0.95);%arrow1
    \draw[very thick] (0,1) -- (0.5,1);%arrow 1 definition
    \draw[very thick,-triangle 90] (5.7,3.5) node (v3) {} 
    -- (6.1,4.2);%arrow2
    \draw[ultra thin,<->] (0.75,0.02) -- (0.75,0.9);%b1 arrow
    \node[right] at (0.25,0.5) {b};%b1 label
    \draw[ultra thin] (v1) -- (v2);%path1
    \node[right] at (2.3,0.7) {r}; %path1 label
    \draw[ultra thin] (2.5,0) arc (180:162:1.5);%angle1
    \node[right] at (2,0.25) {$\phi$};%angle1 label
    \draw[ultra thin] (v2) -- (6.5,3.5);%path2
    \draw[<->,ultra thin] (6.2,3.12) -- (5.7,3.45);%b2 arrow
    \node[right] at (5.9,3.6) {b};%b2 label
    \draw[ultra thin] (5.5,0) arc (0:54:1.5);%angle2
    \node[right] at (4.65,0.4) {$\theta$};%angle2 label
  \end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Trajectory}
  \label{fig:rsTrajectory}
\end{marginfigure}

	If we now consider the final position of the particle by setting r = $\infty$ and  $\phi$ = $\pi$ - $\theta$  then Equation \ref{equ:rsTrajectory} takes the form
	
\begin{equation}
b = \frac{(ze)\cdot(Ze)}{8\pi\epsilon_0K} \cot\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)
\label{equ:rsTrajectoryBounded}%eq2
\end{equation}

	It is not currently possible to monitor the collision between one $\alpha$-particle and one nucleus. A probabilistic approach for handling multiple particles and nuclei is therefore required in order to proceed further.

	Suppose it were possible to make a sheet of material just one atom thick. Then the total area of the sheet, $A_f$, could be approximated by

\begin{equation}
A_f = N\pi R^2
\label{equ:rsSheetArea}%eq3
\end{equation}

where N is the number of atoms in the sheet and R is the radius of a single atom. To an incoming particle each atom would appear as a disk.

\begin{marginfigure}
  \centering
  \begin{tikzpicture}
    %foil surface
    \filldraw (0,0) node (v1) {} circle (2pt);
    \draw[thick] (0,0) ellipse (0.6 and 1);
    \filldraw[thick,pattern=north east lines] (0,0) ellipse (0.3 and .6);
    \draw[thick] (-1.25,0) ellipse (0.6 and 1);
    \draw[thick] (1.25,0) ellipse (0.6 and 1);
    \draw[thick] (-0.65,1.8) ellipse (0.6 and 1);
    \draw[thick] (0.65,1.8) ellipse (0.6 and 1);
    \draw[thick] (-0.65,-1.8) ellipse (0.6 and 1);
    \draw[thick] (0.65,-1.8) ellipse (0.6 and 1);
    %arrows
    \draw[very thick,->] (-3,1.5)--(-1,1.5);
    \draw[very thick,->] (-2.5,2.5)--(0.5,2.5);
    \draw[very thick,->] (-3,-2.5)--(-0.75,-2.5);
    \draw[very thick,->] (-2.5,-1.5)--(0.5,-1.5);
    %
    \draw[ultra thin] (1.9,0) -- (3.5,0);%axis
    \draw[very thick,->] (2,1) node (v4) {} -- (3,2);%exit trajectory
    \draw[ultra thin] (2.5,0) arc (0:65:1);%angle
    \node[right] at (1.8,0.4) {$\theta_0$};%angle label
    \draw[very thick] (0,0.6) -- (-2.5,0.6) node (v2) {};%b_0
    \draw[very thick] (0,0) -- (-2.5,0) node (v3) {};%b_0
    \node[right] at (-3,0.3) {$b_0$};%b_0 label
    \draw[ultra thin,->] (-2.2,1) -- (-2.2,0.65);%b_0 arrow
    \draw[ultra thin,->] (-2.2,-0.5) -- (-2.2,-0.05);%b_0 arrow
    \draw[ultra thin]  plot[smooth, tension=.7] coordinates {(v1) (1,0.3) (v4)};%trajectory
  \end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Trajectory on Foil Surface}
  \label{fig:rsTrajectory2}
\end{marginfigure}

	From Figures \ref{fig:rsTrajectory} and \ref{fig:rsTrajectory2} it can be seen that smaller impact parameters produce greater deflections while larger impact parameters generate lesser deflections. If, for a particular impact parameter $b_0$, the deflection is $\theta_0$, then for scattering angles greater than $\theta_0$ the impact parameters must lie in the range from zero to $b_0$. So all projectiles scattered at angles greater than $\theta_0$ will have approached some atom within a disk of area $\pi b^2$. If the incoming $\alpha$-particles are uniformly distributed over the surface of the foil then the \textbf{fraction} of them that scatter into angles greater than $\theta_0$ must be

\begin{equation}
f_{b<b_0} = f_{\theta>\theta_0}=\frac{\pi b^2}{\pi R^2} =\frac{N}{A_f}\cdot\pi b^2
\label{equ:rsFractionScattered}%eq4
\end{equation}

	A real scattering foil must be many atoms thick. Let the foil have area $A_f$ , thickness t, density $\rho$, and molecular weight M. Then the volume of the foil is $A_ft$, the mass of the foil is $\rho A_ft$, and the number of moles of atoms in the foil must then be $\rho A_ft/M$. The number of atoms in the foil is therefore given by

\begin{equation}
N = \frac{\rho A_f t}{M}N_A
\label{equ:rsFoilAtomNumber}%eq5
\end{equation}

where $N_A$ is Avogadro's number. Substituting Equation \ref{equ:rsFoilAtomNumber} into Equation \ref{equ:rsFractionScattered} yields the fraction of scattered particles in a \textbf{thick} foil

\begin{equation}
f_{b<b_0} = f_{\theta<\theta_0}=\frac{\rho N_A}{M} \pi b^2t
\label{equ:rsFractionScatteredThickFoil}%eq6
\end{equation}

	Equations \ref{equ:rsTrajectoryBounded} and \ref{equ:rsFractionScatteredThickFoil} together describe how alpha particles scatter when they pass through a foil. To experimentally verify this model all particles scattered above some angle $\theta_0$ must be measured by some detector. It is impractical to build detectors that cover a large portion of a sphere surrounding the foil. What is really needed is an equation that describes the \textbf{probability} for a particle to be scattered into a detector with area $A_d$ at some distance r from the foil.

	Using probability theory, it can be shown that the \textbf{derivative} of a cumulative fraction gives the probability distribution. Differentiating Equation \ref{equ:rsFractionScatteredThickFoil} yields

\begin{equation}
df = 2\frac{\rho N_A}{M} \pi bt db
\label{equ:rsFractionScatteredThickFoilDerivative}%eq7
\end{equation}

The differential of b, db, is found by differentiating Equation \ref{equ:rsTrajectoryBounded}. Then the probability of a projectile at angle $\theta$ being scattered into d$\theta$ is found to be 

\begin{equation}
|df| = \pi\frac{\rho t N_A}{M}\left(\frac{(ze)(Ze)}{2K}\right)^2\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\right)^2\csc^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)\cot\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)d\theta
\label{equ:rsScatteringProbability}%eq8
\end{equation}

\begin{figure}
  \centering
  \begin{tikzpicture}
  \begin{scope}[thin]
      \draw[thick] (0,0) node (v2) {} ellipse (1.3 and 2.3);%main ring
      \draw[thick] (0,0) ellipse (2 and 3);%main ring
      \filldraw[pattern=north east lines] (0,2.65) node (v3) {} circle (10pt);
      \filldraw (0,0) circle (3pt);%center point1
      \draw (-4,0) node (v1) {} ellipse (1.1 and 1.5);%small ring
      \filldraw[pattern=north east lines] (-4,0) ellipse (0.65 and 1);%small ring
      \filldraw[fill=white] (-4,0) ellipse (0.3 and 0.6);%small ring
      \filldraw (-4,0) circle (3pt);%center point2
      \draw[very thin,->] (0.79,1.3) -- (0.97,1.475);%rdtheta arrow
      \draw[very thin,->] (1.7,2.175) -- (1.52,2.01);%rdtheta arrow
      \draw[->,dashed] (-4,0.6) -- (1.5,4);%detector arrow
      \draw[->,dashed] (-4,1) -- (2,2.9);%detector arrow
      \draw[->,very thin] (0,0) -- (1,-1.3);%rsintheta arrow
      \draw[very thin] (-1,3.5) -- (0,3);%detector label arrow
      \draw[thick,->] (-4,0) -- (-3.85,0.5);%small ring center arrow
      \draw (-6.5,0.6) -- (-4,0.6);%db
      \draw[->] (-6.5,0.6) -- (-6.25,0.6);%db
      \draw (-6.5,1) -- (-4,1);%db
      \draw[->] (-6.5,1) -- (-6.25,1);%db
      \draw[->,very thin] (-5.5,1.2) -- (-5.5,1);%db
      \draw[->,very thin] (-5.5,0.4) -- (-5.5,0.6);%db
      \draw[very thin] (-5.25,-1) -- (-4,0);%b
      \draw[<-] (0,2.65) -- (-4,0);
    \end{scope}
    \begin{scope}[ultra thin]
      \draw (-6.5,0) -- (v1);%axis
      \draw (-2.9,0) -- (v2);%axis
      \draw (2,0) -- (3.5,0);%axis
      \draw (-2.5,0) arc (0:85:0.5);%angle theta
      \draw (1.5,2.76) arc (0:60:1.01);%angle dtheta
    \end{scope}
    %labels
    \node[right] at (-0.5,-0.75) {r$\sin\theta$};
    \node[right] at (1.65,2.4) {r$d\theta$};
    \node[right] at (1.5,3.5) {$d\theta$};
    \node[right] at (-2.4,3.65) {detector};
    \node[right] at (-2.75,1.15) {r};
    \node[right] at (-2.96,0.2) {$\theta$};
    \node[right] at (-5.6,-1.1) {b};
    \node[right] at (-5.8,1.5) {db};
  \end{tikzpicture}
  \caption{Scattering ring}
  \label{fig:rsRing}
\end{figure}


	As can be seen from Figure \ref{fig:rsRing}, these scattered alpha particles will be uniformly distributed around a ring of radius $r\sin\theta$ and thickness $rd\theta$. The area of the ring, $dA_r$ , is therefore given by

\begin{equation}
dA_r = 2\pi r\sin\theta\cdot rd\theta
\label{equ:rsRingArea}%eq9
\end{equation}

The probability, $N(\theta)$, for scattering into a ring at angle $\theta$ per unit area is thus given by

\begin{equation}
N(\theta) = \frac{|df|}{dA_r}
\label{equ:rsScatteringProbabilityPerArea}%eq10
\end{equation}

Following the example of Equation \ref{equ:rsScatteringProbabilityPerArea} we divide Equation \ref{equ:rsScatteringProbability} by Equation \ref{equ:rsRingArea} to give \textbf{Rutherford's scattering formula}

\begin{equation}
N(\theta) = \frac{\rho tN_A}{Mr^2} \left[ \frac{(ze)(Ze)}{4K} \right]^2 \left( \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \right)^2 \sin^{-4}\left( \frac{\theta}{2} \right)
\label{equ:rsRutherfordFormula}%eq11
\end{equation}

If both sides of Equation \ref{equ:rsScatteringProbabilityPerArea} are multiplied by the area of the detector, $A_d$, 

\begin{equation}
A_dN(\theta) = \frac{\rho tN_AA_d}{Mr^2} \left[ \frac{(ze)(Ze)}{4K} \right]^2 \left( \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \right)^2 \sin^{-4}\left( \frac{\theta}{2} \right)
\label{equ:rsRutherfordFormulaArea}%eq12
\end{equation}
we obtain the probability that a scattered alpha particle will be incident on that detector at angle $\theta$. 	

Lastly, we wish to convert Equation \ref{equ:rsRutherfordFormulaArea} into a form that is independent of  the foil geometry and the detector geometry. To make Equation \ref{equ:rsRutherfordFormulaArea} independent of foil geometry we divide by the number of atoms per unit area of the foil which is $N/A_f$ (Equation \ref{equ:rsFoilAtomNumber}). To remove the detector geometry dependence we divide by the solid angle subtended by the detector, $\Delta\Omega$ , which is

\begin{equation}
\Delta\Omega=\frac{A_d}{r^2}
\label{equ:rsSolidAngle}%eq13
\end{equation}

This gives the \textbf{theoretical differential scattering cross-section}

\begin{equation}
\frac{\Delta\sigma}{\Delta\Omega}=\left[ \frac{(ze)(Ze)}{4K} \right]^2 \left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\right)^2\sin^{-4}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)
\label{equ:rsCrossSectionTheory}%eq14
\end{equation}

The objective of this experiment is to measure the differential scattering cross-section of alpha particles through gold. To experimentally verify Equation \ref{equ:rsCrossSectionTheory} we require measured values that correspond to cross-sections. Equation \ref{equ:rsRutherfordFormulaArea} gives the probability that a scattered $\alpha$-particle will be incident on a detector at angle $\theta$. As an empirical estimate of this we use the ratio of counts detected versus the number of $\alpha$-particles incident on the gold in some time interval $\delta t$. Let the \textbf{incident count rate} of $\alpha$-particles on the target be $R_0$ and the \textbf{detected count rate} of scattered particles at angle $\theta$ be $R_{\theta}$. Then this ratio is

\begin{equation}
\frac{R_{\theta}}{R_{0}}=A_dN(\theta)
\label{equ:rsRatio}%eq15
\end{equation}

Again, we remove the detector geometry dependence and scattering target geometry dependence by dividing out the detector solid angle and the number of atoms per unit area. In this way we obtain the \textbf{measured differential scattering cross-section}

\begin{equation}
\frac{\Delta\sigma}{\Delta\Omega} = \frac{Mr^2}{A_dN_A\rho t} \frac{R_{\theta}}{R_{0}}
\label{equ:rsCrossSectionExp}%eq16
\end{equation}

Figure \ref{fig:rsApparatus} depicts the experimental layout. A beam of $\alpha$-particles emitted from an Am$^{241}$ source is directed at a piece of gold leaf foil. The gold foil target is mounted on a wheel that can be rotated to expose other samples if desired. A solid state detector is placed to observe the scattered particles. This detector can be rotated to different angles and the angle measured using the supplied vernier scale. The output of the detector is sent to a pulse height analyzer (PHA) to obtain a \textbf{pulse height spectrum}.  This spectrum is used to determine the count rate of the detected particles. Since the range of alpha particles emitted from the Am$^{241}$ source is less than 4 cm. in air, the entire arrangement is enclosed inside in a vacuum. A lever is provided underneath the vacuum chamber to rotate the detector to different angles. A horseshoe magnet rotates the target wheel from outside the vacuum chamber. Under normal operation no other controls are needed. The detector is sensitive to light so a dark cover must be used.

\section{Experimental Procedure}

\begin{enumerate}
\item Do a performance check of the vacuum system. The vacuum pump should be running. Turn on the Edwards digital pressure gauge (power switch is at the back of the unit) and press the down arrow on the front panel once to select the proper transducer. Under normal conditions the pressure inside the bell jar should read less than 6.0$\times10^{-2}$ mbar. If there is a problem with the vacuum ask your instructor to contact the lab technician. 

%, do \textbf{not} proceed to step 2. Make sure to turn off the pressure gauge after the reading is taken because it interferes with the operation of the solid state particle detector.
%
%	This paragraph is provided for reference purposes only. None of these procedures should be tried unless a member of the laboratory staff is present. The pump is connected to a large valve which can be used to isolate the chamber from the pump. This valve is seldom used except during pump maintenance and bringing the system up to room pressure. To bring the system back up to room pressure, close the isolation valve and open the other valve located underneath the bell jar. The target foils are very thin, so let air into the system \textbf{slowly} so that they do not tear. Lastly, slowly open the isolation valve. When the chamber is about to be evacuated, check that the rim and grove where the bell jar sits are free of dust and debris. Pump down for at least four hours before powering up the detector. 

\item Do a performance check of the particle detector, spectrometer, pulse height analyzer, computer, and printer. With the vacuum operating correctly and the dark cover in place, turn on the spectrometer. Using the lever underneath the vacuum chamber, rotate the detector in front of the calibration source. Set the energy range to 4-8 MeV and the bias to 50 V. Using the computer and pulse height analyzer, obtain a spectrum for 10 minutes. If the system is working correctly, three well separated peaks should be visible. The three peaks are curium$^{244}$ (5.81 MeV), americium$^{241}$ (5.49 MeV), and plutonium$^{239}$ (5.16 MeV). Calibrate the energy scale on the PHA with these three peaks. Using the PHA computer program, annotate each peak and then print out the spectrum. The solid state particle detector is quite sensitive to abuse. \textbf{Never} turn on the bias voltage unless the dark cover is in place and the chamber is evacuated. \textbf{Never} touch the surface of the detector. \textbf{Never} leave the detector stowed against the calibration source or within the alpha particle beam.

\item  This portion is optional, ask your instructor if you need to perform it. Characterize the incoming alpha particle beam to determine the center angle and the width of the beam. Rotate the sample wheel to a position where there is no target foil using the supplied horseshoe magnet. Make sure the sample wheel is latched in place and pulled as far back towards the particle source as possible. \textbf{Never} put the horseshoe magnet near \textbf{anything} except the sample wheel rotator and the metal shelf where the magnet is stored. Measure count rates at 1 or less degree increments in a 6 degree swath around either side of the estimated center. Determine the probable center angle and the width of the beam. The center angle you measure will define the scattering zero angle.

\item Obtain scattering data with gold foil in place. Rotate the sample wheel to a gold target that has no tears or openings in it. Choose angles starting from just past the forward beam (about 5 degrees from the center angle) to angles further away. For angles greater than 20 degrees long counting times will be required. At each angle obtain a spectrum. Determine the total number of counts. The counts are selected using the \textbf{full-width-half-maximum (FWHM)} method. Choose all counts around the center of the peak out to where the count in a channel is half the count in the maximum channel. Note down the \textbf{live time} taken to acquire the spectrum. Divide FWHM counts by the live time to get a count rate for that angle. Remember to turn off the bias before removing the dark cover to set the detector at a new angle. Also remember to turn it back on after the dark cover is replaced.
\end{enumerate}


\section{Error Analysis}

	There are sources of error in both the theory and measurement components of this experiment. No error analysis of your data is necessary but a discussion of the errors present in this experiment will be requested.


\vspace{12pt}
\textbf{To be handed in to the laboratory instructor}

\section{Prelab}

\begin{enumerate}
\item A short discussion on the similarities and differences between Rutherford scattering and the \textbf{Kepler problem}. The Kepler problem is about the approach of a small satellite towards a large body like the earth under the force of gravitation. Write down a formula for the force law that applies in each case.

\item The numerical information gives K, the kinetic energy of the alpha particles, in MeV. Convert this to a value in Joules, a more useful unit for the purposes of this experiment.

\item A derivation of Equation \ref{equ:rsTrajectoryBounded}.
\end{enumerate}
%%% end prelab %%%

\section{Data Requirements}

\begin{enumerate}[resume]
\item A calibration spectrum obtained from the detector/PHA performance test together with the measured air pressure inside the chamber from the vacuum system performance test.

\item Spectra taken at various scattering angles together with a data table of the count rates at these angles.

\item Present your calculations of $\Delta\sigma / \Delta\Omega$.

\item A semi-logarithmic plot of the observed and theoretical differential scattering cross-section versus angle. 

\item A linearized plot of the observed and differential scattering cross-sections.
\end{enumerate}


\section{Discussion}

\begin{enumerate}[resume]
\item Discuss the errors present in this experiment. Some points to consider could be; measurement errors, systematic errors, theoretical assumptions that will fail for very large and very small impact parameters, and errors arising from the width of the detector.

\item Discuss your experimental results and whether they confirm or deny the theory of Rutherford scattering.

\item Essentially, this experiment examines the angular dependence of the Rutherford scattering formula. Give experimental designs for checking the Rutherford scattering formula against alpha energy K, atomic number Z, and thickness t.

\end{enumerate}

\chapter{Laboratory Safety}

\section{Introduction}
People who survive to reach adulthood generally acquire a mental list of safety rules that are followed to prevent injury to themselves and others. These rules are learned 
from sources such as parents, teachers, and experience. However, the practice of experimental physics can involve the handling of materials, instruments, and processes that
lie outside the realm of common experience. The rules described here must be added to your mental list to handle these new situations. This is part of your education in 
physics. For the safety of yourself and others you are required to read, understand, and follow these guidelines.

All of the physics experiments you will perform have been designed with the safety of the student in mind. This necessarily assumes that all the apparatus is used in a 
reasonable manner. Do not mishandle or abuse the equipment. Use your common sense. Always maintain an awareness of the consequences of your actions for yourself and others.
No food, drink, or smoking is permitted in the laboratory, to reduce the chance that it will be contaminated before being consumed. Also, spilled drinks can be dangerous 
near electrical equipment. Some physics experiments use ice or ice water for cooling. Do not eat or drink the ice or ice water, since it may be contaminated. Never work in a
laboratory alone, there should always be someone else present to get help if necessary. In the event of any accident in the lab, you must notify your instructor immediately.
The following comments describe the hazards you may encounter while in a physics laboratory and the relevant safety procedures to follow.

\section{Heavy Metals}
Lead is used for shielding in radiation experiments. Heavy metals such as lead can be absorbed into your body through the skin and mouth. They accumulate in the brain and 
eventually cause brain damage when a large enough amount is present. The total dosage of lead in the brain builds up over your lifetime as a function of total  accumulated 
exposure. Minimize your exposure to lead in the laboratory by handling it as little as possible. Do not touch any food or your face while working with lead. Wash your hands
after handling lead objects. Lead is also very dense. Be aware of this when moving blocks of lead and do not drop them.

Observe the same precautions when doing an experiment that uses mercury. As with lead, mercury can also be absorbed into the body to accumulate over your lifetime. Mercury 
has the added properties that it is a liquid which can be spilled and any open container of liquid mercury produces mercury vapour which can be inhaled. Avoid spilling 
mercury and try to keep it in a sealed container if possible. Make sure there is a spill tray underneath any experiment that involves the use of mercury. If mercury does get
spilled, notify your instructor so that it can be cleaned up. 

\section{Radiation}
The total dose of radiation you receive depends on the source intensity, the time you are exposed, and your distance from the source. For x-rays and gamma-rays the source 
intensity drops as the inverse square of the distance. For alpha and beta particles the drop is even faster. Minimize the time that a radioactive source is near you. Keep 
radioactive sources  as far away from you as you reasonably can, consistent with doing the experiment. There are strict regulations about the storage and handling of 
radioactive sources. Do not open, drop or lose them.

\section{Lasers}
Lasers are sources of concentrated parallel beams of monochromatic light, which can quite easily be focussed to tiny spots where the power density is high enough to cause 
damage. Never look into a laser beam, or let it shine into your eye, since you may suffer retinal damage if the laser power is high enough. Reflections from polished 
surfaces are almost as dangerous as the direct beam. Never shine a laser into someone elseâs eyes. Resist the temptation to shine the laser around the room or into the 
hallway. If this is done a person could accidentally gaze into the beam.

\section{Rotating Machinery}
Some experiments use pumps, motors, or other moving mechanisms. Keep fingers and other appendages away from such devices. Be especially careful about long hair and 
loose clothing.

\section{Electricity}
Always wire together your circuits with the power off. Make sure the circuit power is off when changing or moving components around. If you must work on live 
circuits only touch the insulated portions and make sure one hand is in your pocket or behind your back. This eliminates the possibility of current flow through the heart 
and lungs, which can be fatal. Do not touch live exposed connections under any circumstances. Beware of loose wires which can fall off or make unintentional connections, 
usually with undesirable results. Be especially vigilant around high voltage circuits. If the voltage is high enough, it is not necessary to touch the circuit to get a 
shock, since sparks can jump across a gap of air. Capacitors require particular care since they can store charge internally for hours after being disconnected from a 
circuit. Make sure capacitors are discharged before touching the terminals. When using spark timers on the air tracks make sure the hands of all your lab partners are clear
before starting the spark source.

\section{Cryogenic Materials}
Some physics experiments involve the use of liquid nitrogen, liquid helium, dry ice, or an organic solvent cooled with dry ice. These materials are cold. Do not touch them 
with your hands. Wear protective gloves when handling a container containing a cryogenic material. Do not splash or spill these cold liquids. Be careful not to touch parts 
that have been in contact with a cryogenic material, they will be cold as well. If a spill does happen, notify your instructor but do not touch the spill, it will evaporate
naturally. There must always be a way for evaporated cryogenic liquid to escape from a vessel, otherwise a dangerous build-up of pressure will occur.

\section{Pressure and vacuum vessels}
Gas bottles are under high pressure. If they are breached they will explode with the force of a bomb. Never jar or mishandle a pressure vessel when it is pressurized. 
Vacuum systems will implode when breached. Do not jar or abuse them either. Always bring the vacuum (or pressure) back to normal slowly. Before adjusting any valves make 
sure you understand the purpose of each valve and the consequences of operating it. Turn it slowly at first so you can change your mind if something seems to be wrong.

\section{Microwaves}
People wearing heart pacemakers or other life supporting electro-metallic implants should refrain from doing physics experiments that involve microwaves.

\section{Strong Magnetic Fields}
Strong magnetic fields will erase your credit cards, computer disks, and audio tapes. They will also damage watches, tape players, and other electronic devices. Do not leave
any such objects near a strong magnet or electromagnet. Check the area around an electromagnet before turning it on. People wearing heart pacemakers or other life supporting
electro-metallic implants should also refrain from doing physics experiments that involve powerful magnetic fields. Anything containing a magnet, or magnetic material like 
iron, steel, nickel, or cobalt, should also be kept away from strong magnetic fields. They may be damaged or pulled into the region of the field with enough force to break 
something.

\section{Stroboscopes}
Some people are susceptible to epileptic seizures or severe migraine headaches if they view strobe lights flashing at a frequency of 5 to 25 Hz. Refrain from doing an 
experiment involving strobe lights if you know you are susceptible. Notify the instructor immediately if you see someone adversely affected by an operating stroboscope.

\chapter{Voltage Dividers and Voltage Sources}

\section{Equipment}

\begin{marginfigure}%[-2in]

\section{Preparation}
% copy and paste the section under preparation (or similar section)
Review the basic ideas of circuit analysis including Ohm's law and Kirchhoff's laws.

\section{Goals of the Experiment}
% copy and paste the section under goals of the experiment (or similar section)
To investigate voltage dividers and their uses. To understand the concepts of internal resistance and Thévenin equivalence. To
get experience with potentiometers, power supplies, and voltmeters, and gain a better understanding of how they work. To 
observe the effects of circuit loading and how this affects measurements.

\section{Theory}

\begin{marginfigure}
\includegraphics{/usr/local/master/labs/physics397-FA2016/Voltage-Dividers-and-Voltage-Sources/Voltage-Dividers-and-Voltage-Sources-Resistors.jpg}
\caption{Examples of resistors of different shapes and sizes}
\label{pic:vdResistors}
\end{marginfigure}

The use of electric circuits today is a large part of everyday life. The radio, television, telephone and computer are all examples of devices that use electric circuits. In almost all circuits \textbf{resistors} are among the most common components. Figure \ref{pic:vdResistors} shows some of the many different kinds of resistors. The different shapes and sizes play a role in their behavior and application. Resistors are used to control the current and voltage in a circuit. They were extensively studied by physicists due to this property. Whether it is a complex circuit, such as the ones found in a computer, or one as simple as a battery connected to a light bulb, there are fundamental rules that all resistor circuits follow.			

Georg Ohm (1789-1854) contributed largely to what is now known about resistors. He speculated how current might work and formulated the law governing resistors that now bears his name. Later, Gustav Kirchhoff (1824-1887) made further contributions to the understanding of electric circuits. He extended Ohm's work describing what are now call \textbf{Kirchhoff's Laws}, which explained how current and voltage in electric circuits are related. In 1883 Léon Thévenin (1857-1926), a French telegraph engineer, described what he thought to be a new theory of equivalent circuits. He showed that any resistor circuit could be simplified to make analysis easier. Coincidentally, the concept of equivalency in circuits had already been proposed almost 30 years earlier by the physicist Herman von Helmholtz (1821-1894). Thévenin was unaware of Helmholtz's work and both theories met with resistance during their time. It was due to Thévenins engineering approach, and the growth of electrical engineering in the coming years, that his result is now called \textbf{Thévenin's Theorem}.

\begin{marginfigure}
%\usetikzlibrary{arrows,snakes,shapes,calc,patterns}
%\usetikzlibrary{circuits.ee.IEC}
      \begin{tikzpicture}[circuit ee IEC]
      \draw[thick] (0,3) to [battery] (0,0); % battery
      \draw[thick] (0,0) -- (1.5,0) -- (1.5,0.5)(1.5,1) -- (1.5,2)(1.5,2.5) -- (1.5,3) -- (0,3);  %wiring
      \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (1.5,2) -- (1.5,2.5); % upper resistor
      \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (1.5,0.5) -- (1.5,1); % lower resistor
      \draw[thick] (1.5,1.5) -- (2.5,1.5) -- (2.5,0) -- (1.5,0); % voltmeter wires
      \node[black,fill=white,draw=black,shape=circle,scale=1] at (2.5,0.75) {V}; % voltmeter
      \draw (1,-0.5) rectangle (2,3.5); % voltage divider box
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Basic voltage divider with power supply}
\label{fig:vdBasicVD}
\end{marginfigure}

Many combinations of resistors exist in circuitry, but the \textbf{voltage divider} is one combination that is seen everywhere. The circuit in Figure \ref{fig:vdBasicVD} contains a voltage source of some kind, connected in series loop with two resistors. A voltmeter is in parallel with one of the resistors to measure the voltage across it. Each resistor in the loop drops a portion of the voltage. This resistor combination, which accomplishes the splitting of voltages, is called a voltage divider. It can be used to control the voltages coming out of, or going into, a particular system, or even be used as a tool for analysis of circuits.

In Figure \ref{fig:vdVoltDivConnect} the connections of the voltage divider to the voltage source and voltmeter are explicitly shown. The voltage source is supplying a voltage with magnitude V$_{in}$ into the voltage divider and the voltmeter reads V$_{out}$ across R$_{2}$. This suggests the voltage divider can be generalized further by extracting it from the circuit. Figure \ref{fig:vdVoltDivIsolated} shows only the voltage divider. The input voltage, V$_{in}$, can be generalized to be any source of voltage such as a battery, power supply or another device. The output voltage, V$_{out}$, is what would be applied to any device or system connected to these two terminals.

   \end{tikzpicture}

    \label{fig:vdVoltDivIsolated}
\end{marginfigure}

For the voltage divider in Figure \ref{fig:vdVoltDivIsolated}, V$_{in}$ is split and V$_{out}$ is some portion of V$_{in}$. This can be shown using Ohms and Kirchhoff's laws. From Ohm's law, the voltage drop across a resistor is the product of its resistance and the current through it. So the voltages across R$_{1}$ and R$_{2}$ are V$_{1}$ and V$_{out}$, which are given by

\begin{equation}
V_{1}=IR_{1}
\label{equ:vdV1},
\end{equation}
and

\begin{equation}
V_{out}=IR_{2}
\label{equ:vdVout},
\end{equation}
where I is the current flowing in the loop. From Kirchhoff's Voltage Law, it is expected that the applied voltage equals the voltage drops across all the resistors in series, so that

\begin{equation}
V_{in}=V_{1}+V_{out}.
\label{equ:vdVin}
\end{equation}
Using Equations \ref{equ:vdV1}, \ref{equ:vdVout} and \ref{equ:vdVin}, it is seen that

\begin{equation}
V_{in}=I\left(R_{1}+R_{2}\right).
\label{equ:vdVin2}
\end{equation}
Substituting for the current using Equation \ref{equ:vdVout} gives the \textbf{voltage divider formula}

\begin{equation}
V_{out}=V_{in}\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}}.
\label{equ:vdVout2}
\end{equation}

Equation \ref{equ:vdVout2} implies that the ratio of $\frac{V_{out}}{V_{in}}$ is equal to the ratio of $\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}}$. It also implies that V$_{out}$ cannot be larger than V$_{in}$ since the ratio of one resistor to two resistors can only be equal to or less than one. A special case is seen when R$_{1}$ is zero. The ratio becomes equal to one and V$_{out}$ is equal to V$_{in}$.

\begin{marginfigure}
  \begin{tikzpicture}[circuit ee IEC]
      \node at (0,1.5) {V$_{in}$}; % Vin label
      \draw[thick,>->] (0,0) -- (2.5,0); % Wiring 
      \draw[thick,>-] (0,3) -- (1.5,3); % Wiring
      \draw[thick](1.5,0) -- (1.5,1.25)(1.5,1.75) -- (1.5,3); % Wiring
      \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (1.5,1.25) -- (1.5,1.75); % lower resistor
      \node[left] at (1.3,1.5){R$_{x}$}; % Rx label
      \node[right] at (1.55,1.2){R$_{P}$}; % RP label
      \draw[thick,<->] (1.6,1.5) -- (2.5,1.5); % Wiring
      \node[right] at (2.2,0.75) {V$_{out}$}; % Vout label
   \end{tikzpicture}
   \caption{Variable voltage divider}
   \label{fig:vdVariableVoltDiv}
\end{marginfigure}

The voltage divider in Figure \ref{fig:vdVoltDivIsolated} supplies a fixed voltage ratio. It is also possible for voltage dividers to supply a variable ratio. This is done with a device called a \textbf{potentiometer}. A potentiometer is a variable resistor whose resistance can be changed by turning a dial. Figure \ref{fig:vdVariableVoltDiv} shows a schematic of a potentiometer used as a variable voltage divider. The resistance of the entire potentiometer is R$_{x}$ and R$_{P}$ is the portion of this controlled by the dial. If the dial is adjusted so that R$_{p}$ is equal to R$_{x}$, then V$_{out}$ is equal to V$_{in}$. Likewise V$_{out}$ becomes zero if the dial is adjusted so that R$_{P}$ is zero.

Suppose two more resistors are added to the potentiometer to get the circuit shown in Figure \ref{fig:vdThreeResistVoltDiv}. The derivation for Equation \ref{equ:vdVout2} involves a loop with two resistors, but in fact can work for any number of resistors. The total series resistance would be on the bottom of the ratio. The output voltage V$_{out}$ could be taken across any or all of the resistors in the circuit and the value of these resistors would go on the top of the ratio. So, the output voltage will be

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
    \node at (0,2.5) {V$_{in}$}; % Vin label
    \draw[thick,>->] (0,0) -- (2.5,0); % Wiring 
    \draw[thick,>-] (0,5) -- (1.5,5); % Wiring
    \draw[thick](1.5,0) -- (1.5,1)(1.5,1.5) -- (1.5,2.25)(1.5,2.75)--(1.5,3.5)(1.5,4)--(1.5,5); % Wiring
    \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (1.5,1) -- (1.5,1.5); % lower resistor
    \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (1.5,2.25) -- (1.5,2.75); % middle resistor
    \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (1.5,3.5) -- (1.5,4); % upper resistor
    \node[left] at (1.3,2.5){R$_{x}$}; % Rx label
    \node[right] at (1.55,2.2){R$_{P}$}; % RP label
    \node[left] at (1.3,3.75){R$_{1}$}; % R1 label
    \node[left] at (1.3,1.25){R$_{2}$}; % R2 label
    \draw[thick,<->] (1.6,2.5) -- (2.5,2.5); % Wiring
    \node[right] at (2.2,1.25) {V$_{out}$}; % Vout label
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Voltage divider with three resistors}
\label{fig:vdThreeResistVoltDiv}
\end{marginfigure}

\begin{equation}
V_{out}=V_{in}\frac{R_{P}+R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}+R_{x}}.
\label{equ:vdVout3}
\end{equation}
This setup produces a range of voltages for V$_{out}$, which can be controlled by the dial on the potentiometer. The output voltage has a minimum greater than zero and a maximum less than V$_{in}$, as determined by R$_{1}$ and R$_{2}$.The minimum output voltage, V$_{min}$, occurs when R$_{P}$ is zero so

\begin{equation}
V_{min}=V_{in}\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}+R_{x}},
\label{equ:vdVmin}
\end{equation}
and the maximum output voltage, Vmax, arises when RP equals Rx which gives

\begin{equation}
V_{max}=V_{in}\frac{R_{x}+R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}+R_{x}}.
\label{equ:vdVmax}
\end{equation}

Not only do voltage dividers exist explicitly as the circuits shown in Figures \ref{fig:vdBasicVD}-\ref{fig:vdThreeResistVoltDiv}. They also exist implicitly whenever any two circuits are connected together. There is a division of voltage between the output of any circuit and the input of a second circuit. For example, imagine that a single resistor is connected to a power supply as shown in Figure \ref{fig:vdPowerSupply}. Here, the second circuit is composed of a single resistor R$_{L}$. Typically, R$_{L}$ is called the \textbf{load}, or in this case the \textbf{load resistor}.

\begin{marginfigure}
  \begin{tikzpicture}[circuit ee IEC]
  \draw[thick] (0,2) to [battery] (0,0);
      \node at (-0.65,1) {V$_{in}$}; % Vin label
      \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (0.75,2) -- (1.25,2); % upper resistor
      \draw[thick](0,2)--(0.75,2); % Wiring
      \draw[thick,->](1.25,2)--(1.9,2); %wiring
      \draw[thick,->] (0,0) -- (1.9,0); % Wiring
      \draw[thick,>-] (2,2) -- (2.5,2); % Wiring
      \draw[thick,>-] (2,0) -- (2.5,0); % Wiring
      \draw[thick](2.5,0)--(2.5,0.75)(2.5,1.25)--(2.5,2); % Wiring
      \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (2.5,0.75) -- (2.5,1.25); % upper resistor
      \node[text centered] at (1,2.3){R$_{i}$}; % Ri label
      \node[left] at (2.2,1){R$_{L}$}; % RL label
      \node[right] at (2.7,1) {V$_{out}$}; % Vout label
      \node[right] at (2.7,1.4) {+}; % Vout + label
      \node[right] at (2.75,0.6) {-}; % Vout - label
      \node[right] at (-0.9,-0.35) {Power Supply}; % Power Supply label
      \draw  (-1.2,2.75) rectangle (1.5,-0.75); % Power Supply Box
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Power supply with internal resistor}
\label{fig:vdPowerSupply}
\end{marginfigure}

Ideally, it would be expected that the entire voltage, V$_{in}$, would be developed across the load resistor. However, what happens in practice is that the voltage across the load, V$_{out}$, is always somewhat smaller than V$_{in}$. Moreover, the smaller the value of R$_{L}$, the larger the discrepancy between V$_{out}$ and V$_{in}$. This situation can be neatly explained by the addition of an internal resistor, R$_{i}$. The voltage is now seen as being split between the load resistor R$_{L}$, and the internal resistance R$_{i}$. The basic voltage divider formula, Equation \ref{equ:vdVout2}, can be used to find V$_{out}$ as before to get

\begin{equation}
V_{out}=V_{in}\frac{R_{L}}{R_{L}+R_{i}}.
\label{equ:vdVout4}
\end{equation}

What is now observable is that the voltage across R$_{L}$ is less than the voltage being supplied by the power supply. If R$_{i}$ is much smaller than R$_{L}$, V$_{out}$ is, to a reasonable approximation, equal to V$_{in}$. At the same time, if the value of R$_{i}$ is close to the value of R$_{L}$, then V$_{out}$ will only be a portion of V$_{in}$. If R$_{i}$ were much larger than R$_{L}$ this effect would be dramatically increased and almost no voltage would be across R$_{L}$. For perfect power supplies R$_{i}$ is zero which means that V$_{out}$ = V$_{in}$ or any load resistor.

\begin{equation}
\frac{1}{V_{out}}=\frac{R_{i}}{V_{in}}\frac{1}{R_{L}}+\frac{1}{V_{in}}.
\label{equ:vdVout5}
\end{equation}

With Equation \ref{equ:vdVout5}, R$_{i}$ can be found by connecting a variable load and measuring V$_{out}$ across different load resistances. It can be seen that plotting $\frac{1}{V_{out}}$ versus $\frac{1}{R_{L}}$ yields a straight line with a slope of $\frac{R_{i}}{V_{in}}$ from which R$_{i}$ can be found.

So what is internal resistance exactly? Thévenin answered this by showing that from the point of view of any resistor in a circuit, the rest of the circuit is equivalent to a voltage source with a series internal resistance, just as in Figure \ref{equ:vdVmin}. For example, the left side of Figure \ref{fig:vdTheveninEqu} shows a circuit containing a number of voltage sources and resistors. From the point of view of a single resistor such as R$_{5}$, the entire remaining part of the original circuit is equivalent to a single voltage source in series with a single resistor, as shown on the right side of Figure \ref{fig:vdTheveninEqu}. This is called the Thévenin equivalent circuit. The voltage source, V$_{th}$, is called the Thévenin equivalent voltage and the resistor, R$_{th}$, is called the Thévenin equivalent resistance. Comparing this with Figure  \ref{fig:vdPowerSupply}, it is seen that the Thévenin equivalent circuit is a power supply with an internal resistance driving a load consisting of the chosen component, in this case R$_{5}$.

There is a standard procedure for calculating V$_{th}$ and R$_{th}$. The Thévenin equivalent voltage is equal to the voltage that would be found across the terminals without anything attached to it. Here, R$_{5}$ is the reference component so it is replaced with an open circuit. So the voltage across R$_{4}$ is the voltage being output by this circuit and is equal to V$_{th}$. In this example the Thévenin voltage is equal to the product of the current in the second loop, I$_{2}$, and the resistance R$_{4}$. If the value for all the voltage sources and resistors are known, the current across R$_{4}$ can be found by solving for the loop currents. This will yield the Thévenin voltage as being

\begin{equation}
V_{th}=I_{2}R_{4}.
\label{equ:vdVth}
\end{equation}

To find R$_{th}$, R$_{5}$ is again removed and all voltage sources in the circuit are replaced with their internal resistance. In this case the voltage sources are assumed to be ideal and are replaced with short circuits. The Thévenin resistance is then the equivalent resistance at the open terminals. For the circuit in Figure \ref{fig:vdTheveninEqu} this is

\begin{equation}
R_{th}=\left(\left(R_{1}\parallel R_{2}\right)+R_{3}\right)\parallel R_{4},
\label{equ:vdRth}
\end{equation}
where $\parallel$ indicates that the resistors are to be added in parallel.

Another way to measure V$_{th}$ and R$_{th}$ is by knowing that the Thévenin equivalent circuit in Figure \ref{fig:vdTheveninEqu} is identical to the circuit depicted in Figure \ref{fig:vdPowerSupply}. Equation \ref{equ:vdVout5} can therefore be used to find V$_{th}$ and R$_{th}$ by varying R$_{5}$. Here, V$_{out}$ is the voltage across R$_{5}$, and V$_{in}$ and R$_{i}$ are V$_{th}$ and R$_{th}$ respectively. Again, plotting $\frac{1}{V_{out}}$ versus $\frac{1}{R_{5}}$ should yield a straight line. This method produces a graph giving R$_{th}$ and V$_{th}$ from the slope and intercept.

So by attaching a load resistor to a circuit, in the case of Figure \ref{fig:vdTheveninEqu} this was R$_{5}$, the voltage across the resistor is dependent on the internal resistance as explained by the voltage divider rule. The effect that a load resistor has on circuits is called circuit loading.  Imagine the basic voltage divider in Figure \ref{fig:vdVoltDivIsolated} where a voltmeter is used to measure V$_{out}$. Just like the power supply, voltmeters have some internal resistance. In the analysis of Equation \ref{equ:vdVout2}, it was assumed that no current goes into the voltmeter, which is true only for an ideal voltmeter. 

The effect that non ideal voltmeters have on voltage dividers is shown in Figure \ref{fig:vdVoltMeterInternalR}. This schematic is similar to Figure \ref{fig:vdVoltDivConnect} with the exception that the voltmeter now has an internal resistance R$_{i}$. Ideally, the voltage across R$_{2}$ is the ratio of R$_{2}$ to the entire resistance, R$_{1}$ + R$_{2}$. Once a voltmeter is connected, the voltage is split between R$_{1}$ and the combined resistance of R$_{2}$ and R$_{i}$, in parallel. In Figure \ref{fig:vdVoltMeterInternalR}, V$_{r}$ is the voltage read by the voltmeter and V$_{out}$, although not explicitly shown, is the actual voltage across R$_{2}$ without the voltmeter attached.This equivalent resistance is given by

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
      \draw[thick] (0,3) to [battery] (0,0); % battery
      \node at (-0.65,1.5) {V$_{in}$}; % Vin label
       \draw[thick,->] (0,0) -- (0.75,0); % Wiring 
      \draw[thick,>->] (0.8,0) -- (2,0); % Wiring
      \draw[thick,->] (0,3) -- (0.75,3); % Wiring
      \draw[thick,>-] (0.8,3) -- (1.5,3); % Wiring
      \draw[thick](1.5,0) -- (1.5,0.5)(1.5,1) -- (1.5,2)(1.5,2.5) -- (1.5,3); % Wiring
      \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (1.5,2) -- (1.5,2.5); % R1
      \node[left] at (1.45,2.25){R$_{1}$}; % R1 label
      \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (3,0.5) -- (3,1); % Ri
      \node[left] at (2.95,0.75){R$_{i}$}; % Ri label
      \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (1.5,0.5) -- (1.5,1); % R2
      \node[left] at (1.45,0.75){R$_{2}$}; % R2 label
      \draw[thick] (4,1.5) -- (4,0); % voltmeter wires
      \draw[thick,->] (1.5,1.5) -- (2,1.5); % Wiring
      \draw[thick,>-] (2.1,1.5) -- (4,1.5); % Wiring
      \draw[thick,>-] (2.1,0) -- (4,0); % Wiring
      \draw[thick](3,0)--(3,0.5)(3,1)--(3,1.5); %Wiring
      \node[black,fill=white,draw=black,shape=circle,scale=1] at (4,0.75) {V$_{r}$}; % voltmeter   
	  \draw (2.35,1.75) rectangle (4.5,-0.25);
      \node[text centered] at (3.4,2) {Voltmeter};
      \draw[->](-0.25,2.25) -- (-0.25,3); % current arrow


%%% Diagram on right side of page

      \draw[snake=zigzag,segment length=5,thick] (8,2) -- (8,2.5); % upper resistor

      \draw[thick](8,1)--(8,2); % Wiring
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Internal Resistance of Voltmeter}
\label{fig:vdVoltMeterInternalR}
\end{figure}


\begin{equation}
R_{eq}=R_{2}\parallel R_{i}=\frac{R_{2}R_{i}}{R_{2}+R_{i}}.
\label{equ:vdReq}
\end{equation}

It is seen that if R$_{i}$ is much larger than R$_{2}$, then R$_{eq}$ is nearly equal to R$_{2}$, and Equation \ref{equ:vdVout2} still holds. This is what would be expected from an ideal voltmeter. If this is not the case then R$_{eq}$ will be smaller than R$_{2}$. So a larger portion of voltage will develop across R$_{1}$ than before the voltmeter was connected. The voltage measured by the voltmeter will now be smaller than expected. This effect is called meter loading and is seen when R$_{2}$ in Equation \ref{equ:vdVout2} is replaced with R$_{eq}$ to get

\begin{equation}
V_{r}=V_{in}\frac{R_{eq}}{R_{eq}+R_{1}}\neq V_{out}.
\label{equ:vdVr}
\end{equation}

Equation \ref{equ:vdVr} gives the output voltage, taking the effect of the voltmeter on the circuit into account. It can be used to calculate the internal resistance of the voltmeter. Furthermore, it is possible to rearrange Equation \ref{equ:vdVr} to find the voltmeter internal resistance by

\begin{equation}
R_{i}=\frac{R_{1}R_{2}}{R_{2}\left(\frac{V_{in}}{V_{r}}-1\right)-R_{1}},
\label{equ:vdRi}
\end{equation}
if R$_{1}$, R$_{2}$ and V$_{in}$ are known, and V$_{r}$ is the reading from the voltmeter.

It has been shown that voltage dividers occur in many circuits containing resistors and/or devices in series. In this experiment several different voltage dividers are examined. A simple voltage divider similar to the one seen in Figure \ref{fig:vdBasicVD} is constructed to examine the voltage divider formula. A potentiometer can then be inserted to check Equations \ref{equ:vdVout3}-\ref{equ:vdVmax}. The power supply can then be probed to find its internal resistance and see the effects of having a power supply with a large internal resistance. Thévenin equivalence can be tested using the three methods previously described, calculation of theoretical values for V$_{th}$ and R$_{th}$, taking direct measurements, and the use of a variable load resistor.

Two multimeters are used in this experiment, the Philips digital meter and the Sanwa analog meter. The Philips multimeter is close to ideal in many situations and is used for most of the measurements in this experiment. The Sanwa multimeter, which is farther from ideal, is used to see the effects of meter loading. The Philips multimeter also has the necessary precision required for observing the small internal resistance of the power supply. 

In this experiment the Philips multimeter is used for taking voltage and resistance measurements. All connections are made to the red V Jack and the black COM jack. Switching between voltage and resistance readings is done via buttons along the bottom of the multimeter, under the display. The DC voltage function is selected by the V\raisebox{0.3 em}{\Beam} button and the resistance function is chosen with the 2W button. For some measurements it may be necessary to change the range of the meter. The three top right buttons on the instrument are the ranging controls. The range can be changed to automatic or manual with the AUT/MAN button. In manual mode the UP and DOWN buttons are used to change the range. Auto ranging is recommended unless otherwise specified in the procedure. When measuring resistance, be sure to disconnect any power supplies from the circuit. The internal resistance of the Philips voltmeter is 10 M$\Omega$.

The Sanwa multimeter is an analog meter with a fairly low input resistance. This multimeter will be used to witness the effect of voltmeter loading. For this experiment the multimeter is in a box and all connections are done using the terminals on the outside of this box. The range can be set using the dial on the front of the device. Useful ranges for this experiment are 0.5 V, 2.5 V, 10 V and 50 V. The internal resistance of the Sanwa multimeter is directly proportional to the voltage range it is reading in and is 20 k$\Omega$/V. For example the internal resistance at the 10 V setting should be 10 V x 20 k$\Omega$/V, which is 200 k$\Omega$.

\item Connect R$_{D}$ = 100 $\Omega$ to the positive output terminal of the power supply. This will show the effects of having a power supply with a high output resistance. Connect a resistance decade box in series to serve as a variable load. The setup should resemble Figure \ref{fig:vdPowerSupply}. Because the 100 $\Omega$ resistor is much larger than the actual internal resistance of the power supply, R$_{i}$ is essentially equal to the value of R$_{D}$. Set the power supply to 1 V. Using the Philips multimeter, take at least 10 measurements of V$_{out}$ while varying the load resistance from 10 $\Omega$  to 10 k$\Omega$.

\item Remove R$_{D}$ from the circuit in step 3. Now, R$_{i}$ is the actual internal resistance of the power supply to be measured. Again set the power supply to 1 V and take measurements, with the Philips multimeter, of V$_{out}$ for load resistance's ranging from  1 $\Omega$  to 10 $\Omega$.

Set the power supply between 1 V and 5 V. Measure V$_{th}$ directly with a voltmeter. Replace the power supply with a short and measure R$_{th}$ directly with an ohmmeter. Remember to disconnect the power from a circuit before taking measurements of resistance with an ohmmeter.
