\section{\bf Experimental Procedure}

\subsection{\bf Measure the Parameters of the System}
According to the equations of motion for the system there are $3$ parameters that govern the motion. The mass $m$, the spring constant $k$, and damping coefficient $c$. All three can be measured. 
\begin{enumerate}

\item Using the digital balance, determine the mass of the spring and the objects hanging from it (the index bar, damping bar, and all additional masses). If the mass of the spring is not negligible, then the effective mass of the system is the sum of the masses hanging from the spring and one third of the spring mass.

\item The spring constant, $k$, is found from Hooke's law. Add mass to the index bar in steps of $5$ to $20$ grams for at least 8 points between $0$ and $100$. Plotting applied force versus extension gives a line with slope $k$. Note that the spring is already extended by the index and damping bars hanging from it. The first data point will then be a spring extension of zero with an applied force of mg Newtons, where $m$ is the mass of the index and damping bars. Use the scale on the index bar to measure the amount of extension.

\item Measure the natural frequency, $\omega_{0}$, of the system. Remove the damping magnets from the system, and set the FUNCTION switch to PERIOD. Pull and release the damping bar. The digital display should stabilize to a roughly constant reading for the period of the system. Determine the period for at least five different masses {\bf including no extra mass}.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{\bf Align and Calibrate the Apparatus}
\begin{enumerate}[resume]

\item Align the DHMA as shown in Figure \ref{fig:doAlignmentOfDampingBar}. This can be done by adjusting the two levelling feet on the bottom of the apparatus, and by twisting the eye that attaches the spring to the bar.  A realignment should be carried out any time an extra mass is added or the spring is changed. If the DHMA is moved or bumped the alignment should be rechecked.

\item The solid bar detects when the top of the black bar passes in front of the sensor, and when this happens the LED in the sensor housing will blink. When the spring is in equilibrium, the top of the solid black bar on the index bar should coincide with the optical sensor. Use the coarse and fine drive cord adjust to position the bar so the the smallest of perturbations of the mass causes the LED to blink. It may even be possible to position the bar so that when the mass is stationary the LED will flicker. If the LED does not blink at all try taking the index bar out, rotate it horizontally, and put it back in place. Be sure to realign as per step 1. 
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{\bf Determine the Damping Coefficient and Frequency for System with Minimum Damping}
Recall that the equation of motion for an underdamped oscillator is 
\begin{equation}
y(t)=Ae^{-\gamma t}cos\left(\omega_{d}t+\phi\right),
\label{equ:doUnderDampedAgain}
\end{equation}
and that the period of the the system is,
\begin{equation}
T=2\pi / \omega_{d}.
\end{equation}

\begin{enumerate}[resume]
\item Adjust the magnet positions for minimum damping (magnets as far away from the damping bar as possible). Measure the magnet spacing with calipers.

\item Measure the damped frequency, $\omega_{d}$, of the system. Set the FUNCTION switch to PERIOD. Pull and release the damping bar. The digital display should stabilize to a roughly constant reading for the period of the system. %Determine the period for at least five different masses {\bf including no extra mass}.

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[thick](.5,0)--(.5,4);
\draw[thick,->](.5,2)--(4.7,2);
\draw[thick,domain=.5:4.43, samples=100]plot(\x, {2*exp(-.4*\x)*sin(\x*220-80)+2});
\draw[dashed](.5,3.6)arc(250:265:15 and 21.8);
\begin{scope}[yscale=-1, shift=({0,-4})]
\draw[dashed](.5,3.6)arc(250:265:15 and 21.8);
\end{scope}
\draw[very thin](.75,3.6)--(.45,3.6);
\draw[very thin](.75,2.9)--(.45,2.9);
\draw[very thin](2,2)--(2,0);
\draw[very thin](3.6,2)--(3.6,0);
\draw[very thin,<->](2,.1)--(3.6,.1);
\draw[very thin](.45,.4)--(.75,.4);
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(.3,.4){-A};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(.3,3.6){A};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(.25,2.9){y$_0$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(.2,2){y2(t)};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(4.8,2){t};
\node[font=\scriptsize,fill=white,inner sep=2]at(2.8,.1){2$\pi$/$\omega_0$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(2.5,3.2){Ae$^{-(\frac{\gamma}{2m})t}$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(4.3,1.4){-Ae$^{-(\frac{\gamma}{2m})t}$};
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Undriven and Underdamped}
\label{fig:doUndrivenAndUnderdamped}
\end{marginfigure}


\item Determine the damping coefficient $c$. For the DHMA, the system is always underdamped when magnetic damping is used regardless of the position of the magnets.  In the undriven underdamped case Figure \ref{fig:doUndrivenAndUnderdamped} shows that the peak amplitudes of the motion lie on an exponential curve.

Notice that Equation \ref{equ:doUnderDampedAgain} predicts that $y(t)$ will be a maximum whenever $\omega_{d}t-\phi = 2\pi$, or rather $cos\left(\omega_{d}t-\phi\right) =1$. Equation \ref{equ:doUnderDampedAgain} can be written as 
\begin{equation}
y(t)=Ae^{-\gamma T N},
\label{equ:doDecayPerCycle} 
\end{equation} 
where $N$ is the total number of cycles. 
Finally by taking the natural log of each side Equation \ref{equ:doDecayPerCycle} becomes,
\begin{equation}
ln(y)=-\gamma T N +ln(A).
\label{equ:doDecayPerCycle2}
\end{equation}
A graph of logarithm of peak amplitudes versus $N$ gives a line with slope of $-\gamma T =-cT / 2 m$, from which the damping coefficient can be determined. Set the FUNCTION switch to AMPL and DRIVE off. Pull the damping bar down and release it. Watch the digital readout and observe that the peak amplitudes decrease with time as expected. Obtain data of amplitude versus oscillation number for $50$ to $100$ cycles. Note the amplitude every fourth or fifth cycle.

\subsection{\bf Determine the Damping Coefficient and Frequency for System with Maximum Damping}

\item Move the magnets as close together as possible without rubbing the damping bar to get maximum damping. Measure the magnet spacing and then repeat steps $5$, $6$, and $7$. Since the oscillations may damp out quickly, the peak amplitude has to be noted down more often than every fourth or fifth cycle.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{comment}

\item Determine the resonance curve of the system. Set the amplitude of the forcing function to 1mm. Any larger and the system will move out of range at resonance. Adjust the damping magnets for minimum damping and leave no extra masses on 
the bar. For frequencies from 0.5 Hz to 3.0 Hz in increments of about 0.2 Hz, determine the steady state amplitude. Set the FUNCTION switch to FREQ and DRIVE on. Adjust the FREQUENCY control until the digital display reads the desired 
driving frequency. Then set the FUNCTION switch to AMPL and measure the peak amplitude. Remember to let the amplitude reading stabilize so that the steady state solution is measured and not the natural solution. Near resonance the 
frequencies should be stepped at smaller intervals. Determine the frequency that gives maximum response.

\item Perform any one of the following investigations.

\begin{enumerate}

\item Show that all the undriven solutions decay to zero if damping is present. Show that without an initial displacement or initial velocity the undriven system remains motionless for all time. For an undriven system that is undamped or 
underdamped, is it possible to make the mass oscillate at a higher frequency by pulling harder on the mass to start it moving? Why or why not? Design and implement an experiment to test this. Present your results.

\begin{equation}
P=F\frac{dx}{dt},
\end{equation}
where the driving force, F, is of the form
\begin{equation}
F=F_{0}cos\left(\omega t + \theta \right),
\end{equation}
and the position of the system, x, has the form
\begin{equation}

\end{equation}

would you expect maximum power to be delivered to the mass bar? In the driven underdamped case examine the formula for the phase angle $\theta$. Which value of $\omega_{d}$ gives a phase angle of $\theta_{max}$? Is this the resonant 
frequency? Why or why not?

\item Derive the actual equation of the forcing function from the geometry of the drive wheel and cam. Show that it approximates Equation \ref{equ:doForcingFunction} under the conditions of the experiment.

\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}
\end{comment}

\section{Error Analysis}

A major source of error in this experiment is the deviation of the mass spring system from the ideal. The largest error is motion of the spring and masses in other directions than the vertical, which cannot be readily quantified with this apparatus. The masses as found on the digital balance can be considered to be exact. The frequency and period measurements made by the DHMA can also be assumed to be exact. The amplitude measurements are made by the instrument internally and electronically. Since the exact measurement process is not known and the error not documented a reasonable error cannot be determined. However, the DHMA measurement errors are smaller than perturbations from nonvertical motions of the mass spring system itself. This leaves the error in measuring the spring extension which is half the smallest division on the index bar. Since most of the errors are small or unquantified, error analysis is not required for this experiment.

\section{Preparation}

Review the mathematics of the forced damped harmonic oscillator.

\section{Goal of the Experiment}

To understand and measure the behaviour of a forced harmonic oscillator system with damping. To gain experience with dynamical systems.

\section{Theory}

A mass hanging from an idealized vertical spring forms a harmonic oscillator. The mass moves with {\bf simple harmonic motion} that will continue on indefinitely. The mass is expected to oscillate forever. However, in a real physical system, the mass bobbing at the end of the spring eventually comes to rest. The amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminishes to zero. This happens because energy is removed from the system. The physical spring gradually converts mechanical energy into thermal energy that is then lost to the environment. Other forces such as air resistance also contribute. All of these energy losses {\bf damp out} the oscillations. A more accurate model of a physical spring and mass system must therefore include energy losses due to {\bf damping}.

Another feature of the idealized spring-mass system is that all energy is input into the system at the start. No further energy is added later. The energy in the mass and spring system is introduced by stretching the spring before release (adding potential energy), or by giving the mass an initial velocity (adding kinetic energy), or both. Once the mass is released, the energy content of the system does not decrease or increase. A system that only has energy input at time zero is called an {\bf unforced} or {\bf undriven} system. 

Suppose however that the support the spring hangs from were moved up and down while the mass is moving. Here, energy can be added to the system on a continuous basis. Such a system is called a {\bf forced} or {\bf driven} system. The equation describing how the spring support moves with time is called the {\bf forcing function}. This experiment examines a driven damped harmonic oscillator where the forcing function is a cosine wave at a single frequency.

\caption{Forced damped harmonic oscillator}
\label{fig:foForcedDampedHarmonicOscillator}
\end{marginfigure}

Figure \ref{fig:foForcedDampedHarmonicOscillator} shows a forced damped harmonic oscillator. Masses and a damping bar are supported by the spring. The upper end of the spring is not fixed. Instead, it is connected to a driver that changes the position of the upper end of the spring. The spring obeys Hooke's Law with spring constant $k$. The damping bar extends between two permanent magnets. As the bar oscillates, eddy currents are generated in the bar that produce heat, thus removing energy from the oscillator. This damping device is called an {\bf eddy current damper}. Using the index bar, the guide and sensor can measure the system position. 

Coordinates must be assigned to the system in Figure \ref{fig:foForcedDampedHarmonicOscillator} in order to derive the equation of motion. Define the {\bf zero point} as the origin. Let the distance to the {\bf index point} from the zero point be the position, $y$. Define the positive direction to be down. The position of the system is then determined by how far the index point is from the sensor guide zero point, and whether it is above (negative) or below (positive) the 
sensor guide zero point. 

In the case of the driven damped harmonic oscillator there are three forces present. There is the driving force, a restoring force applied by a spring, and a damping force applied by an eddy current damper.

The equation of motion for this system can be derived from the expression
\begin{equation}
\vec{F}_{net}=\vec{F}_{drive}+\vec{F}_{damp}+\vec{F}_{spring}.
\label{equ:foNewtonsSecondLaw}
\end{equation}

The driving force a periodic function defined by $F_{drive}=F_{0}cos(\omega t)$, where $F_{0}$ is the maximum magnitude of the driving force, and $\omega$ is the frequency of the driving force. The damping force is a velocity dependent force defined by $F_{damp}=-cv$, where $c$ is the damping coefficient, and $v$ is the velocity of the system. Note that the damping force always opposes the direction of motion. The spring force is $F_{spring}=-ky$ where $k$ is the spring constant of the spring, and $y$ is the system's displacement from its equilibrium position.

Equation \ref{equ:foNewtonsSecondLaw} can now be written as,

\begin{equation}
ma=F_{0}cos(\omega t)-ky-cv,
\label{equ:foEquationOfMotion1}
\end{equation} 
where $m$ is the effective total mass given by the mass of the damping bar, the index bar, the extra applied masses, and one third the mass of the spring all added together.

If Equation \ref{equ:foEquationOfMotion1} is re-written  in Newton's notation and divided by $m$ the result is a differential equation of the form
\begin{equation}
\ddot{y}+ 2 \gamma \dot{y} + \omega_{0}^{2}y =\frac{F_{0}}{m}cos(\omega t),
\label{equ:foEquationOfMotion2}
\end{equation}
where  $\gamma=c/2m$ is the {\bf damping force frequency}, and $\omega_{0}^{2}=k/m$ is the {\bf natural frequency} of the undamped oscillator. This is the equation of motion for the damped undriven harmonic oscillator.

\marginnote{For a complete derivation of equations \ref{equ:foAmplitude} and \ref{equ:foPhase} see Fowles \& Cassiday, "Analytical Mechanics", 7th ed. pg 113-117.}

This system will go from rest to a steady oscillation at the same frequency $\omega$. The amplitude and phase of the oscillations depends dramatically on the driving frequency, $\omega$. The amplitude, A, of the oscillation is 



\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=0.6]
\Large
\begin{axis}[
%       restrict y to domain=0:6,
        samples=500,
        xlabel=$\omega/\omega_0$,
        ylabel=$A/(F_0/k)$,
        domain=0:3,
        grid=major,
        xmin=0,
        xmax=3,
        ymin=0,
        ymax=5.1,
        legend pos= north east
]

\addplot[red!70!black, dotted, very thick, domain=0:3]{
        1./sqrt((1-x^2)^2+4*x^2*(0.1)^2)
};


\addplot[green!70!black, dashed, very thick, domain=0:3]{
        1./sqrt((1-x^2)^2+4*x^2*(0.3)^2)
};

\addplot[blue!70!black, very thick, domain=0:3]{
        1./sqrt((1-x^2)^2+4*x^2*(0.7)^2)
};
\legend{$\gamma/\omega_0=0.1$,$\gamma/\omega_0=0.3$,$\gamma/\omega_0=0.7$}
\end{axis}
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{The amplitude of the oscillation as a function of driving frequency, for different degrees of damping.}
\label{fig:foResonanceCurve}
\end{marginfigure}

\begin{equation}
A(\omega)=\frac{F_{0} / m}{\sqrt{(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2})^{2}+4\gamma^{2}\omega^{2}}},
\label{equ:foAmplitude}
\end{equation}
and the phase of the oscillation is
\begin{equation}
tan(\phi)=\frac{2\gamma \omega}{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}.
\label{equ:foPhase}
\end{equation}

Figure \ref{fig:foResonanceCurve} shows a plot of the amplitude's dependence on the driving frequency.  The horizontal axis gives a measure of the driving frequency in terms of the natural frequency, $\omega_0$.  Similarly the amplitude is given in units of $F_0/k$. Observe that when the driving frequency vanishes ($\omega = 0$) all the amplitudes converge to the same value ($A(0) = F/k$).

Figure \ref{fig:foResonanceCurve} also shows that there is a peak, more pronounced the less damping there is, for a particular value of the driving frequency. This frequency is known as the \textbf{resonant frequency}, $\omega_{r}$, which is given by

\begin{equation}
\omega_{r}=\sqrt{\omega_{0}^{2}-2\gamma^{2}},
\label{equ:foResonantFrequency}
\end{equation} 
which can be derived by taking the derivative of Equation \ref{equ:foAmplitude} with respect to $\omega$ and setting the result to zero.

Notice that Equation \ref{equ:foResonantFrequency} suggests that as the resonance frequency decreases as the damping force increases. It is also worth noting that the amplitude of the oscillator decreases as the driving frequency increases. This is due to that fact that the oscillator has a more difficult time responding to the higher frequencies, and therefore will not be able to increase its amplitude. 

The phase of the oscillation relative to that of the driving force also varies with the driving frequency, as seen in Figure \ref{fig:foPhase}. At very low driving frequencies, the oscillation is essentially in phase with the driving force, while at very high frequencies the oscillation tends to be out of phase with the driving force by 180$^\circ$ (or $\phi = \pi$). The transition is again clearer with low damping. Equation \ref{equ:foPhase} shows that when $\omega = \omega_0$ the phase $\phi = \pi/2$ (since $\tan \phi \rightarrow \infty$) for all possible values of the damping constant $\gamma$.  This is also seen in Figure \ref{fig:foResonanceCurve} where all of the phase transitions pass through $\phi = \pi/2$ for $\omega/\omega_0 = 1$.

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=0.6]
\Large
\begin{axis}[
        restrict y to domain=0:3.2,
        samples=500,
        xlabel=$\omega/\omega_0$,
        ylabel=$\phi$,
        domain=0:3,
        grid=major,
        xmin=0,
        xmax=3,
        ymin=-0.1,
        ymax=3.5,
        legend pos= south east
]

\addplot[red!70!black, dotted, very thick, domain=0:1]{
        atan(2*0.1*x/(1.-x^2))*pi/180.
};

\addplot[red!70!black, dotted, very thick, domain=1:3]{
        atan(2*0.1*x/(1.-x^2))*pi/180+pi
};

\addplot[green!70!black, dashed, very thick, domain=0:1]{
        atan(2*0.3*x/(1.-x^2))*pi/180.
};

\addplot[green!70!black, dashed, very thick, domain=1:3]{
        atan(2*0.3*x/(1.-x^2))*pi/180+pi
};

\addplot[blue!70!black, very thick, domain=0:1]{
        atan(2*0.7*x/(1.-x^2))*pi/180.
};

\addplot[blue!70!black, very thick, domain=1:3]{
        atan(2*0.7*x/(1.-x^2))*pi/180+pi
};

\legend{$\gamma/\omega_0=0.1$,,$\gamma/\omega_0=0.3$,,$\gamma/\omega_0=0.7$}
\end{axis}
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{The phase difference between the driving force and the resulting oscillation.}
\label{fig:foPhase}
\end{marginfigure}

Figures \ref{fig:foResonanceCurve} and \ref{fig:foPhase} show the dependence of both the amplitude and phase of the forced harmonic oscillator on both the driving frequency $\omega$ and damping constant $\gamma$. The experiment in this lab will primarily focus on the creating an amplitude-frequency curve similar to that shown in Figure \ref{fig:foResonanceCurve}.
\\
%This experiment will examine the undriven underdamped harmonic oscillator with two different magnitudes of damping force. %operating in several of the modes described above. The apparatus permits measurements of the system position so that the theoretical equations of motion can be checked.

Figure \ref{fig:foForcedDampedHarmonicOscillator} shows the damped harmonic motion analyzer (DHMA) used in this experiment. The DHMA includes digital readouts necessary for direct measurements of the period, extent of travel, and phase of the index bar. A sinusoidal forcing function is provided with readout and 
adjustment of the driving frequency. Also included, is a manual adjustment for setting and reading the forcing function amplitude.

The DHMA power switch is located at the rear of the unit. The forcing function driving wheel is also located there. As shown in Figure \ref{fig:foForcedDampedHarmonicOscillator}, a manual slide with a scale permits the operator to read and adjust the driving amplitude. The forcing function is engaged and disengaged by the front panel DRIVE switch. The drive frequency $f_{d}=\omega_{d} / 2\pi$ is adjusted with the front panel FREQUENCY control. When the readout 
selector is switched to FREQ., the digital readout gives the forcing frequency, $f_{d}$ , in Hertz.

Observe that the index bar has a scale on one side and a black rectangle on the other side. The black rectangle should be on the right as seen from the front of the DHMA. The blackened and transparent areas on this index bar are used to interrupt a light beam inside the mass guide sensor. The red light on the front of the mass guide is lit whenever the black rectangle is below the guide and off when this rectangle breaks the light beam. The top edge of the black rectangle is the {\bf index point} as shown in Figure \ref{fig:foForcedDampedHarmonicOscillator}. This is considered to be the origin of the coordinate system used by the DHMA. When the mass is oscillating, the flashing phase LED is timed by internal circuitry to give a digital readout of the {\bf period}. The black scale marks on the left side of the index bar are counted as they pass the optical sensor inside the mass guide. The total count of scale marks in each period is a digital measurement of the {\bf travel distance} of the index bar in one period. Lastly, the time difference between when the index point passes the optical sensor and when the forcing function drive wheel passes its zero point gives a digital readout of the {\bf phase}.

In order for the system to perform properly and conform to Equation \ref{equ:foEquationOfMotion2}, the DHMA must be correctly adjusted. The index bar should move through the mass guide and sensor without rubbing. This is accomplished by the levelling screws at the base of the unit and the spade lug connecting the spring to the index bar. Figure \ref{fig:foAlignmentOfDampingBar} gives the details.

The next adjustment to be made sets the forcing function phase to $0^{\circ}$. Move the index bar up and down. Notice that when the phase set LED flashes, so does a lamp inside the phase angle display at the front of the DHMA. Manually turn the driving wheel at the rear of the DHMA until this phase display reads $0^{\circ}$. This adjustment aligns the phase display with the index bar coordinate system.

Lastly, the length of the driving cord needs to be adjusted to conform with the requirements of Equation \ref{equ:foAmplitude}. This effectively sets the origin of the DHMA coordinate system to be at the index point. Use the drive cord coarse adjust to position the top of the black rectangle even with the phase set LED when the system is at rest. At this position small oscillations of the index bar will cause the phase set LED to turn on and off. Next adjust the drive cord fine adjust at the top of the DHMA until the amplitude of the index bar oscillations that make the phase set LED flash are as small as possible.

These adjustments should be rechecked every time the spring is changed or masses are added to 
the index bar. It remains to be experimentally determined whether the actual dynamics of the system correspond to the solution of the forced damped harmonic oscillator equation as described above.

\section{\bf Experimental Procedure}

\subsection{\bf Measure the Parameters of the System}
According to the equations of motion for the system there are $3$ parameters that govern the motion. The mass $m$, the spring constant $k$, and damping coefficient $c$. All three can be measured. 
\begin{enumerate}

\item Using the digital balance, determine the mass of the spring and the objects hanging from it (the index bar, damping bar, and all additional masses). If the mass of the spring is not negligible, then the effective mass of the system is the sum of the masses hanging from the spring and one third of the spring mass.

\item The spring constant, $k$, is found from Hooke's law. Add mass to the index bar in steps of $5$ to $20$ grams for at least 8 points between $0$ and $100$. Plotting applied force versus extension gives a line with slope $k$. Note that the spring is already extended by the index and damping bars hanging from it. The first data point will then be a spring extension of zero with an applied force of mg Newtons, where $m$ is the mass of the index and damping bars. Use the scale on the index bar to measure the amount of extension.
\end{enumerate}
\subsection{\bf Align and Calibrate the Apparatus}
\begin{enumerate}[resume]


\item Align the DHMA as shown in Figure \ref{fig:foAlignmentOfDampingBar}. This can be done by adjusting the two levelling feet on the bottom of the apparatus, and by twisting the eye that attaches the spring to the bar.  A realignment should be carried out any time an extra mass is added or the spring is changed. If the DHMA is moved or bumped the alignment should be rechecked.

\item The solid bar detects when the top of the black bar passes in front of the sensor, and when this happens the LED in the sensor housing will blink. When the spring is in equilibrium, the top of the solid black bar on the index bar should coincide with the optical sensor. Use the coarse and fine drive cord adjust to position the bar so the the smallest of perturbations of the mass causes the LED to blink. It may even be possible to position the bar so that when the mass is stationary the LED will flicker. If the LED does not blink at all try taking the index bar out, rotate it horizontally, and put it back in place. Be sure to realign as per step 1.% Recall that the natural frequency of the system is $\omega_{0}=\sqrt{k/m}$.
\end{enumerate}



\subsection{\bf Determine the Maximum and Minimum Damping Coefficient}
The equation of motion for an underdamped oscillator is 
\begin{equation}
y(t)=Ae^{-\gamma t}cos\left(\omega_{d}t+\phi\right),
\label{equ:foUnderDampedAgain}
\end{equation}
and that the period of the system is,
\begin{equation}
T=2\pi / \omega_{d},
\label{equ:foDampedPeriod}
\end{equation}
where $T$ is the period, and $\omega_{d}$ is the damped frequency of the damped oscillator.
\begin{enumerate}
\item Adjust the magnet positions for minimum damping (magnets as far away from the damping bar as possible). Measure the magnet spacing with calipers.

\item Measure the damped frequency, $\omega_{d}$, of the system with {\bf no extra mass attached to the bar}. Set the FUNCTION switch to PERIOD. Pull and release the damping bar. The digital display should stabilize to a roughly constant reading for the period of the system.

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[thick](.5,0)--(.5,4);
\draw[thick,->](.5,2)--(4.7,2);
\draw[thick,domain=.5:4.43, samples=100]plot(\x, {2*exp(-.4*\x)*sin(\x*220-80)+2});
\draw[dashed](.5,3.6)arc(250:265:15 and 21.8);
\begin{scope}[yscale=-1, shift=({0,-4})]
\draw[dashed](.5,3.6)arc(250:265:15 and 21.8);
\end{scope}
\draw[very thin](.75,3.6)--(.45,3.6);
\draw[very thin](.75,2.9)--(.45,2.9);
\draw[very thin](2,2)--(2,0);
\draw[very thin](3.6,2)--(3.6,0);
\draw[very thin,<->](2,.1)--(3.6,.1);
\draw[very thin](.45,.4)--(.75,.4);
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(.3,.4){-A};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(.3,3.6){A};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(.25,2.9){y$_0$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(.2,2){y2(t)};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(4.8,2){t};
\node[font=\scriptsize,fill=white,inner sep=2]at(2.8,.1){2$\pi$/$\omega_0$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(2.5,3.2){Ae$^{-(\frac{\gamma}{2m})t}$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(4.3,1.4){-Ae$^{-(\frac{\gamma}{2m})t}$};
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Undriven and Underdamped}
\label{fig:foUndrivenAndUnderdamped}
\end{marginfigure}

\item Determine the damping coefficient $c$. For the DHMA, the system is always underdamped when magnetic damping is used regardless of the position of the magnets.  In the undriven underdamped case Figure \ref{fig:foUndrivenAndUnderdamped} shows that the peak amplitudes of the motion lie on an exponential curve.


Notice that Equation \ref{equ:foUnderDampedAgain} predicts that $y(t)$ will be a maximum whenever $\omega_{d}t-\phi = 2\pi$, or rather $cos\left(\omega_{d}t-\phi\right) =1$. Equation \ref{equ:foUnderDampedAgain} can be written as 
\begin{equation}
y(t)=Ae^{-\gamma T N},
\label{equ:foDecayPerCycle} 
\end{equation} 
where $N$ is the total number of cycles. 
Finally by taking the natural log of each side Equation \ref{equ:foDecayPerCycle} becomes,
\begin{equation}
ln(y)=-\gamma T N +ln(A).
\label{equ:foDecayPerCycle2}
\end{equation}
A graph of logarithm of peak amplitudes versus $N$ gives a line with slope of $-\gamma T =-cT / 2 m$, from which the damping coefficient can be determined. Set the FUNCTION switch to AMPL and DRIVE off. Pull the damping bar down and release it. Watch the digital readout and observe that the peak amplitudes decrease with time as expected. Obtain data of amplitude versus oscillation number for $50$ to $100$ cycles. Note the amplitude every fourth or fifth cycle.

% Notice that Equation \ref{equ:foUnderDampedAgain} predicts that $y(t)$ will be a maximum whenever $\omega_{d}t-\phi = 2\pi$, or rather $cos\left(\omega_{d}t-\phi\right) =1$. Equation \ref{equ:foUnderDampedAgain} can be written as 
%\begin{equation}
%y(t)=e^{-\gamma T N}
%\label{equ:foDecayPerCycle} 
%\end{equation} 
%where $N$ is the total number of cycles. A graph of logarithm of peak amplitude versus $N$ gives a line with slope of $-\gamma T =-c / 2 m$, from which the damping coefficient can be determined. Set the FUNCTION switch to AMPL and DRIVE off. Pull the damping bar down and release it. Watch the digital readout and observe that the peak amplitudes decrease with time as expected. Obtain data of amplitude versus oscillation number for $50$ to $100$ cycles. Note the amplitude every fourth or fifth cycle.

\item Move the magnets as close together as possible without rubbing the damping bar to get maximum damping. Measure the magnet spacing and then repeat steps $5$ - $7$. Since the oscillations may damp out quickly, the peak amplitude has to be noted down more often than every fourth or fifth cycle.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{\bf Determine the Resonance Curves of the Systems}

\begin{enumerate}[resume]

\item Set the amplitude of the forcing function to 1 mm. Any larger and the system will move out of range at resonance. Adjust the damping magnets for minimum damping and leave no extra masses on the bar. Set the FUNCTION switch to FREQ and DRIVE on.

\item To make a measurement adjust the FREQUENCY control until the digital display reads the desired driving frequency. Then set the FUNCTION switch to AMPL and measure the peak amplitude. Remember to let the amplitude reading stabilize so that the steady state solution is measured. Near resonance the frequencies should be stepped at smaller intervals. Record the steady-state amplitude, phase of the driving force, and a record of if the phase is leading or lagging (plus for leading and minus for lagging)

\item For frequencies from 0.5 Hz to 3.0 Hz in increments of about 0.2 Hz, determine the steady state amplitude and phase.

\item Determine the frequency that gives maximum response.

\item Repeat steps 9 - 12 for the system with maximum damping.
\end{enumerate}

\end{comment}

\section{\bf Error Analysis}

A major source of error in this experiment is the deviation of the mass spring system from the ideal. The largest error is motion of the spring and masses in other directions than the vertical, which cannot be readily quantified with this apparatus. The masses as found on the digital balance can be considered to be exact. The frequency and period measurements made by the DHMA can also be assumed to be exact. The amplitude measurements are made by the instrument internally and electronically. Since the exact measurement process is not known and the error not documented a reasonable error cannot be determined. However, the DHMA measurement errors are smaller than perturbations from nonvertical motions of the mass spring system itself. This leaves the error in measuring the spring extension which is half the smallest division on the index bar. Since most of the errors are small or unquantified, error analysis is not required for this experiment.

\chapter{Laboratory Safety}

\section{Introduction}
People who survive to reach adulthood generally acquire a mental list of safety rules that are followed to prevent injury to themselves and others. These rules are learned 
from sources such as parents, teachers, and experience. However, the practice of experimental physics can involve the handling of materials, instruments, and processes that
lie outside the realm of common experience. The rules described here must be added to your mental list to handle these new situations. This is part of your education in 
physics. For the safety of yourself and others you are required to read, understand, and follow these guidelines.

All of the physics experiments you will perform have been designed with the safety of the student in mind. This necessarily assumes that all the apparatus is used in a 
reasonable manner. Do not mishandle or abuse the equipment. Use your common sense. Always maintain an awareness of the consequences of your actions for yourself and others.
No food, drink, or smoking is permitted in the laboratory, to reduce the chance that it will be contaminated before being consumed. Also, spilled drinks can be dangerous 
near electrical equipment. Some physics experiments use ice or ice water for cooling. Do not eat or drink the ice or ice water, since it may be contaminated. Never work in a
laboratory alone, there should always be someone else present to get help if necessary. In the event of any accident in the lab, you must notify your instructor immediately.
The following comments describe the hazards you may encounter while in a physics laboratory and the relevant safety procedures to follow.

\section{Heavy Metals}
Lead is used for shielding in radiation experiments. Heavy metals such as lead can be absorbed into your body through the skin and mouth. They accumulate in the brain and 
eventually cause brain damage when a large enough amount is present. The total dosage of lead in the brain builds up over your lifetime as a function of total  accumulated 
exposure. Minimize your exposure to lead in the laboratory by handling it as little as possible. Do not touch any food or your face while working with lead. Wash your hands
after handling lead objects. Lead is also very dense. Be aware of this when moving blocks of lead and do not drop them.

Observe the same precautions when doing an experiment that uses mercury. As with lead, mercury can also be absorbed into the body to accumulate over your lifetime. Mercury 
has the added properties that it is a liquid which can be spilled and any open container of liquid mercury produces mercury vapour which can be inhaled. Avoid spilling 
mercury and try to keep it in a sealed container if possible. Make sure there is a spill tray underneath any experiment that involves the use of mercury. If mercury does get
spilled, notify your instructor so that it can be cleaned up. 

\section{Radiation}
The total dose of radiation you receive depends on the source intensity, the time you are exposed, and your distance from the source. For x-rays and gamma-rays the source 
intensity drops as the inverse square of the distance. For alpha and beta particles the drop is even faster. Minimize the time that a radioactive source is near you. Keep 
radioactive sources  as far away from you as you reasonably can, consistent with doing the experiment. There are strict regulations about the storage and handling of 
radioactive sources. Do not open, drop or lose them.

\section{Lasers}
Lasers are sources of concentrated parallel beams of monochromatic light, which can quite easily be focussed to tiny spots where the power density is high enough to cause 
damage. Never look into a laser beam, or let it shine into your eye, since you may suffer retinal damage if the laser power is high enough. Reflections from polished 
surfaces are almost as dangerous as the direct beam. Never shine a laser into someone elseâs eyes. Resist the temptation to shine the laser around the room or into the 
hallway. If this is done a person could accidentally gaze into the beam.

\section{Rotating Machinery}
Some experiments use pumps, motors, or other moving mechanisms. Keep fingers and other appendages away from such devices. Be especially careful about long hair and 
loose clothing.

\section{Electricity}
Always wire together your circuits with the power off. Make sure the circuit power is off when changing or moving components around. If you must work on live 
circuits only touch the insulated portions and make sure one hand is in your pocket or behind your back. This eliminates the possibility of current flow through the heart 
and lungs, which can be fatal. Do not touch live exposed connections under any circumstances. Beware of loose wires which can fall off or make unintentional connections, 
usually with undesirable results. Be especially vigilant around high voltage circuits. If the voltage is high enough, it is not necessary to touch the circuit to get a 
shock, since sparks can jump across a gap of air. Capacitors require particular care since they can store charge internally for hours after being disconnected from a 
circuit. Make sure capacitors are discharged before touching the terminals. When using spark timers on the air tracks make sure the hands of all your lab partners are clear
before starting the spark source.

\section{Cryogenic Materials}
Some physics experiments involve the use of liquid nitrogen, liquid helium, dry ice, or an organic solvent cooled with dry ice. These materials are cold. Do not touch them 
with your hands. Wear protective gloves when handling a container containing a cryogenic material. Do not splash or spill these cold liquids. Be careful not to touch parts 
that have been in contact with a cryogenic material, they will be cold as well. If a spill does happen, notify your instructor but do not touch the spill, it will evaporate
naturally. There must always be a way for evaporated cryogenic liquid to escape from a vessel, otherwise a dangerous build-up of pressure will occur.

\section{Pressure and vacuum vessels}
Gas bottles are under high pressure. If they are breached they will explode with the force of a bomb. Never jar or mishandle a pressure vessel when it is pressurized. 
Vacuum systems will implode when breached. Do not jar or abuse them either. Always bring the vacuum (or pressure) back to normal slowly. Before adjusting any valves make 
sure you understand the purpose of each valve and the consequences of operating it. Turn it slowly at first so you can change your mind if something seems to be wrong.

\section{Microwaves}
People wearing heart pacemakers or other life supporting electro-metallic implants should refrain from doing physics experiments that involve microwaves.

\section{Strong Magnetic Fields}
Strong magnetic fields will erase your credit cards, computer disks, and audio tapes. They will also damage watches, tape players, and other electronic devices. Do not leave
any such objects near a strong magnet or electromagnet. Check the area around an electromagnet before turning it on. People wearing heart pacemakers or other life supporting
electro-metallic implants should also refrain from doing physics experiments that involve powerful magnetic fields. Anything containing a magnet, or magnetic material like 
iron, steel, nickel, or cobalt, should also be kept away from strong magnetic fields. They may be damaged or pulled into the region of the field with enough force to break 
something.

\section{Stroboscopes}
Some people are susceptible to epileptic seizures or severe migraine headaches if they view strobe lights flashing at a frequency of 5 to 25 Hz. Refrain from doing an 
experiment involving strobe lights if you know you are susceptible. Notify the instructor immediately if you see someone adversely affected by an operating stroboscope.

\section{Preparation}
Review the laws of reflection and refraction and Snell's law. Understand the concept of total internal reflection. Review the geometry of a prism. Know the lensmaker's equation.

\section{Purpose}
To study and observe the laws of reflection and refraction. To understand and practice optical ray tracing. To observe the operation of mirrors and prisms. To examine light travel in rectangles and equilateral triangles using the laws of reflection and refraction,  or to verify the lensmakers equation.

\section{Theory}
Materials transparent to light are called {\bf optical materials}. It has been found that the speed of light varies in different optical materials. The speed of light is highest in a vacuum. In air the speed is slightly slower. In a solid optical material like glass the speed of light can be less than half of the speed of light in free space. This speed of light difference is an important property of optical materials. The {\bf index of refraction}, or {\bf refractive index}, of an optical material is defined as the ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum to the speed of light in the material. The refractive index of empty space is $1.0$, while the refractive index of all other optical materials is greater than $1.0$. The refractive index of air is about $1.0003$ while the index of refraction of the acrylic plastic used in this experiment is $1.49$. 

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[](0,0)rectangle(5,5);
\draw[fill=lightgray, opacity=.4](0,0)rectangle(5,2.5);
\draw[->](1,5)--(2.5,2.5);
\draw[->](2.5,2.5)--(4,5);
\draw[->](2.5,2.5)--(3.2,.5);
\draw[ultra thin](2.5,4.5)--(2.5,1);
\node[scale=1]at(2.75,3.35){$\varphi$};
\node[scale=1]at(2.25,3.35){$\varphi$};
\node[scale=1]at(2.67,1.4){$\varphi'$};
\node[scale=1]at(.5,2.8){$n$};
\node[scale=1]at(.5,2.1){$n'$};
\node[scale=1]at(2.5,4.7){$N$};
\node[scale=1]at(.75,4){incident ray};
\node[scale=1]at(4.25,4){reflected ray};
\node[scale=1]at(4,1){refracted ray};

\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Reflection and refraction of a ray of light at a boundary.}
\label{fig:rr1}
\end{marginfigure}

When a ray of light passes between two optical materials, part of the ray is {\bf reflected} and stays in the first medium while  the remainder is {\bf refracted} and passes into the second medium. Figure \ref{fig:rr1} shows a ray of light crossing an optical boundary. Let the index of refraction of the first medium be $n$ and the second medium be $n'$. A line perpendicular to the boundary called the {\bf surface normal}, $N$, is used to measure the angles of the light rays. The angle the incident ray makes with the normal is called the {\bf angle of incidence}, $\varphi$. The angle the reflected ray makes with the normal is called the {\bf angle of reflection} and the angle the refracted ray makes is called the {\bf angle of refraction}, $\varphi '$. It has been found that the behaviour of reflected and refracted rays can each be described by a law.
	
	
The {\bf law of reflection} states that "{\it the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection and the reflected ray is on the opposite side of the normal from the incident ray and the incident ray, surface normal, and reflected ray all lie in the same plane}". The {\bf law of refraction} states that "{\it the sine of the angle of incidence and the the sine of the angle of refraction are in constant ratio to each other and the refracted ray lies on the opposite side of the normal from the incident ray and the incident ray, surface normal, and refracted ray all lie in the same plane}". The law of refraction is also known as {\bf Snell's law}. The constant in Snell's law is the ratio of the refractive indices of the two materials $n$ and $n'$. The law of refraction is usually written as

\begin{equation}
\dfrac{\sin\varphi}{\sin\varphi'}=\dfrac{n'}{n}
\label{equ:rr1}
\end{equation}

There are three possible cases; $n<n'$, $n=n'$, and $n>n'$. When $n<n'$, the light rays pass from a rarified medium like air to a denser medium like glass. The reflected portion of the light remains in the rarified medium. This is called {\bf external reflection}. As expected from the law of reflection, the incident ray and the reflected ray both are at the same angle with respect to the normal. The refracted part of the light enters the glass with an angle $\varphi '$ that is determined by the law of refraction. For the smallest possible incident angle of $0^{\circ}$ the refracted ray is also at $0^{\circ}$. For other incident angles the angle of refraction will always be {\bf smaller} than the incident angle.

The case $n=n'$ happens when light passes through a boundary between two materials with the same index of refraction or through a single material without a boundary.  Here, the angle of incidence always equals the angle of refraction. So the path of the incident ray and the path of the refracted ray are identical. As a ray of light travels through a single medium it can be imagined that there is an imaginary boundary with $n=n'$ at every point along the path of the light ray. At every boundary, the refracted ray is in the same path as the incident ray. It appears as if the ray travels through the material in a straight line. This explains why light rays travel in straight lines and cast shadows.

The case of $n>n'$ happens when light from a denser medium like acrylic enters a rarer medium like air. The reflected part of the light stays inside the acrylic. This is called {\bf internal reflection} and obeys the law of reflection as expected. The refracted part of the incident ray leaves the acrylic and enters the air with an angle $\varphi '$ that is found from the law of refraction. As with the other two cases, an incident angle of $0^{\circ}$ refracts to an angle of $0^{\circ}$. For all other incident angles the refracted angle will be {\bf larger} than the incident angle. At the critical angle, $\varphi '_c$, given by
\begin{equation}
\varphi_c'=\sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{n}{n'}\right)
\label{equ:rr2}
\end{equation}

\noindent the refracted ray has an angle of $90^{\circ}$. For acrylic with an index of refraction of $1.49$, the critical angle is $42.16^{\circ}$. At incident angles above the critical angle there is no refraction. Instead, the entire ray reflects inside the acrylic. This is called {\bf total internal reflection}. 

The laws of reflection and refraction can be used to examine the passage of light through a plate with plane parallel surfaces. Figure \ref{fig:rr2} below shows an incident ray and the reflected and refracted rays at the boundaries between the air and the acrylic. The light ray emerges from the plate parallel to the original ray but laterally displaced from it.

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[](0,0)rectangle(5,5);
%\draw[](0,0)rectangle(11,8);

\draw[](4,2)rectangle(7,6);
\def\sc{.8}
\def\sca{.7}
\def\scb{.6}
\draw[->](1.8,1)--(4,2.9);
\draw[->,dashed](4,2.9)--(1.8,4.8);
\draw[->](4,2.9)--(7,4);
\draw[->,dashed](7,4)--(4,5.1);
\draw[->,dashed](4,5.1)--(1.8,7);

\node[scale=\scb]at(1,6.7){refracted ray};
\node[scale=\scb]at(1,6.4){(from $n'$ to $n$)};

\node[scale=\scb]at(8.8,5){refracted ray};
\node[scale=\scb]at(8.8,4.7){(from $n'$ to $n$)};
\node[scale=\scb]at(6.1,3.3){refracted ray};
\node[scale=\scb]at(6.1,3){(from $n$ to $n'$)};
\node[scale=\scb]at(1.7,4.1){externally};
\node[scale=\scb]at(1.7,3.8){reflected ray};
\node[scale=\scb]at(1.5,1.6){incident ray};
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Internal reflection and refraction of a light ray passing through a transparent block.}
\label{fig:rr2}
\end{figure}



Incident ray AB partly (about $5\%$) reflects externally to generate the reflected ray BG. The rest of the incident light refracts to ray BC. At the other end of the plate, ray BC internally reflects to give ray CE and refracts to produce ray CD, the exiting light. Ray CE behaves similarly and yields a refracted ray and an internally reflected ray which in turn gives a refracted and reflected component and so on. Note that because the sides of the plate are parallel, rays AB and CD are parallel, rays BG and EF are parallel, all internal angles are equal to the refraction angle $\varphi '$, and all external angles are equal to the incident angle $\varphi$.

If the sides of the plate are not parallel, the deviation produced by the first refraction is not undone by the second refraction. So the incident rays and exiting rays are not parallel. A $prism$ takes advantage of this fact by inclining two surfaces at an angle $\alpha$ to achieve a desired amount of deviation, $\delta$. Figure \ref{fig:rr3} shows an {\bf equilateral prism}. Here the sides are all inclined at $\alpha=60^{\circ}$ to each other.

Suppose that the laws of reflection and refraction are both followed by light travelling inside the prism. Let lines MM' and PP' be surface normals and let ray AB have incident angle $\varphi_1$. The angle of deviation of the refracted ray BC from the first surface is given by $\beta=\varphi_1-\varphi_1'$. Ray BC is further deviated by angle $\gamma=\varphi_2-\varphi_2'$ when it exits the prism at the second surface to give exit ray CD. The total {\bf deviation} of ray CD from ray AB is

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[](0,0)--(3,4.3)--(6,0)--cycle; %prism
\draw[very thin](.5,2.5)--(3.5,.4); %MM'
\draw[very thin](5.5,2.8)--(2,.36); %MM'
\draw[thick,->](0,1.5)--(1.32,1.91)--(4.52,2.12)--(6,1.7); %refracted path
\draw[very thin](0,1.5)--(4.5,2.9); %line A
\draw[very thin](6,1.7)--(3.2,2.5); %line D
\draw[thick,->](1.32,1.91)--(1.2,3); %line F
\draw[thick,->](4.52,2.12)--(4,1); %line E
%arrows
\draw[thick,->](0,1.5)--(.8,1.75);
\draw[thick,->](1.32,1.91)--(3,2.02);
%labels
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(.9,1.55){$\varphi_1$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(1.1,2.3){$\varphi_r$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(2.4,2.1){$\beta$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(3.7,2.5){$\delta$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(2.5,.9){$\alpha$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(3,4){$\alpha$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(4.9,2.15){$\varphi_2$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(3.85,1.9){$\varphi_2'$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(2,1.7){$\varphi_1'$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(3.7,2.2){$\gamma$};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(.2,1.3){A};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(1.38,1.65){B};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(.3,2.6){M};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(1.2,3.2){F};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(1.8,.3){P$'$};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(3.7,.3){M$'$};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(3.9,.8){E};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(2.8,.7){N};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(4.5,2.4){C};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(5.6,2.9){P};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(5.7,1.5){D};
\node[font=\footnotesize,rotate=-55]at(5.3,.7){n};
\node[font=\scriptsize,rotate=-55]at(5.6,.9){n$'$=1.0};
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{An illustration of a prism with incident light rays being reflected and refracted through the medium.}
\label{fig:rr3}
\end{marginfigure}



\begin{equation}
\delta=\beta+\gamma=\varphi_1+\varphi_2-\varphi_1'-\varphi_2'
\label{equ:rr3}
\end{equation}

Angle MNP' is $\alpha$ so triangle BCN implies

\begin{equation}
\alpha = \varphi_1'+\varphi_2'
\label{equ:rr4}
\end{equation}

\noindent so

\begin{equation}
\delta = \varphi_1+\varphi_2-\alpha
\label{equ:rr5}
\end{equation}

Angle $\varphi_2$ is determined by the laws of refraction at the entrance and exit of the prism and $\alpha$ is a constant for a given prism. So Equation \ref{equ:rr5} implies that the angle of deviation for a given prism only depends on the incident angle of the ray and the index of refraction of the prism.

Figure \ref{fig:rr4} shows a graph of the expected deviation of an equilateral acrylic prism. The constants for this prism are $\alpha = 60^{\circ}$ and $n' = 1.49$. As the incident angle decreases from $90^{\circ}$, the deviation decreases to a minimum value of $36.3^{\circ}$. This minimum is called the {\bf angle of minimum deviation}, $\delta_m$. At this angle, ray BC is parallel to the base of the prism. There is a relation between this minimum angle of deviation and the constants of the prism, which is

\begin{equation}
n'=\dfrac{\sin^{-1}\left[\frac{1}{2}(\alpha+\delta_m)\right]}{\sin(\frac{1}{2}\alpha)}
\label{equ:rr6}
\end{equation}

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
\draw[](0,4.38)--(0,0)--(5.28,0);
%ytics
\foreach \y in {0,.146,...,4.38}{
\draw[](0,0+\y)--(.05,0+\y);
}
\foreach \y/\n in {0/30,.73/35,1.46/40,2.19/45,2.92/50,3.65/55,4.38/60}{
\draw[](-.07,0+\y)--(0,0+\y);
\node[left]at(-.1,0+\y){\n};
}
%xtics
\foreach \x in {0,.132,...,5.28}{
\draw[](0+\x,0)--(0+\x,.05);
}
\foreach \x/\n in {0/10,.66/20,1.32/30,1.98/40,2.64/50,3.3/60,3.96/70,4.62/80,5.28/90}{
\draw[](0+\x,-.07)--(0+\x,0);
\node[below]at(0+\x,-.1){\n};
}
%function
\draw[very thick,domain=1.25:4.5] plot [samples=200] (\x, {pow((\x-1.0),-1.0)+pow((\x-.4),1.1)-1.4});
%dashed lines
\draw[dashed](1.1,0)--(1.1,4.5);
\draw[dashed](1.92,0)--(1.92,1.25);
\draw[dashed](1.92,1.25)--(4,1.25);
\node[circle,fill,scale=.4]at(1.92,1.25){};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(4.2,1.25){$\delta_m$};
%labels
\node[font=\footnotesize,rotate=90,shift={(2,1.1)}]at(0,0){Angle of Deviation};
\node[font=\footnotesize,rotate=90,shift={(2,.8)}]at(0,0){(degrees) $\delta$};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(2.5,-.8){Angle of Incidence (degrees) $\varphi$};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(3,4){Incidence angle of};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(3,3.7){critical internal};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(3,3.4){reflection};
\draw[->,thin](1.7,4)--(1.1,4);
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{The expected deviation of an equilateral prism.}
\label{fig:rr4}
\end{marginfigure}

As the incident angle decreases still further, the deviation begins to rise again to a maximum at an incident angle of $27.2^{\circ}$. No deviation is possible at angles smaller than this incidence angle because total internal reflection happens at point C. Ray CD vanishes and ray CE exits out of the bottom face of the prism instead.

The previous objects are all composed of straight sides. Instead, consider an object having sides which are curved. Although the laws of refraction and reflection still hold true, the normal line to which they refer is different at each point on the surface. So parallel rays incident on a curved surface will not remain parallel after reflection from a curved mirror as seen in Figure \ref{fig:rr5}. Similarly, parallel rays incident on a curved surface need not remain parallel after passing through an object as seen in Figure \ref{fig:rr5}.

Consider the lens shown in Figure \ref{fig:rr5}. Each side is produced by a spheroid of given radius $R$ and the index of refraction of the lens material is $n_L$. Furthermore, suppose that  the lens is immersed in air. In this case, the {\bf lensmaker's equation} relates the radii of curvature, $R_1$ and $R_2$, of the two lens surfaces and the index of refraction of the lens material to the focal length by the expression

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[dashed](0,0)rectangle(11,8);

\draw[](0,0)--(0,3)--(.5,3)arc(110:250:.3 and 1.597)--cycle;
\draw[](9,3)arc(110:250:.3 and 1.597)arc(-70:70:.3 and 1.597);
\def\sc{.8}

\draw[->,very thin](3.5,2.8)--(.42,2.8)--(2.5,1);
\draw[->,very thin](3.5,2.3)--(.35,2.3)--(2.5,1.22);
\draw[->,very thin](3.5,1.8)--(.32,1.8)--(2.5,1.4);
\draw[->,very thin](3.5,1.3)--(.32,1.3)--(2.5,1.6);
\draw[->,very thin](3.5,.8)--(.34,.8)--(2.5,1.78);
\draw[->,very thin](3.5,.3)--(.4,.3)--(2.5,2);

\draw[->,very thin](11,2.8)--(9,2.8)--(6,1);
\draw[->,very thin](11,2.3)--(9,2.3)--(6,1.22);
\draw[->,very thin](11,1.8)--(9,1.8)--(6,1.4);
\draw[->,very thin](11,1.3)--(9,1.3)--(6,1.6);
\draw[->,very thin](11,.8)--(9,.8)--(6,1.78);
\draw[->,very thin](11,.3)--(9,.3)--(6,2);

\node[scale=\sc]at(2,3.5){Concave Mirror};
\node[scale=\sc]at(8.5,3.5){Convex Lens};
\node[scale=\sc]at(6.85,0){focal point};
\node[scale=\sc]at(1.9,0){focal point};
\draw[->](6.85,.2)--(6.85,1.47);
\draw[->](1.9,.2)--(1.9,1.47);
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{The focal points of light rays reflecting at concave mirrors and refracting through convex lenses.}
\label{fig:rr5}
\end{figure}


\begin{equation}
\dfrac{1}{f}=(n_L-1)\left(\dfrac{1}{R_1}-\dfrac{1}{R_2}\right)
\label{equ:rr7}
\end{equation}

Note that in this construction, the width of the lens is assumed to be negligibly small in comparison to the distance of object being viewed and the image being formed. Also, the standard convention for a biconvex lens must be used, namely that $R_1>0$ and $R_2<0$. Otherwise Equation \ref{equ:rr7} predicts that a symmetric lens will have an infinite focal length.

The focal point can also be determined by measuring the distance to the object observed and the image produced via the {\bf Gaussian lens formula}
\begin{equation}
\dfrac{1}{f}=\dfrac{1}{i}+\dfrac{1}{o}
\label{equ:rr8}
\end{equation}

\noindent which is valid for both mirrors and lenses.

The radius of curvature for a given spherical lens or mirror may not be known in advance. In this case, the geometric construct shown in Figure \ref{fig:rr6} can be used to measure the radius of curvature. On the arc to be measured, draw any two chords AB and CD. Using a compass and straight edge draw the perpendicular bisectors of these two chords EF and GH. From plane geometry, these two bisectors will intersect at the center of curvature of the arc, point $R$. The radius of curvature can then be measured as the distance between $R$ and the optical surface $S$.

The basic experimental apparatus is shown in Figure \ref{fig:rr7}. A cork board is placed on top of a stand for easier access and observation. To examine the law of reflection, a mirror is pinned to the cork board on top of a {\bf mirror worksheet}. This worksheet is supplied with the experiment and extra copies are available as necessary. Examination of the mirror worksheet shows a protractor drawn beside a roughly triangular shape. The triangular shape is the mirror used for this experiment. Note that each side of the triangle is a different type of mirror surface. One surface is a plane mirror, the other a concave mirror, and the third a convex mirror. Individual rays of light are traced by visually observing the alignment of four pins as shown in Figure \ref{fig:rr8}. Two pins trace an incident ray of light and two others trace the corresponding reflected ray. The angle of incidence is selected by placing two pins on the protractor on the mirror worksheet at a particular angle. The reflected ray is found by placing two more pins that visually appear to line up with the reflection of the incident ray pins. The pins are aligned correctly when all four pins appear to line up. A ruler is then used to draw a line along each pair of pins. In this way an incident ray and reflected ray are drawn on the worksheet. The angle of the reflected ray can then be measured with a protractor. The law of reflection can be examined experimentally using this method.

Similarly, the rectangular plate worksheet and acrylic block can be pinned onto the cork board to examine the law of refraction. As with the mirror, pins can be placed at a given angle of incidence. However, instead of sighting through the block by eye, a laser is used so that the entire path of the rays inside the block can be observed. The laser arrangement is shown in Figure \ref{fig:rr9}. Using one pin for reference on the input side, rotate and align the cork board so that the laser passes through the pin and the zero mark. This sets up the input beam. Then, two more pins can be placed on the output side so that they intersect the laser beam exiting from the block. The exiting ray can then be traced back to the exit point C with pencil and ruler as seen in Figure \ref{fig:rr8}. The worksheet has a dotted vertical line passing through the block. This line has two uses. First, the entrance point B is located on this dotted line at the top of the block. Connecting B to C with a line gives a tracing of the ray of light as it passes through the acrylic block. The angle of this line is measured with a protractor to determine the angle of refraction at point B. The second use of the dotted line is for lining up the protractor when measuring the angle of refraction.

Next, the equilateral prism worksheet and acrylic prism can be pinned onto the cork board to investigate prism behaviour. Again, a laser beam can be placed at a particular angle of incidence on the protractor to create a ray going into the prism. The outgoing ray can then be investigated to measure the angle of deviation, find the angle of minimum deviation, or determine when critical internal reflection happens. Lastly, this same examination can be performed with the double concave and double convex lens blocks and lens worksheets.

\section{Experimental Procedure}
\begin{enumerate}
\item The law of reflection can be experimentally examined by the behaviour of a flat mirror. Arrange the apparatus as seen in Figure \ref{fig:rr7}. Put the supplied universal mirror onto the mirror worksheet and pin it into place. The protractor on the worksheet is used to set the angle of the two pins specifying the input ray. Since light travels in straight lines, an incident ray with a given angle of incidence can be simulated by placing two pins in a straight line at an angle to the flat mirror. Visually place two other pins so that they appear to line up with the reflection of the first two pins. These two pins represent the reflected ray. Use a straight edge to draw lines through the pins. For at least four different incidence angles, plot the incident ray and the reflected ray. Measure the angle of reflection using a protractor. If the law of reflection is to hold, a graph of $\theta_i$ versus $\theta_r$ should be linear with slope $1$.

\item The behaviour of a light rays on a curved mirror can be explored just as in the case for a flat mirror. Using the mirror template, trace at least six separate incoming rays and determine the point at which the reflected rays converge. This will give a value for the focal length of the curved mirror. For a parabolic mirror, the focal point is located on the axis of symmetry, halfway between the mirror surface and the radius of curvature, which theoretically is $f=R/2$. If the mirror is not precisely parabolic there may be some spherical aberration. Using the geometric construction as in Figure \ref{fig:rr6}, determine the radius of curvature for the mirror and compare with the measured value of $f$. Qualitatively describe the resultant image when an object (say, a pencil or a pen) is placed outside $f$, inside $f$, and at a distance of around $f$ from the surface of the mirror. Explain these results quantitatively.

\item The remainder of this experiment is performed with rays of light from a laser instead of sighting pins, although pins can still be used to record the position of the laser beam. Set up the apparatus as shown in Figure \ref{fig:rr9}. For the rest of this experiment the laser should be arranged to emit a horizontal beam roughly at or below chest height. Always arrange the laser so that the primary beam is hitting the screen. Be mindful of the position of all the reflections and refractions of the beam. Do {\bf not ever} look into the laser beam or shine it in someone's eyes. Do {\bf not ever} put your eyes at the level of the laser. The best defense is to always keep your eyes above the level of the laser beam. Keep this in mind if something gets dropped and an experimenter has to bend down to pick it up. Remember to look away or keep your eyes closed. Also, remove watches and all articles of jewelry from your hands. Your eyes and the eyes of your fellow experimenters will thank you.

\item The angle of refraction can be examined experimentally by tracing rays of light through a rectangular plate of acrylic as in Figure \ref{fig:rr2}. Place the rectangular acrylic block onto the rectangular plate worksheet and pin it into place so it doesn't move. The protractor on the worksheet is used to set the angle of  the input ray AB. Once ray AB is in place with the laser, look down on the rectangular plate and observe where the light goes. Trace the exit ray from C to D. Use a straight edge to draw lines representing the input and output rays. Light rays travel in a straight line inside the acrylic. So a straight edge can be used to draw a line connecting points B and C. This represents the path of ray BC inside the acrylic block. Use a protractor to measure the angle of refraction of ray BC. Measure the angle of refraction for at least six different angles of incidence.

\item Referring to Figure \ref{fig:rr2}, plot a graph of $\sin\varphi '$ versus $\sin\varphi$ and determine the index of refraction $n'$ from the slope of the graph.

\item The behaviour of rays as they pass through an acrylic equilateral prism can be examined the same way. The protractor on the prism worksheet is used to set the angle of incidence of the input laser beam. The exit ray can then be located in order to trace the laser beam as it passes through the prism. Trace the input rays for at least six incidence angles ranging from $35^{\circ}$ to $65^{\circ}$. As in Figure \ref{fig:rr3}, extend input ray AB and exit ray CD with a straight edge, and measure the angle of deviation, $\delta$, with a protractor.

\item Using the index of refraction for acrylic found in Step 5 above, rewrite Equation \ref{equ:rr5} solely in terms of $\varphi$ and $n'$. Plot a theoretical curve of $\delta$ as a function of $\varphi$ and plot the values of $\delta$ measured in Step 5 with error bars on top of the theoretical curve. Compare the experimental value for the angle of minimum deviation to that found by solving Equation \ref{equ:rr6}.

\item The thin lens equation (Equation \ref{equ:rr7}) may be verified if both $R_1$ and $R_2$ are known and the index of refraction of the lens has already been measured. In order to determine a value for the radii of curvature, trace an image of the acrylic converging lens onto paper and use the geometry of Figure \ref{fig:rr6}. Since a value of $n$ has already been obtained for the material, $f$ can be found from Equation \ref{equ:rr7}. Using the converging lens worksheet and the laser, trace at least six parallel rays through the lens and determine an average value for the focal length $f$. Compare this to the value predicted by the lensmakers equation and comment on your results.

\item Repeat Step 8 for the double concave acrylic lens and worksheet.


\end{enumerate}

\section{Error Analysis}

In this experiment one source of error that arises is the alignment of the pins. It is not possible to measure when the pins are all exactly aligned. However, it is possible to say with reasonable confidence that the pins are aligned {\bf plus or minus half a degree}. The error in the pin alignment is then said to be half a degree. Once the pins are in place, other errors also arise. There is an error of half a degree in the procedure of drawing a straight line through the pins. There is also an error of half a degree in the accuracy of the angles as written on the graphical worksheets from distortions during the photocopying process. Furthermore, there will be some inaccuracy in the placement of the mirror and the acrylic rectangle and equilateral prism. Assume that this error is also half a degree.

Lastly, once the rays have been drawn, it is necessary to measure their angles with a protractor. Three sorts of errors happen during this measurement. First, the protractor must be lined up properly, in order to read off the angle. The error in doing this is called the {\bf zero point error}. Secondly, there is some difference between the true angle and the markings of the angle on the protractor. This is called the {\bf calibration error} of the protractor. Third, there is some uncertainty in reading the angle because the angle to be measured will not land exactly on a line of the protractor scale. This is called the {\bf measuring error}. It has been found in practice that for instruments with scales (such as a protractor or ruler), the measuring error is often {\bf half the smallest scale division} on the instrument. For the protractors used here, the smallest scale division is one degree, so the protractor measuring error is taken to be half a degree. It is estimated that each of the other two errors, the calibration error and zero point error, are at most half of a degree.

If there are a number of independent measurements, $x_i$, with random errors $u(x_i)$ in an experiment, any quantity, $f=f(x_1, x_2,...x_n)$, that depends on them will have an associated error given by the following expression

\begin{equation}
u(f) = \sqrt{\sum_i\left|\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x_i}\right|^2u(x_i)^2}
\label{equ:rr9}
\end{equation}


\section{The following should be handed in to your laboratory instructor}
\begin{enumerate}

\item The mirror, block, prism, and lens worksheets with labelled rays.

\item A plot of $\theta_i$ versus $\theta_r$.

\item A value for the radius of curvature and focal point of the curved mirror in Step 2.

\item The geometric constructions from Step 2, as well as a description and explanation for the behaviour of the image of an object placed inside, outside, and on the focal point of the curved mirror.

\item A plot of $\sin\varphi'$ versus $\sin\varphi$ from Step 5 along with the slope of the linear fit and a value for the index of refraction.

\item The theoretical curve plotted in Step 7 with the data points from Step 6. Clearly label the angle of minimum deviation.

\item Your calculation for the angle of minimum deviation from Equation \ref{equ:rr6}.

\item Theoretical and measured values for $f$ obtained in Steps 8 and 9.

\end{enumerate}

\section{{\bf Preparation}}

The student should review the basic concepts of physical optics by reading the theory section in this lab and by reviewing the relevant optics section in your textbook from first year physics or from this course. There is significant terminology used in optics of which the student should have a basic understanding.

\section{{\bf Goals of the Experiment}}

To observe the operation of thin lenses and gain experience with the placement and alignment of optical components. To examine and measure real and virtual images in simple optical systems. To measure the focal lengths of double convex and double concave lenses. To understand and use simple optical instruments like the magnifier and the diopter gauge.

\section{{\bf Theory}}

An understanding of lenses as \textbf{converging} or \textbf{diverging} and a classification of their surfaces as \textbf{concave}, \textbf{convex}, or \textbf{planar} is needed for this experiment. The relationship between object distance, $o$, image distance, $i$, and lens focal length, $f$, is used in several parts of the experiment. The formula relating these quantities is:
\begin{equation}
	\frac{1}{i} + \frac{1}{o} = \frac{1}{f}.
	\label{equ:tlFocalLenthEquation}
\end{equation}

A second formula that is used in parts of this experiment is the \text{magnification} of an image. For an object height, $y_o$, and an image height, $y_i$, the magnification, $m$, is given by
\begin{equation}
	m = \frac{y_i}{y_o} = -\frac{i}{o}.
	\label{equ:tlMagnitudeEquation}
\end{equation}

A significant portion of the experiment involves measuring the \textbf{focal lengths} of different lenses. A knowledge of the properties of \textbf{focal points} for converging and diverging lenses is therefore needed here. The distinction between \textbf{real images} and \textbf{virtual images} and \textbf{real objects} and \textbf{virtual objects} is explored. An understanding of their differences will be helpful. Some parts of the experiment examine the operation of simple optical instruments like the \textbf{magnifier} and the \textbf{telescope}. For more information on all these ideas, it will be helpful to study the relevant optics sections in your textbook before doing the experiment. Some ideas not covered in the textbook are discussed below.

An instrument commonly used to measure the focal lengths of lenses is the \textbf{diopter gauge}. The principle of operation of the diopter gauge is based on the \textbf{lens maker's equation}. Suppose a thin lens immersed in air is made from a material with \textbf{index of refraction}, $n$. One side of the lens has radius of curvature, $R_1$, and the other side has a \textbf{radius of curvature}, $R_2$. The focal length of the lens is given by the lens maker's equation
\begin{equation}
	\frac{1}{f} = (n-1) \left( \frac{1}{R_1} - \frac{1}{R_2} \right).
	\label{equ:tlLensMakersEquation}
\end{equation}

For lenses that are double convex, $R_1$ is positive and $R_2$ is negative, so Equation~\ref{equ:tlLensMakersEquation} implies that this type of lens has positive focal length. For lenses that are double concave, $R_1$ is negative and $R_2$ is positive, so Equation~\ref{equ:tlLensMakersEquation} implies that this type of lens has negative focal length. If one of the surfaces is flat the radius of curvature will be infinite. The reciprocal is then zero and the lens maker's formula implies that this surface does not contribute anything towards determining the focal length. A lens with both sides flat (a window) has an infinite focal length.

In many optics formulae (including the lens maker's equation), the focal length only appears as a reciprocal. It therefore makes sense to define a unit of reciprocal focal length. The \textbf{power}, $\mathcal{D}$, of a lens is defined as the reciprocal of the focal length of the lens in meters. The unit of lens power is called the \textbf{diopter} ($D$). Since converging lenses have positive focal lengths and diverging lenses have negative focal lengths, the power of a lens is positive for converging lenses and negative for diverging lenses. For example, a converging lens with a focal length of one meter has a power of one diopter ($1D =$ $1$ $m^{-1}$). A diverging lens with a focal length of $0.2$ meters has a power of $-5.0$ diopters. A flat piece of window glass does not converge or diverge incoming light rays, it has a power of zero diopters. The lens maker's formula can be rewritten in terms of dioptric power to get
\begin{equation}
	\mathcal{D} = (n-1) \left( \frac{1}{R_1} - \frac{1}{R_2} \right).
	\label{equ:tlPowerEquation}
\end{equation}

As shown in Figure~\ref{fig:tlConcaveLensLeftAndRight}, imagine a lens, $L$, as being split in half to form a combination of two lenses, $L_{\text{Left}}$ and $L_{\text{Right}}$, each of which is flat on one side. The two lenses, $L_{\text{Left}}$ and $L_{\text{Right}}$, are in contact on their flat sides and touching. Lens $L$ has a radius of curvature $R_1$ on the left and $R_2$ on the right. The power of lens L is given by Equation 4. Lens $L_{\text{Left}}$ has a radius of curvature $R_1$ on the left and $\infty$ on the right. Similarly, Lens $L_{\text{Right}}$ has radius of curvature $\infty$ on the left and $R_2$ on the right. Let the power of lens $L_{\text{Left}}$ be $\mathcal{D}_{\text{Left}}$ and the power of lens $L_{\text{Right}}$ be $\mathcal{D}_{\text{Right}}$. Then by the lens maker's formula the power of each half lens is given by
\begin{equation}
	\mathcal{D}_{\text{Left}} = \frac{(n-1)}{R_1}
	\label{equ:tlPowerLeftEquation}
\end{equation}
and
\begin{equation}
	\mathcal{D}_{\text{Right}} = - \frac{(n-1)}{R_2}.
	\label{equ:tlPowerRightEquation}
\end{equation}

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}[circuit ee IEC]
	\begin{scope}[shift={(0,0)}]
		\draw[rotate=90, fill=lightgray](0,0) arc(110:70:3) --  (2.05,1) arc(110:70:-3) -- (0,0);
		\node[above] at (-0.5,2.2) {$L$};

		\draw[-stealth,thick] (0,1) -- (1,1);

		\draw[-stealth] (-1.5,-0.5) node[below]{$R_1$} -- (-1,0.5);
		\draw[-stealth] (0.5,-0.5) node[below]{$R_2$} -- (0,0.5);
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(2,0)}]
		\draw[rotate=90, fill=lightgray](0,0) arc (110:70:3) --  (2.05,1) arc (110:70:-3) -- (0,0);
		\draw[dashed] (-0.5,2.5) - - (-0.5,-0.5);


		\draw[-stealth,thick] (0,1) -- (1,1);
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(4,0)}]
		\begin{scope}[shift={(0.5,0)}]
			\draw[rotate=90, fill=lightgray](0,0) arc (110:70:3) --  (2.05,0.5) -- (0,0.5) -- (0,0);
		\end{scope}
		\begin{scope}[shift={(-1,2.05)}]
			\draw[rotate=-90, fill=lightgray](0,0) arc (110:70:3) --  (2.05,0.5) -- (0,0.5) -- (0,0);
		\end{scope}
		\node[above right] at (-0.2,2.1) {$L_{\text{Right}}$};
		\node[above left] at (-0.2,2.2) {$L_{\text{Left}}$};

		\draw[-stealth] (-1.5,-0.5) node[below]{$R_1$} -- (-1,0.5);

		\draw[stealth-] (-0.5,0.5) -- (-0.25,-0.5) node[below]{$\infty$};
		\draw[stealth-] (0,0.5) -- (-0.25,-0.5);
	\end{scope}
\end{tikzpicture}
\centering
\caption{A double concave lens, $L$, can be though of as a combination of two plano concave lens, $L_{\text{Left}}$ and $L_{\text{Right}}$.}
\label{fig:tlConcaveLensLeftAndRight}
\end{figure}

Observe that the sum of Equations~\ref{equ:tlPowerLeftEquation} and~\ref{equ:tlPowerRightEquation} yields Equation~\ref{equ:tlPowerEquation}. This means that \textbf{the power of a lens is equal to the sum of the powers of its two surfaces}. If an instrument could measure the power of a single surface then the focal length of a lens could be measured by adding together the power of each lens surface. This is one of the principles upon which the operation of a diopter gauge is based.

\begin{figure}
\centering

	\node at (-13:2.4) {$-$};

	\end{scope}
