\label{fig:tlDiopterGauge}
\end{figure}

Figure~\ref{fig:tlDiopterGauge} shows a diagram of a diopter gauge measuring one surface of a lens. A diopter gauge measures the power of a single surface by determining the radius of curvature. The gauge is held against the surface of the lens so that it is perpendicular to the surface and the two fixed pins are touching the glass. If it is assumed that the surface is a section from a circle then the amount that the moveable pin is compressed determines the radius of curvature of the surface. If the index of refraction of the material is known, the dioptric power of the surface can be found from Equation~\ref{equ:tlPowerLeftEquation}. The diopter gauges used in this experiment are calibrated for \textbf{crown glass} with an index of refraction of $1.525$. The scales read off the power of the surface directly in diopters when the lens material is crown glass.
	
The procedure for measuring the power of a lens with the diopter gauge is as follows. Determine whether the surface is convex or concave by holding a straight edge against the lens. Do not scratch the surface or leave fingerprints on it. If the surface is convex read from the black inner scale. If the surface is concave read from the red outer scale. A flat surface will read zero on both scales. Hold the gauge perpendicular to the surface so that all three pins touch the surface. The pins are rounded and treated so that they do not scratch the glass. Read the power of the surface in diopters. Repeat the procedure for the other surface. The total power of the lens is sum of the two diopter readings. The focal length is then the inverse of this number in meters.
	
The rules for adding powers of surfaces together to get the total power of a lens are simple. Convex surfaces have positive power, concave surfaces have negative power, and flat surfaces have zero power. The total lens power is the sum of the power of the two surfaces. Examples for various types of lenses are shown in Figure~\ref{fig:tlVariousLens}.

\begin{figure}

Another method useful for determining the focal length of a lens is called the \textbf{displacement method}. Suppose an object and a screen are located a fixed distance, b, apart. The converging lens whose focal length is to be measured is in between. As the lens is moved to different locations between the object and the screen it is found that a real image is focused on the screen only when the lens is in two specific positions. At one position the image is larger than the object and at the other position the image is smaller than the object. 

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=0.8][circuit ee IEC]
	\begin{scope}[shift={(-3,0)},yscale=1.5]
		\draw[fill=lightgray](0,0) arc(20:-20:3) arc(20:-20:-3);
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(3,0)},yscale=1.5]
		\draw[fill=lightgray](0,0) arc(20:-20:3) arc(20:-20:-3);
	\end{scope}

	\draw[dashed] (3,0.5) -- (3,-4); %2nd lens position
	\draw[dashed] (-3,0.5) -- (-3,-4); %1st lens position

	\node[right] at (-2.8,-1.75) {$1$st position};
	\node[right] at (3.2,-1.75) {$2$nd position};

	\draw[dashed] (-6,-1.5) -- (6,-1.5); %Horizontal line
	\draw[dashed] (-6,-4) -- (-5.9,0.5) node[above]{object (fixed)};
	\draw[dashed] (6,-4) -- (5.9,0.5) node[above]{image (fixed)};


	\draw[stealth-] (-6,0.5) -- (-1.8,0.5) node[right] {$o_2$};
	\draw[-stealth] (-1.2,0.5) -- (3,0.5);

	\draw[stealth-] (3,0.5) -- (4.2,0.5) node[right] {$i_2$};
	\draw[-stealth] (4.8,0.5) -- (6,0.5);

	\begin{scope}[shift={(0,-3)}]
		\draw[-stealth] (0.3,0) -- (3,0);
		\draw[-stealth] (-0.3,0) -- (-3,0);
		\node at (0,0) {$a$};
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(0,-3.5)}]
		\draw[-stealth] (0.3,0) -- (6,0);
		\draw[-stealth] (-0.3,0) -- (-6,0);
		\node at (0,0) {$b$};
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(-4.5,-4)}]
		\draw[-stealth] (0.3,0) -- (1.5,0);
		\draw[-stealth] (-0.3,0) -- (-1.5,0);
		\node at (0,0) {$o_1$};
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(1.5,-4)}]
		\draw[-stealth] (0.3,0) -- (4.5,0);
		\draw[-stealth] (-0.3,0) -- (-4.5,0);
		\node at (0,0) {$i_1$};
	\end{scope}

\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Positioning of a lens when using the displacement method to calculate focal length.}
\label{fig:tlDisplacementMethodPositions}
\end{figure}

As in Figure~\ref{fig:tlDisplacementMethodPositions}, define, $a$, as the separation between the two positions of the lens. It is a fact that the focal length of the lens can be found once $a$ and $b$ are known. The focal length is given by the formula
\begin{equation}
	f = \frac{b^2-a^2}{4b}
	\label{equ:tlabFocalLenthEquation}
\end{equation}

The smallest possible value a can have is zero. Substituting $a_0 \geq 0$ into Equation~\ref{equ:tlabFocalLenthEquation} shows that the longest focal length that can be measured for a given $b$ is $b/4$. For the optical bench used in this experiment, this limits the measurable focal length to anything below $30$ cm.

An advantage of this method is that it gives accurate results because the distance, $a$, is independent of the thickness of the lens and the position of the lens in the lens holder. Similarly, the distance, $b$, between object and screen can be measured accurately so that offsets of the screen and object can be eliminated. Furthermore, $b$ needs to be measured only once since object and screen remain fixed.
	
A second advantage of this method is that it permits the measurement of sizes and positions of inaccessible objects such as the filament inside a bulb or a virtual image located behind a lens. This will be used in this experiment to measure the position and magnification of a virtual image produced by a lens used as a magnifier. It will also be used in this experiment to measure the position of a virtual image generated by a diverging lens.

Imagine replacing the object in Figure~\ref{fig:tlDisplacementMethodPositions} with some sort of lens system that produces a virtual image, such as a concave lens. Apply the displacement method with a lens of known focal length to get a value for $a$. Solving Equation~\ref{equ:tlabFocalLenthEquation} for $b$ then gives a value for the position of the virtual image.

The size of the virtual image can also be measured. Suppose the virtual image has size, y. Let $y_1$ and $y_2$ be the sizes of the real image on the screen for the two possible positions of the lens. Let $M_1$ and $M_2$ be the magnifications at the two lens positions. It is a fact that $M_1$ and $M_2$ are reciprocals. So

\begin{equation}
	1 = M_1 M_2 = \left(- \frac{y_1}{y} \right) \left(- \frac{y_2}{y} \right) = \frac{y_1 y_2}{y^2}
	\label{equ:tlImageSize}
\end{equation}

Therefore, the virtual image size, y, is
\begin{equation}
	y = \sqrt{y_1 y_2}
	\label{equ:tlVirtualImageSizeEquation}
\end{equation}

Equation~\ref{equ:tlVirtualImageSizeEquation} gives the size of the image being tested from the measured sizes of the images on the screen.

Figure~\ref{fig:tlOpticalBench} shows the experimental layout. Optical components such as lenses, screens and test objects can be placed into holders that slide along on an optical bench. The optical bench ensures that all the components are aligned correctly. The side of the optical bench has a scale that is used to measure or set the distances between various components. A lighted test object is used to make image location straightforward.

\begin{figure}
\centering
\begin{tikzpicture}[circuit ee IEC]
	\begin{scope}
		\draw (0,0.2) -- (12,0.2) -- (12,1) -- (0,1) -- (0,0.2);
		\draw (0,0.8) -- (12,0.8);
		\draw (0,0.7) -- (12,0.7);

		\foreach \x in {0,0.2,0.4,0.6,...,12}
		{
			\draw (\x,0.7) -- (\x,0.8);
		}
		
		\begin{scope}[shift={(2,-0.8)}]
			\draw (0,0) -- (0,1) -- (0.2,1) -- (0.2,0) -- (0,0);
		\end{scope}

		\begin{scope}[shift={(10,-0.8)}]
			\draw (0,0) -- (0,1) -- (0.2,1) -- (0.2,0) -- (0,0);
		\end{scope}

		\draw[stealth-] (7,0.8) -- (7,2) node[above]{Distance scale};
		\draw[stealth-] (9,1.1) -- (9,4) node[above]{Optical bench};
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(0.5,0.5)}]
		\draw[fill=black] (0,0) -- (1,0) -- (1,0.75) -- (0,0.75) -- (0,0);
		\draw[fill=black] (0.4,0.75) -- (0.6,0.75) -- (0.6,1.5) -- (0.4,1.5) -- (0.4,0.75);
		\draw[line width=0.9mm] (0.5,1.5) -- (0.5,2.1);

\end{figure}

Four converging lenses ranging in focal lengths from short (L$1$), through medium (L$2$ and L$3$), to long (L$4$), and one diverging lens (L$5$) are supplied for use in the experiment.

\section{{\bf Experimental Procedure}}
\begin{enumerate}
	\item The laboratory lights should be dimmed for the duration of this experiment. It is possible to determine the focal length of converging lenses in several ways. This experiment begins by examining some different methods for measuring focal lengths of converging lenses. First, determine the focal lengths of lenses L$1$, L$2$, L$3$, and L$4$ by the method of placing an object at infinity. For a converging lens, when an object is at infinity the image lies at the focal point with zero size. As an approximation to an object at infinity, use a lighted object on the other side of the laboratory. Point the optical bench at the lighted object. The lens to be measured is placed into a holder on the optical bench. Using the screen, locate the position of the real image and thereby the focal length. After these measurements it may be useful to place the lenses on a labelled sheet of paper with the relevant symbols L$1$ through L$5$ so that the lenses do not get mixed up. L$1$ is the shortest focal length converging lens and L$4$ the longest, with L$2$ and L$3$ intermediate. L$5$ is the diverging lens.
	\item Determine the focal lengths of lenses L$1$, L$2$, L$3$, L$4$, and L$5$ with the diopter gauge.
	\item Keep the lighted object at a fixed location on the optical bench. Place lens L$1$ in a holder between the object and the screen. Adjust the position of lens L$1$ and the screen until the real image observed on the screen is the same size as the object. At this position the magnification of the image is $-1.0$. Use this fact to determine the focal length of L$1$.
	\item Use the displacement method to measure the focal length of lens L$2$. Place the screen at a scale reading of $0$ on the optical bench and the lighted object at a scale reading of $115$ on the optical bench. With lens L$2$ between the object and the screen locate the two positions where a real image is formed on the screen. The focal length of L$2$ is then found from Equation~\ref{equ:tlabFocalLenthEquation}. At first glance the value for $b$ must be $115$. However, the screen and object are offset somewhat from the index indicators on the side of the optical bench. To get a better value for $b$ place a meter stick between the screen and object so that it is touching both. The difference between the scale reading on the optical bench and $100.0$ cm then gives the exact offset and hence a more accurate value for $b$. Note that the thickness of the glass in front of the lighted test object is $0.3$ cm. To get an even more accurate value for $b$ use the value $100.3$ cm instead of $100.0$ cm when computing the offset.
	\item The object distance, $o$, and image distance, $i$, are related by Equation~\ref{equ:tlFocalLenthEquation}. For at least five different object distances, measure the image distance for the real image produced by lens L$3$ on the screen. The focal length of L$3$ can be found by plotting a graph of $1/i$ versus $1/o$.
	\item Having measured the focal lengths of some converging lenses by several different methods we now turn our attention to measuring the focal length of a diverging lens using two different methods. Place the screen at a scale reading of zero on the optical bench and the lighted object at a scale reading of $115$ on the optical bench. Put lens L$5$ in a lens holder and position it $10$ to $20$ cm from the lighted object. A glance into L$5$ shows a virtual image at a position somewhere behind lens L$5$ that is smaller than the object.

\begin{figure}
\centering
\begin{tikzpicture}[circuit ee IEC]
	\begin{scope}[shift={(-1,0)},yscale=1.5] %Convex lens
		\draw[fill=lightgray](0,0) arc(20:-20:3) arc(20:-20:-3);
		\node[above] at (0,0) {L$2$};
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(-3,0)},yscale=1.5] %Concave lens
		\draw[rotate=0, fill=lightgray](0,0) arc(20:-20:3) --  (0.5,-2.05) arc(20:-20:-3) -- (0,0);
		\node[above] at (0.25,0) {L$5$};
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(-3.85,0)}] %Dashed vertical line
		\draw[dashed] (0,0) -- (0,-3.5) node[below,align=center]{Virtual \\ image};
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(-5,0)}] %Dashed vertical line
		\draw[dashed] (0,0) node[above,align=center]{Real \\ object} -- (0,-3.5);
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(5,0)}] %Dashed vertical line
		\draw[dashed] (0,0) node[above, align=center]{Real \\ image} -- (0,-3.5);
	\end{scope}

	\draw (5,-1.5) -- (-1,-0.2) -- (-2.75,-1) -- (-5,-1.5);
	\draw (5,-1.5) -- (-1,-2.8) -- (-2.75,-2) -- (-5,-1.5);

	\draw[dashed] (-2.75,-1) -- (-3.85,-1.5);
	\draw[dashed] (-2.75,-2) -- (-3.85,-1.5);

	\begin{scope}[shift={(0.575,-3.4)}]
		\draw[-stealth] (0.3,0) -- (4.425,0);
		\draw[-stealth] (-0.3,0) -- (-4.425,0);
		\node at (0,0) {$b$};
	\end{scope}
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{First method for measuring the focal length of a concave lens.}
\label{fig:tlConcaveFocalLength1}
\end{figure}
	
Select L$2$ as a lens with known focal length, $f$, and place it on the optical bench between L$5$ and the screen. Use the displacement method to find a value for $b$. This gives a value for the distance of the virtual image, $i$, from lens L$5$. Equation 1 can then be used to find the focal length of L$5$ since the object distance, $o$, between the lighted test object and L$5$ is readily measured. Figure ~\ref{fig:tlConcaveFocalLength1} illustrates some of the differences between a real image and a virtual image. Light rays always converge to a real image and diverge away from a virtual image.
	\item The focal length of a diverging lens can also be found by measuring how far a real image shifts when the diverging lens is added to the system. As shown in Figure~\ref{fig:tlConcaveFocalLength1}, suppose a converging lens like L$1$ is used to form a real image on a screen at point $R$. When diverging lens L$5$ is placed between L$1$ and the screen, the real image is no longer focused on the screen. The focal point has moved further away so that a real image appears on a screen at point $S$ instead. Lens L$5$ diverges the light rays so they meet at a point further away.
	
This shift in focal length can be used to obtain a value for the focal length of L$5$. When L$5$ is inserted the real image at $R$ disappears. Instead, lens L$5$ generates a real image at the new position $S$ from the \textbf{virtual} object at point $R$. The image distance is the distance from L$5$ to $S$ (it is positive). The object distance is the distance from L$5$ to $R$ (it is negative). Equation~\ref{equ:tlFocalLenthEquation} can be used to determine the focal length of L$5$.

\begin{figure}
\centering
\begin{tikzpicture}[circuit ee IEC]
\begin{scope}[xscale=-1] %Mirror entire diagram
	\begin{scope}[shift={(3-0.25,0)},yscale=1.5] %Convex lens
		\draw[fill=lightgray](0,0) arc(20:-20:3) arc(20:-20:-3);
		\node[above] at (0,0) {L$1$};
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(1-0.25,0)},yscale=1.5] %Concave lens
		\draw[rotate=0, fill=lightgray](0,0) arc(20:-20:3) --  (0.5,-2.05) arc(20:-20:-3) -- (0,0);
		\node[above] at (0.25,0) {L$5$};
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(-0.75,0)}] %Dashed vertical line
		\draw[dashed] (0,0) node[above]{$R$} -- (0,-3.5) node[below,align=center]{Real image without L$5$\\ Virtual image with L$5$};
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(-5,0)}] %Dashed vertical line
		\draw[dashed] (0,0) node[above,align=center]{$S$} -- (0,-3.5);
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(5,0)}] %Dashed vertical line
		\draw[dashed] (0,0) node[above, align=center]{Real \\ object} -- (0,-3.5);
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[xscale=-1] %Mirror light rays
	\draw (5,-1.5) -- (-1,-1) -- (-2.75,-0.5) -- (-5,-1.5);
	\draw (5,-1.5) -- (-1,-2) -- (-2.75,-2.5) -- (-5,-1.5);

	\draw[dashed] (-1,-1) -- (0.75,-1.5);
	\draw[dashed] (-1,-2) -- (0.75,-1.5);
	\end{scope}
\end{scope}
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Second method for measuring the focal length of a concave lens.}
\label{fig:tlConcaveFocalLength2}
\end{figure}

Figure~\ref{fig:tlConcaveFocalLength2} illustrates one of the differences between a real object and a virtual object. The light rays emitted from a real object are always \textbf{diverging}. The light rays emitted from a virtual object are always converging. Determine the focal length of L$5$ by this method. Best results are obtained when L$1$ is $12$ cm away from the lighted object.

\section{{\bf STUDENT CHOICE SECTION}}

\textbf{To complete this lab, you now have the choice of carrying out either part $8$ or part $9$ of this lab, based on your own interests. Part $8$ allows you to investigate the design and operation of magnifying glasses and microscopes, while part $9$ focusses on the equivalent properties of telescopes. The second half of part $9$ also consists of $2$ choices.  Therefore, a complete version of this lab includes procedure parts $1$ through $7$, plus ($8$a and $8$b) OR ($9$a and $9$b) OR ($9$a and $9$c).}

	\item \textbf{Magnifying Glass and Microscopes}
	\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*)]
		\item A magnifying glass is used to make enlarged virtual images. The size and position of these virtual images can be measured by applying the displacement method with a lens of known focal length. Use L$1$ as a magnifying glass. Apply the displacement method with L$3$ as the known focal length lens. Place the screen at scale reading $0$ on the optical bench and the lighted test object at scale reading $115$ on the optical bench. Use L$1$ as a magnifying glass on the test object. This means that lens L$1$ should be placed less than one focal length away from the lighted object. Look through the lens to verify that a magnified virtual image is indeed visible. Place lens L$3$ between the screen and lens L$1$. Determine a value for '$a$' from the two positions of L$3$ that produce a real image on the screen. Use the known focal length of L$3$ to compute $b$ and therefore find the location of the virtual image. Measure the sizes of the two images on the screen and apply Equation~\ref{equ:tlVirtualImageSizeEquation} to find the size of the virtual image. The size and position of the virtual image can be independently computed (using Equations~\ref{equ:tlFocalLenthEquation} and ~\ref{equ:tlMagnitudeEquation}) by using the known focal length of L$1$ and the object distance. The size and position of the virtual image obtained by these two methods can be compared. If there is difficulty getting two different real images with L$3$, move L$1$ closer to the test object.
		\item Using lenses L$1$ through L$5$ as required, construct a compound microscope. Locate the positions of the lenses that produce the best image. Draw a diagram of your instrument together with the positions and focal points of each lens.
	\end{enumerate}

	\item \textbf{Telescopes}
	\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*)]
		\item Using lenses L$1$ through L$5$, construct a Keplerian refracting telescope. This telescope uses a converging \textbf{objective} and a converging \textbf{eyepiece}. The objective lens is the lens nearest the object being viewed. The eyepiece lens is the lens nearest the eye. The eyepiece position determines the focus of the telescope. People who wear eyeglasses may want to check where the eyepiece needs to be when viewing with and without their glasses. Find the positions of the lenses in your telescope that create the best image of a lighted object located on the other side of the laboratory. Also determine the position of the real image created by the objective lens. Draw a diagram of the constructed telescope. Show the distance between the two lenses. Also include the focal point of each lens as measured in previous steps and the location of the real image generated by the objective.
		\item The Kepler retractor produces an inverted image. Placing an extra converging lens between objective and eyepiece inverts the image. This is called the \textbf{erector} lens. In addition, the position of the erector can be used to adjust the magnification of the telescope. Construct a working Kepler telescope with an erecting lens and draw a diagram of the telescope. Include positions and focal lengths of each lens. It may be that the telescope will not fit onto the optical bench so the eyepiece lens may have to be hand held. Check that the position of the erector determines the magnification and note the range of travel of the erector that still gives a usable image.
		\item Using lenses L1 through L5, construct a a \textbf{Galilean refracting telescope}. A Galilean retractor uses a converging objective and a diverging eyepiece. Find the positions of the lenses in your telescope that create the best image of a lighted object located on the other side of the laboratory. Also determine the position of the real image created by the objective lens. Draw a diagram of the constructed telescope. Show the distance between the two lenses. Also include the focal point of each lens as measured in previous steps and the location of the real image generated by the objective.
	\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\section{{\bf Error Analysis Hints}}

One source of error in this experiment comes from uncertainties in positioning the lenses. The optical bench permits reasonably accurate positioning of lenses along the bench. However, the height at which the lenses are placed is not precisely adjustable. Also, the orientation of the lenses should be perpendicular to the optical bench and parallel to the lighted object. Adjustments in these directions are not available on the apparatus except by rough positioning of the lens inside the lens holder.

A second source of error in this experiment is due to aberrations in the lenses themselves. A full discussion of the deviations of physical glass lenses from the theoretical ideal is beyond the level of this course. However, it can easily be seen that the quality of images at the edges is quite different from image quality at the center. This suggests that the lenses used in this experiment have different properties at their edges than at their centers. One reason for this difference is that the lenses have different thickness's at the edge and at the center. Many of the optics formulas used in this experiment assume that the lenses are thin to partly remove this difficulty.
	
Each lens holder has an index marker on the side that is used to measure the position of the item in the holder (usually a lens, lighted object, or screen). There will be an offset between the true position of the object in the holder and the reading on the scale. Lastly, there is the issue of determining when an image is properly in focus. This is determined by the angular resolution of the human eye and varies somewhat from person to person. The distortions of the real images from lens aberrations also contributes to the uncertainty in establishing the location of a real image. The edges of the image actually focus at a slightly different location from the center of a real image.
	
Since many of these errors are not subject to the direct control and measurement of the experimenter, no error analysis will be used in this experiment.
\\

\section{{\bf Prelab Exercises}}

\begin{enumerate}
	\item Literature  Provide clear and concise definitions for the following frequently used optics terms: focal length, focal point, real image, real object, virtual image, virtual object, and index of refraction.
	\item Literature  Provide basic description of the capabilities of microscopes and telescopes.
	\item Calculation Derivation of the displacement method. It can be seen from Figure~\ref{fig:tlDisplacementMethodPositions} and Equation~\ref{equ:tlFocalLenthEquation} that the following formulae must hold true.
	\begin{equation}
		b = o_1 + i_1 = o_2 + i_2
	\end{equation}
	\begin{equation}
		a = o_2 - o_1 = i_1 - i_2
	\end{equation}
	\begin{equation}
		\frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{i_1} + \frac{1}{o_1} = \frac{1}{i_2} + \frac{1}{o_2}
	\end{equation}
	
	Using these formulas, show that
	\begin{equation}
		f = \frac{b^2-a^2}{4b}
	\end{equation}

\section{{\bf Goals of the Experiment}}

Study the basic principles of the polarization of light and Malus' Law.

\section{{\bf Goals of the Experiment}}

To gain experience using optical equipment. To understand the polarization of light, dichroism and birefringence. To find the transmission coefficient, a, for a dichroic polarizing material. To observe polarization by birefringence and dichroism. To test Malus' Law.

\section{{\bf Theory}}

\'{E}tienne L. Malus discovered the \textbf{polarization} of light by absorption in 1808 by accident when he was playing with a crystal of Iceland Spar in his apartment in Paris. He looked at reflections of the sun in a window of the Luxembourg Palace across the street and noticed how the intensity varied when he rotated the crystal (the image of the sun is partially polarized upon reflection). He followed this with further experiments and ultimately obtained \textbf{Malus' law}, which predicts the intensity of the light transmitted through a polarizer. He also discovered \textbf{double refraction} in crystals, or \textbf{birefringence}, later in $1810$. 

\textbf{Natural light}, or \textbf{unpolarized light}, consists of a large mixture of waves vibrating in all directions perpendicular to the direction of propagation. Each wave is called a \textbf{wavetrain}. These wavetrains do not last for very long and new wavetrains are constantly emitted from the light source. Thus, the overall polarization is constantly changing in an erratic manner. \textbf{Polarized light} occurs when the vibration of the electric field is confined to one plane. Monochromatic light is considered to have an infinite wavetrain, and a perfectly monochromatic plane wave is always polarized. In general, however, any form of light is neither completely unpolarized nor completely polarized. More often, the electric field vector varies in a way that is not totally regular or totally irregular. This is referred to as \textbf{partial polarization}.
 
Light is an electromagnetic wave. Its fundamental characteristics can be described in terms of the electric field intensity, which can take the form
\begin{equation}
	\vec{E}_t = \vec{E}_0 \left[\hat{i} \cos(kz-\omega t) + \hat{j} \sin(kz - \omega t) \right],
	\label{equ:mlGenralizedEMWave}
\end{equation}

where $E_t$ is the transmitted electric field intensity, and $E_0$ is the initial electric field intensity. The \textbf{angular frequency}, $\omega$, and \textbf{wave number}, $k$, are related to the \textbf{frequency}, $f$, and \textbf{wavelength}, $\lambda$, by
\begin{equation}
	\omega = 2 \pi f
	\label{equ:mlAngularFrequencyDef}
\end{equation}
and
\begin{equation}
	k = \frac{2\pi}{\lambda}
	\label{equ:mlWaveNumberDef}
\end{equation}

Equation~\ref{equ:mlGenralizedEMWave} implies that light is a transverse wave because its oscillations occur perpendicular to the direction of propagation of the light. The electric field vector, $\mathbf{E_t}$, is propagating in the $z$-direction, and the electric field is oscillating in the $x$ and $y$ directions (i.e. $E_t = (E_x,E_y)$). When the direction and/or the magnitude of these oscillations of $x$ and $y$ are restrained in some way, then the light wave is said to be polarized. Since the phase constants can be picked arbitrarily for one vector, it is easiest to choose it equal to zero for the $x$-component, $E_x$. Therefore, the total electric field strength perpendicular to the direction of travel is given by
\begin{equation}
	E_x = E_{0,x} \cos(kz - \omega t),
	\label{equ:mlEFieldXComp}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}
	E_y = E_{0,y} \cos(kz - \omega t + \delta),
	\label{equ:mlEFieldYComp}
\end{equation}

where $\delta$ is the \textbf{phase difference}. Equation~\ref{equ:mlEFieldXComp} and Equation~\ref{equ:mlEFieldYComp} are expressions for the curve made by the tip of the electric field vector, $\mathbf{E_{xy}}$. It can be shown that this curve is, in general, an ellipse, when the dependency on time and position is removed. Expanding the expressions for $E_y$ and $E_x$ yields
\begin{equation}
	\frac{E_y}{E_{0,y}} - \frac{E_x}{E_{0,x}} \cos(\delta) = - \sin(kz - \omega t) \sin(\delta).
	\label{equ:mlPhaseSeperatedEquation}
\end{equation}

Solving for $\sin(kz-\omega t)$ in Equation~\ref{equ:mlEFieldXComp} gives
\begin{equation}
	\sin(kz - \omega t) = \sqrt{1-\left( \frac{E_x}{E_{0,x}} \right)^2}.
	\label{equ:mlSolvingForSine}
\end{equation}

Substituting Equation~\ref{equ:mlSolvingForSine} into Equation~\ref{equ:mlPhaseSeperatedEquation} and squaring gives
\begin{equation}
	\left( \frac{E_y}{E_{0,y}} - \frac{E_x}{E_{0,x}} \cos(\delta) \right)^2 = \left[ 1 - \left( \frac{E_x}{E_{0,x}} \right)^2 \right] \sin^2(\delta).
	\label{equ:mlSubAndSquare}
\end{equation}

Expanding out Equation~\ref{equ:mlSubAndSquare} produces the result
\begin{equation}
	\left( \frac{E_y}{E_{y,0}} \right)^2 + \left( \frac{E_x}{E_{x,0}} \right)^2 - 2 \left( \frac{E_y}{E_{y,0}} \right)\left( \frac{E_x}{E_{x,0}} \right) \cos(\delta) = \sin^2(\delta)
	\label{equ:mlEllipticalEquation}
\end{equation}

This is an equation for an ellipse making an angle, $\theta$, with the $(E_x, E_y)$ coordinate system such that
\begin{equation}
	\tan(2\theta) = \frac{2E_{0,x}E_{0,y}\cos(\delta)}{E^2_{0,x} - E^2_{0,y}}.
	\label{equ:mlTan2Theta}
\end{equation}

This ellipse is shown in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbEllipticallyPolarizedRotation}. 

	From Equation~\ref{equ:mlEllipticalEquation}, it is seen that the general form of polarization is elliptical. Special cases of \textbf{elliptically polarized light} are \textbf{linearly polarized light} and \textbf{circularly polarized light}. The electric field vector, $\mathbf{E_{xy}}$, completes one full cycle (either an ellipse, circle or a line) as the wave progresses forward by one wavelength.

\begin{figure}
\centering
\begin{tikzpicture}
	\draw[->] (0,-2) -- (0,2.2) node[above]{$E_y$};
	\draw[->] (-2,0) -- (2.2,0) node[right]{$E_x$};

	\draw[rotate=-45] (0,0) ellipse (1 and 2);

	\draw[dashed] (-1.59,1.59) -- (1.59,1.59) -- (1.59,-1.59) -- (-1.59,-1.59) -- (-1.59,1.59);

	\draw[fill=black] (0,1.59) node[above left]{$E_{0,y}$} circle (0.05);
	\draw[fill=black] (1.59,0) node[below right]{$E_{0,x}$} circle (0.05);

	\draw[-triangle 60] (0,0) -- (0.5,1.5) node[below right]{$E_{xy}$};
	\draw (0.2,0) arc (0:70:0.2);
	\node at (0.3,0.3) {$\theta$};
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{The rotation of the electric field vector $\vec{E}_{xy}$ in the general elliptically polarized case.}
\label{fig:mlbEllipticallyPolarizedRotation}
\end{figure}

	For linearly polarized light, the two beams are perfectly in, or out of, phase. If $E_x$ is zero, then the beam is vertically polarized and if $E_y$ is zero, the beam is horizontally polarized. However, if $E_x$ is equal to $E_y$, then the beam is linearly polarized at an angle of $45$ degrees. More generally, if the phase difference, $\delta$, is zero or an integral multiple of $\pm 2 \pi$, the waves are said to be in phase, and the electric field can be represented by
\begin{equation}
	\vec{E}_{xy} = (\hat{i} E_{0,x} + \hat{j} E_{0,y}) \cos(kz- \omega t).
\end{equation}

This wave has a fixed amplitude of $(\hat{i} E_{0,x} + \hat{j} E_{0,y})$, and is linearly polarized. On the other hand, if $\delta$ is an odd integer multiple of $\pm \pi$, the electric field can be represented by
\begin{equation}
	\vec{E}_{xy} = (\hat{i} E_{0,x} - \hat{j} E_{0,y}) \cos(kz- \omega t). 
\end{equation}

This wave is also linearly polarized, but the plane of vibration is rotated. In all cases of linear polarization, the oscillation is confined to a plane, and the electric field vector goes through one complete cycle as the wave progresses along the $z$-axis through one full wavelength. The electric field vector traces out a line, as seen in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbLinearlyPolarizedRotation}.

\begin{figure}
\centering
\caption{The direction of the electric field vector at various points in time in the special linear case.}
\label{fig:mlbLinearlyPolarizedRotation}
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=0.75]

		\draw[->] (-1,0) -- (1,0);

		\draw[dashed] (-1,-1) -- (1,1);

		\draw[dashed] (-1,-1) -- (1,1);
		\draw[-stealth,thick] (0,0) -- (0.3,0.3);
	\end{scope}

	\begin{scope}[shift={(6,0)}]

		\draw[->] (-1,0) -- (1,0);

		\draw[dashed] (-1,-1) -- (1,1);
		\draw[fill=black] (0,0) circle (0.08);
	\end{scope}

Circularly polarized light occurs when both waves have equal amplitudes $(E_{0,x} = E_{0,y} = E_0)$ and their phase difference is $\delta = -\pi/2+2m\pi$, where $m = 0, \pm 1, \pm 2, ...$. Thus, the wave is given by
\begin{equation}
	\vec{E}_t = E_0 \left[\hat{i} \cos(kz-\omega t) + \hat{j} \sin(kz - \omega t) \right].
\end{equation}

The direction of $\mathbf{E_{xy}}$ is not restricted to a single plane and is time varying. However, the magnitude remains constant and the electric field vector rotates clockwise. This is known as \textbf{right-circularly polarized light}. Again, the $\mathbf{E_{xy}}$ vector makes one complete cycle as the wave moves forward through one full wavelength. On the other hand, if the phase difference is given by $\delta  = \pi/2+2m\pi$, then the wave has the form
\begin{equation}
	\vec{E}_t = E_0 \left[\hat{i} \cos(kz-\omega t) - \hat{j} \sin(kz - \omega t) \right].
\end{equation}

The electric field vector in this case rotates counter-clockwise. This is known as \textbf{left-circularly polarized light}. In both of these cases $\mathbf{E_{xy}}$ traces out a circle like Figure~\ref{fig:mlbCircularlyPolarizedRotation}. 

\begin{figure}
\centering
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=0.8]

Four main methods of producing polarized light are \textbf{scattering}, \textbf{reflection}, \textbf{dichroism} (absorption), and \textbf{birefringence}. Scattering occurs when light is absorbed and re-radiated by small particles. Scattered light is partially linearly polarized in a plane perpendicular to the direction of the source. It reaches a maximum in a direction at $90^{\circ}$ to the source.  For example, if the sky is examined with a piece of Polaroid, it would be seen that the sky near the Sun and $180^{\circ}$ away from the sun is unpolarized. However, the sky that is $90^{\circ}$ away from the sun is partially polarized. The atmosphere also scatters blue light much more strongly than red light. In the absence of the atmosphere, no light would be scattered and the sky would appear dark. Polarization by scattering is highly dependent on wavelength and on the size of the scattering particles. 

Polarization by reflection occurs when unpolarized light is incident on a boundary between two dielectric surfaces (like air and glass). The reflected and transmitted components will be partially linearly polarized. So, reflections of the sun in glass, pavement, or water are highly polarized. Depending on the height of the sun, the reflections can be almost completely horizontally polarized. Polaroid sunglasses take advantage of this polarization of reflected sunlight. Sunglasses are actually polarizing filters with their transmission axes oriented vertically so they can block the light being reflected by surfaces.

The two phenomena to be examined in this lab are polarization by dichroism and birefringence. Dichroism occurs because certain naturally occurring crystalline materials have transmittance properties which depend on the polarization state of light. For example, light which is linearly polarized in a certain direction is absorbed more than the light perpendicular to it. The resultant light is partially polarized. If the dichroism is large enough, then the resultant light may be nearly perfectly linearly polarized. 
	
Birefringence occurs because certain crystalline substances have a refractive index which depends on the state of polarization. This is also known as \textbf{double refraction}. Unpolarized light that enters a birefringent crystal is split into two linearly polarized beams which are refracted by different amounts. One naturally birefringent substance is calcite, or calcium carbonate (CaCO$_3$). A famous form of crystalline calcite is \textbf{Icelandic feldspar}, which is generally used to demonstrate birefringence. The large birefringence shown by calcite arises from the fact that the carbonate (CO$_3$) groups are all in planes perpendicular to the \textbf{optical axis}.
	
Dichroism is usually demonstrated using a \textbf{polarizer} and an \textbf{analyzer}. A polarizer is any material that only allows light with a specific angle of vibration to pass through. This angle of vibration is known as the \textbf{transmission axis} of the polarizer. An analyzer is essentially a second identical polarizer, whose transmission axis is vertical. If two polarizers, or in this case a polarizer and an analyzer, are set up in series so that their transmission axes are parallel, then light passes through both, as seen in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbParallelPolarizer}. However, if the axes are set 90 degrees apart (crossed polarizers), the polarized light from the first will be extinguished by the second, as seen in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbPerpendicularPolarizer}. As the angle is rotated from $0$ to $90$ degrees, the amount of light that is transmitted decreases. This is because only the component of the optical field parallel to the transmission axis passes through.

The most common method of producing polarized light is to use \textbf{Polaroid material}. It was invented by Edwin H. Land, who founded the Polaroid Corporation in $1948$, and is made from chains of organic molecules, called \textbf{herapathite} or \textbf{quinine sulfate periodide}, imbedded in plastic. The discovery of these molecules came about in a rather interesting way. In Bristol, England, a pupil of William Bird Herapath found that, when a drop of iodine is added to the urine of a dog that was fed quinine, small green crystals formed. Herapath looked at the crystals under a microscope and discovered that in some places they were light when they overlapped and in other places they were dark when the overlapped. He realized that they had come across a new polarizing material, now known as herapathite. The light that is transmitted by the herapathite is linearly polarized perpendicular to the direction of the chains of molecules. Actual Polaroid material is not $100 \%$ efficient at transmitting light even along its \textbf{transmission axis}, some fraction is always absorbed. Generally, most polarizers have an efficiency of about $40 \%$, but some can get as high as $95 \%$.

In calculating the effect of a dichroic polarizer on an incident light beam, it can be shown that any linearly polarized vibration, or electric field, can be resolved into two components. One is parallel to the transmission axis and the other at right angles to it, as seen in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbTransmissionAxis}. Only the light parallel to the transmission axis will pass. If the angle between the electric field vector, $\mathbf{E_{xy}}$, and the transmission axis is $q$, then the component passed through is 
\begin{equation}
	E_t = E_{xy} \cos(\theta),
	\label{equ:mlEtExyRelation}
\end{equation}

where $E_t$ is the transmitted part of the initial electric field, $E_{xy}$. 

\begin{figure}
\centering
\caption{Transmission axis.}
\label{fig:mlbTransmissionAxis}
\begin{tikzpicture}
	\draw[-triangle 60] (0,0) -- (2,0);
	\draw[-triangle 60] (2,1) -- (2,0);
	\draw[-triangle 60] (0,0) -- (2,1);

	\node at (1,-0.4) {$E_t$};
	\node at (0.9,0.9) {$E_{xy}$};

	\draw (0.5,0) arc (0:70:0.2);
	\node at (0.8,0.2) {$\theta$};
\end{tikzpicture}
\end{figure}

The \textbf{intensity} of light is what is measured by optical instruments such as eyes or photodetectors. It is known that the intensity is related to the electric field by the formula
\begin{equation}
	I = \frac{c \epsilon_0}{2} E^2_{xy},
	\label{equ:mlIntensityEquation}
\end{equation}

where $c$ is the speed of light and $\epsilon_0$ is the permittivity of free space. So, it is seen that $I$ is proportional to $\mathbf{E_{xy}}^2$. By substituting Equation~\ref{equ:mlIntensityEquation} into Equation~\ref{equ:mlEtExyRelation}, the relationship between intensity and the angle is found to be
\begin{equation}
	I_t = I_0 \cos^2(\theta),
	\label{equ:mlIntensityFunctionOfAngle}
\end{equation}
where
\begin{equation}
	I_0 = \frac{c\epsilon_0}{2} E^2_{xy}.
	\label{equ:mlbI0Def}
\end{equation}

$I_t$ is the transmitted intensity and $I_0$ is the initial intensity of the light. Equation~\ref{equ:mlIntensityFunctionOfAngle} is known as \textbf{Malus' law}, which states that the transmitted intensity, It, of light with initial intensity, $I_0$, varies as the square of the cosine of the angle between the two planes of transmission of successive polarizers. When the polarizers are parallel, as in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbParallelPolarizer}, then $\theta=0^{\circ}$ and Malus law predicts that all of the light is passed through as expected. When the polarizers are perpendicular, $\theta=90^{\circ}$ and Malus law predicts that none of the light passed through, again as expected.

However, most real polarizers do not transmit $100\%$ of the light even when the polarization axis of the light is parallel to the transmission axis of the polarizer. For real polarizers, a correction is made to account for the absorbed light. Here, Malus law takes the form
\begin{equation}
	I_t = \alpha I_0 \cos^2(\theta)
\end{equation}

where a is the \textbf{transmission coefficient} of the polarizer.

Usually, Malus' Law is tested using the experimental setup seen in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbExperimentalSetup}. At first, the natural light has wavetrains going in all different directions. Only light parallel to the transmission axis of the polarizer, at an angle, $\theta$, to the vertical axis, will get though. Then, the light goes through the analyzer, or the second polarizer, which only lets light through that is parallel to its transmission axis, which is vertical. The remaining light then reaches the detector oscillating only in the vertical direction.

The phenomena of birefringence is seen in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbRefractionAngles}. A ray of light that passes through a birefringent is refracted by two different amounts because there are two refractive indices in the crystal. The E beam in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbRefractionAngles} is refracted at an angle of $\theta_E$ to the normal. The O beam is refracted at an angle $\theta_O$ to the normal. The \textbf{optical axis} is the direction within the crystal where there is no double refraction. The \textbf{ordinary index}, $n_o$, is defined to have its electric field vector, $\mathbf{E_{xy}}$, perpendicular to the optical axis. On the other hand, the \textbf{extra-ordinary index}, $n_e$, is defined to have its electric field vector, $\mathbf{E_{xy}}$, parallel to the optical axis. 

\begin{figure}
\centering
\caption{Refraction angles in a birefringent material.}
\label{fig:mlbRefractionAngles}
\begin{tikzpicture}[circuit ee IEC]
	\coordinate (A) at  (0.75,2.25);
	\coordinate (B) at  (5.5,1.5);
	\coordinate (C) at  (5.6,1.8);
	\coordinate (D) at  (0,2.5);

	\draw (0,0) -- (1,3) -- (6,3) -- (5,0) -- (0,0);
	\draw[dashed] (D) -- (3.75,1.25);

	\begin{scope}[shift={(2,1.8)}]
		\draw[rotate=-30] (0,0.025) arc (-20:52:0.19);
		\draw[rotate=-27] (0.5,0.1) arc (-20:32:0.5);

		\node at (0,-0.2) {$\theta_O$};
		\node at (1.2,-0.15) {$\theta_E$};
	\end{scope}

	\draw[->]  (A) -- (B) -- (7,1.5) node[right,yshift=-0.05cm]{O};
	\draw [->] (A) -- (C) -- (7,1.8) node[right,yshift=0.05cm]{E};

	\begin{scope}[rotate=161,shift={(A)}]
		\draw (0,0) -- (30:1);
		\draw (0,0) -- (-30:1);

		\draw[-<] (0,0) -- (30:0.6);
		\draw[->] (0,0) -- (-30:0.6);

		\draw[rotate=1] (0.5,0) node[left,yshift=-0.1cm]{$\theta$} arc (-20:55:0.2);
	\end{scope}
\end{tikzpicture}
\end{figure}

Crystals with two indices of refraction will be strongly absorbing for one polarization direction and transparent for the other. Therefore, birefringent materials are in fact dichroic, and they consequently act as a linear polarizer. Icelandic feldspar is used to demonstrate the phenomenon of birefringence. Feldspar is a doubly refracting, or birefringent, substance that separates light into two components. The two components have different velocities in the crystal. When the two beams of light emerge from the feldspar, they re-combine. Since one beam travels faster than the other, the two are generally out of phase with one another. The extent to which the two components are out of phase depends on the nature of the birefringent substance, its thickness, the wavelength of the incident light, and the orientation of the crystal.
	
Malus' Law can be tested by using a polarizer-analyzer pair to vary the intensity of the light that is transmitted. A \textbf{photodetector} is used in this experiment to measure the light intensity. The photodetector is calibrated to generate a voltage proportional to the light intensity. A multimeter is used to read the amount of voltage that the photodetector generates. The SI unit of light intensity is \textbf{Lux}. The photodetector has three settings to convert light intensity, in Lux, into volts. Here, the $1$ mV = $1$ Lux setting on the detector should be used because the voltage that is measured is quite small. The angle of the polarizer and analyzer can be found simply from the scale on the device. 

One objective of this experiment is to determine the polarization of a laser and of white light. To find the polarization angle of each light source, only one polarizer and a detector is needed as seen in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbStep3Setup}. By changing the angle of the polarizer, the amount of light being transmitted will change.  The amount of change is determined by the polarization of the incoming light. The polarization angle is the angle at which the most light is transmitted. By knowing this angle, Malus' Law can be tested by setting up the apparatus with two polarizers, as in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbStep5Setup}. By setting the polarizer to the experimental polarization angle found for the light source, and by changing the angle of the analyzer, a set of data points will be obtained. Using this data, a graph of intensity, $I$, versus $\cos^2(q)$ will give a linear plot, if Malus' Law holds. The slope can be used to find the value of the transmission coefficient, $a$. The only difference in finding the polarization angle and the transmission coefficient for the light bulb is that a lens is used to focus the light onto the polarizers and detector.

\section{{\bf Experimental Procedure}}
\begin{enumerate}
	\item The first step is to measure the background light in the room. Connect the digital detector to the multimeter. Set the multimeter to the mV setting and the detector to the $0.1$ mV = $1$ Lux setting. Place the detector at one end of the optical bench, where it should remain for the duration of the experiment. Turn on the multimeter and the detector. Record a value for the reading in the room. Try to make sure that the light does not change drastically during the experiment. To get a more accurate reading, take measurements of the background light periodically throughout the lab. The less background light in the room, the more accurate the measurements will be.
	\item Next, measure the intensity of the laser by itself, without an intervening polarizer, to get a value for the initial intensity, $I_0$. For best results, the laser should be allowed to warm up for at least $10$ minutes first. Otherwise, temperature fluctuations inside the laser tube will change its properties enough that the output intensity varies noticeably.
	\item  The polarizer material could have been rotated inside its holder at some time in the past. So the polarizer and analyzer likely have transmission axes that do not directly correspond to each other or to the angular scales on their holders. So a \textbf{correction}, $\theta_0$, is needed for each polarizer and analyzer. To find the correction, use the experimental arrangement shown in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbStep3Setup}. Make sure the laser hits the detector approximately in the center. Start the polarizer at 0 degrees and then rotate it until a maximum voltage is seen on the multimeter. Record the angle of maximum voltage. This is the angle correction, $q_0$, for that specific polarizer and is also its transmission axis. Repeat this for the other polarizer, and label one as the polarizer and one as the analyzer so that they are not mixed up. As with all other optical components, never touch the polarizing material with your fingers.

	\item Examine the laser to see if it is fully or partially linearly polarized, or non-polarized. A fully polarized light source would be completely extinguished when passing through a polarizer that is perpendicular to the axis of polarization of the light source. A partially polarized light source would decrease in intensity somewhat, but not be fully extinguished. Non-polarized light would not change intensity at all. To measure this, use one polarizer, as in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbStep3Setup}. For at least $36$ different polarizer angles, $\theta$, from $0$ through $360$ degrees, record the light intensity. The \textbf{corrected angle}, $\theta-\theta_0$, then gives the intensity with respect to the transmission axis of the polarizer.
	\item Malus law can then be tested with two polarizers. Set the apparatus up as seen in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbStep5Setup}. The angle of the polarizer should be set to the angle of maximum output, which is the $q_0$ that was determined for that polarizer. Take at least $36$ measurements of the intensity while varying the angle of the analyzer through $360$ degrees. A plot of intensity versus $\cos^2(\theta-\theta_0)$, where $\theta_0$ is the correction angle of the analyzer, should yield a straight line if Malus law is obeyed.

	\item Place the light bulb securely in a lens holder and connect it to the power supply as in Figure ~\ref{fig:mlbStep7Setup}. Make sure the voltage knob is turned fully counter-clockwise, and the current knob is turned fully clockwise. Turn on the power supply, and give the light bulb full voltage. The light bulb changes brightness as it warms up so it also needs a few minutes to stabilize. It also needs a constant current to maintain the same brightness. Make note of the current on the power supply, and check from time to time to see if the current has changed. If it does change, then adjust it back to its original value with the current knob. Now, take the lens, and focus the light on the center of the detector. Measure the initial intensity, $I_0$, of the light bulb.
	\item Examine the light bulb to see if it is fully or partially linearly polarized, or non-polarized. Remember that light passing through an interface between air and glass emerges partially polarized, with the degree of polarization being dependent upon the angle of the light ray. As with the laser, use one polarizer as in Figure ~\ref{fig:mlbStep3Setup}. For at least 36 different polarizer angles, $\theta$, from $0$ through $360$ degrees, record the light intensity.

	\item Malus Law can be tested using a light bulb as the source. Set up the apparatus as seen in Figure~\ref{fig:mlbStep7Setup}. The angle of the polarizer should be set to the angle of maximum light output from the bulb. Then insert and adjust the analyzer for maximum output once more. The angle of maximum output for the analyzer is the correction angle, $\theta_0$, for the analyzer and light bulb. Take at least $36$ measurements of the intensity while varying the angle of the analyzer through $360$ degrees. A plot of intensity versus $\cos^2(\theta-\theta_0)$, where $\theta_0$ is the correction angle of the analyzer, should yield a straight line if Malus law is obeyed.
	\item Place the feldspar crystal over the letter in Figure 12. Observe what happens when the feldspar is rotated.
	\item Hold a polarizer over the feldspar (which is still over the letter). Rotate the polarizer and observe what happens to the letter.
\end{enumerate}

\section{{\bf Error Analysis}}

For Malus' Law to hold, it must be assumed that the transmitted light is completely linearly polarized. However, the polarizers that are being used in this lab are not $100\%$ efficient. This means that, when the polarization axis of the light source is parallel to the transmission axis of the polarizer, not all of the light will get through. In a sense, the polarizer resists light flow. This is why Equation 19 is used. The transmission coefficient, a, is a correction constant to account for this resistance. Each polarizer has a different transmission axis. Corrected values of the angle are needed for proper results. To give corrected values of the angle, set the transmission axis of the polarizer to zero. Then, correct each measured angle by subtracting the transmission axis from the angle that is measured. If this number is a negative number, add $360$ degrees to get a number between $0$ and $360$ degrees. Another systematic error in the lab is the background light. If this value is fairly large, then it should be accounted for by subtracting it from all the values of intensity that is measured in this lab. So, it is a good idea to have the room as dark as possible, so that the background light is negligible.
	The error in the $\cos^2(\theta)$ term can be found by standard error propagation from the error in the angle. The angle and its uncertainty must be in radians, not degrees. The error in measuring the voltage is the instrument error of the Fluke meter shown on the bottom of the instrument. The error in the photodetector is $\pm 5\%+0.1$ mV. The uncertainty for measuring the angle of the polarizer and analyzer is half the smallest division on the protractor. 
\newpage

\textbf{To be handed in to the laboratory instructor}

\section{Purpose}
To use and understand the Michelson interferometer. To use the interferometer to measure the wavelength of laser light. To use the interferometer to measure the index of refraction of air. To investigate how changes in pressure affect the index of refraction of air.


\section{Theory}
In 1887, Albert Michelson (1852-1931) built his interferometer originally to investigate the existence of "ether", which was believed to permeate all space. It was the belief of many physicists at the time that ether was the medium through which light propagated, much like sound waves through air. The results of the famous Michelson-Morley experiment supported the idea that there is no stationary medium through which light propagates, which later formed the basis of Einstein's theory of relativity. The interferometer was later used to measure the wavelengths of atomic spectral lines with high precision, as well as displacements in terms of wavelengths of light. This enabled scientists to develop high precision length standards as well as improved methods for calibrating length measuring instruments. The interferometer can also be used to determine the {\bf index of refraction} of transparent materials.

In this experiment, you will use a Michelson interferometer to determine the wavelength of laser light, as well as to investigate the index of refraction of air and how it is affected by changes in pressure. Figure \ref{fig:mi1} is a diagram of the apparatus, the Pasco model OS-9255A Precision interferometer.

A simplified diagram of the Michelson interferometer is shown in Figure \ref{fig:mi2}. Light from a monochromatic source passes through the beam splitter, producing two perpendicular beams of equal intensity. The two beams then reflect off of two separate mirrors which are deliberately located at different distances from the beam splitter. The mirrors are aligned in such a way that the beam is reflected straight back along the incoming path. When the beams recombine at the beam splitter, they will {\bf interfere} with each other.  Whether the interference will be {\bf constructive} or {\bf destructive} depends on the relative phase of each of the combining light beams. This is determined by the path length difference, 2d. With constructive interference, the wave amplitudes add in such a way to produce a maximum intensity beam striking the screen. The condition for maximum constructive interference is

\begin{equation}
2d=m\lambda
\label{equ:mi1}
\end{equation}

\noindent where m is an integer and $\lambda$ is the wavelength of the incoming light. When the path length difference is an integer multiple of the wavelength, the recombining light beams will be in phase since both light beams originated from the same source. The resulting amplitude of the combined beam is then the sum of the amplitudes of each beam. 

With destructive interference, the phases of the light beams are such that the recombining beams cancel each other out.  The condition for maximum destructive interference is

\begin{equation}
2d=\left(m+\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\lambda
\label{equ:mi2}
\end{equation}

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(6,6);
%screen
\draw[](2.5,4.9)rectangle(3.5,5);
%beam
\draw[](1,3)--(5,3);
\draw[](3,4.9)--(3,.3);
%beam splitter
\draw[fill=white,shift={(3,3)},rotate=-45](-.75,-.05)rectangle(.75,.05);
%light source
\draw[rounded corners=1,fill=gray](0,2.9)rectangle(1,3.1);

%mirror 2 image

\label{fig:mi2}
\end{marginfigure}

When the path length is an odd half integer multiple of the wavelength, the recombining light beams will be exactly out of phase. The resulting amplitude of the combined beam will be the difference of the amplitudes of each beam. Moreover, since the amplitudes of the split beams are equal, the combined light beam will have zero amplitude.

By moving one of the mirrors, we can change the path length difference and the relative phase of the light beams. With careful alignment, it is possible to use a laser light source to produce interference. As the path length difference changes, we would see both constructive and destructive interference. By moving Mirror 1 slowly towards the light source, we would see the laser point on screen appear, reach maximum brightness, fade away, and then disappear as the path length difference is increased by one wavelength.

\begin{figure}

\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{The path of a dispersed laser beam.}
\label{fig:mi3}
\end{figure}

It is more practical to use a dispersed beam instead of a thin laser beam. In the lab, you will use a convex lens to disperse a laser light source. With a dispersed beam, the interferometer produces an interference pattern on the screen instead of a single point. Figure \ref{fig:mi3} shows the path of a dispersed laser beam at an exaggerated angle.  For convenience, the primary elements of the interferometer are shown in a linear arrangement. The parallel beams reflected towards the screen interact with each other in a constructive or destructive manner, depending on the path length difference. The path length difference, now dependent on the beam angle, $\theta$, is given by $2dcos\theta$.  Since the path difference is dependent on the angle of the beam there will be certain angles where there is constructive interference and certain angles at which there is destructive interference. The condition for constructive interference is now

\begin{equation}
2dcos\theta=m\lambda
\label{equ:mi3}
\end{equation}

Constructive interference at specific angles will give rise to an interference pattern of bright and dark concentric circular {\bf fringes}, as shown in Figure \ref{fig:mi4}. Note that Equation \ref{equ:mi1} still holds as a special case where $\theta=0$, corresponding to the center of the interference pattern.

With a dispersed beam, we can change the path length difference by moving Mirror 1 and we would see changes in the interference pattern. The interference fringes will move either towards or away from the center of the interference pattern, fringes are either produced or annihilated.  In the center of the interference pattern, we would see the alternating light and dark spot as discussed before. A fringe will be produced or annihilated for every wavelength by which the path length difference is changed. For this reason, very fine control is required to move the mirror. The micrometer screw (see Figure \ref{fig:mi1}) is designed to control and measure the small displacements of Mirror 1.  Mirror 1 is restricted to a path parallel to that of the laser beam. As a result, the distance traveled by Mirror 1 is equal to the change in mirror separation, $\Delta$d. By counting the number of passing fringes corresponding to a measured mirror displacement, we can calculate the wavelength of the laser light. The number of fringes that have passed in a mirror displacement, $\Delta$d, is equal to the number of wavelengths that the path length difference has changed. Therefore, Equation \ref{equ:mi1} implies the wavelength is given by

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}[semithick]
\node[fill,circle,scale=.7]at(0,0){};
\foreach \s in {1,2,...,10}{
\node[line width=(15*exp(-\s*.5)),circle,scale=20-24/(\s),draw]at(0,0){};
}
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{An illustration of a concentric interference pattern.}
\label{fig:mi4}
\end{marginfigure}

\begin{equation}
\lambda=\dfrac{2\Delta d}{N}
\label{equ:mi4}
\end{equation}

\noindent where N is the number of passing fringes corresponding to the change in mirror separation. 

We can further investigate the interference pattern in order to better understand it's origin. We can measure the fringe spacing of the stationary interference pattern, then compare with predictions made by the theory. Given a constant path difference and constant wavelength, there are values of $\theta$ and m that satisfy Equation \ref{equ:mi3}, which correspond to each fringe. So we have

\begin{equation}
2dcos\theta_N=m_N\lambda
\label{equ:mi5}
\end{equation}

\noindent where $\theta_N$ is the angle of the N$^{th}$ fringe from the center of the interference pattern, and $m_N$ is the integer number of wavelengths associated with the N$^{th}$ fringe path difference. If we adjust d so that there is a fringe of maximum brightness at $\theta=0$, then $m_0$ is the value of m that satisfies Equation \ref{equ:mi3} for $\theta=0$. So then

\begin{equation}
2dcos(0)=2d=m_0\lambda
\label{equ:mi6}
\end{equation}

\noindent and $m_0$ is the integer number of wavelengths equal to twice the mirror separation (note that this is a re-statement of Equation \ref{equ:mi1}, the zero angle condition for constructive interference). Since neighboring fringes differ in path length difference by one wavelength,

\begin{equation}
m_0-m_N=N
\label{equ:mi7}
\end{equation}

\noindent Equations \ref{equ:mi5}, \ref{equ:mi6}, and \ref{equ:mi7} together predict that the cosine of the angle between the N$^{th}$ fringe and a fringe at the center of the interference pattern will be given by

\begin{equation}
cos\theta_N=1-\dfrac{N\lambda}{2d}
\label{equ:mi8}
\end{equation}

\noindent By plotting the cosine of the fringe angle versus the fringe number, we can see how well the interference pattern  matches the one predicted by the theory.

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(11,6);
%optical axis
\draw[](0,3)--(7.5,3);
%mirror 1
\draw[rounded corners=2,fill=lightgray](7.5,1.5)rectangle(7.7,4.5);
%aircell
\draw(6,3)ellipse(.2 and 1.3);
\draw(3,3)ellipse(.2 and 1.3);
\draw[](3,4.3)--(6,4.3);
\draw[](3,1.7)--(6,1.7);
\draw[thick](3,4.3)arc(90:270:.2 and 1.3);
\draw[thick](6,4.3)arc(90:270:.2 and 1.3);
%beams
\draw[domain=0:7.5]plot[samples=500](\x,{(sin(\x*1000))*.2+3});
\draw[very thin,domain=0:7.5]plot[samples=500](\x,{(sin(\x*1000-100))*.2+3});
\draw[domain=8.5:10]plot[samples=500](\x,{(sin(\x*1000))*.2+4});
\draw[very thin,domain=8.5:10]plot[samples=500](\x,{(sin(\x*1000-100))*.2+2});
%demarcation lines
\draw[](3,1.5)--(6,1.5);
\draw[](3,1.4)--(3,1.6);
\draw[](6,1.4)--(6,1.6);
%labels
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(9.25,3.5){Incoming beam};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(9.25,1.5){Reflected beam};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(7.6,4.7){Mirror 1};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(4.5,4.5){Air cell};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(4.5,1.3){t};
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Placing an air cell in the path of light.}
\label{fig:mi5}
\end{figure}

The interference pattern is sensitive to changes in the relative phase of the two split beams. So we can use the interferometer to investigate how transparent objects affect the phase of light by placing them in one of the split beam paths. The laboratory apparatus includes an air cell connected to a vacuum system. The air cell is an air tight cylinder with glass windows on both faces. We can use this air cell to investigate the index of refraction of the air inside. Consider an air cell placed in the path of one of the split beams, as shown in Figure \ref{fig:mi5}. As a light beam passes though a medium, the wavelength of light is dependent on the index of refraction by the formula

\begin{equation}
\lambda=\dfrac{\lambda_{vac}}{n}
\label{equ:mi9}
\end{equation}

\noindent where $\lambda$ is the measured wavelength in the medium, $\lambda_{vac}$ is the wavelength of the light beam measured in a vacuum, and n is the index of refraction of the medium. The number of wavelengths that make up the path length in the air cell, W(p), is given by 

\begin{equation}
W(p)=\dfrac{2t}{\lambda_{cell}}=\dfrac{2t}{\lambda_{vac}}n(p)
\label{equ:mi10}
\end{equation}

where t is the thickness of the cell, $\lambda_{cell}$ is the wavelength of the light in the cell, p is the pressure inside the cell, and n(p) is the index of refraction of air at pressure p. Since the index of refraction is a function of pressure, so is the number of wavelengths in the air cell.

It is important to note that the index of refraction of a material medium is always greater than 1, and the index of refraction of a vacuum is equal to 1. This means that the wavelength (as well as the speed) of a beam of light is a maximum in vacuum conditions. As air is evacuated from the cell, the wavelength of the laser light in the cell will increase as the index of refraction approaches 1. For each wavelength decrease in the cell, the relative phase of the split beams will have undergone one complete cycle. This means that the fringes of the interference pattern will move as the air is evacuated from the cell. The number of passing fringes is equal to the change in number of wavelengths in the air cell. From this we know that the number of passing fringes as the air cell pressure changes from atmospheric pressure to some pressure, p, is equal to the difference in number of wavelengths in the air cell at the two pressures. With Equation \ref{equ:mi10}, we have

\begin{equation}
N=W(p_{atm})-W(p)=\dfrac{2t}{\lambda_{vac}}\left[n(p_{atm})-n(p)\right]
\label{equ:mi11}
\end{equation}

\noindent where p$_{atm}$ is atmospheric pressure, and $N$ is the number of passing fringes as the air cell is evacuated from atmospheric pressure to some pressure p. Re-arranging Equation \ref{equ:mi11} with Equation \ref{equ:mi9} we have

\begin{equation}
1-\dfrac{\lambda N}{2t}=\dfrac{n(p)}{n(p_{atm})}
\label{equ:mi12}
\end{equation}

\noindent where $\lambda$ is the wavelength of the laser light in air at atmospheric pressure.

Note that the quantities on the left side of Equation \ref{equ:mi12} and the pressure inside the air cell are measurable. We can evacuate the air cell while counting the number of passing fringes and recording the pressure. From this data, we can then calculate the relative index of refraction, n(p)/n(p$_{atm}$), at each of the pressures. This makes it possible to observe how the index of refraction of air is affected by changes in pressure. We can also determine the index of refraction of air at atmospheric pressure from a plot of n(p)/n(p$_{atm}$) versus p. The vertical intercept of this plot yields a value for 1/n(p$_{atm}$) since n(p)=1 at p=0.

\section{Experimental Procedure}
\begin{enumerate}

\item Begin by aligning the interferometer. Place the interferometer on the wooden stand. The laser should be mounted on the optical bench such that the laser light passes through the interferometer components. Place the laser about 30cm from the interferometer as shown in Figure \ref{fig:mi1}. Loosen the thumb screw that holds the beam splitter and rotate it so that it is out of the path of the beam.  Now align the laser so that the beam reflects off the center of Mirror 1 {\bf directly back} towards the aperture of the laser. Rotate the beam splitter into the laser path so that it is at an angle of approximately 45$^{\circ}$ to the beam. You should see two laser spots on the screen. Rotate the beam splitter until the spots are as close as possible, then tighten the thumb screw. Use the alignment screws on Mirror 2 to superimpose the two spots on the screen.

Now we will diverge the beam in order to produce the interference pattern. Place the convex lens on the stand in between the interferometer and the laser as shown in Figure \ref{fig:mi1}. Adjust the orientation of the lens until you see the dispersed beam reflecting off the center of Mirror 1. You should now see an interference pattern on the screen. You may need to make fine adjustments using the alignment screws on Mirror 2 in order to center the concentric circle pattern. When the alignment is complete, you should see an image on the screen like the one in Figure \ref{fig:mi4}.

\item Adjust the micrometer knob to a medium reading (approximately 50$\mu$m). In this position the relationship between the micrometer reading and mirror movement is most nearly linear. Turn the micrometer knob about one full turn counterclockwise until the zero on the knob is aligned with the reference mark. You should see moving fringes as the micrometer knob is adjusted. Record the micrometer reading (note each small division corresponds to 1$\mu$m). 

\item You will now use the micrometer to measure the wavelength of the laser light. Take note of the initial position of the micrometer. Always turn the micrometer dial one complete revolution counterclockwise before you start to count fringes, to eliminate mechanical backlash (the slight slippage occurring when the direction of motion in a mechanical instrument is reversed). Turn the micrometer screw slowly counter clockwise while counting the number of passing fringes. After about 70 fringes have passed, record the number of fringes as well the mirror displacement from the micrometer screw. Turn the micrometer screw back to the original position and repeat to obtain two more measurements. 

\item Adjust the micrometer screw so that the center of the interference pattern is an illuminated dot of maximum brightness. This implies that there is constructive interference at $\theta=0^{\circ}$ and Equation \ref{equ:mi6} is satisfied. Measure the radius of each fringe from the center of the interference pattern using the ruler on the back of the screen. Record the radius and the corresponding fringe number. Measure the distance from Mirror 2 to the screen with a ruler. From the fringe radius and the distance to the screen, one can determine the angle of the fringe, $\theta$, in order to compare with the predictions made by Equation \ref{equ:mi8}.

\item Record the air pressure with a barometer.

\item Place the air cell in the component stand in the beam path between the beam splitter and Mirror 1. Be sure that the air cell is parallel with the beam path throughout the entire procedure step. Press the pressure release button on the Nalgene pump in order to be sure that the initial air cell pressure is equal to atmospheric pressure. Record the initial pressure reading on the Nalgene pump gauge. Slowly squeeze the pump until the fringe interference pattern has completed one cycle, and record the pressure. Continue to evacuate the air and record the air cell pressure as well as the number of cycles after each passing fringe. Repeat this until the pressure reaches the minimum value and the pump can no longer evacuate air from the cell. When you are finished, be sure to press the pressure release button on the pump. It is important to note that the pressure gauge reads negative values of kPa, therefore, to find the absolute pressure inside the air cell, you must subtract the difference between the pressure on the gauge and the initial pressure reading from the air pressure read on the barometer.
%!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!units on nalgene pump!!!

\item Remove the air cell from the beam path and replace it with the glass slide apparatus. Rotate the glass slide and observe the effect on the interference pattern. Make as many qualitative observations as you can.

\item Perform any optional investigations as required.

\end{enumerate}

\section{Error Analysis}
There will be measurement error in the mirror displacement which can be taken to be one half the smallest division on the micrometer screw. When counting large numbers of passing fringes, even though you are counting whole numbers, it is a good idea to use an uncertainty of one fringe since there is freedom to move the micrometer without a complete fringe passing. When measuring length with a ruler, the error is usually taken to be one half of the smallest division. The error in pressure can also be taken as one half the smallest division on the pressure gauge.

Systematic errors arise because the apparatus can't be perfectly aligned. It is possible to observe an interference pattern even if the laser is slightly misaligned, however, the instrument will deliver poorer results since the mirror movement mechanism is not calibrated for such a situation. If the alignment procedure is followed, the apparatus should function with reasonable accuracy.

\section{To be handed in to your laboratory instructor.}
\begin{enumerate}

\section{Data Requirements}
\begin{enumerate}[resume]

\item (2 marks) A table of values for the number of passing fringes, N, and the corresponding change in mirror separation, $\Delta$d, as measured in procedure step 3, with errors. Include a column of the calculated wavelength with error. Comment on whether or not the results are reasonable (the accepted value of the wavelength of the laser light is 632.816 nm).

\item (2 marks) A table of values for the fringe number, N, with the corresponding fringe radius as measured in procedure step 4, with errors. From the fringe radius and the screen distance, calculate the cos$\theta$ value for each of the fringes, with errors. For this calculation you can assume the beam is perpendicular to the screen and that the beam does not strike the mirrors far from the centre.

\item (2 marks) A plot of cos$\theta$ versus N, with error bars. Is it a linear relationship with reasonable slope and intercept? Comment on whether or not the fringe spacing is consistent with Equation \ref{equ:mi8}. 

\item (2 marks) A table of values for the number of passed fringes, N, and the corresponding pressure, p, as measured in procedure step 6, with errors.  Include a column of the calculated n(p)/n(p$_{atm}$) values. In the calculation, you should use the average of the three wavelength values that you measured in procedure step 3 as the wavelength of the laser light at atmospheric pressure. Also note that the thickness of the air cell is 3.0 cm.

\item (2 marks) A plot of n(p)/n(p$_{atm}$) versus p. Extrapolate the plot to find the n(p)/n(p$_{atm}$) value at zero pressure. From the value of the intercept, determine the index of refraction of air at atmospheric pressure. Comment on whether or not the result is reasonable (the accepted value is 1.00025). Comment on the relationship between the index of refraction of air and pressure.

\item (1 mark) A list of qualitative observations made during procedure step 7. Write a paragraph explaining your observations (note that the index of refraction of glass is around 1.50).

\item (2 bonus marks) Measure the index of refraction of glass using the interferometer. Do this by placing the glass slide on the component stand in the beam path between the beam splitter and Mirror 1 and positioning it so that the glass face is perpendicular to the beam. Using the angle scale very slowly rotate the component stand. Record the number of passed fringes corresponding to the angle of the glass slide around every 10 fringes. Use the calipers to measure the thickness of the glass slide and record the value.

There is some complicated geometry involved in deriving the number of passing fringes as the glass slide is rotated. The relationship between the angle of the glass slide, $\theta$, (measured from the perpendicular position) and the number of passed fringes, N, is


\begin{multline}
N=\dfrac{2t}{\lambda}\dfrac{n_{glass}}{n(p_{atm})}\left[\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{sin^2\theta n(p_{atm})^2}{n^2_{glass}}}}-1\right] \\ +\dfrac{2t}{\lambda}\left[1-cos\theta-\dfrac{n(p_{atm})}{n_{glass}}\dfrac{sin^2\theta}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{sin^2\theta n(p_{atm})^2}{n^2_{glass}}}}\right]
\label{equ:mi13}
\end{multline}

\noindent where t is the thickness of the glass slide, n$_{glass}$ is the index of refraction of the glass slide, $\lambda$ is the wavelength of the laser light, and n(p$_{atm}$) is the index of refraction of air at atmospheric pressure. This complicated function can be simplified by expanding it as a Taylor series and using the first term as an approximation to the function. It turns out that the first term approximation is accurate to within 1$\%$ of the true value for angles less than 45 degrees when the index of refraction of the material being tested is between 1.0 and 2.0. The first term of the approximation function is

\begin{equation}
N\approx \dfrac{t}{\lambda}\left[1-\dfrac{n(p_{atm})}{n_{glass}}\right]\theta^2
\label{equ:mi14b}
\end{equation}

\noindent Plot N versus $\theta^2$ and from the slope you will be able to determine the value of the index of refraction of the glass slide. (Note: Angle calculations must be done in radians)

\end{enumerate}

\section{Purpose}
To investigate the interference phenomena resulting from multiple reflections in thin films. To apply this theory to the measurement of the radius of curvature of a lens and the thickness of a thin object such as a hair. 

\section{Theory}
Interference of light is a commonly observed phenomenon. It can be seen in the intricate color patterns produced by thin films of oil on water, by soap bubbles, or by cracks in a piece of glass. These color patterns are caused by the multiple reflection of light between  two surfaces of a thin film of transparent material. 

\begin{marginfigure}

%lens
