\label{fig:fb1}
\end{marginfigure}

\noindent Consider the reflection of light from a plane parallel film as shown in Figure \ref{fig:fb1}. When  a ray of light from a source S is incident on the surface of the film at point A, the ray splits. Part of the ray is reflected as ray 1 and part is refracted in the direction AF. When the refracted ray reaches F, it will again be split. Part of the refracted ray will be reflected to B and part refracted towards H. At B the ray will again be divided, repeating this process throughout the film. The intensity decreases rapidly from one ray to the next. This process results in two sets of parallel rays, one on each side of the film. If one set of parallel reflected rays is collected by a lens L, and focused at a point P, each ray will have traveled a different distance. Because of the phase relations, constructive or destructive interference will be produced at the point P. This is the effect observed when colors of thin films are observed with the naked eye. In that case L is the lens of the eye, and P lies on the retina.

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}[semithick]
%framework
\draw[](0,3)--(6,3);
\draw[](0,1.5)--(6,1.5);
\draw[thin](0,1.5)--(0,3);
\draw[thin](1.5,4.5)--(1.5,0);
\draw[thin](4,3)--(3.4,4.07);
\draw[thin](1.5,3)--(2.95,1.75);
\draw[thin](2.75,1.5)--(1.5,0);
%light rays
\begin{scope}[decoration={markings,mark=at position 0.5 with {\arrow{>}}}]
\draw[thick,postaction={decorate}](-.3,4)--(1.5,3);
\draw[thick,postaction={decorate}](1.5,3)--(2.75,1.5);
\draw[thick,postaction={decorate}](2.75,1.5)--(4,3);

\draw[thick,->](1.5,3)--(4.2,4.5);
\end{scope}
%angle arcs
\draw[thin](1.5,2.8)arc(-90:-50:.2);
\draw[thin](1.8,3)arc(0:-40:.3);
\draw[thin](1.5,3.2)arc(90:150:.2);

\draw[thin](1.5,.3)arc(90:48:.3);
%demarcation lines

\draw[thin](.7,0)--(1.5,0);

\node[font=\scriptsize,fill=white]at(5.5,2.25){d};

\node[font=\scriptsize]at(4.1,2.8){B};

\node[font=\scriptsize]at(3.7,3.2){$\phi$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(3.9,4.6){$1$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(4.7,3.6){$2$};
\node[font=\scriptsize]at(4.5,2.3){n};
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{A closer look at internal reflection within a thin film.}
\label{fig:fb2}
\end{marginfigure}

In order to find the phase difference between the rays, we must first find the difference in the optical path traversed by a pair of successive rays, such as rays 1 and 2. A more detailed diagram of these two rays is shown in Figure \ref{fig:fb2}. Let d be the thickness of the film, n its index of refraction, $\lambda$ the wavelength of the light, $\varphi$ the angle of incidence, and  the angle of refraction. If BD is perpendicular to ray 1, the optical paths from D and B to the focus of the lens will be equal. Starting at A, ray 2 has the path AFB in the film and ray 1 the path AD in air. The difference, $\Delta$, in these optical paths is given by 

\begin{equation}
\Delta=n\cdot AFB-AD
\label{equ:fb1}
\end{equation}

\noindent where the index of refraction of air is essentially 1.0. If BF is extended to intersect the perpendicular line AE at G, then

\begin{equation}
AF=GF
\label{equ:fb2}
\end{equation}

\noindent because of the equality of the angles of incidence and reflection at the lower surface. Thus we have

\begin{equation}
\Delta=n\cdot GB-AD
\label{equ:fb3}
\end{equation}

\noindent Since

\begin{equation}
GB=GC+CB
\label{equ:fb4}
\end{equation}

\noindent the difference in optical paths can then be written as

\begin{equation}
\Delta=n\cdot (GC+CB)-AD
\label{equ:fb5}
\end{equation}

\noindent Because AC is drawn perpendicular to FB, the thin lines AC and DB represent two successive positions of a wave front reflected from the lower surface. The optical paths must be the same for any ray drawn between two wave fronts. Therefore we may write

\begin{equation}
n\cdot CB=AD
\label{equ:fb6}
\end{equation}

\noindent The path difference then reduces to

\begin{equation}
\Delta=n\cdot GC
\label{equ:fb7}
\end{equation}

\noindent Expressing GC in terms of d and $\theta$ gives us

\begin{equation}
\Delta=n2dcos\theta
\label{equ:fb8}
\end{equation}

If the path difference is a whole number of wavelengths, you might expect rays 1 and 2 to arrive at the focus of the lens in phase with each other and produce a maximum of intensity. However, we must take into account the fact that ray 1 undergoes a phase change of $\pi$ at reflection, while ray 2 does not, since it is internally reflected. The condition

\begin{equation}
m\lambda=2ndcos\theta \hspace{4mm}m=0,1,2,...
\label{equ:fb9}
\end{equation}

\noindent then becomes the condition for maximum {\bf destructive interference}, where m is the order of interference, and $\lambda$ is the wavelength of light. Maximum {\bf constructive interference} will then occur at half wavelength path differences, such that

\begin{equation}
\left(m+\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\lambda=2ndcos\theta \hspace{4mm}m=0,1,2,...
\label{equ:fb10}
\end{equation}

\noindent Since the human eye is more sensitive to small changes of low intensity of light rather than to small changes of high intensity of light, the dark bands of maximum destructive interference are normally used to make measurements.

In the above derivation, only the interaction of the first two rays was discussed. Since intensity of the ray decreases each time it is divided into a reflected and refracted ray, the first two rays will have the highest intensity, and hence will have the most impact on the interference pattern. This is not to say that the other rays do not affect the interference pattern. On the contrary, the reason complete darkness is observed at maximum destructive interference is because rays 3,4,5,.., are all in phase with ray 2. The addition of all these rays results in an intensity as great as that of ray 1, allowing for complete cancellation. Although inclusion of other rays does affect the magnitude of the interference, they do not change the conditions for maximum constructive or destructive interference.

Names are given to the different types of interference bands that result from varying different factors in Equations \ref{equ:fb9} and \ref{equ:fb10}. If the right hand side of the equation is kept constant and the wavelength is allowed to vary, then for certain wavelengths destructive interference results, whereas for others, constructive interference results, depending on the value of m. These interference bands are known as {\bf fringes of equal chromatic order}, or {\bf FECO bands}. If on the other hand, wavelength is fixed, and the angle of refraction varies, the resulting interference bands are called {\bf Haidinger bands}, or {\bf fringes of equal inclination}. The last type of interference bands, called {\bf Fizeau bands}, are the result of varying d. The distinction between the three types of bands is not absolute though, for more than one factor may vary at the same time, and the types become merged.

The type of interference we wish to investigate here are Fizeau bands in thin films of air. Since we are really concerned with the effects of d on the band pattern, a simplified version of Equation \ref{equ:fb9} can be applied. If the thin transparent film used is air, then the index of refraction will be very close to 1.0. Also, if the angle of incidence is 0$^{\circ}$, then the condition for destructive interference becomes

\begin{equation}
m\lambda=2d
\label{equ:fb11}
\end{equation}

When monochromatic light is used to observe Fizeau bands, they are interpreted in exactly the same manner as the contour lines on a topographical map. The larger the thickness of the film, d, the larger the spacing between the bands. This relationship though, deals with height differences on the order of micrometers, as opposed to height differences on the order of hundreds of meters for topographical maps. Because the distance between Fizeau bands is dependent on the thickness of a thin film, they have many practical uses. They are , for example, used for testing the flatness of optical surfaces. An object is tested by laying it on top of a known optical flat and observing the resultant band pattern. If the bands appear parallel, straight, and equally spaced, then the tested surface is flat. 

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}[semithick]
\node[fill,circle,scale=.7]at(0,0){};
\foreach \s in {1,2,...,10}{
\node[line width=(15*exp(-\s*.5)),circle,scale=20-24/(\s),draw]at(0,0){};
}
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{An illustration of Newton rings.}
\label{fig:fb3}
\end{marginfigure}

Fizeau bands were actually one of the first types of interference bands to be observed. They were first seen by Robert Boyle in 1663. He observed them as concentric rings centered around the contact between a long radius convex lens and a flat glass plate, as demonstrated in Figure \ref{fig:fb3}. Because Newton studied these interference bands further, they are now known as {\bf Newton's rings}.

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}[semithick]
%parabolic convex lens
\draw[domain=1:10] plot (\x, {(0.0365)*pow(\x-5.5,2)+2});
\draw[domain=1:10] plot (\x, {(-0.0365)*pow(\x-5.5,2)+3.5});
%glass plate
\draw[](1,1.2)rectangle(10,1.98);
%metal rings
\draw[pattern=north east lines](.4,.5)--(.4,3.6)--(1.6,3.6)--(1.6,3.1)--(.9,3.1)--(.9,1)--
(1.6,1)--(1.6,.5)--cycle;
\draw[pattern=north east lines,rotate=180,shift={(-11,-4.1)}](.4,.5)--(.4,3.6)--(1.6,3.6)--(1.6,3.1)--(.9,3.1)--(.9,1)--
(1.6,1)--(1.6,.5)--cycle;
%tension screws
\draw[line width=2pt,draw=darkgray](1.25,3.9)--(1.25,2.9);
\draw[line width=2pt,draw=darkgray](9.75,3.9)--(9.75,2.9);
\draw[line width=3pt](1,3.9)--(1.5,3.9);
\draw[line width=3pt](9.5,3.9)--(10,3.9);
%demarcation lines
\begin{scope}[thin,font=\normalsize]
\draw[](5.5,8)--(5.5,2);
\draw[](5.5,2.4)--(8.8,2.4);
\draw[](5.5,8)--(8.8,2.4);
\draw[](8.8,2)--(8.8,2.4);
%labels
\node[]at(7.5,5.3){R};
\node[]at(5,5){R-d};
\node[]at(9,2.2){d};
\node[]at(7,2.6){r$_m$};
\node[]at(4,2.8){Convex lens};
\node[]at(1.25,4.2){Tension screw};
\node[]at(5.5,1.6){Flat glass plate};
\draw[<->](1.7,.7)--(9.3,.7);
\node[fill=white]at(5.5,.7){Metal rings};
\end{scope}
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Experimental setup for the investigation of Newton rings.}
\label{fig:fb4}
\end{figure}

Newton's rings are produced by the air gap between a flat glass plate and a long radius convex lens. An apparatus used to produce such an interference pattern is shown in Figure \ref{fig:fb4}. The curvature of the convex lens is exaggerated in order to demonstrate the desired effect. The lens, in reality, appears, to the naked eye, to be flat. If the convex lens did have a large curvature, the rings would be so close together we would not be able to see them. Since the spacing between the rings decreases as the air gap increases, the ring pattern observed should get closer together as we move outward from the point of contact between the lens and the glass plate. By measuring the change in spacing we can determine the curvature of the convex lens. To see how this can be done, consider again Figure \ref{fig:fb4}. In this figure, R represents the radius of curvature of the convex lens, r$_m$, the distance from the center to the m$^{th}$ ring, and d, the air gap between the lens and the flat glass plate at the m$^{th}$ ring. By applying the Pythagorean theorem we get

\begin{equation}
R^2=(R-d)^2+r_m^2
\label{equ:fb12}
\end{equation}

\noindent By expanding this out and collecting like terms, the equation becomes

\begin{equation}
r_m^2=2Rd\left(1-\dfrac{d}{2R}\right)
\label{equ:fb13}
\end{equation}

\noindent Since d/2R is much smaller than 1, this can be simplified to get

\begin{equation}
r_m^2=2Rd
\label{equ:fb14}
\end{equation}

Combining Equations \ref{equ:fb11} and \ref{equ:fb14} gives a relationship for R in terms of the distance to the m$^{th}$ ring and the wavelength of light used, namely

\begin{equation}
R=\dfrac{r_m^2}{m\lambda}
\label{equ:fb15}
\end{equation}

Fizeau bands can also be used to determine the thickness of very thin objects like hair, paper, or aluminum foil. The thickness of thin objects can be determined through the use of an {\bf air wedge}, as demonstrated in Figure \ref{fig:fb5}. The air wedge works on the same principle as Newton's rings. The larger the air gap, the smaller the separation between the lines. As long as the glass surfaces are perfectly flat, the bands will be straight, otherwise they will tend to curve, forming contour lines from the unevenness in the surfaces.

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}[semithick]
%clip
\draw[line width=2.5pt](2.5,3)arc(-90:-460:.06)--(1.5,3.3)arc(20:-20:1.7)--(2.5,2.5)arc(90:-200:.06);
\draw[draw=gray,line width=2pt](2.39,3.14)--(.7,3.66);
\draw[draw=gray,line width=2pt](.7,1.73)--(2.39,2.35);
%glass slides
\draw[rotate=6,shift={(2.57,2.5)}](0,0)rectangle(6,.2);
\draw[shift={(2.3,2.55)}](0,0)rectangle(6,.2);
%thin object
\draw[draw=gray,fill=gray](7,2.79)rectangle(7.6,3.23);
%demarcation lines
\begin{scope}[thin]
\draw(2.6,3.8)--(2.6,1.7);
\draw(4.6,3.8)--(4.6,1.7);
\draw(7,3.8)--(7,1.7);

\end{scope}

\node[]at(9.5,3.2){Glass};
\node[]at(9.5,2.8){Slides};
\draw[<->](8.35,3.45)--(9,3)--(8.35,2.65);
\node[]at(9,1.5){Thin object};
\draw[->](8.1,1.7)--(7.4,3);
\node[]at(4.6,4){P};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(5.2,2.9){d$_1$};
\node[]at(6.7,3){d$_2$};
\node[font=\footnotesize,fill=white]at(3.5,2.2){x};
\node[font=\footnotesize,fill=white]at(5.8,3.6){y};
\node[font=\footnotesize,fill=white]at(5,1.8){L};
\end{scope}
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Schematic depiction of the air wedge.}
\label{fig:fb5}
\end{figure}

Suppose that the interference bands are only due to the formation of an air gap caused by the placement of an thin object between two glass slides. We can derive an equation which will give us the thickness of the object in terms of the distance between the object and the edge of the clip, L, and the distance, y, from the object to a point P. From similar triangles we find that

\begin{equation}
\dfrac{d_2}{d_1}=\dfrac{m_2}{m_1}=\dfrac{L}{x}
\label{equ:fb16}
\end{equation}

\noindent where m$_2$ is the number of dark bands from the edge of the object to the edge of the clip, and m$_1$ is the number of dark bands from any point P to the edge of the clip. Because of distortions caused by using a clip to hold the two glass slides together, it is hard to get an accurate value for m$_1$. We can avoid this problem by counting the bands from the edge of the object to some point P, so that

\begin{equation}
m=m_2-m_1
\label{equ:fb17}
\end{equation}

\noindent We then use the corresponding distance y by applying the relation

\begin{equation}
y=L-x
\label{equ:fb18}
\end{equation}

\noindent The thickness of the object, d$_2$, can then be determined by combining Equations \ref{equ:fb11}, \ref{equ:fb16}, \ref{equ:fb17}, and \ref{equ:fb18}, so that

\begin{equation}
d_2=\dfrac{m\lambda}{2}\dfrac{L}{y}
\label{equ:fb19}
\end{equation}

Even though interference bands are visible to the naked eye, their spacing is such that you need a microscope in order to make an accurate measurement. The experimental setup used to measure the spacing between Fizeau bands is shown in Figure \ref{fig:fb6}. A monochromatic light source, in this case a Sodium lamp, illuminates the arrangement thereby keeping $\lambda$ constant. A traveling microscope is used  to count the number of bands and measure the related distances. A beam splitter allows the light to be incident on the Newton's rings or air wedge apparatus surface at nearly 0$^{\circ}$, while allowing us to view the surface at the same angle. This lets us avoid using the cosine term, allowing the use of Equation \ref{equ:fb11}. The microscope sits on the beam splitter stand which is placed on a lab jack so that the beam splitter is at the same height as the light source. The Newton's rings or air wedge  apparatus is placed under the beam splitter on a riser block. The riser block is put in place in order to keep the bands within the focusing range of the microscope.

\section{Experimental Procedure}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Adjust the Newton's ring apparatus until the rings are visible and centered. This may require cleaning the lenses. To do this remove the screws which hold the two metal rings together. Remove the two lenses to be cleaned, remembering how they were positioned. If the two lenses are not put back together properly a saddle pattern, as opposed to a ring pattern will result. Before using the lens paper and lens cleaning fluid to clean off finger prints, gently blow away any dirt to avoid scratching the lenses. The ring pattern may be centered by adjusting the tension in the screws. Be careful not to tighten the screws too much or the observed pattern will not be caused by the shape of the two lenses, but by the distortion of  the lenses caused by the pressing metal rings.
  
\item Measure the separation between the rings in order to determine the radius of curvature of the convex lens. The path difference at the point of contact between the convex and flat lenses is not necessarily zero. Even if there is no dust and the surfaces actually touch, the pressure between the lenses causes distortion. Hence it is better to measure the distance from say ring 10, as opposed to taking measurements from the center. Since the lines are so closely spaced, it is more accurate to measure the distance between a number of rings. The Newton's ring apparatus should be placed so that light from the sodium lamp, 589.3 nm, is reflected down onto it by the beam splitter. Using the traveling microscope, measure the distance from a set ring, such as ring 10, to at least five other rings. These rings should be separated from each other by at least five rings. When using this method, m is the number of rings between the two measurements, and r$_m$, the separation. 

\item Determine the thickness of a hair using the air wedge method. Make sure that the two glass slides are clean. Place a hair between the two glass slides near one end. Place the clip at the other end. Put the air wedge apparatus on the riser block so that the clip hangs off the edge. This is done so that the air wedge apparatus does not make another air wedge with the riser block. Place the riser block and air wedge apparatus under the beam splitter and use the traveling microscope to observe the interference bands produced using the sodium lamp. The bands observed should be parallel with the hair. If the bands are almost perpendicular with the hair, then the slides need to be cleaned again. Line the microscope up with the interference bands, not the hair. Starting at the edge of the hair closest to the clip, measure the distance between the hair and an m$^{th}$ band. Repeat the measurement for at least five different m values. The value of m used should be no smaller then 10. Measure the distance between the hair and the edge of the clip.
 
\item Repeat step 3 using a piece of aluminum foil to determine its thickness.

\item With a micrometer, measure the thickness of the hair and the aluminum foil. Be sure not to over tighten the micrometer. The clutch at the end of the micrometer must be used to get a correct reading. This ensures a gentle uniform pressure for all micrometer measurements.

\item Perform any optional part of the experiment as desired.
\end{enumerate}

\section{Error Analysis}
The wavelength value, $\lambda$, along with the number of bands, m, are taken to be exact. This leaves the distance measurements, which do contribute to the error in the final result. Normally when error is taken off a vernier scale it is taken as half the smallest division. Because of complications resulting from lining the microscope up with the bands, error should be considered to be at least the value of the smallest division. When using the micrometer, error should be taken to be half the smallest division.

The values obtained for the curvature of the convex lens, or for the thickness of thin objects, may not be entirely correct. This is because there are some uncontrollable factors that effect the results. Fizeau bands can be used to determine the flatness of an optical object. This means that if an object is not perfectly flat, distortions in the band pattern will result. The glass slides used for the air wedge are not optical flats, therefore, some of the band patterns observed may be due to the distortions in the glass and not in the placement of the thin object. Any dust on the slides or the lenses will also cause variation in the observed ring or band pattern. There is also no guarantee that for the Newton's rings the two lenses are actually touching, or for the air wedge that the slides are making contact with the thin objects. This will cause the values to appear larger then they actually are. A main source of unavoidable error comes from the use of clamping devices, the metal rings on the Newton's rings apparatus, and the clip on the air wedge apparatus. Both of these clamping devices are required to ensure that the two lenses or slides are actually making contact, but they also create distortions.

\section{The following should be handed in to your laboratory instructor}
\begin{enumerate}

\item (1 mark) A derivation of  Equation \ref{equ:fb19}.

\item (2 marks) A table which includes the values m, r$_m$, r$_m^2$, along with their associated error, for the trials done to determine the radius of curvature of the convex lens.

\item (2 marks) A graph of r$_m^2$ versus m and obtain a regression equation for the straight line, including the uncertainty. From this equation recover the value for the radius of curvature of the convex lens along with its uncertainty.

\item (4 marks) Two tables, one for determining the thickness of a hair and one for finding the thickness of a piece of aluminum foil, which contain the values L, m, and y, along with their errors.

\item (4 marks) Two graphs of y versus m, one for the hair and one for the aluminum foil. Obtain the regression equations for the straight lines, including the uncertainty. From the equations recover the values, with uncertainty, for the thickness of the hair and the aluminum foil. 

\item (2 marks) Values for the thickness of the hair and aluminum foil, along with the uncertainty, using the micrometer. Compare the values obtained with the micrometer with those obtained through optical means. Discuss which method is better for measuring thickness.

\item (2 marks) A one paragraph discussion on whether your results support or deny the wave nature of light.

\item (2 bonus marks)  Even though we have been observing Newton's rings through monochromatic light, they can be observed through white light. When this is done the resulting pattern does not strictly result in Fizeau bands, since it is not just d which is changing, but $\lambda$ as well. If all we were doing was varying $\lambda$, then the result would be a FECO band pattern, where color bands would be alternated with dark bands. The resulting colorful ring pattern does not follow a standard white light spectrum either, but instead follows an interference color pattern. This pattern can be seen on the color interference chart provided in the laboratory. The resulting interference pattern is a combination of both Fizeau and FECO bands.

Observe the Newton's ring pattern in white light by placing the Newton's ring apparatus under one of the desk lamps. It is easier to observe the color pattern by using the larger Newton's ring apparatus. Starting from the center, write down the color sequence. Compare this sequence to the one on the chart provided in the laboratory. Does a black spot appear in the center? If not, where in the interference color pattern spectrum does the ring pattern start at? While still looking at the ring pattern under the white light adjust the tension in the tension screws. How does this affect the interference color pattern? Include in your discussion any other observations you make.

\item (2 bonus marks) By illuminating a thin plane parallel reflecting surface with diffuse monochromatic light, fringes of equal inclination can be observed. One way to observe this type of interference pattern is with a thin cover glass and a Sodium lamp. First, place the cover slip on the table in front of the lamp and have a lab partner {\bf carefully} tilt the lamp at an angle. Move your head, or the cover slip, until you can see the reflection of the Sodium lamp in the cover slip. Observe the interference pattern present on the surface of the cover slip. Rotate the cover slip and note what happens.  Observe the appearance of the band pattern as you change your viewing angle. Replace the cover slip with a glass slide and make similar observations. How do the bands produced with the thicker glass slide compare to the bands produced with the cover slip? Include in your discussion any other observations you make.

\end{enumerate}

\section{Equipment}

\item Screen
\item Tape measure
\item Calipers
\end{itemize}

\begin{marginfigure}[+1.5in]
\includegraphics{/usr/local/master/labs/physics375-FA2016/Fraunhofer-Diffraction/Fraunhofer-Diffraction-Setup.jpg}
\caption{Experimental Setup}
\label{fdSetup}
\end{marginfigure}

\section{Preparation}
Study Fraunhofer diffraction and the diffraction of light through a thin slit.

\section{Purpose}
To observe the far-field diffraction patterns for single, double, and multiple slits, and verify qualitatively the theoretical relation bewteen slit width, spacing, and the form of the diffraction patterns. To measure the wavelength of a laser using a diffraction grating and a two-dimensional grid.

\section{Theory}
Suppose, as depicted in Figure \ref{fig:fd1},  that a laser is shone upon a small slit.  The light passing through the slit is then allowed to fall on a screen, positioned at some distance, L, from the slit, with its plane perpendicular to the path of the light's propagation.  If light traveled in straight lines one would expect the screen to display a single image of the slit with the rest of the screen in shadow.  For a sufficiently small slit, however, it is found that this is not the case.  Instead, a {\bf diffraction pattern} is observed, consisting of a central bright fringe along the slit-screen axis with alternating dark and bright fringes on either side of the central fringe.  It is evident, based on this observation, that light does not travel in straight lines since bright fringes are seen where shadow would be expected.  It follows then, that light has the property of being able to "bend" around corners, a property called {\bf diffraction}.

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(11,6);
%screen
\draw[fill=gray](8,3)rectangle(11,6);
\draw[fill=white,rounded corners=3,draw=darkgray](9.4,4)rectangle(9.6,5);
\draw[fill=white,rounded corners=3,draw=darkgray](9.1,4.1)rectangle(9.3,4.9);
\draw[fill=white,rounded corners=3,draw=darkgray](9.7,4.1)rectangle(9.9,4.9);
\draw[fill=white,rounded corners=3,draw=darkgray](10,4.2)rectangle(10.2,4.8);
\draw[fill=white,rounded corners=3,draw=darkgray](8.8,4.2)rectangle(9,4.8);
\draw[fill=white,rounded corners=3,draw=darkgray](8.5,4.25)rectangle(8.7,4.75);
\draw[fill=white,rounded corners=3,draw=darkgray](10.3,4.25)rectangle(10.5,4.75);
%diffracted rays
\draw[thin](4,2.5)--(8.6,4.5);
\draw[thin](4,2.5)--(8.9,4.5);
\draw[thin](4,2.5)--(9.2,4.5);
\draw[thin](4,2.5)--(9.5,4.5);
\draw[thin](4,2.5)--(9.8,4.5);
\draw[thin](4,2.5)--(10.1,4.5);
\draw[thin](4,2.5)--(10.4,4.5);
%slit
\draw[fill=darkgray,line width=1](3.2,1.5)rectangle(4.7,3.5);
\draw[fill=white](3.9,2.25)rectangle(4,2.75);
%incident rays
\draw[thin](1.25,1.5)--(3.95,2.5);
\draw[thin](1.25,1.5)--(3.95,2.65);
\draw[thin](1.25,1.5)--(3.95,2.35);
%laser
\draw[](0,.8)rectangle(.5,1.3);
\draw[](1,1.164)rectangle(1.5,1.664);
\draw[fill=white](0,1.3)--(1,1.664)--(1.5,1.664)--(.5,1.3)--cycle;
\draw[fill=white](.5,.8)--(1.5,1.164)--(1.5,1.664)--(.5,1.3)--cycle;
%labels
\begin{scope}[very thin,font=\footnotesize]
\node[]at(1,.6){Laser};
\node[]at(3.9,1.3){Slit};
\node[]at(6,5){Diffraction pattern};
\node[]at(9.6,2.8){Screen};
\draw[triangle 60-triangle 60](4.8,1.5)--(9.8,3.2);
\node[fill=white]at(7.1,2.3){L};
\end{scope}
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Experimental setup for the investigation of Fraunhofer diffraction.}
\label{fig:fd1}
\end{figure}

In order to examine diffraction we will assume that light behaves like a wave.  With this assumption one can imagine a beam of light to consist of a series of wave fronts aligned perpendicular to the direction of light propagation. As shown in Figure \ref{fig:fd2}, a {\bf ray} can be drawn perpendicular to the wave fronts, indicating the direction of light propagation.  This wave model of light allows us to make use of {\bf Huygen's principle} which claims that any point on a wave front can itself be regarded as a point source emitting circular wave fronts.  Applying this principle to the situation under consideration, every point located in the slit acts as a point source. Consequently, the diffraction pattern must be the result of the constructive and destructive interference of the various waves generated by these point sources.

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(6,5);
\foreach \x in {0,.5,1,1.5,2}{
\draw[thick](0.4+\x*1.7,1)arc(-30:30:3);
}
\draw[very thick,-triangle 60](.8,2.5)--(5.5,2.5);
%labels
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(2.5,4.8){Wavefronts};
\draw[very thin,->](2,4.6)--(.5,4);
\draw[very thin,->](2.2,4.6)--(1.3,4.05);
\draw[very thin,->](2.4,4.6)--(2.1,4.05);
\draw[very thin,->](2.6,4.6)--(2.95,4.05);
\draw[very thin,->](2.8,4.6)--(3.7,4.05);
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(5,1){Ray indicates};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(5,.7){direction of};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(5,.4){propagation};
\draw[very thin,->](5,1.2)--(4.7,2.4);
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{The direction of propagation of wavefronts.}
\label{fig:fd2}
\end{marginfigure}

Diffraction phenomena are usually separated into two different types called {\bf Fraunhofer} (far field) and {\bf Fresnel} (near field) diffraction. The former describes the diffraction pattern observed in the far field (i.e. at large values of L) where rays of light incident upon the observing screen are almost parallel to one another. As might be expected, Fresnel diffraction describes the near-field pattern observed when the screen is placed close to the slit (i.e. at small values of L).  The expected image of the slit is cast on the screen without diffraction only in the limiting case when L$ = 0$.  Since Fresnel diffraction is complicated to analyze mathematically we will restrict our attention to Fraunhofer diffraction.

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}

%screen
\draw[very thick](10.9,0)rectangle(11,7);
%incident rays
\foreach \y in {0,1,...,8}{
\draw[-triangle 60](0,1+\y*.625)--(.8,1+\y*.625);
}
%optical axis
\draw[thin](1.5,3.5)--(10.9,3.5);
%slit
\draw[thick,fill=gray](2,0)rectangle(2.2,1.5);
\draw[thick,fill=gray](2,7)rectangle(2.2,5.5);
%diffracted rays
\foreach \y in {0,1,2,3,4}{
\draw[](10.9,6)--(2.3,5.5-\y);
}
%demarcation lines
\draw[](1.1,5.5)--(1.9,5.5);
\draw[](1.1,1.5)--(1.9,1.5);

\draw[<->](1.2,1.5)--(1.2,5.5);

\node[]at(4.5,6){5};
\node[]at(8.5,3.7){optical axis};
\node[]at(10.6,6.3){P};
\node[]at(10,.5){screen};
\node[]at(1,3.8){a};
\node[fill=white]at(1.6,4.6){$\dfrac{a}{2}$};
\node[]at(2.6,3.9){$\Delta p$};
\node[]at(3.5,3.65){$\theta$};

\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Incident light rays passing through a slit.}
\label{fig:fd3}
\end{figure}

To begin a more careful analysis of diffraction phenomena, we examine the single slit described earlier in more detail.  Figure \ref{fig:fd3} shows a slit of width, a, viewed from above.  Note that the rays incident upon the slit must be parallel and in phase.  The laser is used in this experiment to ensure that this is the case.  It also has the added advantage of being monochromatic so that all rays have the same wavelength.  Assume that the aperture to screen distance is much larger than the size of the aperture.  With this assumption, rays arriving at point P on the screen can be considered parallel to one another.  To determine the conditions necessary for the appearance of a dark fringe at P it is convenient to consider rays that are half the slit width apart from one another.  In Figure \ref{fig:fd3} each of the rays are separated by a distance of a/4 so that rays 5 and 3, 4 and 2, and 3 and 1 are half the slit width removed from one another. Note that one member of each of these pairs of rays must travel a small extra distance, $\Delta$p, before reaching the screen.  As determined from the geometry depicted in Figure \ref{fig:fd3}, this distance is given by the equation

\begin{equation}
\Delta p=\dfrac{a}{2}sin\theta
\label{equ:fd1}
\end{equation}

where $\theta$ is the angle between the optical axis and the rays emitted by point sources located along the slit width, converging upon point P.  Equation \ref{equ:fd1} holds true for all pairs of rays that pass through the slit a distance a/2 apart.

In order to obtain a dark fringe on the screen at the angle $\theta$ from the optical axis the waves generated by the point sources in the slit must interfere destructively.  For each of the aforementioned pairs of rays, this condition is met if the path difference between the rays is half the wavelength, $\lambda$, of the laser.  If, for example, the point of arrival of ray 3 at the screen corresponds to a peak in the wave then ray 1, which has to travel the extra distance $\lambda/2$, will arrive at the screen as a trough.  The trough and peak cancel each other resulting in a dark point on the screen.  It follows from Equation \ref{equ:fd1} that the condition for a dark fringe caused by the interaction of waves generated by points in the slit separated by half the slit-width is given by

\begin{equation}
\dfrac{a}{2}sin\theta=\dfrac{\lambda}{2}
\label{equ:fd2}
\end{equation}

We can repeat the analysis for pairs of rays separated by one quarter the slit width resulting in the condition 

\begin{equation}
sin\theta=\dfrac{2\lambda}{a}
\label{equ:fd3}
\end{equation}

for a dark fringe.  Similarly, for pairs of rays separated by one sixth the slit width we find that a dark fringe is produced at the angle $\theta$ if the condition 

\begin{equation}
sin\theta=\dfrac{3\lambda}{a}
\label{equ:fd4}
\end{equation}

\noindent is met.

Generalizing, based on the pattern established by Equations \ref{equ:fd2}, \ref{equ:fd3}, and \ref{equ:fd4}, it follows that a dark fringe appears at an angle $\theta$ if it satisfies the equation 

\begin{equation}
sin\theta=m\dfrac{\lambda}{a}\hspace{4mm} (m=\pm1,\pm2,\pm3,...)
\label{equ:fd5}
\end{equation}

Equation \ref{equ:fd5} shows that the structure of the diffraction pattern depends on the both the wavelength of the light illuminating the slit and the slit width.

Having now considered the diffraction pattern generated by a single slit we turn our attention to the {\bf diffraction grating}.  A grating consists of a large number of parallel slits and is characterized by the so-called grating constant, d, which is the center to center distance between two adjacent slits.  If we replace the single slit in Figure \ref{fig:fd1} by a diffraction grating we will find that the grating generates a diffraction pattern similar to that of the slit.  In the case of the grating, however, the light fringes are considerably more compact and, as a consequence, we shall focus our attention on the light fringes rather than the dark fringes in this analysis.

Figure \ref{fig:fd4} shows a number of rays exiting from a small section of the diffraction grating and arriving at the screen.  

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(11,7);

\draw[very thin](1.5,3.5)--(10.9,3.5);

\draw[very thick,fill=white](9.7,0)rectangle(10,7);

\foreach \y in {0,1,...,8}{

\node[]at(10.5,3.8){x};
\node[]at(8.6,3.3){optical axis};
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{Incident light rays passing through a grating.}
\label{fig:fd4}
\end{figure}

Assume that the distance L is large enough that we can consider the rays depicted to be essentially parallel.  According to the geometry illustrated here the condition for a light fringe, also called a maximum, appearing at the angle $\theta$ with respect to the optical axis is given by the equation 

\begin{equation}
dsin\theta=m\lambda\hspace{4mm}(m=0,\pm1,\pm2,\pm3,...)
\label{equ:fd6}
\end{equation}

Let x be the distance from the central maximum (m = 0) to some other maximum, identified by a non-zero value of m.  With this definition the sine term in Equation \ref{equ:fd6} can be replaced to obtain

\begin{equation}
\dfrac{xd}{\sqrt{x^2+L^2}}=m\lambda
\label{equ:fd7}
\end{equation}

\begin{marginfigure}
\begin{tikzpicture}
%\draw[very thin](0,0)rectangle(6,5);
\draw[thick,fill=gray](0,0)rectangle(4.55,3.55);
\foreach \x in {0,.5,...,4}{
\foreach \y in {0,.5,...,3}{
\draw[fill=white,draw=white](.1+\x,.1+\y)rectangle(.45+\x,.45+\y);
}}
\draw[thick,<->](5,3)--(5,2.2)--(5.8,2.2);
\draw[angle 90-angle 90](.3,-.2)--(.8,-.2);
\draw[angle 90-angle 90](-.2,.2)--(-.2,.7);
%labels
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(.55,-.4){d};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(-.4,.45){d};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(5.3,2){x};
\node[font=\footnotesize]at(4.8,2.6){y};
\end{tikzpicture}
\caption{A diffraction grating made of a grid of small openings.}
\label{fig:fd5}
\end{marginfigure}

Equation \ref{equ:fd7} is simpler to verify experimentally than Equation \ref{equ:fd6} since x and L are more easily measured than the angle $\theta$.

So far we have been considering diffraction patterns that extend along a single axis.  To conclude this exploration of diffraction phenomena, the two dimensional diffraction pattern created by a grid of small square openings, as shown in Figure 4, will be examined.  

The conditions governing the two dimensional diffraction pattern can be analyzed by considering the openings along the x and y axis, as defined in Figure \ref{fig:fd5}, separately.  Any line of squares along the x-direction behaves in the same fashion as a regular diffraction grating with a center to center slit distance d.  Hence the component of the diffraction pattern due to horizontal lines of the grid must obey Equations \ref{equ:fd6} and \ref{equ:fd7}.  Similarly any line of squares along the y-direction behaves like a regular diffraction grating also with a center to center slit distance d.  The resulting diffraction pattern will, however, lie perpendicular to those created by lines of squares aligned parallel to the x-axis.  Again, Equation \ref{equ:fd6} applies but in order for Equation \ref{equ:fd7} to apply the 'x' must be replaced by 'y' giving

\begin{equation}
\dfrac{yd}{\sqrt{y^2+L^2}}=m\lambda
\label{equ:fd8}
\end{equation}

The diffraction pattern observed on the screen is a result of the superposition of the diffraction patterns created by both the horizontal and vertical lines of squares.  This pattern will consist of a square array of bright dots decreasing in intensity away from the optical axis of the system.  

Position measurements of maxima for the diffraction grating and grid will allow us to determine the wavelength of the laser via Equation \ref{equ:fd7}.   A similar calculation of laser wavelength using the dark fringes of the single slit diffraction pattern can also be made.

\begin{figure}
\begin{tikzpicture}

\draw[thick](0,1)rectangle(10,1.4);
\draw[](0,1.2)rectangle(10,1.3);

}

\label{fig:fd6}
\end{figure}

Figure \ref{fig:fd6} shows the experimental arrangement that will be used to study diffraction patterns.  The laser, mounted on the optics bench by means of the two-axis translation stage, shines on the slide holder which holds one of the various diffraction slides or gratings. The translation stage is used to accurately adjust the x and y position of the laser. The resulting diffraction pattern is observed on the screen.

The diffraction pattern created by a number of different slides can be measured on the screen located at a known distance, L. Equations \ref{equ:fd7} and \ref{equ:fd8} are then used to determine the wavelength of the laser light used in this experiment.

\section{Experimental Procedure}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Arrange the equipment so that the laser and screen are at opposite ends of the optics bench with the slide holder positioned quite close ( 5.00 cm) to the laser. Throughout this experiment it is important to remember that looking directly into the laser can cause retinal damage. As a consequence the optics bench should be positioned so that the laser is directed towards the wall, away from other people.

\item  Place the slide consisting of four single slits with openings of 0.02 mm, 0.04 mm, 0.08 mm, and 0.16 mm in the slide holder. Adjust the two-axis translation stage so that the beam of the laser passes through the largest slit. Repeat the process for the remaining three slits. Describe qualitatively the diffraction pattern for each slit and note the effect of decreasing slit width on the single slit diffraction patterns.

\item  Replace the single slit slide with the slide consisting of four double slits of varying width and slit spacing.  Compare the resulting diffraction patterns and note, qualitatively, how slit width and spacing affect the pattern.

\item  Replace the double slit slide with the multiple slit slide consisting of four multiple slit patterns with the same width and spacing.  Compare the resulting diffraction pattern and note, qualitatively, how the number of slits affects the diffraction pattern.

\item  Replace the multiple slit slide with the slide consisting of three diffraction gratings.  Remove the screen from the optical bench so that the laser is allowed to pass through the grating with the resulting diffraction pattern displayed on the wall.  The wall is used in this portion of the experiment because the diffraction pattern does not fit on the screen.  Make sure the grating is positioned perpendicular to the optical axis.  This can be accomplished by twisting the slide holder so that  the distance between adjacent maxima of the diffraction pattern is a minimum.  Adjust the two-axis translation stage so that the laser is incident upon the grating ruled with 2400 lines/inch.  (1 inch = 2.54 cm).

\item  Using the tape measure determine the distance, L, between the central maximum displayed on the wall and the diffraction grating.  For at least six maxima on one side of the central maximum measure the displacement, x, from the central maximum.

\item  Replace the diffraction grating slide in the slide holder with one of the nylon grid slides.  Re-attach the screen to the optics bench and measure the grid to screen distance using the optic bench scale.  

\item  For each of the seven nylon grid slides (each labeled with the center to center distance, d, of two adjacent squares in its grid) measure the distance, x (or y) between the central maximum and either the sixth or seventh maximum.  This measurement is most easily accomplished by placing a blank sheet of paper directly on the screen and marking, in pencil, the position of the central and sixth or seventh maximum.  Calipers can then be used to obtain an accurate measure of the distance.  Maxima closer to the central maximum than the sixth tend to be at distances that are too small to measure accurately.

Make sure the maximum you choose to measure, whether it be the sixth or seventh, is readily observable in at least one of the two axes of the diffraction pattern for each slide in the set.  The intensity of each maximum falls off quite rapidly away from the central bright spot and, in some instances, a maximum may appear to be missing altogether.  this is a consequence of the fact that each square of the grid creates its own single slit diffraction pattern which may interfere with the overall pattern of the grid. Before making your measurements be sure the grid is positioned in a plane perpendicular to the optical axis using the method specified in step 5.
\end{enumerate}

\section{Error Analysis}
The error in all measured distances is half the smallest division of the scale from which they are read.  In the course of the experiment it will be necessary to determine the error in the term x/(x2+L2)$^{^1/_2}$ from the errors u(x) in x and u(L) in L.  A rigorous calculation of this error for each set of measurements is a time-consuming process.  As a consequence, assume that measurements of x are exact so that the error in this term, as determined from u(L), alone using standard methods, is given by

\begin{equation}
u\left[\dfrac{x}{(x^2+L^2)^{^1/_2}}\right]=\dfrac{Lx}{(x^2+L^2)^{^3/_2}}u(L)
\label{equ:fd9}
\end{equation}

\section{To be handed in to your laboratory instructor}

\end{enumerate}

\section{Data Requirements}
\begin{enumerate}[resume]

\item A description of the observations made in step 2 of the procedure section.

\item A description of the observations made in step 3 of the procedure section.

\item A description of the observations made in step 4 of the procedure section.

\item A table of values for m, x, and x/(x2 + L2)$^{^1/_2}$ from step 6 in the procedure section together with uncertainties.

\item A graph of x/(x2 + L2)$^{^1/_2}$ versus m with error bars.

\item An equation for the best fit line of the graph in part 6. Determine the wavelength of the laser from the slope of the line together with an uncertainty.

\item A table of values for d, 1/d, x, and x/(x2 + L2)$^{^1/_2}$ from step 8 in the procedure section together with their errors. Also record which value of m was used in your measurements.

\item A graph of x/(x2 + L2)$^{^1/_2}$ versus 1/d on graph paper with error bars.

\item An equation for the graph in part 9. Uncertainties must be specified if appropriate.  Determine the wavelength of the laser with uncertainty from the slope of the line.

\section{Discussion}
\item Compare the laser wavelength measured in parts 8 and 11 with the accepted value you looked up.
\end{enumerate}
